HEADLINE: CONGRESS AND TAXES: THE REACTION;
Potshots From All Sides Offer Tax-Fight Preview

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Offering a preview of the rancorous debate that lies ahead, interest groups pounced on the tax package proposed today by the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, with some calling the tax cuts too limited and others calling them too generous to the wealthy.
The package drew a guarded response from White House officials, who said they had some "serious concerns" about parts of the plan. 
 "There are a lot of problems that are going to need some serious attention," said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who joined others in complaining that the plan drafted by the Republicans was weighted too heavily against poorer people.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, which writes tax legislation, released details of a five-year plan for net tax relief worth $85 billion -- about $135 billion in tax cuts and $50 billion in new revenue from tax and fee increases -- at a noon news conference on Capitol Hill. Within minutes, his proposal was being picked apart.
Citizens for Tax Justice, a tax research group, called the plan a "flimflam." "They have cooked the books so much that French chefs would be jealous of this fine work," said Robert S. McIntyre, the director of the group. Corn growers and an alternative fuel association vowed to fight an attempt to eliminate tax subsidies on ethanol production.
The nation's largest lobbying group for small businesses, the National Federation of Independent Business, said that while it was pleased with much of the plan, it found the proposed changes on estate taxes -- increasing the current $600,000 exemption to $1 million over the next 17 years -- too limited.
In what could well be one of the major political flash points, a coalition of Indian tribes challenged the constitutionality of a provision that would impose a new Federal income tax on gambling and other commercial enterprises on American Indian lands. The tribes are backed by 45 members of Congress from both sides of the aisle.
Mr. Archer, who tried and failed to push a similar measure through the last Congress, said the new tax would generate $1.9 billion in revenue through 2002.
But critics of that idea -- who include Senators Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the majority whip, or second-ranking Republican, in the Senate, and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Budget Committee -- said that Federal law and Federal court decisions had recognized the special sovereign status of Indian tribes and had given them the same legal status as states, whose gambling operations are not subject to taxation.
One major provision of the tax package, the per-child tax credit, was also part of the House Republicans' Contract With America, and Mr. Archer said it would benefit the families of 41 million children under the age of 17. It would start with a maximum credit of $400 per child in 1998, which would be $500 per child thereafter.
But even that came under criticism today from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, which argued that the tax credit would not apply to two of every five children, or about 28 million, because their family incomes are not high enough.
About the only supportive comments Mr. Archer heard today came from his Republican counterpart in the Senate, Senator William V. Roth Jr., the chairman of the Finance Committee. "I know how difficult it is to balance the competing interests within a limited tax bill, and I think he did a fine job," Mr. Roth said in a brief statement.
A major lobbying group for big business and Wall Street gave its approval to the proposed cut in capital gains taxes. The proposal would reduce the current 28 percent rate to 10 percent for couples making less than $41,200 a year and would set the rate at 20 percent for people in higher income brackets.
"I think the capital gains portion is extremely well crafted, and it will have a positive effect on the economy," said Mark A. Bloomfield, president of the group, the American Council for Capital Formation.
The tax cuts were part of the budget deal that Republican Congressional leaders and President Clinton signed off on last month.
In broad terms, the two sides agreed to net tax relief of $85 billion over the next five years -- $250 billion over the next 10 years -- that would include a tax credit of $500 per child, roughly $35 billion in postsecondary education tax incentives demanded by the Administration, broad-based capital gains relief, expansion of Individual Retirement Accounts and a "significant" reduction in estate taxes.
But it was left to Mr. Archer to fill in the details. White House officials suggested today that he might have strayed from the agreement.
For example, Mr. Archer's plan -- called a chairman's mark -- proposes a scaled-back version of Mr. Clinton's proposal for a $1,500 tax credit to help parents pay for a child's first two years of college. And it limits the deduction of up to $10,000 that Mr. Clinton wanted for postsecondary education expenses by requiring parents to invest in special savings accounts. It also would make it much more difficult for low- and some middle-income people to get the college tuition tax credit.
"Our basic objective is to have a tax plan that is good for the American people, good for working people, good for average families, good for the economy and that is permeated by fairness throughout," Mr. Rubin said. "By that test, we have serious concerns with significant parts of the chairman's mark that we have received today."

HEADLINE: Deregulation in Boston: Disruption, but Also Construction

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 4

 BODY:
In the two years since Massachusetts voters ended most rent controls for the cities of Boston, Cambridge and Brookline, two distinct interpretations of the results are beginning to emerge: While tenant advocates and landlords agree that noticeable disruptions and turnover have occurred in some neighborhoods, landlords say there are also signs that eliminating the rules has encouraged new housing construction and repairs.
One scenario is on display at the Hemenway Hotel apartments, a rambling eight-story building in the Boston neighborhood known as the East Fens. Sitting in her apartment in the building recently, Susan Starr counted the stalwarts: the former Avon lady who had lived in her apartment for 40 years; the retired merchant marine who had been there almost as long; the man who ran the cluttered antique shop on the ground floor, a fixture for two decades. 
 They were among the few longtime tenants who had gone to court to fight rent increases and remain in their building, as other neighbors were replaced by college students and young professionals.
The other side of the complicated rent decontrol story unfolding in and around Boston comes from landlords, who say the return to a market system here has already been beneficial citywide, leading to an increase in property tax revenues and appearing to cause new housing construction, which could eventually bring prices back down.
Furthermore, while landlords concede that some neighborhoods have been inevitably and sometimes even painfully changed, they say that the most vulnerable tenants, the poor and the elderly, have been affected much less than expected.
It is difficult to draw significant economic comparisons between New York and the Boston area because Boston's huge student population skews the market and New York has higher demand and 20 times more rent-regulated apartments, but both sides in New York have plucked examples to use as lessons for lawmakers in Albany.
Citing the Hemenway and buildings in other neighborhoods where prices have risen sharply, tenant leaders say Boston has already proven that ending rent regulations, whether quickly or over several years, forces the working class and middle class out of desirable neighborhoods.
Tim Davis, a tenant advocate with the Fenway Community Development Association, a nonprofit housing group, said: "There are now only two kinds of people here who are able to afford to live in a lot of the buildings in this neighborhood: People who make $50,000-plus or students who are willing to double and triple up."
Blocks in the neighborhood once had an eclectic mix -- from municipal and college employees to hotel dishwashers to lawyers, artists and students -- but, Mr. Davis said, "There's really no mixture anymore."
Ms. Starr, a secretary at Northeastern University who makes $24,000 a year, has fought the owners of the Hemenway, as the building is still called, although the name was formally changed to the Parkside when it was bought and renovated in late 1994. She said the owners wanted to increase the $565 monthly rent for her one-bedroom apartment to $850. And while she has succeeded in keeping her old rent for two years, she does not think she or many other old tenants can stay much longer.
"In December of 1994, the Hemenway had about 160 tenants, most of whom were rent-controlled," she said. "As of today, there are fewer than 20 of those people left -- in a mere two years. It's not the same building."
The owners of her building, Forest Properties and Fenway Parkside Limited Partnership, did not respond to several requests to be interviewed for this article. But as a group, the city's landlords do not dispute that tenants have been pushed to other neighborhoods and sometimes to other cities by rising prices. They are not apologetic, however, saying that it was grossly unfair for landlords ever to have been saddled with the rent rules.
"The hypothetical secretary might have to come to the realization that she's not entitled to an apartment in a given block," said Edwin J. Shanahan, the managing director of the Rental Housing Association, Boston's largest landlord group.
He said the end of the rent controls appeared to be having a beneficial effect for the city as a whole and the housing industry, which could eventually increase the stock of affordable housing.
A study released this week by Henry O. Pollakowski, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, reported that in Cambridge, which had the strictest controls, building permits increased in 1996 and assessors predicted that residential property tax revenues would rise 9 percent.
Since the Boston area was in the middle of a housing boom when the rent controls were lifted, Mr. Pollakowski's study said, it is difficult to know how much of the building can be attributed to rent deregulation. But the current high level of renovation and repair of Cambridge buildings once under rent control had not been matched during the previous market peak, in the late 1980's, the study concluded.
Those on all sides of the issue agree that Boston rents have increased on average, but the effects of decontrol are still developing. and it is hard to pin down exactly how much they have risen and where.
In Cambridge, which adopted rent controls in 1971 and had about 15,000 regulated apartments two years ago, Stanley Lastoff, owner of Porter Square Realty, said that one-bedroom apartments then renting for $433 a month can now fetch about $900.
While landlords say that such increases were bound to happen in some neighborhoods, they contend that the effect on residents has been much less predictable. And they argue that there were far fewer elderly, disabled or poor people who had to look elsewhere than originally expected.
When rent controls were ended in January 1995, the State Legislature provided for two-year extensions for the elderly, the disabled and the poor, if they qualified under certain income guidelines. But in the three affected cities of Boston, Cambridge and Brookline, where about 45,500 units were subject to rent controls, only 3,090 units eventually qualified for the exemption, according to Mr. Shanahan and the M.I.T. study.
"Our experience indicated that a lot of people could afford the increase and they paid the increase," Mr. Shanahan said. "A lot of others just said, 'Well, the jig's up.' It wasn't a case of people undergoing mass relocation."
At the Hemenway, Ms. Starr and the remaining holdouts said they had begun to accept that they would not be able to stay much longer. The antique shop owner has already decided to move and close his store. "I probably won't be around here in a couple of years, either," Ms. Starr said.
But while she remains, she said, she will continue to argue that the landlords' purely economic viewpoint overlooks a lot: "Whatever happened to neighborhood stability and civic pride and human connections?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: In the two years since rent regulations ended in Boston, Susan Starr says, higher rents have driven out most of her building's longtime tenants and changed the character of the neighborhood. (Kirsten Elstner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Peru's Stark Poverty Dulls Fujimori's Gleam

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, June 6

 BODY:
Eager to show what a man of the people he was, President Alberto K. Fujimori drove his jeep high into the dusty slums where Lima's poor live. With his country's two most important guests in tow, he rolled over stretches of new road and pointed out freshly built schools. He waded into swarms of cheering mothers and youngsters, who scrambled to touch his sleeve.
But after the President and the dignitaries had gone, the people who remained behind spoke of a desperation for jobs that was not about schools or roads or a presidential handshake. 
 "He comes once every five years," said Willy Saavedra, a 27-year-old father of two. "Only when he needs something."
Less than two months after Peruvians treated him like a conquering hero and sent his popularity soaring to 69 percent, Mr. Fujimori finds himself facing an increasingly hostile electorate. Polls show that his approval rating has plummeted in recent weeks and now stands at 39 percent -- exactly where it was before the raid.
For the first time in seven years in office, Mr. Fujimori is confronting public protests stirred both by the pervasive poverty and some of his recent actions.
There have been media exposes about corruption, killings and torture by the intelligence services that are integral to his hold on power. And the President came under diplomatic and domestic criticism when his congressional majority dismissed the three judges who had ruled against his bid to run for a third term in the year 2000.
But the most pervasive threat to Mr. Fujimori's popularity can be seen in places like the The Carnations soup kitchen, an unlit shack more cave than house, where the hot lunches that sell for 40 cents are gone by 1 P.M.
 
Economic Crisis A Way of Life
Throughout the country, thousands of soup kitchens like The Carnations began with the economic crisis of the 1980's. Now, people here said, crisis has become a way of life.
It was to places like the soup kitchen that Mr. Fujimori invited the Unites States' special envoy, Thomas F. McLarty, and Enrique Iglesias, chief of the Bank for Inter-American Development, on one of the President's locally famous "windshield tours" through the slums. And it is in places like the soup kitchen that the discontent that simmered after he left helps explain the drop in the President's popularity,
Seven years of the President's fiscal austerity program, for example, has left countless young fathers like Mr. Saavedra waiting on the sidelines, praying for a job.
According to figures published in Gestion, a financial newspaper, last week, 19 percent of all Peruvians, or 4.5 million people, live in extreme poverty, without sanitation, water, electricity or gas. Half the population lives below the poverty level, up from 38 percent in 1985.
"We didn't even get to work on the road, because the Army did it," he said. His wife, Yesinia Ramos, watched one of their daughters, Lady Denise Rosa, as she fed a pebble to her doll, lying on the ground.
Like Mr. Saavedra, Luis Garcia, 22, was waiting for work. He left school at the age of 10 to collect fares on a public transportation van. At 15, he got his first and last steady job, at a shoe factory that went bankrupt before the year was out. On Monday, the last day somebody hired him, Mr. Garcia was back collecting bus fares for the day. He earned less than $4.
Last year, Mr. Garcia's wife abandoned him and their daughter, Damares Milagros. The child is now 18 months old, with a moon face and bangs that fall over her eyes, and Mr. Garcia is raising her alone. She wears unmatching socks, but her clothes are clean. Her father's sneakers are torn clear across the top.
Political analysts say the President, facing popular protests for democracy for the first time since taking office in 1990, is at a turning point. The slack that he was once granted, in the name of overcoming terrorist violence and righting the economic shambles left by his predecessor, appears to be running out.
"Only 15 percent of all Peruvians either don't know, don't care, or think we're living in a democracy," said Hernando de Soto, an economist who is a former adviser to Mr. Fujimori. The gutting of the Constitutional Tribunal, however, was "the last straw" for many Peruvians.
"Before, the things Fujimori may have done that weren't following the rules, people saw them as necessary or required to end the violence," he said. "Now, there's a sense that these measures are being taken in terms of personal interests and ambition."
Last week, a broad base of opposition leaders, students and workers turned out by the thousands in protests the country had not seen in at least a decade. The Pontifical Catholic University of Peru took out a newspaper ad to decry the dismantling of the Constitutional court.
 
Tales of Torture Raise Public's Ire
News media reports of torture, killing and corruption by the intelligence services have set off crackdowns, with journalists complaining that they have received death threats and harassment in the form of sudden problems with the bureaucracy.
Mr. Fujimori himself lashed out last week at the news media, using a speech at a meeting here of the Organization of American States to accuse some journalists of taking bribes "to attack those who try to eliminate corruption."
Mr. Fujimori's speech notwithstanding, the Government worked tirelessly at the meeting to build a fire wall between its image and the sparks of discontent. Beatriz Ramacciotti, the Peruvian Ambassador to the O.A.S., worked tirelessly, and ultimately unsuccessfully, to prevent the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights from publishing a special section in its annual survey criticizing Peru.
The report condemned Peru for maintaining a state of emergency in many places, even though the threat of terrorism had generally diminished. It also attacked two 1995 laws Congress passed in the middle of the night, the first granting amnesty to all agents of the state and the second barring judicial review of the law.
"Some of the crimes covered by the amnesty, including acts of torture, forced disappearances and extrajudicial executions, have been considered an affront to the conscience of the hemisphere and are crimes against humanity," the Commission's report says.
Though Cesar Gaviria, the Secretary General of the O.A.S., would not comment on the dismissing of the judges, the Human Rights Commission issued a statement criticizing the dismissals and heard a rundown of the cases that have been the focus of popular ire.
They heard about Leonor La Rosa, a whistle-blower who disclosed the "Bermuda plan," which she said was a secret strategy to silence the press.
Ms. La Rosa's lawyer said she was tortured by her former colleagues in the basement of military headquarters, nicknamed the Pentagonito, where suspected terrorists were also tortured. Despite a court order, Ms. La Rosa was held against her will at the Military Hospital while the O.A.S. met. On Friday, she was transferred to a private clinic.
The commission also heard about Baruch Ivcher, president of a television station, who was now being threatened with losing his citizenship and his station after his investigative news shows reported on the La Rosa case, and raised questions about the annual income of Vladimiro Montesinos, the shadowy head of intelligence and Mr. Fujimori's adviser.
Mr. Montesinos, who seldom appears in public, has not denied a report that he receives a salary of $600,000. Nor has he answered the questions Peruvians inevitably began asking: who could be paying him so much money, and why?
 
'Step Backward For Democracy'
After the broadcast, Mr. Ivcher, a naturalized Peruvian born in Israel, became the target of accusations that he was an agent of Israeli intelligence who sold weapons to the Ecuadorians during that country's brief border war with Peru. The accusations, which Mr. Ivcher maintains were based on forgeries, were printed in publications friendly with the military, but remain so far unsubstantiated.
Mr. Fujimori declined a request for an interview. But both Mr. Iglesias and Mr. McLarty said the President of Congress, Victor Joy Way, had defended the dismissal of the judges. He said the Constitutional Tribunal had no right to rule on the re-election law, since three of the seven judges had abstained.
Mr. Iglesias, who five years ago froze the development bank's funding of projects here after Mr. Fujimori dismantled other branches of Government, said he found Mr. Joy Way's explanation for the current actions "interesting." Mr. McLarty, though he backed a statement by American Ambassador Dennis C. Jett branding the dismissal of the judges "a step backward for democracy," called Mr. Joy Way "impressive."
Aside from lashing out at unidentified, nefarious interests in the media, Mr. Fujimori has not addressed the accusations or protests directly. But in a sense, his answer to his critics is the practice of making visits to the poor districts of Lima. Here, he can show the practical results of his Administration, and the appreciation of poor people. The poor, after all, make up 49 percent of Peru's population.
In the slums Mr. Fujimori visited with his guests, nearly all of the signs announcing works in progress bear Mr. Fujimori's name. Even a vocational program in a small, empty restaurant carries a plaque with his name. But the need is vast, and what people in the slums notice is not the number of signs, but how thinly the money is spread -- too thinly to give them hopes of a better life.
 
Fears That Power Breeds Corruption
While ministries and various programs -- like the newly-paved road where he waited -- are funded with Government money, Mr. Saavedra said, he was troubled by the concentration of power in the Presidency. "I just hope that when Fujimori leaves, it doesn't turn out that he took everything, like Alan Garcia." He was referring to Peru's previous President, who fled to France after he was accused of enriching himself in power.
The local soup kitchen said it received some $170 a month from the Government, and a couple of sacks of rice. Though Mr. Garcia is blamed for sacking the country's coffers, people at the soup kitchen's said they received more substantial help under his Administration.
"He may have been a crook, but at least we could eat meat," said Pablo Correa, a 32-year-old taxi driver who said he worked 14 hours a day. At Peruvian prices, his family of four gets to eat meat no more than twice a month, he said.
Some do not rule out Mr. Fujimori moving toward greater democracy under the new-found pressure from Washington, the broadening opposition and the streets. Until now, a former ally of the President noted, there has been no counterbalance to the repressive tactics of the military and intelligence branches.
But there has been an unexpected turnaround since the special forces killed the guerrillas: the two men Mr. Fujimori paraded through the house after the raid, Mr. Montesinos, and Gen. Nicolas Hermoza Rios, have become his greatest liabilities. Though cleared by a military court, the amnesty spared the two from publicly answering questions about alleged atrocities in the early 1990's. According to polls, they are the most reviled public figures in Peru.
And the misgivings over the President's respect for institutions like courts, which arose with reports guerrillas were executed instead of arrested when they tried to surrender, appear to have grown, and pushed Peruvians near their breaking point.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS AND TAXES: THE OVERVIEW;
G.O.P. LAWMAKER UNVEILS PROPOSAL FOR A BIG TAX CUT

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The chief Republican tax writer unveiled his plan today for apportioning the first big Federal tax cut since 1981, making good on his party's promise to reduce tax bills for investors and families but prompting criticism from Democrats that the plan favors the wealthy.
Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, laid out his legislative blueprint for tax cuts that would be worth nearly $135 billion over the next five years, paid for in part by about $50 billion in new revenue, for a net tax relief of $85 billion. The new revenue would come from sources that include an extension of a tax on airline tickets and a proposal to tax business activities by Indian tribes, including casinos. 
 Mr. Archer's proposal will frame the debate over taxes as Congress turns to the details of enacting the balanced-budget package agreed to in outline by the Republican leadership and the Clinton Administration last month.
But the proposal faces the likelihood of amendment as Mr. Archer writes a bill that can win President Clinton's signature while accommodating the somewhat different demands likely to emerge from Senate Republicans.
The centerpiece of Mr. Archer's plan is a reduction in the top rate on capital gains from the sale of stocks, bonds and other assets to 20 percent from 28 percent -- a proposal that helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average today to 7,478.50, the second straight record finish for the blue chip index -- and a credit for many families of up to $500 per child under the age of 17.
The plan would also expand the Individual Retirement Account program, reduce inheritance taxes slightly and try to stimulate economic development in the beleaguered District of Columbia.
It includes tax breaks for college tuition sought by Mr. Clinton, but in a scaled-back form, one of several issues that put Mr. Archer in conflict with the White House and Democrats in Congress.
While today's announcement by Mr. Archer generated no shortage of partisan and interest-group protest, the start of this year's tax process is welcome to both political parties.
It gives them their first chance since the beginning of the Reagan Administration to enact broad-based tax relief, the dividend from more than six years of economic growth that has swelled the Government's coffers sufficiently to allow both parties to claim they are balancing the budget even as they cut taxes.
"The tax relief package that we will consider represents a solid first step toward a smaller government for bureaucrats in Washington and a larger paycheck for workers in America," Mr. Archer said.
Democrats said Mr. Archer's plan rewarded Wall Street and wealthy families at the expense of middle- and lower-income working families.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the ranking Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee, said he doubted that Mr. Archer's proposals would have any Democratic support in the committee, which is scheduled to vote on the tax bill this week and move it on to the full House for consideration.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the Administration had serious concerns about the Archer plan because "it seems to have moved the tax benefit away from the less well off, and even away from middle-income people, toward higher-income people."
Some Democrats said they feared that the final bill could include even less in the way of tax relief for lower- and middle-income people than Mr. Archer's proposal because two of the measures he is relying on to pay for the tax cuts are politically unpopular even among Republicans and stand little chance of being adopted.
Mr. Archer wants to raise $4.5 billion over the next decade by imposing a Federal income tax on the earnings of businesses run by Indian tribes. A bipartisan group of senators representing states with large Indian populations came out against the plan; among the senators was Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader.
Mr. Archer is also standing almost alone among Republican leaders in proposing to scale back and eventually repeal all subsidies for the production of ethanol, a corn-based alternative fuel that has long had strong support from farm-state delegations. Mr. Archer's plan counts on $4.1 billion over 10 years from eliminating the subsidies.
The chairman's plan also includes the following:
A tax credit for families with children under 17. The credit would be $400 per child in 1998 and $500 thereafter, to be phased out for single taxpayers with income above $75,000 and for couples filing jointly with income above $110,000. Mr. Archer estimated the cost of the program at $71.3 billion over five years and $148.4 billion over 10 years.
A reduction in the top rate on capital gains. The top rate on profits from the sale of securities, real estate and other assets would fall to 20 percent from 28 percent, effective for all sales starting last May 7. The gain on the sale of a principal home would be exempted up to $250,000 for single people and up to $500,000 for joint filers. Starting in the year 2001, capital gains would be reduced to account for the effects of inflation on assets held for at least three years.
The capital gains rate for corporations would be gradually reduced to 30 percent in 2000 from its current level of 35 percent.
Tax breaks for college expenses. The plan would create a tax credit of up to 50 percent of the costs in each of the first two years of college after accounting for financial aid, up to a maximum of $1,500 a year. The President's version of the plan was more generous, and White House officials said Mr. Archer's plan would shortchange lower- and moderate-income students in community colleges. Mr. Archer's plan also radically rewrote Mr. Clinton's plan to offer families a deduction of up to $10,000 a year for college expenses, limiting it to those families that put money into special education-savings accounts.
Mr. Archer would help pay for the tax breaks by requiring employees of colleges and universities to pay taxes on the value of tuition breaks that their children receive.
The Republicans had agreed to spend $35 billion over five years on higher education proposals "consistent" with the President's plan, but Mr. Archer's blueprint came to only $31 billion, reflecting Republican reluctance to apportion such a large chunk of the tax cut to a program that had only modest support.
An expansion of the Individual Retirement Account. The plan would create accounts into which taxpayers could make non-deductible contributions. The interest earnings could be withdrawn tax-free for retirement or buying a first home.
A reduction in inheritance taxes. Under pressure from the small-business lobby, Mr. Archer included a reduction in the Federal estate tax. He proposed a gradual increase in the portion of an estate exempted from the tax, to $1 million from the current $600,000, to be phased in over 17 years.
Changes to the alternative minimum tax. Mr. Archer proposed phasing out the alternative minimum tax for corporations and to eliminate it entirely by 2006. The tax had been intended to insure that all companies paid some tax even if they had access to sophisticated tax-avoidance strategies. For individuals, the plan would gradually increase the income level at which they would become subject to the alternative minimum tax.
Over all, the Republican plan largely fulfilled the demands placed on the party by its two most powerful factions, the social conservatives who wanted a substantial child credit, and the economic conservatives, who made a deep cut in capital gains taxes their priority.
But to do so, Mr. Archer had to keep the costs down, and he did so by structuring many of the tax cuts in ways that Democrats and some independent analysts said hit lower- and middle-income taxpayers harder than the wealthy.
In particular, they said, the child credit was structured in such a way that many families with incomes under $30,000 who benefit from the earned income tax credit would not receive the full $500 credit.

Here are the main tax reductions proposed today by Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and the estimated revenue effects over the five years covered by the balanced budget agreement. Dozens of additional proposals will bring the total tax cut to $135 billion over that period, partly paid for by $50 billion in new revenues.
 
TAX CREDIT FOR CHILDREN -- $71 billion revenue loss
Parents would be given a tax reduction of $400 in 1998 and $500 every year afterward for each child 17 years old and younger. The credit would be reduced for families with incomes over $75,000, and families with incomes over $110,000 would not be eligible.
 
CAPITAL GAINS -- $3 billion revenue gain
The top rate for individuals, now 28 percent, would be lowered to 10 percent for taxpayers with incomes below $41,200 and to 20 percent for everyone else for property sold after May 7, 1997. Beginning in 2001, profits would be adjusted for inflation. Couples would be exempt from taxation on $500,000 in profits from the sale of their principal home; for a single person, the exemption would be $250,000. After $3 billion revenue gain through 2002, a loss of $35 billion through 2007.
 
RETIREMENT ACCOUNTS-- $33 million revenue loss
A new form of individual retirement account would be created for taxpayers regardless of income in which the deposit would not be tax deductible, but the money could be withdrawn tax-free after retirement or for the purchase of a home. A revenue loss of $33 million through 2002, but $13 billion through 2007.
 
EDUCATION -- $31 billion revenue loss
Taxpayers would be entitled to a tax credit up to $1,500 a year to help pay as much as half the cost of each of the first two years of college. Couples with incomes above $100,000 and single people with incomes above $50,000 would not be eligible. A deduction of up to $10,000 per year (but no more than $40,000 aggregate per student) could be taken regardless of income to cover undergraduate expenses paid through a state-sponsored prepaid tuition program. A tax break would be allowed for money parents contributed to an education savings account, similar to an I.R.A., and then withdrew to meet tuition expenses. The revenue loss includes other, smaller tax breaks for education.
 
ESTATES -- $3 billion revenue loss
The amount of money in an estate exempt from taxation, now $600,000, would be increased by $20,000 a year through 2002 and $25,000 a year thereafter, to a maximum of $1 million. The revenue loss includes other, smaller tax breaks for estates. (pg. D25)

HEADLINE: In France, the Grass Isn't Greener Than Ours

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Diane Johnson has swallowed the reassuring lies the French tell themselves when they begin to suspect that their society is perhaps not the best in the world ("Liberty, Equality, Bon Appetit," Op-Ed, June 8). 
 "Working mothers have day care": yes, if they sign up a year in advance. "Early retirement for people who work at hard jobs": rather, for people whose predecessors 50 years ago worked at hard jobs; but if anyone thinks of decreasing those privileges, the country comes to a standstill.
American society has many problems, and might look with longing at the greener grass; but it should know that those same problems the French thought impossible in their society are now taking root: run-down projects, unemployed youths forming gangs and dealing drugs, deteriorating education and emergence of an underclass marked by skin color.
On the other hand, the French economy has created fewer jobs in 20 years than the United States does in a year, and the last time the French unemployment rate was below 8 percent was in 1981.
The French were not offered the choice between an American economic model and social protections; the Gaullists believe too much in the state to offer anything like the dreaded "Anglo-American" model. The choice was between one and the same; the Socialist leader Lionel Jospin promised more jobs, fewer taxes and a smaller deficit, which is what Jacques Chirac promised in 1995.
 
FRANCOIS VELDE
Baltimore, June 8, 1997

HEADLINE: In France, the Grass Isn't Greener Than Ours;
Low Child Poverty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Comments on the French election have emphasized some of the luxuries that the French people enjoy and want to try to keep, such as long vacations, early retirement and those famous 500 cheeses (Op-Ed and Week in Review cartoon, June 8). 
 But the French welfare state does far more important things. For example, it finances programs that keep child poverty low. The child poverty rates in the United States and France are 22 percent and 6 percent, respectively, despite similar rates of out-of-wedlock births.
The French keep child poverty low by spending about 80 percent more than we do to help families with children and concentrating a lot of that help on parents who work at low wages.
A French single mother with two preschool children leaving welfare to go into a modest job would not lose most of her benefits, as would be the case here. She would get cash and housing benefits equal to about $6,000 a year to supplement her wages, free or highly subsidized high-quality child care, and coverage under France's national health insurance plan.
The American economy would be somewhat less prosperous if the United States behaved more like France. But the American people might consider the trade-off worthwhile.
 
BARBARA R. BERGMANN
Washington, June 9, 1997

HEADLINE: The Urban Happiness Quotient;
New York's Well-Being Is Up. Figures Don't Lie, Right?

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Wouldn't it be swell (for the mayor of a big city who had staked his reputation on upgrading the quality of life) if there were a Dow Jones-style index for tracking the city's mental and social state?
The Giuliani administration, thinking just that, paid a mathematician and a team of researchers $25,000 last year to come up with a formula with which to follow the ebb and flow of the city's mental health and social well-being. 
 The researchers spent months pondering indicators, numerators and denominators, conferring about domain factors and data sets, and charting billowy (and opportunely upward-sloping) shapes on graphs.
Then they delivered a 41-page report, jam-packed with phrases like "need per unit of economic output" and "support per unit of need," purporting to have discovered a diagnostic instrument for gauging the city's health.
Here it is:
 
[The urban happiness quotient]
 
(where a,b and c are greater than 0, and a+b+c=1)
Into that formula they had plugged all sorts of statistics; on poverty, employment, wages, murders, education spending, the mental-health budget, homelessness, even the number of housing units near boarded-up buildings.
Presto!
According to the "social and mental well-being index" developed for the Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services, and to be presented at a meeting of psychiatrists in Washington this fall, the well-being of New Yorkers in general rose 14 percent between 1991 and 1995.
And according to the "mental health index" the researchers developed for the department to gauge conditions for the mentally ill in New York, the improvement there was a modest, but still cheery 9 percent.
Sounds nifty. What does it mean?
"It's like I.Q., what does I.Q. mean?" said Dr. Carole Siegel, head of a lab at the Nathan S. Kline Institute for Psychiatric Research in Orangeburg, N.Y., who led the team that developed the indices.
"I.Q. measures what's in the Stanford-Binet test, but we use it to say something about intelligence," she said. "So the mental well-being index is about mental well-being. What is it? It is what we've measured."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani moved quickly to use the findings to enhance his own well-being. "This study shows scientifically what New Yorkers have felt for the past few years, that the quality of life in New York City is improving," a spokeswoman said. "This is an objective measure that what we're doing is making a difference."
Ruth W. Messinger, who would like Mr. Giuliani's job, was withering about the results: "They don't tell me anything. Somebody else could look at the same indicators and reach a different conclusion. Why is this something useful to do with tax money? I just don't get it."
Every New Yorker, of course, has his or her own way of measuring the city's state of mind: assessing communal hypertension on the IRT, or the attitudes of panhandlers outside the bagel store, or the fortification quotient in taxi cabs.
And every New Yorker has an opinion about whether urban well-being is even desirable, considering that psychic stability has never been a building block of the city's reputation.
But look at it this way: even if New Yorkers are too neurotic to accept that the city could ever become less neurotic and dysfunctional, the formula is exportable. Another city, San Diego or San Antonio or Sao Paulo, could put it to good use.
The idea of the indices first surfaced in 1995, when members of Mayor Giuliani's staff and the mental health department began talking about creating a "report card" to measure the agency's effectiveness.
So the agency contracted with Dr. Siegel, who had once tried to find simple ways of tracking the mental health of entire countries for the World Health Organization (she says she found it "an almost impossible task").
The agency and Dr. Siegel decided that while they were looking at the quality of life for the mentally ill, they might as well use the same approach to figure out how everybody else was doing.
"We very much wanted to have a measure to assess the progress we've made toward improving the quality of life for people with mental illness and for all New Yorkers," said Dr. Neal L. Cohen, the Commissioner of the department. "It tells us how much we've accomplished and where we need to go from here."
Dr. Siegel's group began by compiling long lists of indicators that might reflect the mental health and well-being of the city, from socioeconomic factors like the poverty rate to data on crime, infant mortality and drug-related hospitalizations.
Then the researchers gave their lists to an outside panel of researchers, policy makers, public officials and others to scrutinize, and to rank each indicator on a scale of importance, Dr. Siegel said.
Finally, they wrote the formula: outcomes plus supports plus economic conditions divided by needs equals urban contentment, or lack of it.
"If the outcomes improve, the index improves," Dr. Siegel said. "If supports improve, the index improves. If economic conditions improve, the index improves. But if need goes up, and everything else doesn't, the index goes down."
Indicator projects are fashionable. Marc L. Miringoff, a social policy analyst at the Fordham University Graduate Center in Tarrytown who has been doing an annual index of the country's social health for 11 years, said no other projects existed when he began. Now there are 200.
Some, like the Oregon Benchmarks project, track progress toward environmental, educational or other goals. Others have taken factors from alarm-clock sales to amounts of time lost commuting to and from work as their indicators.
"We measure the stock market every day," Professor Miringoff said. "We have durable goods and factory inventories and housing starts measured every month. All those things are very visible and precise. What we don't know is the social well-being of our people."
Dr. Juan E. Mezzich, a professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, called the report useful. But because it had to rely on available data, he said, it lacked any assessment of emotional health.
But D. J. Jaffe, a board member of the National Alliance for the Mentally Ill, complained that the mental health department should not be spending its money finding out if people in general are happy. "The economy is up, therefore fewer people have brain disorders?" he said. "It's ludicrous."
Will it last?
Dr. John A. Hornik, a former official of the New York State Office of Mental Health who advised Dr. Siegel, said: "Politicians are going to be happy about it as long as the index continues to show improvements. But as soon as the curve turns, people who are happy with it now are going to say: 'There must be some methodological problem.' "
 
The Serenity Equation
Try this at home at the risk of your own mental health:
The formula used to develop the mental health and social and mental well-being indices adds O (outcomes, like the murder rate), S (supports, like the size of the mental health budget) and E (economic factors like the average income of full-time workers), then divides that by N (needs, like the number of New Yorkers with serious mental illness).

CORRECTION-DATE: June 12, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about the indexes devised for New York City mental health officials to measure the social and mental well-being of New Yorkers misstated the mathematical formula involved. Three factors in the formula -- labeled outcomes, supports and economic factors -- are multiplied, not added.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Looking At What Black Looks Like

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON 

 BODY:
I have been reading fashion magazines for years, and most of them have been filled with women who looked quite unlike me and wore clothes I was unlikely to wear in settings I was unlikely to find myself in. And yes, one of the obvious differences between us was racial.
I would have been delighted to see Lena Horne or Dorothy Dandridge photographed beyond the racial cloister of Ebony Magazine, draped, say, on a divan in Vogue or exuding hauteur on the boulevard of some major European capital for Harper's Bazaar in the 1950's. And I despised the reasons they were excluded, if prejudice, ignorance and timidity can be called reasons. 
 But thank goodness I could still love great non-Negro models like Suzy Parker and Lisa Fossangrives. It is fine visual and imaginative training, this learning to be at ease with something that on the surface seems quite removed from you. It is the kind of training people go out of their way to acquire when they believe that esthetics, not race or ethnicity, are at issue. The truth is, when it comes to fashion, esthetics can't really be separated from how we visualize race and dramatize ethnicity.
Women of color (some color, more color, less color) started showing up in white fashion magazines in the 1960's and 70's. Donyale Luna, Naomi Sims, Pat Cleveland, Beverly Johnson and Iman neither resembled one another nor added up to some comfortably all-purpose African-American type.
Their presence did illustrate the little-known but interesting fact that the people we have called colored, Negro, black and African-American exhibit a range of looks that goes from Nordic to Sub-Saharan, with all sorts of geographic in-betweens. (When I was growing up, we also had the Negro-Mediterranean, American Indian, East Indian, Mexican-Indian, Sephardic, Egyptian, Nubian and Ethiopian looks.)
These models and the clothes they wore also signaled that the United States was no longer in a state of acute culturally infantile paralysis. Non-Nordic styles could now, like avant-garde art, rhythm-and-blues and sexually frank European films, be appreciated openly, not pored over in secret and in flagrant violation of all civilization held dear.
Oh for that brief moment when politics, esthetics and economics were in perfect accord! In the 1960's and 70's, fashion matched civil rights and civil liberties with visual rights and imaginative liberties. Fashion saw that it needed new markets to expand and new stimuli -- colors, shapes and fabrics -- to thrive. Whenever a new physical type appears (new in terms of height, weight or bone structure, not just ethnicity), whenever designers experiment with new cultural styles and references, we, the consumers, have to expand not only our sense of fantasy, but also our sense of reality.
Sometimes consumers just can't or won't: last week The New York Times quoted a forthcoming Vogue magazine editorial to the effect that whenever nonwhite models appear on the covers of mostly white magazines, sales go down. The Times article also noted that the layouts that use, in fact depend on, nonwhite models follow highly predictable, shall we say old hat racial and cultural conventions: lush tropic paradises, funky third world streets accessorized with natives in native garb.
I don't mind some of this visual tourism. The black and British Naomi Campbell looks wonderful in Ralph Lauren's Masai-esque dresses. But so might the white and German Nadja Auerman, especially if you like your Masai stylings to have a high-Teutonic Leni Riefenstahl gloss. And Naomi Campbell also looks wonderful in Ralph Lauren's mega-WASP Polo ads, as does the black American Tyson Beckford. (After what must have been a careful study of the Benetton and Tommy Hilfiger ad campaigns, Mr. Lauren has finally realized that when you put black people in preppy clothing, you create a refreshingly up-to-date un-nostalgic brand of chic exoticism.)
What I do mind is the lack of inventiveness that so often restricts models of color to these ostentatiously "natural" habitats. And don't just blame the consumers for that: blame the editors, stylists and photographers. This is not about being politically correct. This is about being visually alert and creative, which is, after all, their job. And the lack of inventiveness is not limited to race and ethnicity. It never is: a failure of racial imagination is always tied to other lags and lapses.
Fashion photography is filled with cliched layouts and pseudo-narratives right now. Apart from the heroin chic look under attack (wan, hollow-eyed forms slumped against pale bathroom tiles), they include the lone girl, sullen and enigmatic, standing or squatting on a highway or roadside in semi-biker or high-toned slut gear; the lone girl, vibrant but contemplative, walking along a generic beach or wading in a generic body of water; the lone girl, poised in a botanically undistinguished garden or field, wearing something fragile and lyrical, and the lone girl against a blank backdrop, displaying a set of 60's-starlet attitudes. What is with all these fake-cinematic photo-soliloquies? Why aren't they more interestingly lighted and designed? And why aren't there more dynamic group photographs in magazines?
When we look at a fashion layout, all kinds of conscious and unconscious reactions roil around inside us. If the model is our ethnic or racial twin, we may find ourselves rooting for the home team. If the model is wildly exotic or "other," we may borrow the fantasy for an everyday costume or encounter. We may feel judgmental or condescending or intensely envious. But we have to feel curious and excited, eager to be (or play at being) something we hadn't yet dared to imagine.

HEADLINE: Stanley Schachter Dies at 75; Psychologist of the Mundane

BYLINE: By KAREN FREEMAN 

 BODY:
Dr. Stanley Schachter, who delighted in finding simple explanations for seemingly complex social behavior, died on Saturday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 75 and also had a home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
The cause was colon cancer, said his wife, Sophia. 
 Dr. Schachter, a professor emeritus at Columbia University, was one of the few social psychologists to be elected to the National Academy of Sciences.
Dr. Judith Rodin, president of the University of Pennsylvania, called Dr. Schachter, who had supervised her doctoral work at Columbia, the "greatest living social psychologist of our time."
Dr. Schachter's interests were wide-ranging, and he asked the kinds of questions about topics like obesity, addiction, emotions and the behavior of stock market investors that the public found interesting.
In studies on obesity, Dr. Schachter found that people of normal weight ate when they were hungry and stopped when they were full but that overweight people ate because of other cues, like the presence of enticing food, the time of day and other external factors.
Dr. Schachter found that the way food was presented helped determine how much an obese person would eat. "He found that if you put peanuts under a light, fat people would eat them," said Dr. Don Hood, a colleague at Columbia. "If you hid them in a dark corner, they wouldn't walk over to pick them up."
Dr. Schachter also liked to puncture the elaborate theories of others. In the 1970's, he and Dr. Hood challenged the efficient-market hypothesis of economists, which said that the stock market operated independently of the behavior of independent investors. They produced data that ran counter to that theory and showed that the psychology of individuals was affecting the market.
The answer, Dr. Schachter said, was simple. So simple, in fact, that if the economists had asked their grandmothers what was going on, he contended, their grandmothers would have told them to pay attention to the fear and greed of individual investors if they wanted to understand the market. He coined the term "bubba psychology" ("bubba" is "grandmother" in Yiddish) to describe this common-sense approach.
Dr. Schachter's friends and colleagues were sometimes swept up by his experiments.
When he became interested in the metabolic basis of cigarette addiction, Dr. Schachter persuaded friends near his summer home in East Hampton to join a study.
He gave the friends cigarettes with different levels of nicotine but did not tell them which cigarettes they had been given. The friends kept track of their cigarette consumption and other activities and even kept daily urine samples in their refrigerators for graduate students to pick up.
As a result of that study, Dr. Schachter came up with the idea that social interactions can affect the acidity of urine, which affects nicotine retention and, therefore, cigarette consumption -- a metabolic explanation for why smokers smoked more in social gatherings. Dr. Hood said that that idea had been validated since then.
But the experiment was not trouble-free for Dr. Schachter's friends. "It led to problems in some families, with people on the low-nicotine cigarettes going into withdrawal and getting hard to live with," Dr. Hood said. "Husbands and wives were coming to Stanley to say, Will you please give him or her the real cigarettes."
Dr. Schacter's interest in why people become tongue-tied was aroused at a faculty meeting, said Dr. Robert M. Krauss, a psychology professor at Columbia, when he began keeping track of how many times each colleague stumbled for words by saying "um." Soon he had students out recording professors giving lectures in various fields and counting up how many times they cast about for a word. He found that professors lecturing in the humanities were much more prone to do that than those in the sciences, and professors in the social sciences fell in between.
But all professors showed the same tendency to trip over their tongues in interviews on another subject, leading Dr. Schacter to conclude that it was the subject matter, not the kind of person attracted to each field, that accounted for the differences. In the humanities, he said, the number of ways to voice a particular idea are far greater than in the sciences, leading to more indecision.
Dr. Schachter was born in New York City in 1922. He got bachelor's and master's degrees from Yale University in 1942 and 1944, and, after serving in the Air Force, earned his doctorate in social psychology at the University of Michigan in 1949. After teaching at the University of Minnesota, the University of Amsterdam and Stanford University, he joined Columbia's psychology faculty as a professor in 1961. He became the Robert Johnston Niven Professor of Social Psychology there in 1966, and he retired in 1992.
He won many honors, including the James McKeen Cattell Award, the Social Psychological Prize of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and awards from the American Psychological Association and the Society for Experimental Social Psychology. Dr. Schachter was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Science in 1976.
In addition to his wife, Dr. Schachter is survived by a son, Elijah, of New York City.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Slide As Corporate Flood Is Due

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
An expected flood of new corporate debt weighed on Treasury prices yesterday, erasing early gains on increased buying from foreign investors and on a regional report that showed moderate economic growth.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 6/32, to 97 10/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.84 percent, from 6.82 percent on Monday. 
 Treasury prices were helped in early trading by concerns over the prospect of European monetary union, which drew foreign investors seeking a safe haven.
But a number of large corporate debt issues are scheduled to come to market this week and that prompted some investors to sell Treasury securities, especially the 10-year note, as a hedge yesterday, said Greg Jones, an economist at Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Menlo Park, Calif.
The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, plans to sell $2.5 billion of securities backed by student loans. The MBNA Corporation plans to sell $500 million of credit card back debt, and the Olympic Financial Corporation plans to issue $775 million of debt backed by auto loans. Some analysts said the abundance of higher-yielding asset-backed debt could lure investors away from Treasury bonds, causing Treasury prices to fall further.
With interest rates low and demand good, several companies priced debt yesterday. The Associates Corporation sold $500 million of three-year notes at a price to yield 6.46 percent, about 18.5 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- more than a comparable Treasury security, through underwriters led by UBS Securities. The A. H. Belo Corporation priced $750 million of debt in three parts through Morgan Stanley & Company, with $250 million of notes due 2002 priced to yield 6.923 percent, or about 47 basis points over a comparable Treasury security; $300 million of 10-year notes priced to yield 7.236 percent, or about 67 basis points over a similar Treasury, and $200 million of 30-year debentures priced to yield 7.754 percent, or 87 basis points over a comparable Treasury.
Waiting in the wings are the Mercantile Bancorporation and the Long Island Savings Bank among others that are planning to sell a total of at least $4 billion of debt this week.
A report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond bolstered Treasury prices yesterday. Although the report is only a regional survey, it helped confirm a view that the economy is still growing at a moderate pace.
The Richmond Fed reported declines in its major monthly retail and services indexes, but rising price trends. The service revenue index fell to 26 in May from 33 in April and the retail revenue index fell to 14 from 36. New orders also fell, to 16 from 25 in April.
Though the economy appears to be slowing moderately, the report outlines a tighter labor market and rising price trends, said an economist with the Richmond Fed, Raymond Owens.
Another report, the weekly LJR Redbook retail sales survey, showed signs of a pickup, however. Retail sales rose a surprisingly strong 2.3 percent, according to the survey. "It is the first clean evidence that the slowdown in consumption in April through May could be blamed on the cold weather," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York.
The next notable economic report comes tomorrow, when the Government releases its report on retail sales for May.

HEADLINE: City Budget Deal Was Not Just Political 'Theater'

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"The Next City Budget Debate" (editorial, June 6) remarks that the New York City Council did little to change Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's fiscal plan. 
 You neglect the Council's creation of a $30 million "emerging industry" development fund for job creation, our large expansion of library services, our initiative to begin eliminating double taxation through changes in the unincorporated business tax, and our financial support for alternatives to incarceration -- not to mention a host of other investments long supported by your editorial page.
You also seem surprised that the "let's-party end of City Hall" would adopt a budget "more fiscally responsible" than the one proposed by Mayor Giuliani.
Since the 1989 charter revision, the City Council has been as fiscally responsible as any mayor, if not more so. In addition, the Council's more accurate revenue forecasts led both sides to a budget agreement that included greater tax cuts and new investment in the economy than the Mayor had initially proposed.
You are correct that the adopted budget is a better budget for the city than the one proposed by the Mayor. However, that was the result not of "theater," but of a lot of hard work by both sides.
 
PETER F. VALLONE
Speaker, New York City Council
New York, June 9, 1997

HEADLINE: TRACK AND FIELD;
Having What It Takes To Perform a Perfect 10

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, June 10

 BODY:
As a kid growing up in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Chris Huffins wanted to be Julius Erving, not Bruce Jenner. His interest was basketball, not the decathlon. If he was to toss anything, it was to be a jump shot, not a javelin.
When Huffins was 11, his mother moved to Indianapolis, never imagining that her son would eventually become a favorite to win a national decathlon championship in her adopted hometown and that he would one day challenge for the title of world's greatest athlete. 
 "I was looking for blue skies and green grass," Sandra Gay said. "Indianapolis beat a poke in the eye with a sharp stick."
After remaining a year with his grandparents, Huffins followed his mother to the Midwest in 1981. But she kept his athletic endeavors on a short leash. School before sports, Gay told him. She had carried a double major of education and drama at Fordham University, and she had little interest in her son becoming a double-letter winner in basketball and track. Choose one sport, she told him. He chose basketball.
Finally, in Huffins's junior year at Cathedral High in Indianapolis, his mother relented and allowed him to compete in track and field, as well. Eventually, he leaped 23 feet 6 1/2 inches in the long jump, took third in the state meet and reached the state semifinals in the 100-meter dash.
After a short, unhappy stay at Purdue, Huffins transferred to Cal-Berkeley and took up the decathlon. Last year, he ran the fastest 100 meters ever for a decathlete, 10.22 seconds, qualified for the Olympics and finished 10th in the Summer Games in Atlanta.
This week, the national championships have come to Indianapolis, to the very same Indiana University track where Huffins competed in high school. Dan O'Brien, the Olympic champion, has withdrawn because of an injury, which makes Huffins the favorite in the 10-event competition that begins Wednesday. He also believes he can win at the world championships in Athens in August.
"I feel like it's my year," the loquacious, 27-year-old Huffins said of the national championships. "I came with a mission to win."
O'Brien, who withdrew from the nationals with a stress fracture in his right tibia, has said he will likely petition American officials for a wild-card berth in the 1997 world championships. "There should be exemptions for people who deserve them," O'Brien said recently.
The United States is the only country that selects athletes for the Olympics and world championships on the strict basis of a first, second, or third-place finish in the national championships. Huffins said that while he understood O'Brien's argument, he preferred the current selection system over wild-card entries.
"I think it would set a bad precedent," Huffins said. "It's cutthroat, but there's something to be said about earning your way onto the team."
Huffins's own rise to Olympian heights is as improbable as any story in track and field. It seems as unlikely to him as the emergence of a rapper named LL Cool J, whom Huffins used to see entertaining at block parties in Hollis, Queens.
For Huffins, the playgrounds in Brooklyn held the allure of basketball, not the running, jumping and throwing of a decathlon.
"I knew who Bruce Jenner was and I thought he was cool, but I wanted to be Doctor J," he said. "That's pretty much it."
At Cal-Berkeley in 1991, the 6-foot-2-inch, 180-pound Huffins attempted a decathlon on the advice of his coach, Ed Miller, who had been the 1976 collegiate decathlon champion.
A year later, in only his second official decathlon, Huffins competed in the 1992 Olympic trials. By 1995, he had finished eighth in the world championships, shooting up the charts like one of LL Cool J's songs.
In 1996, Huffins qualified for the Olympics, delivering 7 personal bests in the 10 events at the trials: 10.22 seconds at 100 meters; 53-11 in the shot-put; 6-7 1/2 in the high jump; 48.05 seconds at 400 meters; 14.09 seconds in the 110-meter hurdles; 15-9 in the pole vault and 208-9 in the javelin.
His mother, who works in a local bookstore, is proud and amused by her son's achievements. Gay was a high jumper herself at Samuel J. Tilden High in Brooklyn "about 100 years ago." But, admittedly, her passion for the decathlon is not exactly a threat to her passion for poetry and the theater.
"It was interesting to see people pay so much attention to him at the Olympics," she said. "I was thinking, 'This is the same kid who didn't want to take out the garbage or walk the dog.' "
With another 18 inches to his pole vault, 10 seconds off his personal best of 4:51.20 at 1,500 meters, and an improved high jump, Huffins feels he can one day succeed O'Brien as the world record-holder (8,891 points) and approach the 9,000-point barrier that is to decathlon what four minutes was to the mile.
Huffins, the holder of a degree in the political economies of industrial society, is now a consummate student of track and field. He trains up to 60 hours a week, participates in a track-and-field fantasy league and has collected an estimated 200 videotapes, everything from college meets to 60 hours of NBC's ill-fated Triplecast of the 1992 Barcelona Games.
"I want to be the best decathlete that ever lived," Huffins said. "If you take the top 10 in the world, we can play any sport -- basketball, bowling. I've been in some vicious pool games. World's greatest athlete is probably the most glamorous title on the planet. Michael Johnson and Donovan Bailey can fight about who's the fastest athlete. That doesn't have any implications for who the greatest all-around athlete is."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chris Huffins practicing his discus spin yesterday in Indianapolis. Huffins is favored to win the decathlon at the national championships. (Mary Ann Carter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
A Law Firm Takes Years To Find the Right Space

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
When the 112-year-old Atlanta-based law firm of King & Spalding recently signed a lease to move its New York offices to 1185 Avenue of the Americas, a small news article appeared. But behind that report were two years of planning and six months of negotiations, a combination of decision- and deal-making that provides a glimpse into the complex strategies and economic considerations of commercial real estate.
"We've been in New York for seven years," said James H. Wildman, the partner in charge of the 50-lawyer New York office for the 350-lawyer firm. "We started with three lawyers in a building on Fifth Avenue. Then we merged with a small firm that was already in Tower 45, 120 West 45th Street, and moved in." 
 They renegotiated the lease and, as the firm grew, wound up with three full floors, about 33,000 usable square feet. But the firm kept growing.
"About two years ago, we started to look very hard into how to accommodate more growth," Mr. Wildman said. "We looked first at Tower 45, but there was no way to expand on contiguous floors. And for a law firm, being on contiguous floors is very important -- there's a sense of community that you can't achieve otherwise."
So they entered the market. They hired Richard Bernstein of the Edward S. Gordon commercial brokerage company, which is now Insignia/ Edward S. Gordon Company. The goal: to find sufficient space for growth, and to get that space at the right price.
"For a growing law firm in New York, the challenge is having just the right amount of real estate," Mr. Wildman said. "Unlike any other market, it's virtually impossible to acquire options to expand in anticipation of growth. And you don't want too much space so you're overloaded. Occupancy cost is the second-largest expense for a law firm, after attorney compensation, and with clients concerned about billing rates it's very important to keep occupancy costs below a certain level."
Next came the questions of location, of the quality of the building -- and of its owners. He said he knew he could find "great economics" in the Wall Street area, where a high vacancy rate brought about by the recession of the early 90's has kept rental rates much lower than in midtown.
"But most of our clients are in midtown," he said, "and our lawyers' commuting patterns were such that relocating downtown would extend their commute."
He also wanted to be where other law firms are. A decade ago, that would have most probably meant east of Fifth Avenue, but recent years have seen a westward movement by many law firms that includes a large concentration on the Avenue of the Americas.
"We looked on Park Avenue," Mr. Wildman said, "and even east of Park, and were actually fairly close to a Park Avenue deal that didn't work out, but eventually we turned to Sixth Avenue. A number of buildings satisfied us in a general way, but Richard Bernstein took us to 1185, and everything came together."
The 42-story, 1.1 million-square-foot office building between 46th and 47th Streets is run by W & M Properties, the marketing and management arm of the Malkin real estate family; Peter L. Malkin and his son, Anthony E. Malkin, are the general partners of 1185 Avenue of the Americas Associates, which owns the building.
Finding large blocks of contiguous office space in midtown is becoming increasingly difficult, but 1185 had such space left -- its last large bloc -- from the move of Alexander & Alexander Services, an insurance consulting and brokerage company, to 11 Madison Avenue, at 24th Street.
King & Spalding was interested in about 53,000 square feet, the 34th and 35th floors. The negotiations began and lasted about six months.
"With any deal there are bumps in the road," Mr. Wildman said, "but they were resolved as amicably as possible. When you negotiate a deal you're laying the groundwork for a relationship that will extend for a long time. The object is not to squeeze the last cent out of the deal. You want it to work for everyone."
He declined to specify the bumps, but the end result was a 15-year lease valued at about $30 million, reflecting an average annual rent in the upper $30-a-square-foot range. Fred C. Posniak, vice president of W & M Properties, said his company was building the space for the tenant, reflecting a landlord contribution to the deal of more than $2 million, or more than $40 a square foot.
"We could have got superior economics elsewhere," Mr. Wildman said, "but it would not have been for as good quality space, as good location and as good ownership. What you pay in rent is important, but the rent in terms of cost per lawyer is important, too. We hired Gensler & Associates architects, and they laid out the space in all the buildings we looked at.
"And 1185's space was the most efficient. There was a low loss factor. The building is rectangular, nearly square. There's a good depth from the window to the core, which is perfect for a law firm in terms of design, and you get a good lawyer count per square foot. The number of buildings that do not work for a law firm is surprisingly high, and at 1185 you can get in enough lawyers without crowding."
The plan is for King & Spalding to move in by Sept. 1. And it will be moving in to even more space than originally planned. After closing the original deal, the firm decided to take an additional 15,000 square feet, just downstairs on the 33d floor.
"Real estate deals don't often work out this easy -- or this friendly," Mr. Posniak said.

HEADLINE: About New York;
In Yiddish Or English, A Valued Voice

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
ABRAHAM CAHAN, the legendary editor of The Jewish Daily Forward, used to say that his newspaper's job was to teach immigrants who traded shtetls for tenements how to live in America. It steadied their grip on their adopted culture, with stories and advice on such varied things as baseball and schooling for girls. It strengthened their resolve, covering the struggles of the nascent labor movement. It gave them an unvarnished vision of the Golden Land.
"It wasn't averse to talking with its readers about problems with their behavior," said Harold Ostroff, the general manager of the Forward Association, which publishes the paper. "This included not being ashamed about talking about Jewish criminals, Jewish prostitutes and the seedy side of life. Yet it always held out the hope we could overcome that through the educational process and improving the economic life of those unfortunate people who used other means to survive. It was always a teaching experience." 
 Such was their success that the Yiddish paper went from a daily circulation of 250,000 in the 1920's to a weekly readership of 10,000 today. Time and upward mobility have eroded its base of Yiddish speakers. But even in its centennial year, no one is setting type for its obituary. An English version that began publishing in 1990 is aimed at the children of those immigrants who grew up with the old Forward. More recently, the publishers rolled out a Russian-language edition to serve thousands of new immigrants.
RATHER than bemoan past glories, there is a sense at the paper that the changes are in keeping with the tradition of reassuring its readers that they could treasure the best of their heritage while moving, naturally, forward.
"Those ideas are in question in the Jewish community itself," said Sam Norich, who will succeed Mr. Ostroff next year. "We can help maintain what The Forward helped to create, which is an understanding of pluralism as central to American culture. That's a notion that's more and more at risk these days with the resurgence of true-blue Americanism. This country was made by immigrants who figured out -- sometimes with the example of The Forward -- how to maintain respect for where they came from while becoming American."
Founded by Socialists, The Forward was a general-interest newspaper for Yiddish-speaking immigrants who cut, sewed, hawked and hauled. The working man was able to read the day's grittier news and also keep up with the literature of stellar Yiddish writers like Isaac Bashevis Singer. Its coverage of politics and labor gave it a preeminence that later came into play when the paper broke from its Socialist past to endorse Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
"The Forward spoke for the largest single block of Jewish voters in the critical city of New York," said Arthur Hertzberg, a professor at New York University and a contributor to the Yiddish version of The Forward. "It had a major hand in creating the Jewish labor movement's participation in the New Deal coalition. So it has been a shaping influence in New York as a liberal state and on liberalism in America."
Roslyn Bresnick-Perry, who first heard of The Forward as a child in White Russia, recalled how the newspaper reminded her that Jews were capable of greatness, too.
"They really developed in us a sense of pride," said Ms. Bresnick-Perry. "Look who's Jewish: Einstein, Freud, Marx. Even though Eugene Debs isn't Jewish, he likes Jews."
THE paper's supporters say it is still capable of greatness, even if Yiddish is more studied than spoken. There is now talk about making the English Forward a daily newspaper.
Seth Lipsky, who left The Wall Street Journal to edit the English paper, flicked his finger across stories from recent editions, pointing to scoops big and small. He acknowledged that moving away from Yiddish was a break from tradition, but it presented an opportunity to help new generations connect with topics from a Jewish perspective.
Miriam Goldstein grew up with the Yiddish Forward. Such was its influence that her voice cracks and her eyes grow moist at the memory. It reminds her of childhood, not to mention the days when her mother would cover newly mopped floors with old editions of the paper to keep the floor clean on the Sabbath.
"I have a subscription to the English Forward," she said. "I do read Yiddish, but it takes me ten thousand years."
By then, who knows what language the paper will be printed in.
