HEADLINE: Sport Utility Vehicles Pose Growing Danger to Car Occupants

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 10

 BODY:
The rising number of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks on the nation's roads, combined with their increasing weight, poses a growing danger to car occupants and pedestrians, the Transportation Department concluded today in its first study of the issue.
In collisions between cars and light trucks, 80 percent of the fatalities are in the cars, the study found. Even though cars remain twice as common as light trucks, collisions involving cars and light trucks have been killing more Americans than collisions between cars since 1992. 
 "Continued growth in the number and weight of light trucks, unless offset by safety improvements, is likely to increase the hazard in collisions between the trucks and smaller road users," today's study concluded. "A reduction in truck weights is likely to generate significant benefits for pedestrians and car occupants that might exceed the added risk for the occupants of the trucks."
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the Transportation Department agency that produced today's study, has already formed a working group to review ways to reduce the death rate in collisions involving vehicles of very different sizes. Philip R. Recht, the agency's deputy administrator, said that today's study would be added to that review, but was not enough by itself to justify regulatory changes.
Today's study only looked at the statistical relationship between weight and collision casualties. The height and rigidity of light truck bodies, which sometimes override protective bars built into car bodies, may also play a role in the death rate, and this also needs to be studied, Mr. Recht said. If the Federal Government decides that regulatory changes are needed, one possibility would be to change the crash safety tests that vehicles must meet before being allowed on the road, he added.
Current crash tests and Federal safety ratings are designed to simulate a vehicle crashing into a similarly shaped vehicle within 500 pounds of its own weight. The tests do not measure how a one-ton compact car would fare in a collision with, for example, a Chevrolet Suburban weighing nearly three tons. But auto safety engineers here say privately that it is nearly impossible to design a small car that will do well in such a wreck.
Officials in the auto industry, which has benefited from strong sales for the biggest mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, quickly pointed out that light truck weights have risen partly because the Government now requires them to carry many of the same safety features as cars, like air bags. Barry Felrice, the director of regulatory affairs at the American Automobile Manufacturers Association in Washington, emphasized the study's finding that reducing the weight of a light truck would provide somewhat less protection for the occupants.
"If you're an occupant of that light truck, you probably wouldn't be happy to put your family at greater risk to reduce the risk to another family," Mr. Felrice said.
The average light truck now outweighs the average new car by half a ton, or 1,000 pounds. Reducing the average light truck weight by 100 pounds would decrease road fatalities by 40 a year, cut serious injuries by 601 a year, but increase less-serious injuries by 1,794 a year.
The reduction in fatalities is not statistically significant. The margin of error for the estimate of 40 deaths is plus or minus 60 deaths with 95 percent confidence, meaning that there is a small chance of an increase in deaths.
Barring Government regulatory changes, light trucks are likely to grow even heavier and more numerous in the coming years, judging by the future models displayed by manufacturers at recent auto shows.
Federal fuel-economy standards have been the main limit on vehicle weights for the last 20 years, because lighter vehicles can go farther on a gallon of gasoline than heavier vehicles of similar design. Auto makers must produce cars that go an average of 27 miles per gallon, while light trucks only need an average fuel economy of 20.7 miles per gallon. So cars have stayed small in recent years while light trucks have become much bigger and heavier.
Detroit auto makers, which produce 86 percent of the nation's light trucks, are preparing to build even more heavy, low-mileage sport utility vehicles. They are beginning to take advantage of a provision in Federal law intended to encourage the building of vehicles that can burn ethanol, a type of alcohol commonly made from corn. The legal provision lowers the fuel-economy standard for cars or light trucks by up to 1.2 miles per gallon for auto makers that produce vehicles that can run on either gasoline or ethanol or a combination of both.
The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would begin this autumn to produce 180,000 dual-fuel mini-vans a year. The Ford Motor Company announced last week that it would produce 250,000 dual-fuel vehicles by 2001, almost all of them Ranger pickup trucks.
Safety experts have been appalled by the spread of dual-fuel vehicles.
"It'll probably allow them to make even heavier trucks," widening the weight disparity in collisions with cars, said Gerald A. Donaldson, the senior research director at Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety in Washington. "This is awful for safety."
The General Motors Corporation has also been considering whether to introduce a dual-fuel vehicle.
Republicans in Congress have, with the support of the auto industry, attached provisions to the Transportation Department's budget for the last two years barring the agency from further increases in fuel-economy standards for light trucks. The original fuel-economy legislation, which dates to the first oil crisis in 1973-74, called for regulators to steadily increase fuel-economy standards as technology improved. While the Clinton Administration has discussed whether to seek higher fuel-economy standards, it has not actually done so.
Today's study began two years ago partly because Transportation Department officials wanted to know the safety effects if they raised fuel-economy standards and vehicle weights dropped. But the final report omits any discussion of fuel-economy issues.

HEADLINE: New Survey Shows Americans Pessimistic on Race Relations

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Four days before President Clinton is scheduled to deliver an address on race relations, a new survey shows that a majority of Americans are pessimistic that blacks and whites will ever learn to get along.
The most despairing among those polled by the Gallup Organization were young, college-educated blacks. 
 According to the survey, 55 percent of both blacks and whites, believe that relations between whites and blacks will "always be a problem" in the United States, while 42 percent say that a solution will eventually be found.
As Mr. Clinton was preparing his speech on race relations that will be delivered on Saturday in San Diego, the survey provided fresh evidence of how daunting a task he faces.
In one sharp difference, whites generally opposed and African-Americans supported increased governmental efforts like affirmative action to lift black achievement.
"When he does advocate those types of remedies for problems, he will certainly have agreement from the black American community that that's an appropriate action," said Frank Newport, editor in chief of the Gallup Poll, "but he'll be running up against a wall of attitudes of white Americans who are saying we don't see that there are problems currently and we don't believe therefore it is necessary for the Goverment to intervene."
Only 6 percent of whites and 10 percent of blacks rated themselves as prejudiced toward other racial groups, indicating that most feel they do not need Presidential exhortations about tolerance.
Today Mr. Clinton met with a group of black and Hispanic civil rights leaders to discuss racial issues and his coming speech.
To produce its findings, Gallup interviewed 3,036 adults over the age of 17 from Jan. 4 through Feb. 28. To make sure it accurately gauged black attitudes, the poll surveyed 1,269 African-Americans, a far larger proportion of the total number of people surveyed than is usually included in such a poll.
Among the more intriguing findings of the survey was the amount of pessimism among African-Americans. The poll indicated that 76 percent of black college graduates said race relations would always be troublesome for the country, while 56 percent of blacks who have not earned a college degree felt that way. Blacks under 25 years old also felt that race relations would always be a problem while those over 65 were more likely to say things would be worked out.
Conversely, 48 percent of white college graduates voiced such a pessimistic view, while 56 percent of whites without a college degree felt no solution to animus between the races would ever be found.
Gallup researchers said the object of the poll was to measure attitudes among blacks and whites. As a result, Hispanics were not broken out into a separate group and anyone who said he or she was Latino was asked to place himself or herself in a racial grouping instead.

HEADLINE: Joining NATO: Central Europe Sees a Cure-All

SERIES: EXPANDING ALLIANCE: European Voices

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 7

 BODY:
As Krzysztof Bertram rushes through the hectic pace of his daily life, balancing studies in business with work at an insurance company, he has little doubt where his country should be headed.
"For sure Poland has to join NATO," said the crisply dressed Mr. Bertram, 27, as he checked out courses at the Warsaw Polytechnic that might further his career. "The balance of power has changed. The Soviet Union is not around anymore, and I think NATO will be the organization to provide security for the world." 
 Mr. Bertram is enjoying the increased material well-being that has come to Poland as it progresses toward a market economy. Poles want to secure that new prosperity, but their overwhelming support for admission into NATO also suggests their almost reflexive fear of Russia, and a desire to be enveloped in a Western security blanket.
Three Central European countries are lined up for admission in July: Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary. Poland is the most enthusiastic, but for all three, joining NATO is seen as a long-term economic advantage, because it brings them closer to Western Europe. Still, there is nervousness over how the costs of military upgrading will be met, particularly in the Governments of Hungary and the Czech Republic.
The alliance is also considering membership for Romania and Slovenia, where popular sentiment for joining is overwhelming. The United States has shown lukewarm interest in expanding the list of newcomers to five, but with nine of the 16 NATO members in favor of admitting Romania and Slovenia, the possibility is being discussed in Washington.
The leaders of the three likeliest new members -- from the Czech President, Vaclav Havel, and the former Polish President, Lech Walesa, who initially pressed the NATO case with President Clinton, to the Hungarian Prime Minister, Gyula Horn, and the current Polish President, Aleksander Kwasniewski -- have campaigned in the halls of Washington and Brussels to join NATO.
On the home front, too, they have pushed the idea of joining NATO -- though with little explanation of costs or responsibilities -- as a panacea to all kinds of problems, a golden bridge to the West.
One of the most enduring, almost interchangeable, television images in these three nations, the most economically advanced of Central Europe, has been of Presidents and Prime Ministers boarding planes to Western capitals with a wave, and returning days later with the solemn pledge that entry into NATO headquarters is all but certain.
But their nations, often lumped together in the American psyche as former Warsaw pact allies, have their own histories, military traditions and world outlooks.
In Poland, where there is an almost visceral fear of Russia based on more than a century of Russian rule and about 75 years of Soviet Communism, support of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has been consistently strong; it was at 79 percent five years ago and climbed to 88 percent in March, according to OBOP, a polling firm. Those against joining NATO have not exceeded more than 14 percent and now number 3 percent, OBOP surveys show.
This popular support stems largely from the geographic difficulty of being sandwiched between Germany and Russia, and from serving as a stamping ground for both.
Despite its many setbacks, which include the Nazis' rapid conquest of the country in 1939, Poland's military has always been held in high regard among its citizens, in contrast to the armies in the rest of Central Europe. Today, the Polish military is impoverished and poorly equipped compared with its standing in the Communist era, but the army continues to rank as the most esteemed institution in the country, above state and church.
Most Poles reckon that whatever is good for the army is good for the country. Being in NATO has to be good for the army, goes the argument.
Another ingredient in the Polish zest for NATO, say analysts, is the strong link with the United States. Many Polish families have a relative in the United States, and a pro-American sentiment reinforces the acclaim for NATO.
In contrast to Poland, support in the Czech Republic for NATO ranges from 28 percent to 42 percent, depending on how the question is phrased, according to Zdenek Borkovec, the director for the department for NATO cooperation in the Ministry of Defense. Mr. Borkovec said he discounted a recent poll commissioned by the Czech Ministry of Foreign Affairs that showed a level of support exceeding 50 percent.
"Czechs feel secure," said Mr. Borkovec, as a way of explaining the thinness of support. "They are occupied by private problems. And Czechs are not informed about NATO; they need more information."
Historically, Czechs have held a low opinion of their army, he said, adding, "People say our army never fought for our country." Indeed, a favorite aphorism of the Czechs is that their army has not fought since the Battle of White Mountain in 1620 when the Bohemian Army lost badly. In modern times -- in 1938, when the Germans marched in; in 1948, when the Communists took over; and in 1968, when the Warsaw Pact invaded -- the army stood by.
The prestige of the Czech Army was not helped in March when the Government determined that not one brigade was ready for combat. The ability of the army to "fulfill its tasks continues to decline," the Government said.
In Hungary, eagerness to join NATO is also subdued. Ferenc Petroczki, the Mayor of Nyirbator, which is on the eastern flank of Hungary, not far from where the Russians marched in more than 50 years ago, said his constituents were more interested in jobs than NATO.
"Even with the military base nearby, people don't bother with it," said Mr. Petroczki. "The least of their bothers is which military organization they should belong to." When the Hungarian Defense Minister, Gyorgy Keleti, came to the area recently for a meeting with citizens, NATO was mentioned just once, in passing.
In Hungary, a small country of 10 million people, which once was part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire, there is some readiness for a kind of Austrian neutrality. There is also concern about the costs of updating the armed forces, and resistance, particularly among older people, to the possibility of another set of foreign troops being stationed on Hungarian soil after 50 years of enduring Soviet bases.
The most recent of many Gallup polls commissioned by the Hungarian Ministry of Defense showed the strongest support for NATO so far. In March, 47 percent of the respondents were in favor of joining, 27 percent were against, and 26 percent indifferent. Most respondents said they felt no particular external threat to their security, said Gyorgy Fischer, project director for Gallup.
"Those who are in favor of NATO often say that as a small country we can't manage our business alone," Mr. Fischer said. They look to NATO in the way a "child does when it cuddles a mother, for no particular reason but to generally feel safer."
In none of the three countries have politicians posed the question of how the population feels about Article 5 of the North Atlantic Charter, which states that an attack on one country in the alliance is considered an attack on all and obliges other members to come to its defense.
Mr. Fischer said this was a little-understood obligation. "Article 5 is not yet a factor in public opinion," he said. "You cross your bridges when you come to them. The first task is to win public opinion in joining NATO."
Romania and Slovenia have their own reasons for wanting membership. With economic survival uppermost in most Romanian minds, fear of national security is not the sole factor. There is a kind of NATO-mania in Romania, with radio and newspapers devoting large amounts of time and space to the topic. NATO membership is seen as emblematic of being accepted in the West, of having grown out of the Communist past.
And in Slovenia, a survey in March indicated that 70 percent of the population of two million favored membership, a move that is interpreted as finally breaking from the past and severing the country's connection with Yugoslavia, of which it once was a part.
From Central Europe's military bases to university campuses, and from parks and pubs, a visitor can hear a variety of opinions on the topic. "It is impossible for Hungary to evolve its own independent foreign policy, so the best is to coordinate our common issues with Europe within NATO," said Zoltan Nemeth, 23, a history instructor at the Kossuth University at Debrecen, Hungary. "And the possibility of Chapter 5 being put into effect is as unlikely as the use of nuclear weapons."
The most enthusiastic supporters seem to sense that joining will not come cheap. For others, the cost seems to outweigh the gain. "The problem is how much we have to pay," said Jan Riha, a 50-year-old horticulturist, as he ate lunch at the U Kloubku, a pub in the village of Lysa nad Labem, 40 miles north of Prague, where the Russians kept a base during the Communist era. "I don't see a very strong reason to join, and why should I pay for it?"
But Mr. Riha had no doubt where his allegiance stood in a test of East versus West. "We're part of the West," he said, suggesting that NATO was not needed to confirm that status.
But in the leafy park outside, Helena Kopecka, 37, a mother of three young children, said she saw NATO as a plus after "too many years allied to the East."
"Freedom was such a joy," she said as she pushed a stroller with her new baby. "It would be good if we could be connected to something. Our army is in bad shape, and we don't have a chance if something happens."

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Romario and Ronaldo: Brazil's Thrilling Strikers

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 10

 BODY:
"Ronaldo, Romario." "Romario, Ronaldo." Either way, it rolls off the tongue, and either way, it has become a mantra from Porto Alegre in the south of Brazil to Rio De Janeiro and Belem further north.
Exactly one year before they begin defending their World Cup title in France, the Brazilians again appear to possess the most dangerous striker tandem in international soccer. 
 In the United States in 1994, Bebeto was Romario's sidekick, and even though the team that backed them up was busier defending than channeling the bulk of its energy into encouraging offensive artistry, the two strikers' individual talents were decisive.
Ronaldo, then 17, watched every memorable minute from the bench.
"It was difficult not to play," he said. "But I learned a lot from Romario and Bebeto. They were on top of their games."
Three years later, Bebeto has moved on, Ronaldo has emerged as the sport's biggest star, and Romario, the consensus 1994 world player of the year, has returned to the blue-green-and-yellow fold after a prolonged and well-documented fall from grace.
The English have Alan Shearer, the Germans Jurgen Klinsmann, the Croats Davor Suker and Alen Boksic. But no team currently has the blend of youthful explosiveness and mature guile up front that the 20-year-old Ronaldo Luis Nazario de Lima and the 31-year-old Romario de Souza Faria represent.
In the seven games since Romario returned to the national team after two years of a very public separation and often uninspired play, he and Ronaldo have combined for 11 goals on a team that looks considerably more committed to the attack than in 1994. Romario has scored eight goals, including the game-winner in tonight's 1-0 victory over England in the Tournoi de France, a friendly four-team tournament organized as an aperitif before next summer's 64-course meal: the World Cup finals.
England had already clinched the tournament title with victories over Italy and France. Brazil finished with one victory and two ties, but Romario, his teammates and the venerable coach Mario Zagallo are more interested in what happens next June than this June.
"I am looking for a second world championship, and I am counting very much on Ronaldinho," Romario said recently, using Ronaldo's nickname in Brazil. "You will see. The two of us will finish on top of the scoring tables in 1998."
That would be nothing new for either of these men who share the same home city (Rio de Janeiro), the same modest economic backgrounds and the same ability to go from first to fourth gear in a big hurry. Both have led the Brazilian, Dutch and Spanish leagues in scoring. Like Romario, Ronaldo left Brazil for P.S.V. Eindhoven in the Netherlands; like Romario he was then sold to Spain's high-profile F.C. Barcelona where he promptly became the role model of choice on playgrounds around the world by ramming home spectacular goal after spectacular goal. Like Romario, who left Barcelona in a hurry in December 1994 after two tempestuous seasons, Ronaldo's stay in the Catalan capital looks likely to end quickly.
For the last seven months, he and his many advisers have been involved in an increasingly acrimonious contract dispute with Barca that has had more twists and turns than the Amazon and created nearly countless headlines in Spain. Though it appears that he will ultimately sign with Inter Milan for a world-record transfer fee of about $30 million, appearances have been deceptive in the past.
Romario's future is more uncertain. After two and a half years with the Brazilian club Flamengo, he signed with the Spanish club Valencia last August, but after less than three months in Spain, only four goals and at least twice that many round trips to Rio de Janeiro, Valencia agreed to loan the unhappy striker back to Flamengo after he agreed to take a 50 percent salary cut.
He has played brilliantly ever since. Zagallo welcomed him back to the national team in February. Valencia wants him back in August, as do a number of other European clubs with money to match their desire. The Oscar-winning director Anthony Minghella is reportedly mulling making a documentary of his life. But for now, all that looks like a sure bet is that Romario and Ronaldo will be complicating defenders' lives considerably in France next summer.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Rightly or Not, Tax Writers See Deep Pockets in Airlines

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The airline industry, which only a few years ago was in dire financial straits, now has the reverse problem: Many people seem to think it makes too much money.
That was evident this week when the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Representative Bill Archer, proposed increasing the fees and taxes on airlines and their passengers to help offset $135 billion in tax cuts. 
 Others also see the airlines as a convenient source of new Government revenue. Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, has proposed using fuel taxes to subsidize passenger rail service, in effect asking airlines to pay tens of millions of dollars a year to help a competitor. Representative Bill Barrett, Republican of Nebraska, wants to allow states to impose a fee of up to $3 a passenger to subsidize air service to smaller communities. A state legislator in Texas recently proposed a tax of 4 cents a gallon on aviation fuel to help offset a cut in property taxes.
Mr. Archer's proposal, in particular, has unnerved investors, contributing to yesterday's sharp selloff in airline stocks.
While such proposals often remain just that -- proposals -- they nevertheless reflect a growing perception that the airlines and their customers can readily afford the increases. The airline industry, after all, is more stable and financially strong than it has been since it was deregulated in 1978. That new-found prosperity has even prompted sharp debate over whether the industry is charging unfairly high prices to travelers and competing too roughly against some smaller low-fare carriers.
"It's getting to the point where it's cheaper to fly to Europe than from Albany to Buffalo," said Catherine M. Abate, a State Senator who held hearings yesterday on the cost of air travel within New York. "It's getting worse."
The airlines counter that it is the degree to which they are singled out for taxes that is getting worse. In part because of problems of their own making, United States airlines have a terrible financial record, losing some $13 billion from 1990 to 1994, and consistently trailing the average profit margin of corporate America. Last year was the strongest performance by the industry since 1978; still, it earned only $2.8 billion on $100 billion in revenue.
Only four years ago, a Presidential commission formed to study the financial ills of the industry concluded that the airlines bore a disproportionate tax burden. Representative Archer did not agree with that finding, said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee. "Every transportation sector in the economy points at somebody else, stating, 'They should pay, not us,' " he said. "Our provisions are fair and they are equitable."
The airline industry disagrees. "The Government is trying to pick the airlines' pockets," Carol B. Hallett, president of the Air Transport Association, an industry trade group, said in a recent interview. "We're not the cash cows, and our passengers won't pay inflated prices for air service."
To a degree, the industry is right. Several studies have shown that for every 1 percent increase in the price of air travel, there is a corresponding percentage decrease in the number of people who fly.
Such thinking is also behind the Federal Aviation Administration's position that it will not require parents to buy a seat for babies. The agency calculated that the higher cost of air travel for families with young children would force more of them to take to the highways, where statistics suggest they are more likely to be killed than in a plane crash.
But Mr. Archer's proposal is likely to add to the travel costs of passengers, even though some of the fees and taxes would probably be absorbed by the airlines, cutting into their profits. Mr. Archer would revamp the existing tax on airline tickets, which was to have expired at the end of the year, lowering it to 7.5 percent from 10 percent but imposing new fees on new flight segments. In addition, it would raise fees on round-trip international flights to $20 a person from the current $6.
The airlines have calculated that Mr. Archer's proposal will cost the industry and its passengers an additional $4 billion to $4.5 billion over the next five years.
Concerns about this proposal, as well as projections of weaker passenger traffic and airline earnings, depressed airline stocks yesterday, even as much of the stock market was rising to record highs. For example, shares of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American, fell $4.625, to $94.50, and shares of Delta Air Lines dropped $3.75, to $88.
There are many reasons the airlines, for all their protests about thin profits and an unfair tax burden, are being viewed as an easy target. For one, air fares, particularly for travel on short notice, are hovering at record highs. With round-trip fares exceeding $1,500 for many last-minute flights within the United States, it is hard for many travelers not to think that the industry is making extraordinary profits on tickets, particularly when advance-purchase fares on the same flight sell at a fraction of the cost of the full fare.
In many ways, airline passengers are also a largely faceless group, without a powerful lobbying group to rise up against any increased taxes that would be shared by both the industry and travelers.
The largest airlines have also been facing criticism about the way they have made life difficult for smaller carriers.
Several smaller airlines have complained to the Transportation Department and the Justice Department about what they say is predatory behavior by the major airlines.
Although the details change from case to case, their complaints follow the same pattern. The smaller carriers say that when they start service on a route, offering competition to a major carrier, the bigger airline retaliates by flooding the route with more flights and matching, even undercutting, the low fares offered by the smaller carrier.
Given the advantages held by a major airline, like popular frequent- flier programs, the smaller carrier finds itself with too few passengers to justify the service, and often pulls out. With no more competition, the fares often rebound to their previous levels.
Officials at the Transportation Department appear sympathetic. Charles A. Hunnicutt, Assistant Secretary for Aviation, said during a Senate Commerce Committee hearing that the agency was increasingly concerned about the "overly aggressive exclusionary behavior of major airlines toward new entrants."
At a minimum, the department has said it will start to publicize average fares in big cities -- similar to its publicizing of statistics on complaints, lost bags and on-time performance -- with the hope that the airlines will feel some public pressure to put a lid on fares.
But many people who have studied the airlines say that for all the pressure from consumers, government agencies and legislators, the industry may need high fares to restore long-battered balance sheets.
"They are not out of the woods yet," said Gerald Baliles, a former Governor of Virgia who led the Presidential commission on the industry in 1993. "Even the healthiest airlines have high debt-to-equity ratios that would make most companies in other industries shudder"

HEADLINE: Congressional Memo;
Cutting Taxes a Luxury Now With Consequences Deferred

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
For all the anguish they say they went through to get an agreement to balance the budget within five years, what members of Congress are really doing now is what they enjoy most: cutting taxes and increasing spending.
This is the first time in 15 years that they have allowed themselves this luxury. Ever since economists and politicians discovered in 1982 that the tax cuts enacted the year before would lead to an explosion in the budget deficit, the main item of business in Congress has been to decide who would pay higher taxes and who would be pinched by the belt-tightening needed to bring the deficit under control. 
 But next year, if the budget agreement is followed, the deficit will actually rise -- to $90 billion from $67 billion this year, according to the estimates made by the Congressional Budget Office. The deficit is not scheduled to fall below this year's level until 2001.
The House Ways and Means Committee will take the first step on Wednesday toward parceling out tax reductions to families and investors. Many of the new tax breaks under consideration, including a lower capital gains tax rate, are being structured so that the revenue loss will be small in the next few years but will mushroom in the next century -- when some future Congress can worry about the problem.
In addition, a spending freeze in effect since 1990, under Democratic and Republican Presidents and Democratic and Republican Congresses, has been lifted, and additional money will be approved this year for popular education and health programs.
True, the lawmakers have begun writing legislation this week that would pare $115 billion from what would otherwise be spent on Medicare in the next five years. But except for an increase in premiums of less than $10 per month, the savings would not come from retirees, who are the main beneficiaries of the program. In fact, retirees would get new coverage for mammograms, Pap smears and screenings for prostate and colon cancer.
The savings in Medicare would be extracted from doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and other providers of medical care. Their lobbyists will complain, of course, but they may get less of a hearing than they usually do. Studies show that in the main, the Federal Government is paying more for the providers' services under Medicare than the providers are getting from patients who have private insurance coverage.
Many experts in budget policy defend this year's agreement as better than nothing. "This is not the deal we wanted," said Martha Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a nonpartisan organization that lobbies for a balanced budget. "But it is absolutely better than no deal at all, and there's very little chance of replacing it with anything better."
White House officials brag, with some justification, that under President Clinton, the deficit has been cut by more than 75 percent, from $290 billion in 1992. There is no reason to believe, they say, that the final decisions will not be made to wipe out the deficit completely -- in 2001 and 2002, when Mr. Clinton is no longer in the White House.
But other budget specialists are skeptical. Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, put it this way: "This was an agreement between the 105th Congress and President Clinton to have the 107th Congress and -- who? President Gore? -- engage in fiscal restraint. One has reason to doubt that the political system will deliver in 2002 on a promise made in 1997."
This is Mr. Reischauer's point: The politicians can always renege on their promise to cut spending in 2001 and 2002. They have carefully avoided suggesting which Government programs they intend to take the hit, and they probably have not thought much about it.
Furthermore, if effects of the Medicare savings turn out to be more severe than expected, and retirees begin experiencing reduced medical services, it is a safe bet that the lawmakers will leap in and fix the problem.
But once a tax break is on the books, it is almost impossible to get it removed.
The President and Congress agreed that the net tax cuts would be no more than $85 billion in the next 5 years and no more than $250 billion in the next 10 years. But the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research institute whose budget projections have often been reliable, has calculated that in the following 10 years, from 2008 through 2017, the revenue loss could exceed $650 billion.
It is impossible to make such calculations with any precision. But there is little doubt, Mr. Reischauer said, that the cost of the tax breaks would "continue to grow at a rapid rate in the future and could cause serious hemorrhaging just at the time when the nation is trying to cope with the huge fiscal problem of the baby boom retirement."
One of the most expensive of these tax breaks in the early years of the next century would be the reduction in the rate of tax on capital gains, which are the profits from the sale of investments.
The Republican tax plan, offered this week by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, is written in such a way that the eventual cost of this tax cut is concealed. Taxpayers would be induced to sell stock and pay the capital gains tax in the early years after the lower rate was in effect. As a result, this part of the tax cut would actually lead to a $3 billion increase in revenue in the first five years, the Congressional tax staff estimates.
But in the next five years, the revenue loss from the capital gains break would be $38 billion, and it would be even steeper in the years that followed.
Similarly, the new rules on individual retirement accounts would cost only $33 million in lost revenue in the first five years but $13 billion in the next five.
But such long-term imbalances seem to be of little matter to the senators and representatives nowadays as they crack the tax and spending pinata, many for the first time in their political careers.
The consequences can always be dealt with manana.

HEADLINE: In Rockaways, a Plan Draws Mixed Reviews

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
George Williams was washing his 1985 Oldsmobile yesterday morning on an abandoned road in the Arverne area of the Rockaways, Queens, his back to the Atlantic Ocean, surrounded by blown-out tires and jettisoned car parts. Mr. Williams, 53, a letter carrier, moved to the area 30 years ago and remembered Arverne before the bulldozers cleared it of 4,000 bungalows in the late 1960's, leaving only rubble and the distinction of being one of the nation's most notorious examples of failed urban renewal.
And yet, a day after a tantalizing plan was unveiled to build a $1 billion entertainment, sports and hotel complex there, Mr. Williams was hesitant. Should public funds be used to pay for new roads leading to an entertainment center in one of the poorest corners of Queens? he asked. Or should the city instead be encouraging the construction of decent housing in an area where many live in towering housing projects? 
 "Anyway, we might not even get to that," Mr. Williams said. "We've seen a lot of plans come and go over the years. I'll believe it when I see it."
Like Mr. Williams, many residents of the Rockaways sounded skeptical yesterday about the most recent plan to redevelop Arverne, though many could not help feeling a twinge of excitement that maybe, just maybe, this plan would move beyond architectural blueprints. It was perhaps no surprise that the level of skepticism seemed commensurate with how long the people had lived in the area, and how many times they had been disappointed by past plans.
"It's a great idea," said Joshua Rodriguez, 19, whose family moved to Arverne eight years ago. "I'll be the first one to apply for a job."
On Monday, the Queens Borough President's office announced that a Canadian company proposed to build a complex that would include a hotel, convention center, movie theaters, an indoor ski slope and a whitewater rafting facility. The company, Heathmount Arts and Entertainment Corporation, is headed by two members of the Reichmann family of Toronto, whose vast real estate empire, Olympia & York, collapsed in the early 1990's. A company spokesman said that the Reichmanns wanted to complete the project in 2002, creating more than 10,500 permanent jobs.
Yesterday, on the beach season's first hot day, seagulls circled over the vast wasteland of the Arverne urban renewal area, looking for scraps amid the bald dirt patches and weeds. The elevated A train rattled along the northern boundary of the area, which stretches about two miles from Beach 32d Street to Beach 73d Street. A young couple rose from a grassy area, where they had been hidden, as the man put on his shirt.
Arverne, like other neighborhoods on the Rockaway peninsula, was once dotted with bungalows that working-class families rented for the summer. But after World War II, as the vacationers went elsewhere, bungalows were converted to fulltime residences and occupied by the poor, who also were moved into several housing projects the city erected on the peninsula. Mayor John V. Lindsay razed Arverne in 1968, but his urban renewal project went nowhere, in part because of the city's fiscal crisis in the 1970's.
Even though a developer recently won the city's approval to build 161 nonsubsidized houses on 15 acres of the urban renewal area's 307 acres of city-owned land, the area's social and economic problems have also been an obstacle to the construction of private homes. According to the 1990 Census, Arverne had a median household income of $22,701, compared with $34,186 for the whole of Queens.
In the early 1990's, Oceanview Associates of Manhattan, a partnership led by Forest City Ratner Companies, proposed a $1.5 billion complex of 7,500 apartments, stores and movie theaters. But the project was abandoned because of the souring real estate market and an agreement whereby the developers were to pay for about $300 million in new roads and sewers needed in the urban renewal area.
Neither Heathmount nor city officials estimated the cost of the infrastructure improvements the Reichmanns' project would require. But the costs, which the city and state would have to pay, are expected to be enormous.
"If the cost was $300 million eight years ago," said Jonathan L. Gaska, the manager of the local community board, "it's at least half a billion, if not $700 million now, which is a really big amount."
Mr. Gaska added: "But it's the board's contention that the Government owes us because for the last 30 years, they've done nothing but give us the problems of the city and state. We have loads of adult and nursing homes."
But like Mr. Gaska, Louis Caucig, president of the Rockaway Chamber of Commerce, said the peninsula's small businesses were excited by the new plan.
"There's always skepticism," Mr. Caucig said. "But we're pretty ecstatic about it. We needed a shot of adrenalin in the arms, and this might be it."

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: A Prophecy Both False and Successful

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
The report was a dramatic call to arms that shaped the nation's view of its schools like few documents in history.
"A Nation at Risk" warned in 1983 that the nation's educational system was an escalating disaster that amounted to "an act of unthinking, unilateral educational disarmament imperiling the nation's economic health." 
 Now, as if tagging along on the good-news trends of lower crime, more jobs and low inflation, comes the Third International Mathematics and Science Study showing the nation's fourth graders near the top of achievement in science and above average in mathematics compared with their peers in 26 countries.
So, was "A Nation at Risk" wildly overblown? Have the schools improved so much since then? Or are these most recent findings less than meet the eye?
It's a bit of all three.
The latest math and science findings are undoubtedly positive news. Fourth graders in only one country, South Korea, score statistically higher than American fourth graders in science. Five countries are similar to the United States and 19 below it. In mathematics, 7 countries score above the United States, 6 countries are similar, and 12 are below.
While the findings are striking in a population accustomed to thinking the worst of its schools, they are consistent with generally positive trends in many test scores and a 1992 international reading comparison that found American fourth graders second only to those in Finland.
Those skeptical about the conclusion of "A Nation at Risk" say the remarkably robust economy now does not bear out the warning that schools in the 1970's and 1980's were so bad that they were turning out barely educated dolts who were putting the nation's economic future in jeopardy.
Most experts now regard "A Nation at Risk" as brilliant propaganda: it almost singlehandedly saved the United States Education Department from a Congressional plan to scuttle it. And it is seen as an effective call to action at a time of lagging achievement. But it is also seen as incendiary rhetoric that outstripped the reality of educational decline.
"There's no question the sense of doom was overdone, but a wake-up call was necessary, so I don't fault the report," said Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, an independent research and advocacy organization. "But what bothers me is that we still have people getting up and saying the schools have gone to hell, we've got to so something. Well, we are doing something. We've done a lot."
Most experts agree that current fourth-grade scores reflect the educational progress over the past few years. They note that voluntary national standards were agreed upon for math and science well ahead of those for other disciplines.
Many of the math and science recommendations are now in place in elementary schools, a sharp contrast to the American history and English standards, where reaching a consensus on what should be taught, and how, took longer. As a result, experts say it is likely that at least some of the gap between the good fourth-grade performance and a largely mediocre performance by eighth graders reflects better preparation of the younger pupils.
To some, the real story of the test is not what it shows about how well fourth graders do, but how poorly eighth graders do. Experts say they are extremely doubtful that the third part of the study, the analysis of 12-grade performance due out next spring, will match the good news of the recent test.
"The fourth-grade results show us that our children didn't start out behind all these other countries, but actually we fall behind them along the way," said William Schmidt, an education professor at Michigan State University and executive director of Third International Math and Science Study's national research center, at Boston College.
Still, Dr. Schmidt and others say that the most positive element of the research is not the results but the way its rigorous attention to teaching practices and curriculum in industrialized countries provides international benchmarks. For instance, he said, the fourth-grade math and science curriculum in the United States is much more advanced and challenging compared with those in the rest of the world than is the eighth-grade curriculum.
The research also highlights the complexities of teaching, curriculum and cultural factors that go into addressing the problems. Many say the kind of data that the study is producing is an argument for the kind of regular national tests being advocated by President Clinton.
To some, the whole process of international comparisons, and the resulting alarms about the state of schools, miss the main point of the United States' radically decentralized education system: that it includes both many of the best and many of the worst schools in the world and that they vary to a degree that schools in South Korea, Singapore or Japan do not.
Still, even those skeptical of its tone say "A Nation at Risk" did set the country on the road to a sustained level of concern about education unusual in the nation's history, even if its end result remains very much in doubt.
"We've had periods of concern, like after Sputnik in the 1950's, but this may be the most sustained discussion we've had about education across the board in the nation's history," said acting Deputy Education Secretary Michael Smith. "That's the kind of commitment you need to really make progress."

HEADLINE: Clinton Rejects G.O.P. Tax Cuts as Unfair to Middle Class

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
President Clinton today rejected the Republican blueprint for apportioning proposed Federal tax cuts, saying it would shortchange the middle class and violate the terms of the balanced budget package agreed to by both parties last month.
The Republican plan "does not meet the standards of fairness to families and promotion of education," Mr. Clinton said. "Nor do I believe it is consistent with the budget agreement." 
 One day after the chief Republican tax writer laid out his proposal to reduce taxes for families, investors and many corporations, Democrats in the House today drafted a plan that was intended less as a serious alternative than as a vehicle for highlighting the Democrats' desire to direct more of the reductions to lower- and middle-income people.
The maneuvering came as Democrats and Republicans prepared for several weeks of give and take over both broad ideological approaches to tax cutting and the nitty-gritty legislative details that determine winners and losers. The process will formally begin on Wednesday, when the House Ways and Means Committee takes up the proposal unveiled on Monday by Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is the committee's chairman.
Watched and prodded by lobbyists, lawmakers will try to come up with a compromise that will give the Republicans who control Congress much of what they want but will be acceptable to Mr. Clinton, who must sign it if it is to be enacted without a veto override.
Mr. Archer is facing a torrent of criticism from Democrats who say his plan would be unfair to many moderate-income families, particularly because it would deny some families with low tax bills the full benefit of credits that higher-income families would enjoy. He defended his plan as the best way to deliver tax relief to the middle class.
"To protect middle-income taxpayers," Mr. Archer said, "I will strongly oppose any effort to take money away from the taxpaying public, notably parents with teen-age children, so people who pay no taxes can receive a government check."
Mr. Archer said that of the $116.4 billion in tax cuts his bill would grant to individuals in the plan's first five years, $83.5 billion, or nearly 72 percent, would go to people with incomes between $20,000 and $75,000.
Mr. Archer did not release figures for the second five years of the plan, when wealthier people would reap most of the benefits of his proposed reduction in taxes on capital gains from the sale of stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets.
Mr. Archer's plan would cut the top rate on capital gains for most individuals with such income to 20 percent from 28 percent, and, starting in 2001, would allow investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating gains on assets held more than three years. The plan would also grant tax credits of up to $500 per child for many families, provide a scaled-back version of Mr. Clinton's proposed breaks for college expenses, expand the Individual Retirement Account program and provide other tax reductions.
After getting more details of Mr. Archer's plan today, Democrats and some liberal research organizations said the Republican proposal relied on gimmicks to hold down the cost of its tax cuts in the early years. They said that its costs would accelerate sharply in the second five years and that the Republican plan could ultimately send the budget deficit sharply higher again.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research group, calculated that the Republican package, which values the tax cuts at $250 billion over the first 10 years, would cost as much as $750 billion in the second decade.
The group's analysis said, "This is the period when the baby boom generation begins to retire and deficits are forecast to rise to alarming levels that will damage the economy unless unprecedented austerity measures are instituted."
Despite the back-and-forth partisan criticism today, both Administration officials and Republican leaders said they believed that compromises could be worked out, especially when the Senate Finance Committee took up its tax bill next week.
"We'll work with the Administration," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader.
White House officials said they would not support any single alternative to Mr. Archer's bill but would back individual proposals emerging from both House and Senate Democrats and perhaps from the Republican bill in the Senate. Administration officials said they were particularly intent on restoring more of Mr. Clinton's college-tuition tax breaks.
Mr. Clinton met today with the Democratic leader in the House, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and with Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee.
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, his party's ranking member on the Ways and Means Committee, plans to introduce an alternative tax-cut bill in the committee on Wednesday.
Mr. Rangel's plan, which will get no more than a cursory hearing from the Republican majority, would have a far more limited capital-gains tax cut than Mr. Archer's bill, a bigger package of education incentives and breaks, and a per-child credit program of roughly the same size as the Republican bill but with more generous provisions for low- and moderate-income taxpayers.

HEADLINE: For Poorest Indians, Casinos Aren't Enough

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: PINE RIDGE, S.D.

 BODY:
The image of the Indian gambling casino as money machine evaporates among the destitute Oglala Sioux of the Pine Ridge Reservation. The casino here consists of three double-wide trailers stuck together on cinder blocks in a rutted lot with two rusty oil drums outside for trash.
The Oglalas earn $1 million a year from gambling, about what the Pequot tribe in Connecticut earns in half a day at Foxwoods, which is considered the nation's most profitable casino. The Oglalas tried to build a bigger, permanent casino, but construction stopped in December with just the foundation laid because the contractor wanted more money. The dispute could take years to resolve, and fissures have formed in the foundation's concrete walls. 
 This two-million-acre reservation is a pit of fissured dreams. It is the site of the Wounded Knee massacre, where the Army killed some 200 braves, women and children in 1890, and was the home of the Oglala band of Red Cloud and Crazy Horse.
It is as poor as America gets.
"It's very bleak," said John Yellow Bird Steele, 51, president of the Oglala Sioux Tribal Council.
In recent years, with casinos going up on one reservation after another, many Americans have come to believe that Indian reservations are boom towns. Indeed, with Indian casinos bringing in about $6 billion last year, compared with $100 million in 1988, a few tribes are doing well.
A visit to Pine Ridge is a striking reminder that most reservations remain places of bone-crushing poverty. And things are likely to get worse as the Government cuts some of the welfare payments that are crucial to their economies.
At least half of the 1.3 million American Indians who live on reservations are poor, the Bureau of Indian Affairs says, and 49 percent of the reservations' labor force is unemployed -- 10 times the national unemployment rate. The sickest economy is in Pine Ridge, the second-largest reservation, after the Navajo reservation in the Southwest.
Here, just 1 in 4 adults has a job. People subsist almost entirely on Federal, state and tribal government checks: paychecks and welfare checks, retirement and disability checks. Now welfare and housing aid is being cut.
The casino, for all its travails, sets the standard for success. Alone among the businesses sponsored by the tribe, it makes a little money.
Nature has wrought a topographical masterpiece here, with expanses of butte-broken prairie and the Badlands' sinister white spires and menacing cliffs. But this immense terrain yields no oil or gas, coal or gold, crops or lumber.
Its one readily exploitable natural resource is grass. The Bureau of Indian Affairs says 20,205 cattle, 753 bison and about 5,000 horses are grazing reservation lands. But that business, too, has stalled. Cattle prices have dropped to 60 cents a pound, compared with 90 cents four years ago.
About 25,000 people -- no one has a reliable count -- live on the reservation in shacks, trailers and small, shoebox-like ranch houses subsidized by the Government, the lots of many cluttered with the hulks of dead cars. No car here usually means no job because of the vast distances between home and work.
Five years ago, Mr. Steele aspired to build three casinos with adjoining motels and restaurants. But that idea has faltered, as have all other missions to rescue the economy -- a ranch, a moccasin factory and a beef-packing plant. The prospects for yet another venture, a herd of choice cows to produce beef for Pequot casino restaurants, dimmed in May when the council suspended from his post as treasurer the man who had conceived it.
The Census Bureau found eight years ago that Shannon County, S.D., which includes most of the reservation, was the poorest of the nation's 3,143 counties. Using different criteria in its latest survey, done four years ago, the bureau said Shannon County was the fourth-poorest.
"It's like living at the bottom of a well," said Milo Yellow Hair, vice president of the tribe. "The great white father looks down and says, 'Here's a few dollars.' "
Now those dollars are dwindling. One new blow is the demise of the old welfare system. Wilbur Campbell, manager of the local office of the South Dakota Department of Social Services, said that through April, 128 of the 896 reservation mothers on welfare had lost a portion of their cash assistance because they had not gone to work. For a mother with one child, he said, that meant the check was cut to $78 a month, from $250.
Another group of welfare recipients could begin losing out soon. The Bureau of Indian Affairs allots $38 a month in general assistance to the poor who do not qualify for family assistance. Robert D. Ecoffey, superintendent of the bureau's Pine Ridge agency, said that in the last couple of years, Congress had chopped his general-assistance budget to $714,000, from $1.7 million. He has not cut anyone off yet, he said, because he has been scrounging up the money from other accounts.
Housing, primitive as it is, is also being squeezed. Paul Iron Cloud, director of the tribe's housing authority, said Federal money for home renovation had been cut by 20 percent last year. The wait for Government-subsidized homes, about the only kind built here, stretches for four to five years.
Families double and triple up; Mr. Steele has 4 adults and 18 children in his house. Now, Mr. Iron Cloud said, changes in Federal policy could freeze out the the poorest families, who pay no rent and get free utilities.
Poverty is taking an ever-bigger toll on health. Pine Ridge's infant mortality rate is almost three times the national average. Alcoholism, the scourge of indigent Indians, is as entrenched as ever. Doctors say that for the first time, they are spotting adult-onset diabetes, which usually strikes people past 40, in much younger patients.
"I just saw a 12-year-old who has it," said Dr. David Mulder, the reservation hospital's chief of staff. Young people were not getting that five years ago, Dr. Mulder said.
"That's really frightening -- they're already insulin-resistant," he said.
Mr. Yellow Hair explained: "A six-pack of soda costs less than a gallon of milk. So mothers get the soda and put it in their babies' bottles and shake it up to get the fizz out. It starts there."
Kibbe Conti, the hospital's nutritionist, said that for these Northern Plains Indians, who have a genetic predisposition for diabetes, "pop is poison."
The blame for these conditions goes all around. The roots of the troubles lie in political pandering among tribal leaders, who must run for election every two years, and in corruption, the 19th-century treaties that shunted the Oglalas off richer lands, the cuts in state and Federal support, and discrimination.
In early May, the Justice Department penalized the nearby First National Bank of Gordon, Neb., for charging the Pine Ridge Sioux interest rates that were five percentage points higher than the rate paid by white customers off the reservation.
But the Indians also blame themselves for their problems.
Baptiste Poirier, 45, is an anomaly here. A tribe member and, like his wife, Pat, 39, a recovering alcoholic, he owns Big Bat's, a bustling convenience store, restaurant and Texaco gasoline station at the four-way stop in the center of the village of Pine Ridge.
Mr. Poirier and his family also own a propane distribution business, a small, 150-head herd of cattle and, over the Nebraska line in Chadron, another convenience store. The Poiriers and their two sons, both students at an Indian college, live in a 16-by-55-foot trailer with a single concession to conspicuous consumption, a hot tub.
"It's so hard to do business here," he said. "For every one Indian trying to get ahead, there's 20 trying to pull him down."
In the nine years since he opened Big Bat's, Mr. Poirier said, last year was his worst. The store lost money. "You know what it was over?" he asked. "Employee theft. Merchandise and cash." Nationally, stores lose about 3 percent to employee theft, he said. "For me, it was well over 10 percent," he said.
Scarce as jobs are here, Mr. Poirier said his employee turnover rate was 50 percent a year; a typical worker stays only six months. "Most of it is alcohol-related," he said. "There's so much hopelessness. They get drunk. They don't show up for work. I've got to let them go.
"We don't have a business class, a middle class," Mr. Poirier said. "We have a political class. It's a welfare government. When you've got political people in charge, they're going to take care of the voters."
The tribe is the biggest employer, through services and business ventures. Among the ventures that have not panned out is the tribe's own ranching operation, Farm and Ranch Enterprise, which once received a Federal development grant of $5.5 million. "That money was lost," Mr. Yellow Hair said.
The ranch, with a herd of only 340 cattle, has little water, so the tribe installed a windmill-powered water pump. "But they put the windmill in a gulley, a place where there's no wind," said Melvin Lee Houston, an Oglala official.
The farm survives on a $100,000 annual tribal subsidy.
The three-year-old casino is off to a happier start. Its $1 million in profits, although only $38 per capita and far from enough to offset the decline in the Government's aid, is distributed across the reservation, mostly to the elderly.
It has also created jobs, including 129 for residents of the reservation. Thirty-four-year-old Amy Rodriquez, a pit boss who oversees the casino's four blackjack tables, earns $10.92 an hour, a very high wage around here. "I'm doing a lot better," she said. "I have a steady job. I have a car now."
But the tribe's great expectations for casino gambling, like those of many tribes, are withering.
Here, one obstacle is the construction dispute. A bigger obstacle is the reservation's isolation. The nearest sizeable source of customers is Rapid City, S.D., 80 miles to the north. "The reality is," Mr. Yellow Hair said, "there is no population."
For a short time recently, the reservation's hopes shifted to a newer enterprise.
The tribe's treasurer, Chuck Jacobs, 41, proposed buying a herd of cattle that were not only free of growth hormones and other additives but also had an impressive genetic record of yielding choice beef. He would lease the bulls to reservation ranchers and, bypassing most middlemen, sell the beef to the Pequots and other wealthy tribes for their restaurants.
A former all-Indian rodeo champion, Mr. Jacobs has a degree in regional planning from the University of Massachusetts and was awarded a MacArthur Foundation fellowship 10 years ago for analyses of reservation economies.
Mr. Jacobs prepared an inch-thick plan including reams of correspondence showing the support of potential customers. In a close vote last December, the tribal council authorized Mr. Jacobs to proceed. He bought a foundation herd of 70 cows and 17 bulls for $187,000.
Today, the cattle are grazing at the Farm and Ranch Enterprise site, but what will become of them is unclear. Some tribal leaders, alarmed at the cost and the realization that the cattle would not be yielding much beef for some years, now deride the purchase as the "golden cows."
The tribal council voted 8 to 8 earlier this month to suspend Mr. Jacobs. Mr. Steele, who defeated Mr. Jacobs among other candidates in the race for the presidency last year, broke the tie by voting against him.
"People have a lot of questions about the viability of the whole project," Mr. Steele said. Mr. Ecoffey, of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, said, "He was the kind of guy we need to be leaning on."

HEADLINE: THE RENT BATTLE: THE REACTION;
RENT REGULATIONS FIRMLY SUPPORTED IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
With the tenacity of a New Yorker refusing to surrender a hard-won parking spot, city residents by an overwhelming margin support regulations that keep rents below what the market will bear, and therefore do not want state rent ceilings to expire on Sunday, according to the latest New York Times poll.
At least 70 percent of those polled by The Times -- including homeowners and tenants -- said rent regulations were necessary to provide affordable housing and to prevent rents from soaring. 
 That does not necessarily mean, however, that the public is unwilling to consider substantial changes in the laws. Opinions were closely divided, in fact, when residents were asked about some of the proposals being debated in Albany for replacing the current laws. For instance, nearly half voiced support for lifting the ceilings when apartments become vacant, a proposal, known as vacancy decontrol, recently made by Gov. George E. Pataki.
Nonetheless, virtually every cross section of the city -- homeowners, tenants, Republicans, Democrats -- clings to the concept of rent protections as if they were some kind of natural law in New York. Nearly 80 percent, an extraordinary majority for any question in New York City, said they did not want the laws to expire, as the state's top political opponent of rent regulations predicted yesterday would happen on Sunday.
Despite the support that seems to exist for the Governor's vacancy decontrol plan, he appears to be bearing the brunt of the public anger over the rent debate. According to the poll, Mr. Pataki's approval rating has plummeted 10 percentage points in just three months, to 31 percent, an enormous drop for someone whose popularity in the city had been growing. Although there could be other reasons for the change, there have been no other issues in the last three months that would seem to explain it.
Asked which politician or group of people they will hold most responsible if the rent laws expire, 31 percent of those polled cited Mr. Pataki, the largest number for any public official. Only 10 percent cited the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who began the current turmoil with his call for the end of rent regulation, and 9 percent named Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who supports the rent laws. And while Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato has shown he can exercise great political influence in Albany, he was blamed by only 1 percent of those polled.
An unrelated statewide poll, released yesterday by John Zogby, a Utica pollster, found that Mr. Pataki's job approval rating had declined only three percentage points since March, a statstically insignificant shift, indicating that the rent issue has far less impact upstate.
The Times poll, conducted by telephone between June 5 and 8, surveyed 913 adult New York City residents on their attitudes on rent laws, achieving a mix of homeowners and renters in rough proportion to their numbers in the city. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The poll's findings demonstrate many of the inconsistencies that can arise in public opinion on a complex, politically charged issue. For instance, residents were evenly split on the vacancy decontrol plan, which would lift rent ceilings when a tenant moved out or died, effectively phasing out controls over a long period of time. At the same time, two-thirds of the people polled said that "a lot" of landlords would unscrupulously try to pressure tenants to move out if vacancy control is approved -- the usual argument against the idea.
Democrats and tenant advocates, in other words, may have succeeded in their political efforts to focus public discontent on the Governor and on landlords, but they seem to have been less convincing in branding vacancy decontrol the equivalent to an end to all rent protections.
Zenia Mucha, the Governor's communications director, said Mr. Pataki's drop in the poll was the result of a "multimillion-dollar campaign to terrorize tenants" waged by tenant advocates and Democrats for political purposes. That 69 percent of city residents do not blame the Governor, she said, shows that the majority of the city supports his plan.
But one theme remains quite clear throughout: the virtual citywide consensus on rent protections shows how thoroughly the laws have been woven into the city's fabric. Like the subways or the water system, rent controls for many people seem a fundamental entitlement of city life. In follow-up interviews, many residents polled in the survey said they could not imagine life in the city being the same without the laws.
"The reason we have all this diversity in the city, with all the different ethnic groups and different kinds of people, is that people can still afford to live here, and I think this would be lost if we didn't have rent controls," said John Rasile, an architect who owns the Ozone Park, Queens, home he grew up in. "Otherwise, we're just going to have wealthy people living here, because it's just going to be so expensive."
For decades, the elected officials in the city who set the terms of local debate have been unvarying in their support for rent protections, no matter their political stripe, and the poll showed that such support among residents continues to cross all the usual partisan and ideological lines. More than 80 percent of Democrats want to keep rent regulations, as do 71 percent of Republicans. Even two-thirds of homeowners, who would not be affected by rent protections unless their property values rise with decontrol, say they support the laws.
The unanimity apparently stems from a collective understanding within the city of how difficult it is to find adequate, affordable housing in New York City. Many homeowners used to be renters, and nearly everyone knows or carries with them the scars from a desperate apartment search, an endless battle in Housing Court, or the sticker shock when first pricing real estate. In the poll, 77 percent said the end of rent regulations would mean the city would become too expensive for people like themselves, and 69 percent said many people would be forced from their apartments.
"Being a former renter I know how hard it is and how expensive it is," said Maureen Thomas, an accountant who owns a co-op in Manhattan. "It's a lack of space. There aren't enough apartments for everyone. Even though I know it's to my advantage if we didn't have rent control, I just don't think you should have the rents skyrocket."
Advocates of decontrol, of course, say it is precisely because the city does not have a free market in rents that it has experienced such a severe shortage of affordable housing. But that argument is apparently not persuasive to many residents, who say they prefer a more comforting government restriction to an economic theory. Ms. Thomas said that landlords were making enough money already and that she did not believe that they would build new housing if rents were allowed to rise. Others in the survey said they agreed.
"People are a little tired of the whole greed factor," said Brian Bilcher, a firefighter who rents an uncontrolled apartment in Staten Island. "You see it every place, from sports and movies to being a landlord. I don't think it's right that some people are living in great apartments in the Village for just $200 a month, but there's a lot of people who make half of what I make or less and they need access to a living place, too. To me, it's a moral issue."
 
How the Poll Was Done
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews with 913 adults conducted from June 5 to 8 in all parts of New York City. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of city exchanges. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into a residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus five percentage points for those living in rent-regulated apartments, eight points for those living in unregulated apartments, and six points for those who own their home.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Pension Bonds Pass a Test

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
A new law allowing the state to sell $2.75 billion in pension bonds cleared a judicial hurdle yesterday when a Superior Court judge ruled that it was constitutional. 
 Judge Philip S. Carchman of Mercer County dismissed a lawsuit filed by a Democrat, Mayor George A. Spadoro of Edison, who contended that any measure that increases the state's indebtedness must be approved by the voters. The judge said that because the bonds would be issued by the State Economic Development Authority, and not by the state itself, the sale would not require a referendum.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Yen as U.S. Warns About Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar touched a nine-month low against the yen yesterday after Japan reported a sharply higher trade surplus and a top Treasury official warned the Japanese not to try to export their way out of a long economic slump.
The admonition on Japan's trade surplus came from Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers as the United States prepared for a meeting of leading industrial nations in Denver next week. 
 In a speech to Denver business executives on Tuesday night, Mr. Summers said the United States wanted the Japanese to stimulate their economy through domestic-led demand and avoid an increase in the trade surplus "on a scale that could hurt global growth and fuel protectionism."
His remarks coincided with trade data from the Japanese Finance Ministry that showed the April surplus rose 92.7 percent, to 1.1 trillion yen in April compared with the year earlier. It was the second consecutive monthly increase.
The official's remarks reinforced the possibility of renewed trade friction between Washington and Tokyo as a result of the protracted weakness in the yen, which has made Japanese products more affordable abroad and American products more expensive in Japan.
It was the fifth consecutive day the dollar declined against the yen, and the selling helped pull the dollar lower in most other foreign-exchange dealings. "The dollar-yen was the story du jour," said Susan Stearns, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Bank of Montreal in New York.
The dollar fell to an intraday low of 110.52 yen, the weakest since Sept. 11, before recovering somewhat to settle in New York at 111.20 yen, down from 112.25 yen on Tuesday. With the latest decline, the dollar has retreated more than 5 yen, or 4.3 percent, in a week. The dollar fell to 1.7160 marks from 1.7185 marks. The pound fell to $1.6377 from $1.6385.
The dollar's weakness against most European currencies partly reflected the uncertainty over the future of the euro, the single currency scheduled for January 1999.
Traders were waiting to see whether France and Germany could agree on a compromise on a stability pact designed to assure fiscal discipline among participating countries.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Crude Oil Tumble On Report of Rise in Inventory

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report showed that inventories in the United States were rising even as refiners operated at close to maximum rates.
On other markets, coffee prices fell. 
 After the market closed on Tuesday, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude oil inventories rose 336,000 barrels last week, to 324.0 million barrels, the most since June 1995, even as refiners ran at 98.3 percent of their capacity.
While prices rose in early trading after Iraq's Ambassador to the United Nations said Iraqi exports would be suspended this month, traders deemed the inventories sufficient to make up for any shortfall.
Iraq is allowed to export as much as $2 billion of oil over a six-month period to purchase food and medicine. The Ambassador, Nizar Hamdoon, said Iraq halted exports to protest what he called late shipments of the humanitarian aid.
"People view the oil market as oversupplied and the A.P.I. report was pretty bearish," said Al Lindseth, an analyst with the GSC Energy Corporation in Atlanta. "Although the Iraqi Ambassador said oil sales will be delayed for a month, it's just a delay. It's ridiculous to think they won't export."
Crude oil for July delivery sank 14 cents, to $18.53 a barrel, its lowest since Feb. 12, 1996.
Coffee fell for a third day, reaching a two-month low, as warmer weather in Brazil ended the immediate threat of frost damage to the world's largest crop.
Overnight temperatures in Brazil stayed in the mid-40's, the Weather Services Corporation said, with normal or above-normal temperatures forecast for the coming week. Frost, which struck close to coffee-growing areas Monday night, damages coffee trees, reducing future crops.
At the same time, higher retail prices are expected to cut demand. Best Coffee of Seattle, which roasts between 3.5 million and 4 million pounds a year, will raise prices on average by 90 cents a pound next week, a company spokesman said.
Coffee for July delivery slid 10.30 cents, to $2.0765 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the lowest for a contract closest to delivery since April 15.
