HEADLINE: Congo's Dire Need for Help Will Test Mettle of Its New Leaders

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Congo, June 10

 BODY:
The garbage has not been collected in most neighborhoods here in the capital in seven years. It has been that long since schoolteachers, police officers, firefighters, soldiers, nurses -- indeed, Government workers of any kind -- have been paid on a regular basis. And when they are paid now, a month's salary is just about enough to buy a loaf of bread.
The ill die because they cannot afford surgical gloves or medicine, which hospitals do not have. A journey from Lubumbashi, the country's second-largest city, to the copper mines, a major source of revenue, used to take three days; it now takes nine, the bridges having crumbled and the roads having been consumed by jungle. 
 "How can they possibly do it?" said Frederick Racke, the Dutch Ambassador, staggered by the magnitude of what the new Government faces. "The country is in total ruin. It is an unprecedented challenge."
But many people gave up comfortable lives in the United States, Europe and South Africa to return to the country they had fled during Mobutu Sese Seko's reign, when it was called Zaire, to try to rebuild it.
The policies and politics of this country's new President, Laurent Kabila, are still largely unknown, and there are disturbing signs that the 56-year-old leader may create a one-party state. But the new ministers seem to be driven by a genuine desire to do something for their country, not to steal from it.
The looming question is whether their dedication and enthusiasm will be enough to compensate for their striking lack of experience.
The Foreign Minister, Bizima Karaha, is a pediatrician educated in South Africa; asked if he is 30 yet, he said sheepishly, "I am 29." He will try to conduct foreign affairs without so much as a fax machine in his offices.
The Minister of Mines, Mututolo Kambale, taught English at a teachers college and was a human rights advocate in the last years of Mr. Mobutu's rule.
"I will absolutely vouch he's as honest a man as you're ever going to meet," said Anthony Gambino, who works for the United States Agency for International Development and has known Mr. Kambale since Mr. Gambino was in the Peace Corps here 20 years ago. "He's smart. But will he be able to do it? Who knows."
At the Interior Ministry, the new occupant of the crumbling headquarters, Mwenze Kongolo, studied to be a Bible translator and was working as an investigator with the warrants division of the Philadelphia District Attorney's Office when he signed on with Mr. Kabila.
Now, Mr. Kongolo is in charge of a police force for a country as large as the United States east of the Mississippi. First he has to build one. What are the most pressing needs at the police academy? Electricity, clean water and shoes for the cadets, he said.
"This is the time in the history of this county when there should be great faith," said Mr. Kongolo, who has a master's degree in criminal justice from Temple University in Philadelphia.
He will need it. His responsibilities include immigration. The Interior Ministry has no computers.
"It's going to be better," said Mr. Kongolo, who hopes to be joined soon by his wife and their three children. "It's going to get worse before it gets better. But it's going to get better."

HEADLINE: F.A.A. Caught in an Urban Policy Battle

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A Federal Aviation Administration plan for a suburban-style office building near Kennedy International Airport is emerging as the center of a dispute over a little-known Presidential order that says Federal agencies should consider downtown areas when moving employees.
The proposal is unremarkable in Government real estate planning: 840 administrative workers would move to a new building just north of the airport where almost everyone would have a parking space with access to Long Island highways. 
 But opponents say the plan defies an executive order that says Government agencies must give "first consideration" to declining commercial cores of big cities. They point to one such area five miles from the airport, downtown Jamaica, arguing that it provides a textbook example of where a new Federal office building would do the most good.
Although a final decision is not expected until late summer, Congress has already approved a version of the Federal proposal that excludes downtown Jamaica from consideration. The plan has also won the tacit approval of the Giuliani administration, which wants to steer the agency to city-owned property near the border of Nassau County. One possible site in Jamaica, near a Social Security Administration regional office with 1,000 employees, is also owned by the city.
The F.A.A.'s plan is opposed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, some elective officials in Queens and a coalition of urban policy advocates. Similar conflicts have erupted in other cities, including Fresno, Calif., and Columbia, S.C., where officials have invoked the same Presidential mandate in unsuccessful attempts to block Government real estate investments. But several experts said the dispute in Queens provided the clearest test of Federal policy.
Opponents of the F.A.A. plan say the criteria laid out in the Presidential order point directly to downtown Jamaica, the once-vibrant commercial hub of central Queens, which remains one of New York City's business and public transportation hubs.
City, state and Federal agencies have focused on downtown Jamaica as a center for urban renewal. The latest government project in the neighborhood involves the F.A.A. itself: the long-delayed $1.3 billion light rail system that is to be built by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey over the next five years, connecting Kennedy Airport's terminals to the Long Island Rail Road and New York City subway system.
Mr. Moynihan brought the debate to a critical point when he persuaded Rodney E. Slater, the Secretary of Transportation, to meet privately on May 2 in Manhattan with several advocates of downtown Jamaica, including Archie Spigner, City Councilman from Queens, and officials of the Regional Plan Association.
"We knew that air pollution and mass transit are top priorities for Secretary Slater," said Tony Bullock, Mr. Moynihan's chief of staff, "and here we had a test of his own convictions, as well as those of the President."
Through a spokeswoman, Mr. Slater said that he did not intend to intervene publicly, but gave no indication about his own preferences.
The plan's critics say they do not plan to challenge it in court, because the President's executive order is a guideline, not a law. And since the F.A.A. excluded downtown Jamaica from consideration in 1994, the relevance of the executive order was murky: President Clinton had not yet revived it from the dustbins of two previous Administrations.
"When you look back, the question of timing is very important," said Renee Miscione, a spokeswoman for the General Services Administration, which is representing the F.A.A. in its office development. The agency itself, through a spokesman, Jim Peters, declined to comment.
But urban planners and advocates of downtown revitalization elsewhere say the dispute has added fuel to the debate over the President's urban policy. "There are other cases, but Queens is the atrocity," said Jeffrey A. Finkel, executive director of the Counsel for Urban Economic Development, an advocacy group.
Although only sites in Queens are now being considered, the agency also looked at suburban locations. Officials close to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, including the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, now say they will endorse any Queens site.
"The people who are stirring this pot do so at the risk that over 800 jobs will be lost to the suburbs," said Charles Millard, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which has not only endorsed the Federal agency's current plan but also offered a development site. That site consists of eight acres of undeveloped city-owned marshland, surrounded by residential streets, in the Springfield Gardens section, north of the airport.
Mr. Millard said the city had reached an agreement with Edward J. Minskoff, a large-scale developer, to develop the site, if it is selected for the aviation agency. But advocates of downtown Jamaica say they will not accept defeat quietly.
"This is a critical issue for the region, if not the nation," said Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, a nongovernment planning group that has long recommended increased investment in downtown Jamaica. "Downtown Jamaica gives us a litmus test of whether there is any urban policy coming from Washington."

HEADLINE: U.S. Sues to Block Merger Plan of 2 Long Island Hospitals

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

 BODY:
The Justice Department filed suit yesterday to block the merger of two of Long Island's largest hospital networks, Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems. The lawsuit contends that the merger would violate antitrust laws, lead to higher hospital rates and inhibit the development of competing hospital systems.
"Unless this transaction is blocked, Long Island consumers will face higher prices," said Joel I. Klein, Acting Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division. 
 He said the Government viewed the suit as precedent-setting as many hospitals across the country, faced with declining markets in economically troubled areas, are merging to cut costs. "But these are two giants in a thriving area where it's best to let them compete," he said.
The State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, took the opposite view. He issued a statement yesterday endorsing the merger and he said a review by his office had concluded that it would save consumers $100 million or more a year.
"This will create a health care entity that will rival some of the biggest and best Manhattan hospitals," he said.
The Justice Department suit caught both nonprofit hospitals by surprise, and they said they would contest the Government's claims in court. "The Government's conclusions are entirely unwarranted and inaccurate," said James Rill, a lawyer for the hospitals who was Assistant Attorney General for antitrust during the Bush Administration.
"The merger is designed to create efficiency that will actually reduce prices and produce vigorous competition with the many other quality hospitals on Long Island and in New York City," said Mr. Rill, who is with the Washington law firm of Collier, Shannon, Rill & Scott. The merger would save $188 million in operating costs and capital expenditures over five years, the hospitals maintain.
Dr. David R. Dantzker, president of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, remarked: "We have been planning this for at least two years and never expected anything like this. For years now, the Government has been telling us to consolidate, rid ourselves of redundancy and make savings wherever possible, and now the Justice Department seems to be telling us the opposite."
But the Federal suit observes that Long Island Jewish and North Shore are "each other's principal competitor by virtue of their premier reputations, comparable full range of services and strategic location."
Mr. Klein said managed-care companies currently have the option of including either Long Island Jewish or North Shore in their plans, or they can use a favorable price negotiated with one hospital to get price concessions from the other and then offer both hospitals in their plans. In either case, he said competition between the two hospitals keeps prices low.
Two large health insurers, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and the Health Insurance Plan, or HIP, joined Mr. Vacco in supporting the merger. "Based on information given to us by the hospitals, we believe that this alliance can achieve cost savings to benefit the consumer," said Michale A. Stocker, president of Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
North Shore is one of the largest hospital networks in the Northeast, consisting of nine hospitals with more than 3,400 beds. Its major complex in Manhasset is a 729-bed teaching hospital that the Federal complaint says competes vigorously with the Long Island Jewish Medical Center's 591-bed academic hospital in New Hyde Park.
In its complaint, the Justice Department also contends that the proposed merger would be contrary to New York State's policy of promoting competition among hospitals.
Mr. Vacco said he had concluded just the opposite. Chris McKenna, a spokesman for Mr. Vacco, said the Attorney General was considering joining the two hospitals in court to oppose the Justice Department.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries End Session Mostly Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mostly flat yesterday, as investors waited for what they hope will be favorable economic data for the bond market.
Prices rose early in the day, with gains underpinned by a steady dollar and the Federal Reserve's entry into the market to buy various coupons for its own account. The purchase of securities, called a "coupon pass," is used by the Fed to add money to the banking system. The Fed bought securities maturing between Dec. 15, 1997, and May 31, 1999. But those early advances were later erased by a heavy issuance of corporate and municipal debt, which competes for the dollars of investors. 
 The 30-year bond rose 1/32, to a price of 97 17/32, pushing its yield down to 6.83 percent, from 6.84 percent on Tuesday.
Investors are hoping that retail sales today and the Producer Price Index tomorrow will be favorable, meaning that they will show a sufficiently tepid economy, thus leading the Federal Reserve to take no action on interest rates in July.
Analysts said these hopes might have been bolstered because Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, did not hint of a change in monetary policy when he spoke recently in New York to the Woodrow Wilson Center for International Scholars. He spoke, however, about the Russian economy, not the American one.
Elsewhere in the fixed-income market, the Puerto Rico Public Buildings Authority came to the municipal bond market with a $565.7 million offering of governmental facilities revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney Inc.
Puerto Rican bonds are a favorite of investors because they are tax-exempt in most states, and because the island is a commonwealth associated with the United States Government, its debt carries an implicit Government backing. For a New York City resident these securities enjoy triple tax-exempt status.
Sylvan G. Feldstein, a municipal bond analyst at the Guardian Life Insurance Company, said he did not think the bonds were a bargain.
"But because of strong investor demand," Mr. Feldstein said, "they came at pretty steep prices, which enabled underwriters to push yields about 5 basis points lower." (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) Part of the reason they were able to do this, he added, was that it was a new issue where people could buy a sizable block of paper and get the structure they wanted, along with coupon and maturity.
"The underlying attraction to this issue is its tax-exempt status in most states throughout the country," Mr. Feldstein said. "And that is why it came in richer than we had expected." It is also a reflection of the new- issue market, where strong demand is outstripping supply at present.
Some analysts speculate that the strong demand results from investors shifting some money out of stocks into municipals. Others say it is redemption money, which has to be put to work.
The Puerto Rican issue was offered at a price to yield a maximum 5.65 percent for a long bond due in 2021, with another long bond due in 2027 priced to yield 5.50 percent.
For serial bonds with shorter maturities, yields range from 4.25 percent for an issue due in 1999 to 5.40 percent for one due in 2017. Of the bonds that are insured, most are insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, with the longest insured by Ambac Indemnity.
The Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, was also in the market. It priced $2.5 billion of asset-backed securities through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.
The issue was offered in three parts, with the bulk designated class A securities. The class A1 of $1.6 billion of securities with an average life of 2.42 years was priced to yield the equivalent of a three-month Treasury bill, plus 54 basis points, while the $808 million of class A2 securities with an average life of 6.72 years was priced to yield a three-month Treasury, plus 60 basis points. For $87.5 million of the class B securities with an 8.1-year average life, the yield was that of a three-month Treasury, plus 83 basis points.

HEADLINE: A Republican for Rent Regulation

BYLINE: By Frank Padavan; Frank Padavan, a Republican, represents northeastern Queens in the New York State Senate.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
When my wife and I married more than 30 years ago, we moved into an apartment in Glen Oaks, a sprawling complex on the eastern edge of Queens providing affordable housing for young families.
In time, like the countless New York families that preceded us, we left the apartment for the space and privacy of a house. 
 My experience has taught me that rent regulations help young families establish themselves in New York. Without rent-stabilized apartments, how many couples would be able to start families and their careers in New York City? Very few, I fear.
As a Republican, I agree that eliminating excessive government regulation and fostering private ownership of property are worthy fundamental beliefs of the party, both nationally and in New York State. So I understand why Gov. George Pataki and Joseph Bruno, the New York Senate majority leader, have proposed loosening rent regulations.
But I also believe that Republican principles must be tempered with reality in the case of New York City. Very simply, affordable housing is essential for the city's economic survival. If apartments were deregulated as they became vacant, there would be fewer and fewer apartments that middle-class families could afford.
Republicans in New York City recognize this above all else. That's why I and other Republican officeholders, including State Senator Roy Goodman, support Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's call for renewal of the 23-year-old Emergency Tenant Protection Act.
The facts back us up. In my own State Senate district in Queens, which is about as far from midtown Manhattan as you can get, the rent for an unregulated apartment in Bayside is 54 percent higher than the rent for a similar unit under stabilization.
A study released in April by the Rent Stabilization Association projected that if the laws are not renewed, rents in Bayside will rise immediately by 15 percent to 19 percent.
Tenants in stabilized apartments are far from wealthy. In fact, 27 percent of all households in rent-stabilized units have incomes below the poverty level, and the average income for a family in a rent-stabilized unit is less than $30,000. How many of these families could afford a huge jump in their rent?
Rent regulation was not foisted on many landlords unwillingly. Over the last two decades, many of them, including those who are now complaining bitterly, accepted rent regulation in exchange for tax abatements on their properties. These landlords initially offer apartments at market rates; the units then fall under rent regulation until the landlord's property tax abatement lapses -- usually in 15 or 20 years.
Rent stabilization may not be without flaws. But the fact is, it has kept the city alive. The state tried decontrolling the rents for vacant apartments in the early 1970's, and it didn't work.
Let's preserve New York's economy by keeping rent regulations intact. It's in the best interests of everyone, Republicans and Democrats alike.

HEADLINE: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;
Among the Not So Well Heeled of Gucci Gulch

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The first benefits of the proposed 1997 tax cut began trickling down through the economy early this morning when the $10-an-hour professional standees arrived to hold places for the $300-an-hour lobbyists who would not show up until hours later for their seats in the big tax-pie hearing room.
"Welcome to Gucci Gulch," announced Gerald Brant, a 25-year-old entrepreneur in a baseball cap who held a prime spot for one of the power lobbyists stereotyped on Capitol Hill as the tasseled-loafer class of inside operators. 
 "We line-standers at the Ways and Means Committee are very much at the bottom of the food chain," said Mr. Brant, who was enriched by the minute as the committee's public session was delayed throughout the day and the buzz of anticipation over the city's ultimate political spectacle, enacting a tax cut, only grew. "The lobbyists pay us, and then the interest groups and corporations seeking tax breaks pay the lobbyists. We all squeeze a few dollars out of the Beltway."
Mr. Brant omitted mention of the middleman, the private broker services known as CSC and CVK, which are paid $25 or more to hire the $10 standees for the $300 lobbyists. And he did not note that many lobbyists even then will finally send an office gofer to audit the panel's sessions. But otherwise he had it right: It is growth time on the Hill. Fat crumbs are tumbling down from the groaning-board hearing rooms where the crucial details of a dozen major tax and spending revisions are being wrestled over.
"This is the beginning of the real action," boomed one well-tailored man, a trucking industry lobbyist who recognized Robin Tallon, a former Congressman from South Carolina. Mr. Tallon had been unable to resist stopping by the Ways and Means session to sample vicariously the politics of tax cutting -- a glory denied him in his decade of incumbency, which ended three years ago.
"There's a great deal of interest in what's going on in this room," Mr. Tallon said enviously amid the hubbub outside the closed doors of hearing room 1100 in the Longworth office building. Through the day, the room attracted a raft of conflicting special interest representatives ready to lobby the familiar spectrum, from corporate to social needs. They all knew that once the delays were weathered and a bill produced, the devil, not to mention Santa Claus, would be in the details.
"You have to be vigilant," Mr. Tallon said, grinning rather mischievously while his former colleagues met in private and reportedly fought long and spiritedly over the politics of munificence. "Yeah, you never know. As Will Rogers said, 'Those fellers bear watching.' "
As the day dragged on through serial delays, it became clear that the committee chairman, Bill Archer of Texas, was having troubles.
"We hear he's having problems rounding up his own Republicans," said one paid line-waiter, Andrew Eiva, a Bosnian-American volunteer at the Washington office of the Bosnian Government.
Other professional lingerers played games outside the hearing room, the most politically poetical on this day being poker and Monopoly. But Mr. Eiva was busy writing a letter to Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, seeking his help in some part of the Bosnian cause.
"I can use the money from waiting here," Mr. Eiva noted, "and sometimes I grab a legislator going by."
Down the corridor, Mark A. Bloomfield, president of the American Council for Capital Formation, a business group, was unfazed by the delays. He stayed busy making phone calls and chatting with Congressional staff and fellow lobbyists, looking particularly after the fate of the corporate alternative minimum tax.
"In some ways, the tax package is a debate about the Republican Party," Mr. Bloomfield said with a certain professional fascination as he waited to see how fragile Mr. Archer's "mark" -- his detailed tax proposal -- would prove once the committee went public. "That is to say, a debate between social conservatives focusing on the family tax credit, and others focusing on the economic provisions."
As Mr. Bloomfield delved into the macroeconomic possibilities of the day, John Likens, the president of the CSC company, moved down the long line of standees, checking on the fidelity of his 15 hired place-holders. All was well. Linda Morris, a housewife in his first client's spot, at the very head of the line, was a study in good posture and patience after seven hours, even as lobbyists passed conversing about "depreciation recapturing" and other arcana.
"All I know is it's something about taxes," Ms. Morris said of the richly important matters to be settled inside, sooner or later.
Her boss, Mr. Likens, had sugarplum thoughts of the profits of 1995, when he scrambled to place dozens on overnight waits, some as long as 40 hours. That year, the precious hearing spots for the huge telecommunications bill proved to be a bonanza for that industry and his own.
"This year was slow until they passed the budget resolution," Mr. Likens said. "But as each of its parts are taken up, we get busy -- over 30 people yesterday holding spots at the Medicare-Medicaid hearings, and now this big one, tax cuts, just beginning."
Down the line Mr. Brant, of the Gucci Gulch welcome, shared the bullish mood of the day as he sat on the floor and dreamt of larger schemes than waiting.
"I'm a refugee from the Dole campaign," he said, referring to political public relations work he did last year in hopes of landing a job with a new administration. "Now I've gone private sector, and I'm doing a telecommunications deal," he continued, sounding indomitable, smiling up from elaborate-looking sheets of paperwork.
"I'm sitting on a $50 million deal involving telecommunications in Brazil," the place-holder said, waiting ambitiously for whenever the lobbyists would finally show, as harbingers of the lawmakers. "In the meantime, we all have to keep busy, don't we?"
By 6 P.M., Mr. Brant was freed to wait no more. The lobbyists arrived, cell phones in hand, to take their protected spots.

HEADLINE: THE RENT BATTLE: THE LANDLORDS;
Strategist Helps Owners Lobby for Their Concerns

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In the cacophonous battle over the future of rent controls, New York's largest landlord group, the Rent Stabilization Association, has long complained that its voice gets drowned out in a city of renters.
Even as it assembled many of its members on the steps of City Hall on Tuesday for a show of unity, its message sometimes seemed overwhelmed, as one of its most prominent landlords, Lewis Rudin, struggled to be heard over the Rev. Al Sharpton at a political news conference just feet away. 
 But perhaps at no other time in its 28-year history has the group -- which represents 25,000 landlords, ranging from working-class owners of small Brooklyn buildings to those with hundreds of luxury apartments -- found itself in such a pivotal and high-profile position.
As Republican state lawmakers wage the most serious campaign in decades to weaken laws that regulate apartment rents and leases, the group's leaders have become the prime spokesmen for a return to the free market in the city's rental business and are fixtures in newspapers and on television news talk shows.
Its members, many long content to pay their dues and remain anonymous, have come forward to complain about cumbersome rules and scant returns on their investments.
Most important, after years of being criticized for its lack of political acumen, the group has transformed itself into a major player in Albany. In the last five years, through its political action committee and another closely related one made up of the group's largest landlords, it has become one of the biggest contributors to the State Republican Party and to Republican state candidates.
Many within the real estate industry credit the group's increased profile to its president, Joseph Strasburg, hired in 1994 after spending eight years as the chief of staff to the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, of Queens. They say Mr. Strasburg, 45, has been more successful than his predecessors in unifying a membership with widely divergent economic interests and focusing them on a bottom line: scaling back rent protections.
The association was formed in 1969 when the state's rent stabilization laws were enacted, and until 1983, when the rent system was put under state control, it acted as a quasi-city agency, helping to draft and administer rules. Now, it serves primarily as a lobbying group and provides a wide range of services mostly to its small owners: those who own 60 or fewer units, who make up 70 percent of the membership.
It refuses to discuss its operating budget, generated through dues. (In the early 1980's, it charged members $5 per apartment. Its members now own about a million apartments in the city.)
A savvy and sometimes pugnacious political strategist with an ever-present cigar, Mr. Strasburg said the group had been largely responsible for pushing the Republican leadership to attack rent laws.
"The fact that this is being debated to the extent it's being debated -- the first time since 1974, really -- and the fact that we have been able to make people aware of the abuses of the system shows that to a large extent, I think we've moved the process forward dramatically," said Mr. Strasburg, who grew up in a rent-controlled apartment in the Bronx and lived in a rent-stabilized apartment in Stuyvesant Town before moving to Staten Island.
Others say the association was as shocked as everyone else when the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, vowed last December to do away with rent protections for all but the elderly, poor and disabled.
"They've really just gone along for the ride," said a city official familiar with the association.
The impact of the political contributions -- almost $750,000 to state candidates and party committees since 1992 -- is also unclear. Mr. Strasburg discounts the money, saying its only effect has been to keep doors open and calls returned. The association's members have heavily favored Republicans, he said, "because the Assembly will clearly take their money and never respond."
But tenant advocates and other observers contend that the money has been the prime motivator in the debate, underscoring the role of several large property owners in the association who have actively opposed rent laws, among them Leonard Litwin, whose company owns several thousand apartments on the Upper East Side; Jeffrey Manocherian, a partner in Manocherian Brothers, which owns several thousand Manhattan apartments, and Arnold Goldstein, a successful developer and the acting chairman of the landlord association.

HEADLINE: Gingrich Picks Republicans to Find Ways to Press China on Rights

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, has put together a group of prominent Republican legislators, some of whom favor continuing normal trading status for China and some of whom oppose it, and has asked them to come up with another approach to pushing the Chinese on human rights, their legal system and the general promotion of democracy, Congressional aides said today.
With Representatives John E. Porter of Illinois and David Dreier of California serving as co-chairmen, the informal task force is debating various policies that might have a stronger impact on China's direction than the empty threat of revoking China's trading status, which is currently the main instrument Congress has with which to show its displeasure with China and Clinton Administration policy toward it. 
 The threat has been raised repeatedly through the Bush and Clinton Administrations, but the United States has never actually revoked the status.
The ideas being considered for the legislation range from providing more money to Radio Free Asia, Voice of America and pro-democracy projects by non-governmental organizations, to selling missiles to Taiwan and restricting visas for Chinese officials who carry out a "forced abortion" policy.
The annual vote in the House on reversing President Clinton's decision to continue China's trading status -- which is formally known as "most favored nation" status but is given to nearly every country in the world except those deemed terrorist states -- is now expected on June 25, a week before Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule. Many Congressional aides now think the House will not vote to overturn Mr. Clinton, but even if it does, the action would not survive a Presidential veto.
Mr. Porter said it was clear that, in the end, normal trade status would not be revoked.
"So that policy leads us nowhere," he said. "We need a policy that really does impact China and promote the values we hope to see grow in China, like democracy, human rights and the rule of law."
Mr. Gingrich, who favors normal trade status for China, is looking for alternatives that legislators and staff members say could be introduced quickly after the vote on China's trading status.
But Mr. Gingrich has not decided if he will support an alternate bill or bills if they are introduced. Mr. Porter said that the group had asked its staff to draft legislation hoping for Mr. Gingrich's support "and we'll proceed as soon as we have it."
Representative Christopher Cox, a Republican from California who is also on the task force and plans to vote to revoke China's trading status, said, "We all know that M.F.N. can't bear the weight of all the work to be done on the panoply of issues between the United States and China."
While some lawmakers favor new, more pinpointed economic or trade sanctions -- against products produced by factories owned by China's military, for instance -- the Dreier-Porter group has decided not to propose any trade sanctions.
"That was the precondition," a Congressional aide said. "That was what the Speaker said."

HEADLINE: Charleston Bounces Back After Closing of Base

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C.

 BODY:
When the United States Navy announced in 1993 that it was weighing anchor from Charleston and shutting down the naval base and shipyards that sprawled along the banks of the Cooper River, Mayor Joseph Riley worried that the news might amount to the city's obituary.
Charleston, Mayor Riley said, had prided itself for generations as a Navy town. 
 "It was like a death," he recalled recently. "No one had ever imagined Charleston without the Navy. The citizens loved the Navy, and the Navy loved our citizens, and the Navy's presence here was so big that every citizen in Charleston was touched by it."
The 91-year-old, 1,600-acre base was the city's largest employer, responsible for 22,000 jobs, including about 8,000 civilian jobs, and more than a third of the local economy. With the Charleston Naval Base closed, the Mayor said, the city's economic prospects were "terrifying."
Yet today along Charleston's wisteria-perfumed streets -- as in dozens of other communities around the country where military bases have been shuttered in the aftermath of the cold war -- the fears about base closings have been replaced by something approaching optimism.
To the surprise of many Charlestonians, their city has survived. And according to some economic indicators, it has thrived as well.
Unemployment is less than 5 percent; more than 40 companies have moved to Charleston or expanded their operations since 1993, many taking over property on the former Navy base. The companies have committed more than $1.5 billion in new investment and have created nearly 6,000 jobs, equal to about three-quarters of the civilian jobs lost because of the base closing.
With the Pentagon's announcement last month that it will ask Congress to approve another round of base closings early in the next century, the story of Charleston's turnaround should offer comfort to communities facing the threat that they, too, will lose the military installations that dominate their economies.
"This community has responded well to what could have been a devastating situation," said Ben Cole, president of the Charleston Regional Development Alliance. "In the end, I actually think we're going to be a better city for having lost the base."
Recent studies suggest that communities have much less to fear from base closings than they might think. Of the 495 major military bases that existed across the United States in 1988, 97 have been ordered closed, and a study by the Congressional Budget Office last December found that "relatively few communities or regions have been affected severely" by the closings.
The study, citing figures from the Pentagon, said that the base closings would result in the loss of about 236,000 jobs over a decade across the country, representing only about two-tenths of 1 percent of the nation's total employment.
A separate Pentagon-financed report by the Rand Corporation last year found that, in California, communities around shut-down military bases had weathered the closings with far less economic damage than had been predicted, and that some had even experienced economic growth. (Nearly two-thirds of the jobs lost because of base closings since 1988 have been in California.)
Even many of the remote rural communities where bases were closed have managed to do well, usually with the help of the Federal Government, which has transferred the offices of civilian agencies to the former military installations to bolster employment.
The studies have done little to quiet critics on Capitol Hill who say that the Defense Department has already cut too far, and that the Pentagon will not save enough money from the base closings to justify the turmoil they create.
"I think we need to digest what we have done before we go any further," said Representative Joel Hefley, a Colorado Republican who is chairman of the National Security subcommittee on military installations. "It puts these communities through absolute torment."
There is no doubt that Charleston experienced that torment beginning in 1988, when Congress created an independent commission to oversee the closing of military bases deemed unessential as the Pentagon cut its budget at the end of the cold war.
Charleston's naval shipyards survived the first two rounds of closings, in 1988 and 1991. But in 1993, the base came into the commission's sights.
At first, city leaders struggled to persuade the commission to save the base, citing dire economic forecasts that suggested the city faced collapse without the Navy's presence.
They drew on the political muscle offered by South Carolina's Congressmen, especially Senator Strom Thurmond, who was then the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee and is now its chairman.
But the commission had been designed to eliminate politics from the equation of base closings -- Congress was required to consider the panel's recommendations as a package instead of base by base -- and the battle for the Charleston Naval Base was lost.
"What happened immediately was this tremendous decrease in morale in the city," said Albert Parish, an economist at Charleston Southern University. "There was depression, especially among the businesses located close to the base: convenience stores, gas stations, little restaurants, mom-and-pop operations. They knew they were doomed."
Many small businesses around the base did close. Real estate values in parts of the city collapsed in the expectation of the exodus of Navy families, with land values falling more than 30 percent in some neighborhoods.
But the bad news for Charleston was remarkably short-lived, thanks to community leaders who decided that they had no time to lose in restoring the city's confidence.
Charleston County and two adjoining counties put aside years of rivalry in recruiting new business, declaring a truce and forming the Regional Development Alliance to seek investments on behalf of all three.
The alliance made an important early decision: no politicians would be allowed to serve on its board of directors.
"I don't have anything against politicians," said Mr. Cole, the president. "But it's a fact of life that when politicians get involved, things are done because of political interests."
Potential investors were impressed, not only with the commitment of the community but also with what the Navy had left behind: a well-maintained complex of 23 piers, 5 drydocks and 1.8 million square feet of warehousing along six miles of waterfront on the Cooper River.
At one end of the complex are the old officers' quarters along Navy Way, many of them stately turn-of-the-century houses shaded by canopies of oak trees draped in Spanish moss.
"It looks like Tara out there," said Jack Sprott, executive director of the group responsible for developing the Navy base, who hopes to turn the lawns around the officers' quarters into a public park and tourist destination.
Today, nearly 60 percent of the available space at the Navy base has been leased, including 70 percent of the piers and all of the drydocks.
Along the sun-bleached piers where generations of young sailors parted with their families and lifted anchor for the high seas, cargo ships were recently being loaded with Tyson Foods frozen chicken bound for Russia, the brand name printed in Cyrillic on each package.
Farther down the waterfront, a private ship-maintenance company was repairing the salvage ships used by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to fish space shuttle rocket boosters out of the ocean. In the old Navy commissary, set designers prepared for filming of a CBS television movie, "Carriers."
Charleston is now so confident about the former base that the city and surrounding counties expect to open negotiations with the Navy next year to buy the land outright, ending the Government's claim to the base.
"This base closing could have been absolutely horrible, but we've made it work," Mr. Sprott said. "This has opened doors for us."

HEADLINE: The Long Arm Of Small Business;
Delivering a Big Blow to the Death Tax

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Daisy Crowder says she is not a rich person, but she is angry that the Federal Government might treat her like one when she dies, by levying a hefty inheritance tax on the small stoneworking and construction company that she and her husband have built from scratch in Newport, Tenn.
She has complained about the tax to the people who represent her in Congress. But if she and other small-business owners across the country who oppose the tax persuade Congress to pare it back -- and the odds are that they will win at least a partial victory this year -- they will owe their success not just to their own passionately expressed feelings on the issue, but to the power and skill of their lobbying organizations in Washington. 
 Change in Washington can come from the grass roots. But it is most likely to come about when it is pushed by lobbyists who know how to work the system, combining appeals from constituents with the ability to mobilize an army of interest groups, and the votes and campaign contributions they represent.
In the case of the Federal estate tax, the formidable small-business lobby, led by the National Federation of Independent Business, has taken an issue that touches relatively few -- and relatively wealthy -- people and pushed it to the top of the nation's economic agenda.
In just a few years, the issue has gone from a quixotic quest by a few die-hard tax cutters in Congress to one that enjoys almost unanimous support from Republicans and backing from a considerable number of Democrats as well and is mentioned in the same breath as capital gains in the list of the Republican leadership's tax-cutting priorities.
"When you're in this business long enough you can smell momentum, and this issue has momentum," said Bob Packwood, the former Republican Senator from Oregon who was once his party's chief tax writer. Mr. Packwood is now lobbying for estate-tax reduction on behalf of family-owned timber and other natural-resource companies.
Still, the small-business lobby has had to put its influence to the test the last several days as it has battled to increase the amount of estate-tax relief in the Republican tax-cutting bill taken up by the House today.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, included only a minimal amount of estate-tax relief in his original proposal, which was announced on Monday. That proposal would have increased the amount of an estate that is exempted from Federal taxation to $1 million, from the current $600,000, but do it gradually over 17 years. The change would have cost the Government $18.9 billion over 10 years.
Furious because they felt they had been promised more generous provisions, the National Federation of Independent Business and the other lobbying groups working on the issue held an emergency meeting on Tuesday, and drafted a letter to the Republican leadership demanding changes.
Separately, they worked with a Democratic member of the Ways and Means Committee, John S. Tanner of Tennessee, on an amendment to Mr. Archer's proposal that would increase the exemption within seven years and provide an additional $1.5 million exemption for family-owned businesses.
By midday today, the small-business lobby had made its influence felt. Under pressure from Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich, who earlier this year said he favored repeal of the tax, Mr. Archer agreed today to increase the size of the estate-tax reduction by $10 billion, allowing the increase to the $1 million exemption to be phased in by 2007. In a sign of how the influence of small businesses can be greater even than that of corporate America, most of the money to pay for the bigger cut would come from scaling back Mr. Archer's proposal to eliminate the alternative minimum tax on corporations.
"Things are getting better," said Jamie Wickett, a lobbyist for the National Federation of Independent Business.
It is unclear what action the Senate will take on the issue, and the newest House proposal could still be scaled back as lawmakers try to satisfy conflicting demands for tax cuts from a swarm of special interests.
To be sure, there are still some defenders of the tax, which has been levied in various forms since 1916, both as a means of raising revenue and as a way to limit the concentration of wealth. They say the tax is a fair method of maintaining the tax code's progressivity and that it touches only a tiny minority of wealthy people.
"The estate-tax cuts only go to help the top 1 or 2 percent of the population," said Bob McIntyre, the director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research group. "They're using these noble yeomen of American small business as a stalking horse for the very rich."
For its part, the Clinton Administration has been cool to any big estate-tax reduction. But it has not been outspoken on the issue since Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers last month termed the repeal effort "selfishness" -- a statement that generated such a firestorm of criticism that Mr. Summers quickly apologized.
The tax raised $17 billion last year, just 1.2 percent of Federal revenues, and was levied on the estates of only 37,000 people, or about 1.6 percent of those who died. It should generate far bigger revenues in coming decades because of demographic changes -- more people will be dying -- and because of the soaring values of stocks and other assets, including farmland and small businesses.
So far, though, small-business owners and farmers account for a relatively small portion of taxable estates, even though those are the groups that have made the most vociferous case for repeal or reduction.
But as Mrs. Crowder's case suggests, the issue is as much emotional as economic. Mrs. Crowder, 58, and her ailing husband, Charles, 67, have plowed the earnings from their business for years into equipment, buildings, land and other assets to help expand. As a result, she said, they do not have much cash or other liquid wealth but will leave an estate worth well above the level at which the Federal tax kicks in.
Since the tax bite on every dollar above the $600,000 exemption -- $1.2 million for couples -- starts at 37 percent and rises to 55 percent on every dollar above $3 million, Mrs. Crowder said she was fearful that her four children would be forced to sell some or all of the business to pay the bill when she and her husband died.
"I started out living in little two-room shacks," she said. "We work long hours still -- 12 or 13 hours is nothing around here -- and we still struggle every day to pay our bills. It's not fair in the least to subject to estate taxes what's already been taxed in my lifetime."
Opponents of the levy also make an economic argument against it. They say the inheritance tax -- or the "death tax," as they call it -- no longer captures the assets of the very wealthy, most of whom manage to evade it through sophisticated estate planning.
Moreover, they argue, the tax discourages investment in small businesses and farms and not only leads to the breakup of small companies, but also to the loss of the jobs they support. And they contend that the tax is so expensive for the Internal Revenue Service to administer and generates so many legal conflicts over the valuations assigned to the estates that there is little justification for retaining it. (Critics make the same arguments against the separate inheritance taxes imposed by many states.)
"If Uncle Sam is going to do this to me, why should I go on," said Kennard W. Campbell, 57, who runs a 20-employee plumbing and real estate company in Stuarts Draft, Va. "I have a son who's 37 and who I want to see continue doing what we're doing today."
Those arguments have been made forcefully over the last several years by the small-business lobby, which represents the people members of Congress tend to meet when they go home to their districts: active and often prominent in their communities -- and overwhelmingly conservative. And there are a lot of them: an average of 1,200 members of the National Federation of Independent Business in each district.
Jack Faris, the federation's president, last exhibited his influence when he played a key role in blocking President Clinton's health care plan in 1993. And the small-business lobby's influence increased substantially when the Republicans took control of Congress in the 1994 elections.
The Democratic committee chairmen in Congress before that election voted to support positions backed by the federation only 20 percent of the time. The Republican chairmen who replaced them voted with the federation 97 percent of the time.
"We no longer needed to take a defensive posture," Mr. Faris said.
As it went on the offensive in 1995, the small-business lobby quickly put the estate tax at the top of its list.
"This is a huge, emotional issue with our members," Mr. Faris said.
Indeed, the entire inheritance-tax issue fits neatly into the anti-Washington, anti-tax movement that has come to characterize the way many small-business owners feel about the Government, and lobbyists like Mr. Faris are quick to push those hot buttons in describing the tax's effects.
"People are dealing with the death of a loved one, and now they have the I.R.S. coming in and trying to rip what's left out of the heart of the family," Mr. Faris said.
Starting three years ago, Mr. Faris's group began putting together a coalition of other lobbying groups whose constituencies had similar concerns. An early recruit was the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, which represents ranchers who face the same problems with inheritance taxes as entrepreneurs.
The coalition grew steadily. The American Farm Bureau joined, as did groups representing florists, vintners, auto dealers, wholesalers, retailers, bakers, dentists, plumbers, restaurant owners and the Amway Corporation, among scores of others -- 105 lobbying groups in all.
By bringing so many groups together, the coalition has been able to unleash waves of constituents on members of Congress at regular intervals. A few weeks ago the National Retail Federation brought a group of its members here to knock on doors. Beer wholesalers did the same thing that week, and restaurant owners were in a few weeks earlier.
H. James Baum, 59, an opponent of the tax who owns a retailing company in Illinois that has been in his family since 1874, stopped in to see Representative Gerald C. Weller, a second-term Republican who represents his district. Mr. Baum said he has known and supported Mr. Weller for years and that he was supportive of reducing the tax.
"Our influence in Washington," Mr. Baum said, "is almost disproportionate."

HEADLINE: Some Odd Assumptions on Capital Gains

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
As the next millennium begins, American investors will voluntarily pay more than $6 billion in taxes that they do not owe to the Federal Government -- even though they will not have taken in any cash to pay the taxes.
At the same time, inflation will be widely feared, and the bull market in stocks will be roaring on. 
 If those forecasts strike you as unrealistic, perhaps you do not work for the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. They appear to be crucial to the revenue estimates relating to capital gains taxes in the tax bill proposed by Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Archer's proposal is to cut the top rate on capital gains to 20 percent from 28 percent, effective for sales made on May 7 or later. That, it is assumed, will provoke a rush of selling, enough so that the Government will take in $1.7 billion more during the current fiscal year, ending Sept. 30, and $6.3 billion more in the next fiscal year, than it would have without the changes.
To take in that extra $8 billion, with the capital gains tax rate being eight percentage points lower, one must assume that taxpayers will realize much more in capital gains over the period than they would otherwise have realized.
There may be some optimism there. But it is in later years that the figures are truly impressive. By the fiscal year 2001, the revenue estimate numbers assume that the lower rates will be costing the Government $3.6 billion in comparison with current tax law. In other words, because rates are lower, those taking capital gains will be paying less.
Then, in the fiscal year 2002, the official revenue estimates once again show the Government doing better than it would have done. In that year, it takes in an extra $2.5 billion -- a swing of $6.1 billion compared with the year earlier.
What produces that swing? In that year, Mr. Archer proposes indexing capital gains for inflation. Any assets acquired after Jan. 1, 2001, will, if held for at least three years, be subject to capital gains tax only to the extent the gain outpaces inflation over the period. That provision will, of course, start to cost the Government money a few years later.
But the immediate effect is said to be quite different. Anyone can elect on Jan. 1, 2001, to treat stock as sold at the closing price of the next day's trading, and then reacquired at the same price.
The taxpayer would then pay a capital gains tax on the profit from that phantom transaction. And, if the stock is then held for at least three more years, its sale would qualify for the indexation break.
To make the revenue numbers work, assuming the 20 percent rate, taxpayers will have to elect to pay that tax on more than $30 billion of profits. This would be on assets held for at least a year (to get the long-term treatment) and which the taxpayer intends to hold for at least three more years.
Would that be a good idea? Let's assume, for argument's sake, that you own a stock position worth$10,000 on Jan. 1, 2001, and let's assume that it cost $5,000. And let's assume that inflation will then be running around 3 percent a year, for a three-year cumulative growth of 10 percent. (That assumes, by the way, a substantial pickup in inflation. The indexing is based on the deflator for the gross domestic product, which is now rising at a rate of less than 2 percent a year.)
To qualify for indexing, you pay $1,000 tax, that is a 20 percent tax on the $5,000 in profits.
Let us assume the stock doubles again over the next three years. In that case, you would owe tax on $9,000 of profits, because your cost basis would be adjusted by the 10 percent rise in inflation over the period. So you would owe $1,800 in taxes, in addition to the $1,000 you paid three years earlier.
Or, you could do nothing in 2001, and if the same events unfolded, sell at $20,000 and pay $3,000 in taxes.
The net effect? You have saved $200. To get that savings, you paid $1,000 three years earlier. One way to look at that is as a 20 percent profit on that $1,000 over those three years. But that came during a period when your stock doubled. Clearly, you would have been a lot better off to have invested that $1,000 in 2001 in more stock.
"I've known a lot of taxpayers," said Robert Willens, a tax expert at Lehman Brothers, when asked yesterday if the revenue estimates seemed reasonable to him. "They don't pay what they don't have to. I have a hard time believing people are going to sign up for that."
Of course, if inflation was expected to be much higher, it would make more sense to pay the taxes earlier. If you assume that inflation over those three years will amount to 20 percent, instead of 10 percent, then the tax savings would be $400 instead of $200.
In other words, to get this kind of extra tax revenue, one has to assume that there will be a lot of profits available to be taken -- that the bull market is still raging -- and that people will be willing to sign up for the indexing because they think inflation will be running fairly high. Most market analysts would not forecast a strong bull market to continue if inflation was indeed a major concern of investors.
Under the rules established by the budget accord, the new tax bill is supposed to have net tax cuts of $85 billion between 1997 and 2002. By assuming that $6.1 billion in additional revenues, the bill can have that much more in other goodies during that period without going over the limits. It is probably nonsense, but there are times when assuming nonsense can make life much more pleasant.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Report on Mortgages Gives Mixed Signals

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Mortgage delinquencies are lower in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut than in the nation, but the proportion of the region's homes that are in foreclosure is far higher, a banking group reported yesterday.
"It shows that your region is spotty, with a level of foreclosure that continues to be huge," said David Lereah, chief economist for the group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. 
 In New York City, Rae Rosen, a senior economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said the data reflected the sharp division in economic strength between the city and its nearby suburbs, with strong income gains and steady home values, and the more rural and industrialized sections of the region.
The report found that the percentage of mortgage loans that were delinquent in the first three months of the year was 4.31 percent in New York, 4.25 percent in New Jersey and 3.6 percent in Connecticut, compared with 4.36 percent in the nation.
It said the percentage of homes in foreclosure during the same period was 1.67 percent in New York, 1.82 percent in New Jersey and 1.75 percent in Connecticut, compared with 1.08 percent in the nation.
 THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft Joins Netscape In On-Line Privacy Plan
Microsoft said it would take the unusual step of agreeing with its archrival on the Internet, Netscape, on a standard for privacy software.
The collaboration, which is backed by about 100 companies, is a pragmatic accommodation in response to growing concerns about privacy on line -- worries that threaten to slow the growth of Internet commerce and possibly lead to regulation. [Page D4.] 

As the free-flowing exchange and exploitation of information is being celebrated as the main engine of economic prosperity into the next century, privacy is looking more and more like an endangered natural resource. [A1.]
 
Pacificorp Deals Said to Be Set
Pacificorp, the big West Coast utility, has reached an oral agreement to acquire Energy Group of Britain for $6 billion in cash and is selling its telecommunications subsidiary, Pacific Telecom, for $1.5 billion to help pay for the acquisition, a person familiar with the transaction said. [D7.]
 
Dow Climbs 36.56 to Another Peak
Investors took heart from meager inflation and stable interest rates, sending the Dow industrials up 36.56 points, to another record, 7,575.83. With computer stocks recovering in late trading, the Nasdaq rose 6.16 points, to 1,407.85. [D8.]
 
Sallie Mae Chief to Resign
Seeking to break a bitter fight for control of the Student Loan Marketing Association, Lawrence A. Hough, the chief executive, said that he would resign from the company, which is facing a proxy challenge from dissident board members. [D2.]
 
Settlement in Stock Case
Four former executives of T2 Medical, a high-flying stock in the early 90's that later plunged, agreed to pay more than $456,000 to settle regulatory charges that they had fraudulently inflated earnings. [D8.]
 
High Stakes for Blue Cross System
With the collapse of Anthem's merger with Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey, the ultimate survival of the nationwide Blue Cross system may be at risk. News analysis. [D5.]
 
Gingrich Seeks Options on China
The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, has put together a group of prominent Republican legislators and asked them to find a way of pushing the Chinese on human rights issues that does not involve the threat of revoking most-favored-nation trading status, Congressional aides said. [A4.]
 
Treasury securities were little changed, after rising early in the day, bolstered by a steady dollar and Fed purchases. The 30-year bond yield fell to 6.83 percent from 6.84. [D15.]
 
Archer Modifies Tax-Cut Plan
Yielding to pressure from the airline industry and small-business groups, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, modified his tax-cutting plan slightly, even before dealing with demands from the Clinton Administration for wholesale changes. [B16.]
 
Euro Pressure Catches Up to Kohl
Confronted by a political and financial squeeze over the plan for a single European currency, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, a master at solving crises by postponing them, has seen his management style come to appear increasingly frayed. [A12.]
 
Selling Shares, Not Just Shirts
Polo/Ralph Lauren sold shares for $26 each in the second-largest initial public offering this year, raising roughly $767 million. The offering is sure to make an even richer man out of a former necktie salesman from the Bronx. [D8.]

Bosnian City Is Cited In Voter Registration Fraud
International election monitors said that all voter registration centers in the Bosnian city of Brcko would be closed, the local staff fired, and the process begun again. Fraud was widespread, they said, with Bosnian Serb officials trying to maintain control of the town, once predominantly Muslim, by issuing fraudulent identity papers to Serbian refugees, some of them bused in from Serbia. Elections were set for September. A12

William Hague, the youngest Cabinet member of Britain's former Prime Minister, John Major, has emerged as the unexpected favorite in a race to be the new leader of the Conservative Party. Mr. Hague was the choice of the right wing of the party, which objects to former Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke's European sympathies. A11
 
France to Relax on Immigration
France's new Socialist Government promised to revoke two anti-immigration laws enacted by the former center-right Administration over the past four years. The laws sharply curtailed new immigration and promoted deportation of undocumented foreigners. A13

A prominent former member of a Protestant death squad in Northern Ireland was shot dead by an unknown assailant. Kenya's general elections will not be fair unless constitutional reforms are carried out and repressive public-order laws are repealed, according to Amnesty International. HEADLINE: After Foxwoods, Pequots Turn to Building Ferries

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
The Mashantucket Pequot Indians of Connecticut do not do things halfway. The tribe has made millions as owners of Foxwoods Casino, building and rebuilding their resort in the eastern Connecticut woods until today Foxwoods is considered one of the most profitable gambling halls in the world.
But will the Pequot touch work for ferryboats? 
 The first Pequot-built ferry, a 148.5-foot catamaran launched yesterday at a ceremony on the Thames River near the tribe's one-year-old shipyard in New London, Conn., is probably the most expensive ferry ever built in the United States for its size, at $11.5 million. It may well also be the fastest, at 47 knots, about 54 miles per hour. And it is almost certainly the first ever to be marketed with its own interactive computer CD.
"Nobody in the ferryboat business has the resources to go out and build a $10 million ferryboat except for them," said one of the tribe's competitors, Peter Duclos, a vice president at Gladding-Hearn Shipbuilding in Somerset, Mass., which is one of only a handful of builders of a new generation of fast ferryboats. "That boat is not a 747, it's a Concorde."
The Pequots opened their boatyard, called Pequot River Shipworks, with twinned goals of building boats to carry gamblers from New York City to Foxwoods and also for the commercial ferry markets in North and South America. Tribal officials said they believed those markets were ripe for an advanced trihulled turbine catamaran seating 302 passengers.
They said yesterday that their first completed boat, called the Sassacus, would begin running as early as September between an undetermined site in New York and the casino -- about two and a half hours total, or about one hour less than the current drive.
Tribal officials also announced the first commercial ferry sale, to an Argentinian company, Buquebus, which plans to begin a three-hour run early next year between Key West and Fort Myers, Fla. That trip now takes about eight hours by car.
"We believe these boats will play crucial roles in the marine superhighways of the future, just as our ancestors' first boats played a key role on the first marine highways on the East Coast," said Richard A. Hayward, the tribal chairman.
Local officials in New London, which grew up as a shipbuilding center for the whaling fleets of the 1800's and later prospered building submarine fleets for the United States Navy, credited the Pequots with helping keep a piece of the local culture and identity alive as military needs wound down at the end of the cold war.
Jane L. Glover, the Mayor of New London, said that the boatyard had pumped about $6 million into the local economy and kept the roughly 80 boatyard employees -- most of whom are laid-off former submarine workers from the nearby Electric Boat shipyard in Groton -- working in their craft. "Otherwise, they might have had to go to work for the casino," she said.
Ms. Glover said that what really drove that point home to her yesterday was her meeting a local contractor who had just landed a contract for refrigeration work on the Pequots' next boat. "It made a difference to someone locally," she said.
But ferry industry experts and operators said that the Pequots would have to fight a lot of economic currents to build a broader commercial application for their ferries. The tribe's boats -- a design licensed from a British company, FBM Marine Group -- may simply be too specialized: too fast, too expensive and too plush, with first-class seating patterned after British Airways, to make much sense commercially in the real workaday ferryboat world.
"It is difficult to conceive of a commercial setting without a subsidy in which the boat could make money," said Mark Stanisci, the president of Express Navigation Inc., which runs two ferries between Wall Street and Atlantic Highlands, N.J. The company's nine-year-old boats only go two-thirds as fast as the Pequot boats -- about 30 knots -- but they cost only $2.25 million back then and can be replaced today, Mr. Stanisci said, for a next-generation design that still costs only about $3.5 million.
But there is also little doubt that demand for new high-speed ferries stands to increase. NY Waterway, which operates 14 boats in the New York City metropolitan area, plans to expand to about 25 by 2000, including 5-to-10 high-speed boats needed for a new route beween LaGuardia Airport and Manhattan.
Juan Carlos Lopez Mena, the chairman of the Argentine ferry company that made the first Pequot purchase, said through an interpreter that part of the attraction of the new ferries, in addition to their speed, was that their turbine engines polluted less than other less-efficient designs. They were also built to international maritime specifications, unlike most American-built vessels. He said his company had an option to buy three more boats, all for planned use in United States waters.
Mr. Duclos of the Gladding-Hearn shipyard said he thought that Pequots had in fact carved out such a different market that they could only help competitors like his company by aggressively marketing to the world in a way that his 42-year-old family-owned business could simply never afford.
"All the efforts of the Pequots are going to help us out," he said. "They're going to bring to the attention of a lot of people the high-speed ferry business -- we might even pass leads back and forth."
