HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rally on Report That Retail Sales Slipped in May

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
An unexpected decline in May retail sales eased bond traders' worries yesterday about the possibility that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates next month and pushed Treasury prices sharply higher.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 26/32 , to 98 5/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.77 percent, from 6.83 percent on Wednesday, matching last Friday's low yield following the May employment report. 
 The rise in prices meant that bondholders gained about $8.13 for every $1,000 invested.
Bond prices rose after the Commerce Department reported that retail sales fell one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Analysts had expected a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent.
The Commerce Department also revised its report of April retail sales, saying that sales in that month had fallen nine-tenths of 1 percent, not the three-tenths of 1 percent originally reported.
"Essentially, the last time retail sales were down three times in a row was the fourth quarter of 1981, in front of one of the worst recessions in 20 years," said Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of fixed income at Barnett Capital Advisers Inc. "At the very least, it does signal a slowdown in the economy."
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that the weakness shown in recent retail sales reports "hardly exhibits the 'persisting strength in demand' that so concerned the Fed when it last tightened on March 25."
The latest weekly data on initial jobless claims did nothing to change the market's view of a slowing economy. As a result, the retail sales report suggested the likelihood of a significant slowdown in second-quarter economic growth.
Among bond market participants, expectations are growing that Federal Reserve policy makers, the Federal Open Market Committee, will not raise short-term interest rates for a second time this year when they meet on July 1 and 2.
"But despite the expectation of an unchanged Fed policy at the upcoming July F.O.M.C. meeting, the longevity of the current economic slowdown is still an open question," Mr. Fine said.
"The economy's strong foundation and tighter labor markets seem to be pointing to another round of Fed tightening at some point in the future. Thus, the bond market seems to be facing at least one more bullet in the chamber in its Russian roulette approach to Fed policy decisions."
Market participants now turn their attention to today's release of the Producer Price Index for May, which is expected to continue to show few inflationary pressures building. And the University of Michigan is scheduled to issue its survey of consumer sentiment in June.
"My guess on P.P.I. is that we're looking at a one-tenth of 1 percent gain in the core number, after being down last month," Mr. Ablin of Barnett Capital said, "so we expect it to be positive and not very strong.
"The long bond yield is being targeted at 6.50 percent toward year-end. I think we had more than a 50 percent chance of tightening. We are now down below 50 percent."
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a consulting and forecasting firm, said: "When the Fed raised the Federal funds rate in March, the Open Market Committee cited persisting strength in demand as the main reason.
"But at the very time they were raising rates, the demand was weakening. Today's retail sales report shows that the persisting strength was neither persistent nor strong."
Mr. McCarthy said that the Fed had tightened to slow down an economy that was already slowing on its own.
"The likelihood of further tightening in this environment," he said, "is virtually nil."

HEADLINE: E.P.A.'s New Air Standards Will Harm Cities

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your June 5 editorial endorsing the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed tightening of air quality standards treated objections to the new rules dismissively. But the rules lack adequate scientific basis, would come with unacceptably high costs in terms of jobs and urban economic development and would undermine the Clean Air Act. 
 Although you cite the E.P.A.'s independent board of scientists as backing the proposed standards, you fail to consider that the head of that panel, Dr. George Wolff, said in a February Senate hearing that there is "no known biological mechanism for the influence of fine particulate matter on human health."
To suggest, as you do, that the costs of the new rules can somehow be ignored because they are not mandated by legislation is ridiculous. In an era of fiscal constraint, where will hard-pressed cities get the money to replace Federal resources their noncompliance will deny them, especially given that many likely will never reach compliance at all? Alicia H. Munnell, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, has estimated that the overall cost of compliance with the new ozone standards alone could be as high as $60 billion annually -- many times greater than the E.P.A.'s own estimate.
The new regulations are a recipe for economic stagnation. Tens of thousands of American workers could find themselves on the unemployment line. About 800 counties would fall into immediate noncompliance with the new standards. And many major cities would lose Federal benefits by not being able to follow the excessively severe new regulations.
 
JERRY J. JASINOWSKI
President, National Assn.
of Manufacturers
Washington, June 5, 1997

HEADLINE: Holding Our Breath

BYLINE: By George E. Pataki; George E. Pataki is Governor of New York.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration will soon make one of the most important environmental decisions of this decade: whether to support the Environmental Protection Agency's proposal for tough new rules on air pollution.
The E.P.A. is asking for stricter limits on ozone, or smog, and the dustlike particles known as particulates. Toughening these national standards for smog and soot is essential to protect the public health. 
 But opponents of the proposed rules have been lobbying the President to moderate them. He should resist. No one can deny that the standards will lead to cleaner air and fewer respiratory problems, particularly for the elderly and the young.
Government has few responsibilities more important than providing clean water and clean air. We must do whatever is reasonable to protect the quality of the air we breathe.
That's why New York is moving ahead to further reduce emissions from utility plants beyond the levels required by Federal law. This state is also taking aggressive measures to curb emissions from motor vehicles, including trucks and buses that spew soot, and we are eliminating polluting coal-fired boilers from New York City schools.
But while New York's air quality is steadily improving, there's a limit to what we can do on our own. We are at the end of the air pollution pipeline. Air entering New York from the Midwest already exceeds national standards for ozone. Under the E.P.A.'s proposed rules, Midwestern states would be forced to impose stricter pollution control measures already used in the Northeast, like requiring cleaner-burning power plants.
This is particularly important given the advent of competition in the electric power industry. Thanks to deregulation, large Midwestern coal-fired plants, which have lower costs for controlling air pollution, will be at a competitive advantage. If their sales of electricity increase, so will their downwind emissions to the Northeast. New national standards would not only protect the environment but also help insure more fairness in the market for electricity.
In addition to allowing all of us to breathe easier, the proposed rules offer other environmental benefits. For one thing, the standards would reduce acid rain, which continues to devastate New York's majestic Adirondack Park. The rules would also decrease the amount of nitrogen entering Long Island Sound, leading to cleaner water and healthier aquatic life. New York State is already spending $200 million, through the Clean Water-Clean Air Bond Act, to reduce nitrogen deposits in the Sound.
Although health considerations demand that we adopt these new air standards, economic factors are important, too. The E.P.A. should allow industry as much flexibility as possible to meet emission reduction goals in a cost-effective way. The success of the Federal program allowing companies to trade credits for emissions that produce acid rain suggests not only that industry can meet environmental protection standards, but also that market forces can drive down the cost of doing so.
In the end, the most important question in evaluating the proposed rules on pollution is whether they will provide cleaner and healthier air. Let's hope that when the Clinton Administration decides whether to stand by the E.P.A.'s air quality standards, concern for the health of our children and grandchildren leads the way and political considerations take a back seat.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Henrick Drescher)

HEADLINE: Bounced Commissioner Practices Her Rebound

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, June 10

 BODY:
Cardboard boxes clutter the floor of Dr. Mary Hibberd's office here, some filled with files to discard and others bulging with mementos to keep. Her desk is strewn with folders and a hammer and a screwdriver for removing photos from the wood-paneled wall.
Dr. Hibberd, the Suffolk County Health Commissioner, is making an abrupt and highly publicized career change in a life that has never worked out quite the way she planned. 
 Her pattern was set early, when hopes of becoming a naturalist were thwarted by a graduate program's males-only policy. Since then, her zigzag career as a scientist and pediatrician has taken her to a remote Montana Indian reservation, the squalor of Bangladesh and the poorest neighborhoods of Long Island.
None of it seemed to prepare Dr. Hibberd for the rough and tumble of politics in Suffolk County. She says she was ousted because she would not play patronage games; her detractors disputed her health policies and said she was a poor manager. In any case, by Friday, she will have vacated her office.
As Dr. Hibberd sorted through her things, she said, "Look -- here's something." It was the plaque commemorating her induction in March into the Suffolk County Women's Hall of Fame. Etched at the bottom is the name of County Executive Robert J. Gaffney -- who two months later, without warning, created a committee to search for her successor.
Dr. Hibberd was in Virginia picking up her daughter from college, and found out when she called her answering machine from a pay phone in a Wendy's and heard urgent messages from reporters.
"It was very painful," she recalled. "I was crying and saying it's not fair -- I'm not there to defend myself. We drove back home in this big line of violent thunderstorms. It seemed like the perfect metaphor."
Mr. Gaffney said his decision stemmed from a growing rift with Dr. Hibberd over health policies. He also questioned her management skills, saying that her agency had failed to get millions of dollars in state aid, that malpractice expenses were high and that its managed-care system was floundering.
Dr. Hibberd rebutted his complaints, saying, for example, that Suffolk would get all its state aid after the normal lags in claims, payments and budget cycles. But she also mounted a counterattack, saying that the real reason for her removal was that she blocked attempts at interference by Mr. Gaffney, his top aides, two legislators and others.
Over the years, she said, those officials had tried to foist unqualified but politically connected job candidates on her agency. She said they also tried to force her agency to spend money advertising in a politically connected newspaper and tried to strong-arm her into backing off on smoking regulations to help their business friends.
Dr. Hibberd, 50, a divorced mother of two who is given to quoting Gandhi and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., said she would not give in. "My duty is to protect the public health, not to engage in politics," she said.
Nor did she seem concerned about losing her job. "I always think God has a plan, even though we don't know it," she said.
Dr. Hibberd has a legion of admirers who see her as a Mother Teresa who championed suburbia's invisible needy, and, in the process, cut Suffolk's infant mortality rate by more than 40 percent.
"Mary is credible, and the rest of them aren't," said Maxine Postal, a Democrat and chairwoman of the County Legislature's Health Committee. "That slim woman has a backbone made of tempered steel. From the person who does the maintenance work right up to the top, they say she's the very best we've ever had."
Mr. Gaffney and the other officials denied the charges of interference. Mr. Gaffney declined to be interviewed for this article.
Although some people called for an investigation get to the bottom of the dispute, there appears little chance of that. Instead, Dr. Hibberd will start a new job Monday as a senior executive at Ipro, a health-care consulting firm in Lake Success.
Growing up in Upper Darby, Pa., Dr. Hibberd never envisioned that she would some day be at the helm of a $275 million-a-year health agency.
"It was actually a fluky thing," Dr. Hibberd said of her career. Her own requirement was to find something "that was work I wanted to do and that made a difference." After being shut out of the naturalists' program, she earned a master's degree in microbial genetics, then another in human genetics, which led her into medicine.
"I liked surgery best, but women rarely went into that," she said, so she shifted to pediatrics. In nearly five years practicing at the Flathead Indian reservation, she realized the medical toll of social and economic ills. "I saw a lot of unemployment, alcoholism, fetal alcohol syndrome."
Her career was transformed again by 10 months as a volunteer in the Care Medico program in Bangladesh. "People went blind from lack of vitamin A. There was scurvy, polio, tetanus, diphtheria, TB -- all preventable. You could save thousands."
She earned a master's degree in public health and took a residency in community and preventive health at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. A stint at the Suffolk Health Department prompted a job offer, and she became director of reproductive care for six years. County Executive Patrick Halpin named her acting health commissioner in 1991, and Mr. Gaffney made the appointment permanent.
Many trace her undoing to a dispute four years ago with Suffolk's District Attorney, James Catterson Jr.
She accused Mr. Catterson of threatening to investigate her agency unless she overturned the failing results of a psychological exam given to a son of a longtime associate of his. The son, an investigator in Mr. Catterson's office, needed to pass for authorization to carry a gun.
Perhaps emboldened by Dr. Hibberd, other Republican officials also began to speak out, saying that Mr. Catterson had improperly pressured them on various issues. But he denied all the complaints, and a state inquiry ended with no action taken against him.
"There's a pattern here of someone who sees things that other people don't," Mr. Catterson said in an interview. "I've never understood her agenda." He said Dr. Hibberd had been "canonized" by the news media, but he conceded, "She comes across in private as she does in public, as Mother Teresa, and it's very disarming."
Her tenacity, however, hardly ingratiated her with Mr. Gaffney. This year she went over his head to the County Legislature to win more funds for her department.
About the last thing to come down from Dr. Hibberd's office wall was a display of 13 color snapshots of beaming mothers and their babies from Project Hope, in which health workers monitor infants through their critical first year.
"This is one of the programs I started and one of the best things in the department," she said. "So I am definitely taking these pictures. It just makes you feel good."

HEADLINE: THE RENT BATTLE: THE IMPACT;
Although Meant to Create Fluidity, Decontrol Could Freeze the Market

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
Living with her aunt in a rent-stabilized apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, has become just about untenable for Sheria G. McFadden, 29. She has a new baby and job at City College in Harlem, more than an hour's commute away by subway. She needs to move.
Under the Republican proposal to remove rent regulations from apartments when they become vacant, it would be impossible for Ms. McFadden to find a rent-stabilized home if she moved. So she is unpersuaded when she hears Gov. George E. Pataki and other advocates of the plan known as vacancy decontrol say repeatedly that it would protect 99 percent of tenants. 
 "How is he protecting me?" she asked. "By forcing me to live here for the rest of my life?"
The Republican plan would let renters remain under rent stabilization or rent control as long as they stay in their apartments. But the rents would rise to any level the market would bear when tenants move, die or are evicted. The Republicans would also remove rent ceilings for households earning $175,000 a year or more under a plan called luxury decontrol.
It is true that under that scheme, 99 percent of people living under rent regulation would continue to do so, but with one important condition: to keep their rent ceilings, they could not move. No one would ever again find a vacant rent-stabilized apartment, and that, renters say, is why the Pataki plan has evoked such ire.
New Yorkers, who have taken rent regulation for granted for generations, are a fairly transient lot. In a recent New York Times poll of New York City residents, half of all renters said they had moved in the last five years, and most likely a few hundred thousand of them are in the market for a new home right now. And it has dawned on many people that under vacancy decontrol, they would have to choose between staying put and taking their chances in an unregulated market.
Young adults would think twice before leaving their family homes. Two people living alone could be dissuaded from looking for a larger place to live together. Couples would have to consider the difficulty of moving when making family planning decisions.
Similar effects might also be seen from luxury decontrol: a woman might not be so eager to have her boyfriend move into her rent-stabilized unit if their combined income pushed them over the $175,000 limit and sent her rent soaring.
Critics of the current system of rent regulation argue that it ossifies the market by giving people incentives to stay where they are, leading to poor uses of space and exacerbating the housing shortage. For instance, an elderly person whose spouse has died and whose children have grown and moved away may be unwilling to give up a three-bedroom apartment if the rent is so low that it is not worthwhile to move to a smaller unit.
Paradoxically, many housing experts, including some who support deregulation, say that vacancy decontrol could make the market rigidity much worse. "Vacancy decontrol would give people fewer options, so they would stay in their units longer," said Elizabeth Roistacher, an economist at Queens College and the City University Graduate Center who has studied the city's housing market. "The turnover rate would fall. The number of vacancies at any one time would actually drop. And, ironically, that would make the shortage worse, and drive up rents."
In the long run, experts say, as more of the market became deregulated, such symptoms would ease, but the first several years could be difficult. Real-estate experts also point out that there are dozens of neighborhoods, most outside Manhattan, in which demand is so low that landlords will probably not be able to raise rents even if they are allowed to.
The essence of the Governor's plan, indeed the sole reason for changing the current law, is to gradually deregulate the state's 1.2 million rent-stabilized or rent-controlled units, nearly all of them in New York City and its suburbs. Yet Mr. Pataki avoids saying so, and will not say the words "vacancy decontrol."
When asked this week if his plan might pose a problem for anyone who needed to move, the Governor said, "I'm not going to talk about everybody, the possible thoughts of every individual," and quickly turned to another question.
Advocates of decontrol say it would encourage new housing construction, easing the shortage and, in the long run, driving down rents, and that it would encourage renovations. Skeptics counter that builders cite a number of other factors, including a labyrinthine city approval process, that hinder new construction.
They also note that developers have been free to build unregulated housing for more than two decades, but that that freedom has not resulted in a building boom. In fact, most builders have voluntarily submitted to rent regulation in return for tax breaks.
Critics of the Governor's plan also note that owners of unregulated apartments are not required to give their tenants leases, that they can raise rents at any time, and that they can evict renters at will. Supporters counter that about one third of the city's rental market is already unregulated, but that there has not been an epidemic of such abuses.
For Ms. McFadden, as for many others, the sum of the changes Mr. Pataki would make is a feeling of being trapped. "I can't afford more than $500 a month, and there's hardly any one-bedrooms that cheap in Harlem," she said. "Even if I did find something, without a lease, without any protections, it would be like walking on the edge. You're not secure, not stable. How can you live like that and raise a child?"

HEADLINE: For Now, U.S. Insists on Limiting New NATO Members to 3

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, June 12

 BODY:
The United States defied most of its NATO allies today and announced its determination to limit the first wave of the alliance's expansion to Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic.
While those three countries had long been the leading candidates to join the alliance, 9 of the 16 NATO members had also favored including Romania and Slovenia. The Clinton Administration's announcement today means that a final decision on the number of new members will probably not be made until the meeting of NATO leaders in Madrid next month. 
 Defense Secretary William S. Cohen presented the American decision at a meeting of NATO defense ministers in the alliance's headquarters here and sought to reassure Romania and Slovenia -- and the nations backing their membership -- that "the door is still open" and that they would be "very prime candidates in the next round."
NATO decisions require consensus -- at least in principle, every member has a veto -- and the Clinton Administration tried to create at least the appearance that there was no room for compromise on the number of new members.
"The United States' position is firm," said Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman. "Our own military believes that NATO will better be able to absorb new members if we start with three, so there was a military reason to keep the number at three."
Mr. Cohen said that President Clinton had wanted to limit the first round of new members to Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic because "those three countries have demonstrated the necessary level of progress on military, political, economic and social reform."
In Romania and Slovenia, he said, "a good deal of progress has been made in a short time, but it is still a short time, and there needs to be a longer-term commitment to the progress that has been made in terms of democracy, civilian control over the military and the emphasis on human rights."
Administration officials traveling with Mr. Cohen said that with an army of only 4,100 full-time troops and an arsenal largely made up of old Soviet-era arms, Slovenia was not militarily ready to join NATO, while Romania was still struggling to establish the sort of democratic government that would be compatible with the alliance.
The officials said the United States believed it had the needed diplomatic support within NATO to limit the expansion to the three countries.
Their optimism grew today, they said, after consultations with France, which had strongly supported the inclusion of Romania, and with Italy, which had just as strongly backed Slovenia, in which the two countries offered only muted protests to the American plan.
Mr. Cohen met today for the first time with his French counterpart, Defense Minister Alain Richard, and described the meeting as "very cordial" despite their disagreement over Romania's proposed admission.
France has longstanding cultural and political ties with Romania and had been lobbying aggressively among NATO's Mediterranean members for an expansion to the south to supplement the addition of Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic to the east.
A NATO decision to invite a larger group of new members would complicate what Clinton Administration officials acknowledge could be a difficult battle to win Senate approval for the expansion of the alliance; a Senate vote is required.
Many Senators say they are reluctant to spend the billions of dollars that would be needed over the next two decades to incorporate new members into NATO from Central and Eastern Europe. Some also question whether the United States wants to take responsibility for the defense of some of the nations now seeking admission.
Mr. Cohen said that by limiting the first wave of new members to three, the United States hoped to make clear that there would be further rounds. "A limited initial group will underscore that the process is a deliberate one, a small initial group underscores that there really are going to be additional rounds," he said.
"The prudent course is to defer invitations where the countries are on the right path but need more time," he continued. "This approach is all the more appropriate since the door to membership is going to remain open, so there will be ample opportunity to invite additional members."
In Washington, Mr. Clinton underscored the point, saying, "As I have repeatedly emphasized, the first new members should not and will not be the last."
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott began a round of meetings in Washington with ambassadors from Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic to notify them formally of the American decision to support their membership.
The Hungarian charge d'affaires, Gabor Horvath, said after the meeting that his Government was delighted with the decision.
"It's a historic moment," he said. "The vision of having a unified, peaceful and stable Europe is making another very strong step. And it is also very important the process should and will remain open for making this Europe broader, even more stable, even more united."

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Drop Unexpectedly for Third Consecutive Month

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Retail sales dropped unexpectedly last month and have now declined for three months in a row, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, confirming that the economy is slowing from the rapid pace of growth over the previous six months.
The drop in automobile, building material and gasoline sales that pulled down the May total by one-tenth of 1 percent came as the Commerce Department also revised March and April data to show steeper declines than were reported earlier. 
 This is first three-month decline in retail sales since the fall of 1981.
In addition, the sales report comes on the heels of last Friday's employment report for May that showed a much lower increase in new nonfarm payroll jobs than forecast.
But among economists and investors, the debate is still raging over whether this slowdown is permanent or just a breather before another surge in consumer spending.
Investors seemed to favor the more permanent view yesterday as the bond market rallied, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to 6.77 percent and the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 135.64 points, to 7,711.47, a new high. A sharp drop in short-term interest rates seems to imply that there is no longer much expectation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates when its policy-making committee meets in early July.
"These data are the icing on the cake," said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "The Fed will be on hold through its next meeting."
David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said that the Fed's decision in May not to raise interest rates, followed by the weakish May jobs reports and yesterday's retail sales data had been a succession of "green lights" for the stock market. He expects that the Dow will easily pass 8,000.
Some economists, however, said that without any further rate increases by the Fed, consumer spending should rebound enough in the second half of the year to push economic growth higher again. And that could force the Fed to act.
These economists all think that the current slowdown is more an aberration than a trend because of seasonal factors, like the weather, special factors, like higher-than-expected income tax payments in April, and because the economic fundamentals that underlie the consumer are still strong. These fundamentals include the growth of jobs and the improving financial condition of Americans.
David Munro, the chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, argued that the healthy jumps in other sectors of retail sales, including clothing, which rose eight-tenths of 1 percent, and general merchandise, which rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, were more indicative of the attitude of consumers.
Mr. Munro said he thought the seven-tenths of 1 percent decline in the total value of gasoline sales at service stations was more a result of a fall in price rather than a drop in consumer demand. And he also wondered about the two-tenths of 1 percent decline in automobile sales, which he said did not fit with the industry's report of rising sales.
Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers, noted the same trend, adding that the declines in sales over the last three months were led by discretionary items, such as automobiles, televisions and computers.
Both warned about the tentative nature of the May data, a fact reflected in the report the Commerce Department puts out and in the steep revisions made in the April and March data. The nine-tenths of 1 percent drop in retail sales for April was revised down from an initial report of a three-tenths of 1 percent decline, while the March report changed to a three-tenths of 1 percent decline from unchanged. For May, the Wall Street forecast, according to Bloomberg News, had been for an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent.
If these economists are right, the volatility that has marked the economy in the last year and a half should continue, with little boomlets followed by small busts.
In the six months through March, the economy grew at a 4.8 percent annual rate, with a 5.8 percent surge in the first quarter, the strongest growth in almost a decade. Many economists are forecasting that growth will slow to about 1 percent this quarter. On retail sales alone, the 5 percent decline at an annual rate over the last three months followed a 15 percent surge over the previous three months.
Adding to the picture of a slowing economy was the additional report that initial jobless claims in the week ending June 7 were up by 1,000, to a seasonally adjusted 339,000. Analysts had been expecting a decline.

HEADLINE: U.S. Faces 'Real Challenge' in Selling U.N. Plan, Annan Says

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 12

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that Clinton Administration officials had told him that their agreement with Senate leaders to attach conditions to the payment of overdue debts to the United Nations "was the best deal they could get under the circumstances."
But Mr. Annan added that selling the package to the 184 other members of the organization "is going to be a real challenge for U.S. diplomacy." 
 "One can discuss these things in Congress," Mr. Annan said at a news conference. "That does not mean it's going to become law in the U.N. It does not necessarily mean that the member states are going to accept it. My sense is that quite a lot of the issues the U.S. will have to come and negotiate."
The Secretary General welcomed an effort by Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, to amend a State Department authorization bill that went to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today. Mr. Lugar proposed settling all arrears, now at just over $1 billion, without conditions, or "benchmarks."
"Obviously as Secretary General of the U.N., like all the member states, we would have been happier if the totality of what we believe is owed were paid, and if the deck had been cleared and if we did not have to deal with benchmarks," Mr. Annan said.
"But of course the process is going on, and I don't know how we will come out of it at the end of the day. But as far as positions of principle are concerned, I'm 100 percent for Senator Lugar."
On Friday Mr. Annan is to meet here with Senator Rod Grams, a Minnesota Republican and member of the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Grams, who heads the subcommittee responsible for allocations to international organizations, is also the Congressional delegate to the United Nations General Assembly.
The Secretary General's remarks came at a time when envoys here are complaining that the United States Mission to the United Nations, which will have to do the tough negotiating, seems crippled by the frozen appointment process in Washington.
Among conditions the Senate attached to budget legislation are the opening of United Nations' books to inspection in Washington, and the reduction of American payments to both the regular United Nations budget and peacekeeping operations. Neither can be done without the agreement of other United Nations members.
At this critical moment, three of the four ambassadors assigned to the United States Mission are in a holding pattern awaiting new jobs for which they must be confirmed by the Senate.
American diplomats say there have been roadblocks in the Foreign Relations Committee, where the chairman, Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, has held up confirmation hearings to extract concessions from the Administration. But American officials also say the White House has been very slow at announcing appointments. A number of large American embassies are without ambassadors.
At the United Nations, the deputy permanent representative, Edward W. Gnehm Jr., has been nominated as Foreign Service director general, but has yet to be confirmed. The third-ranking diplomat, Karl Inderfurth, has been nominated as Assistant Secretary of State for South Asia.
The United States Mission will also lose Ambassador Victor Marrero, who has been dealing with international economic and social issues, and Cameron Hume, a minister counselor for political affairs who has been involved in Security Council work.

HEADLINE: Electrolux to Cut 12,000 Workers and Shut Plants

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Electrolux A.B., the Swedish maker of Frigidaire appliances, said yesterday that it would lay off about 10 percent of its work force, or about 12,000 workers, and would close 24 factories and 50 warehouses in two years.
The cuts will mostly be in Europe, where Electrolux is the largest appliance maker, and in North America, but not in the United States. Electrolux will spend $321 million on the cost-cutting, which comes as global manufacturers are increasingly consolidating operations in Europe. Such companies face tough marketing conditions in the region as well as pressures to become more efficient as Europe moves toward greater economic unity. 
 Still, the area remains an important focus for Electrolux and other manufactures as they seek to expand their international reach, particularly by moving into the developing European markets.
"Europe is still a major marketplace, and it is also seen as a springboard to emerging consumer markets of Central and Eastern Europe," said Steven Gluckstein, an analyst who follows appliance manufacturing companies for the Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder investment firm in New York. "Look where investment has been going; it hasn't just been in traditional European countries. You're seeing investment in Poland and Hungry, and that will continue."
Such expansion, though, means companies must operate with more efficiency because of lower productivity in many of those regions as well as sluggish consumer confidence because of economic weakness. "As these major players, such as Whirlpool and Electrolux get more efficient, that is going to create much more pressure on smaller players," Mr. Gluckstein said. "That will push another wave of consolidation."
The competitive United States market has helped fuel the push into emerging markets. The United States appliance market is largely driven by replacement purchases. And since the introduction of the microwave, there have been few new products to excite consumers.
As a result, the domestic market has gone flat. "Over the last 20 years, shipments of core appliances have registered average growth of only 2.4 percent annually," said Jonathan L. Goldfarb, an analyst who follows appliance manufacturing companies for Merrill Lynch & Company.
"Appliances," he added, "have essentially saturated U.S. households. With each category of appliance performing efficiently and economically, there is little opportunity for truly significant product innovation."
Moreover, the proliferation of superstore retailers has resulted in a decrease in the number of appliance retailers. "These shifts have further intensified pricing pressures, and have somewhat moved market power away from the manufacturers and toward the customers," Mr. Goldfarb said.
And with four manufacturers now controlling more than 90 percent of the United States appliance market, opportunities to improve results through acquisitions are few.
Whirlpool has 35 percent of the domestic market followed by General Electric with 29.3 percent, according to Merrill Lynch. Maytag is third with 14.4 percent, and Electrolux is fourth with 13.5 percent.
Electrolux has had a particularly tough time operating in the the United States as competitors have been more successful with product innovation and marketing efforts. The company lost ground in the vacuum cleaner market, for instance, because its floor-care products only included canister models when consumers favored upright versions.
"G.E. is known for refrigeration and cooking, and laundry is Whirlpool's strength," said Lawrence J. Horan, an analyst who follows appliance companies for Prudential Securities. "Maytag is also really known for laundry, but they are also No, 1 in dishwashers."
As for Electrolux, he said, "in my opinion, they are strong in nothing."
But the cutbacks announced yesterday heartened investors. American depository shares of Electrolux, each representing one B share of the Swedish company, surged $9.50, or nearly 16 percent, to $69.50, in Nasdaq trading.
Electrolux, which has sales of about $16 billion, has reported a decline in profits for two years, which it attributed to a decline in demand for its industrial and commercial products as well as to the weak conditions in Europe.
"You reach a point where you have to do more," said Assa Mattsson Stenqvist, the company's vice president for investor relations. "The European market for white goods declined by 2 percent in 1996 in volume, and it continued into 1997. For the first quarter, the market was down 3 percent again."
Even so, the company, like many of its competitors, has continued to expand.
"During the 1980's they acquired a number of companies all over Europe, and they have been consolidating production since the beginning of the 1990's but at quite a slow pace," said Staffan Ostlin, an analyst who follows Electrolux for Enskilda Securities in New York. "A new chief executive came in with, I'd say, a fresh set of eyes."
Indeed, it took that executive, Michael Treschow, only two months on the job to announce the big overhaul. He said he expected the revamping to generate an operating margin of about 7 percent and to increase return on equity as high as 15 percent. The company reported only a 1.7 percent operating margin last year and a return on equity of 8.6 percent
Electrolux said it would not discontinue products as part of the streamlining initiative. Instead, the reorganization will result in a leaner, more competitive company, executives said.
Mr. Treschow, who is known for his cost-cutting plans, had been an executive with a European industrial machinery manufacturer before becoming chief executive of Electrolux in April. He replaced Leif Johansson, who became chief executive of the auto manufacturer Volvo A.B.
Electrolux manufactures household and commercial appliances such as refrigerators, ovens and washing machines. The company also makes outdoor products, including chain saws, mowers and weed trimmers.

HEADLINE: When It Comes to Stock Funds, Investors Can't Seem to Say No

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Six and a half years into a record-breaking bull market, American investors have crossed a threshold, committing more than half of their mutual fund assets to stocks, double the level at the beginning of the decade.
Americans, moreover, are not the only ones who have grown infatuated with seemingly ever-rising stock prices. Foreign investors, too, have significantly stepped up their investments in American stocks this year, to the highest level since 1990. Together, those trends have produced a rich fuel that this year has powered the stock market beyond the expectations of virtually everyone on Wall Street. 
 Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped more than 135 points, or 1.8 percent, as a drop in retail sales in May signaled a slowdown in the growth of the economy and, thus, a reduced chance that inflation will revive. That put the gain in the Dow industrials, the market bellwether, at nearly 20 percent since the beginning of the year. [Page D1.]
Those gains have come in part because of the huge volumes of money pouring into mutual funds. The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, estimated yesterday that $18.5 billion flowed into equity funds in May, the seventh-highest monthly total ever. So far this year, investors have added $92 billion to mutual funds that invest in stocks -- well behind last year's record pace, but 50 percent ahead of the next-best year.
Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that in the first quarter foreign investors bought shares of United States stocks at more than double the rate of last year. That increased foreign holdings of American equities to 6.5 percent of the total, the highest level since 1990, when the current run of the bull market began.
The long rise in stocks has also led mutual fund investors to place a bigger portion of their fund assets in the stock market than in two decades. At the end of April, according to the Investment Company Institute, stock funds contained $1.88 trillion in assets, just more than half the $3.73 trillion contained in stock, bond and money market funds.
At the end of 1990, stock funds accounted for only 23 percent of the $1.07 trillion in mutual fund assets -- far less than bond funds, which contained 30 percent of the total, and money market funds, which had 47 percent.
Still, the percentage of Americans' total financial assets that are invested in the equity market -- both through mutual funds and direct holdings of stocks -- remains well below the peak. About 28 percent of household financial assets are invested in stocks, said Melissa Brown, an analyst at Prudential Securities. That is double the portion in 1985, but well below the peak of 34.5 percent, reached in 1965.
The recent popularity of equity funds and the flow of money from overseas investors into the United States have contributed to greater demand this year for stocks, analysts say. But the supply of stocks for sale has been shrinking, as new public offerings of shares have not kept pace with corporate takeovers, which take shares of stock out of circulation.
"We're seeing close to 10 corporate takeovers being announced each week, most of them for cash," said Charles Biderman, president of Trim Tabs Financial Services, which tracks both mutual fund cash flows and stock market liquidity. "That gives investors money in their pockets, but with less shares to choose from, it drives up prices."
Add to that mix a growing number of companies announcing plans to repurchase shares of their own stock, Mr. Biderman said, and the result is an astounding run-up in stock prices.
The $18.5 billion that flowed into equity mutual funds in May -- the second-highest total this year, behind only January's record of $29.1 billion -- marked a resurgence in Americans' appetite for stock funds. Cash flows fell sharply in March and early April, as a sharp drop in the price of stocks of smaller companies was followed by a decline in the broader market, which chased investors to the sidelines.
But stock prices began to rise again last month as some of the country's biggest corporations reported favorable first-quarter earnings, attracting new cash through May and into this month.
In all likelihood, the market's rise and the May cash flows pushed stock fund assets past $2 trillion for the first time. That would mark a doubling of stock fund assets in just two years. Stock fund assets surpassed $1 trillion in May 1995, 55 years after the passage of the Investment Company Act of 1940, the statute that marked the formal beginning of the mutual fund industry.
Bond prices, too, have risen since mid-April, as investors began to anticipate, correctly, as it turned out, that the Federal Reserve would not raise short-term interest rates in May. That, too, has hastened the demand for bond mutual funds, which last month added $2.5 billion in new cash, the most in any month since January, according to the Investment Company Institute.
In some recent instances, the demand for mutual fund shares has taken on the look of a feeding frenzy. Last week, Aim Management Group, which manages the Aim Family of Funds, reopened the Aim Aggressive Growth fund, allowing new investors to buy shares for the first time in two years.
Aim had planned to keep the fund, which had $2.5 billion in assets, open until it attracted $500 million in new assets. That much was contributed in less than a day, and Aim closed the fund again after only two days, in which the fund added $688 million in new assets.
Last week marked the second time in two years that the Aim Aggressive Growth fund was flooded with money in a two-day span. In July 1995, when the fund last opened to new investors, $1 billion flowed in over two days. But at the time, aggressive growth funds, which invest in stocks of small, fast-growing companies, were much more in favor among fund investors.
In contrast, aggressive-growth funds as a category have been shunned by investors through much of this spring, after a downturn in small stocks. In March, for example, aggressive growth funds added only $144 million in new cash, the lowest monthly total in more than four years.
The growth in mutual fund investing has also created a bull market for the companies that manage the funds, an industry that is undergoing mergers and acquisitions at a rapid pace. Analysts expect what could be the biggest-ever fund company takeover to be announced any day now: Scudder, Stevens & Clark, parent of the Scudder family of mutual funds, is in talks to be acquired by Zurich Insurance Group, people close to the talks have said.
Analysts say the rapid consolidation among fund companies is being driven in part by a desire by foreign financial services companies -- like Zurich Insurance, which is based in Switzerland -- to gain access to American investors and markets. In that regard, the trend parallels the rise in sentiment that has occurred among foreign investors in their attitude toward United States equities.
After steadily building their holdings of American stocks through the 1980's, to a high of 7.2 percent of the total in 1989, foreign holdings slipped to less than 6 percent in 1994. The sharp jump in the first quarter of this year, reported yesterday in the Federal Reserve's report, took the percentage back up to 6.5 percent.
That could be a mixed blessing, said Ms. Brown, the analyst at Prudential Securities. "Historically, foreigners have not been the best market timers," she said, noting that several months after foreign holdings of United States stocks peaked in 1989, the Dow industrials suffered their steepest decline since the crash of 1987. That was also the last time the Dow industrials has fallen 10 percent from an all-time high.

HEADLINE: THE RENT BATTLE: THE OVERVIEW;
Behind the Lines in the Rent War, Cautious Motion Toward a Treaty

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 12

 BODY:
Beneath the deeply pessimistic tone of the rent debate, negotiators have actually begun serious deliberations on proposals that could prevent the rules from expiring on Sunday. Officials on both sides of the fight said today that Democrats are now privately displaying greater openness than in the past about helping landlords increase rents on some apartments.
The negotiators have been focusing their discussions on ways of allowing landlords to bring rents closer to market levels on regulated apartments that become vacant. Current laws place strict limits on rent increases for vacated units, but landlords contend those restrictions must be lifted to end huge price disparities in the market. 
 On the surface, the issue has seemed insoluble. Republicans, led by Gov. George E. Pataki, have advocated deregulating apartments once tenants move out or die, a policy known as vacancy decontrol. Democrats, led by Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, have rejected vacancy decontrol out of hand, saying it would end all rent regulations over time as more and more units turned over.
But behind closed doors, negotiators for both sides have shown greater flexibility than has been expressed by their leaders in public. Democrats have floated ideas about mechanisms to enable landlords some increases on vacant apartments, but less than could be obtained on the open market. And Republicans have proposed a number of partial vacancy decontrol ideas, ranging from applying the policy only to small buildings or high-priced apartments, to spreading out market-rate rent increases over extended periods of time.
So far, none of those ideas has stuck. But officials in both parties say they believe that if vacancy decontrol can be resolved, the other outstanding issues -- such as lifting protections for wealthy tenants -- will fall into place. And there is a widespread sense among legislators in both parties that if Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican Senate majority leader who has been Albany's staunchest advocate for vacancy decontrol, plays a smaller role in the endgame talks -- as recent actions have suggested -- the way could be paved for a compromise.
But the negotiators still face a tall political hurdle: structuring a deal that allows all sides to declare victory. Democrats have so staunchly opposed vacancy decontrol that they would find it difficult to accept anything that even faintly smacks of the policy, lest they come under fierce attack by an important constituency, tenants groups. Republicans have been so adamant about bringing a gradual end to rent regulations that a complete retreat from vacancy decontrol would be widely viewed as a political embarrassment.
Still, negotiators have expressed very guarded optimism that a deal can be struck that would allow Republicans to contend that they had brought free-market reforms to New York City's rental system and Democrats to proclaim that they had kept tenant protections largely intact, thereby protecting the middle class.
The question is: can they do it by the end of the day on June 15, when the laws, which set rent ceilings for more than one million apartments, are to expire? "I don't know that anyone has found the answer yet, but I'm confident we will," said one Republican official, speaking on condition of anonymity. "I just don't think that it will be by the 15th."
Though aides to the Governor and legislative leaders met today, there were no major negotiations on rent because Mr. Silver was observing the Jewish holiday of Shavuot. The leaders were scheduled to resume their talks on Friday morning.
Both houses of the Legislature are to return to Albany on Sunday night just a few hours before the laws are set to expire, giving themselves enough time to pass a bill if Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders reach an agreement. The Legislature could also pass a short-term extension of the current laws to buy negotiators time to iron out their differences. But Mr. Bruno has said he will block any extensions of the existing law. If the Legislature does nothing, the laws will lapse.
Officials in both parties say that Mr. Silver's chief negotiator, Fred Jacobs, has rejected Republican proposals on vacancy decontrol during the closed-door negotiations. But that has not prevented discussion about other ideas that might achieve some of the goals of vacancy decontrol -- namely, providing ways for landlords with regulated units to increase their income -- without actually decontrolling large numbers of units.
One idea that Democrats have tentatively advanced would be to increase what is known as the vacancy bonus already allowed under law for regulated units that become vacant. But the two sides have been sharply divided over the size of the bonus, who would set it and how expansive the policy should be: Republicans want it applied to all regulated units; Democrats want it restricted to a small number of apartments.
Another idea that has been promoted by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani during talks with Legislative leaders would be to allow vacancy decontrol for high-rent apartments. Current law allows units that rent for over $2000 a month to be decontrolled if vacated. The policy could be expanded by lowering that threshold to, say, $1750 a month or lower.
Democrats have been opposed to that idea on the grounds that, with time and inflation, the majority of apartments will fall into this category. To address that concern, they have discussed the idea of lowering the threshold, but then allowing it to rise again according to an index tied to the inflation rate. So far, Republicans have balked at that idea.
Republicans have floated proposals to apply vacancy decontrol only to small buildings, for example, those with 10 units or less, and to allow landlords to bring rents on vacated units to market levels, but only over long periods of time. So far, Democrats have been unwilling to accept either. But the fact that they continue to talk has kept Republican hopes for compromise alive.
Many Republicans also say that as the deadline approaches, Mr. Silver might soften out of concern that Democrats, too, will be blamed for the laws lapsing. "You won't see any meaningful dialogue until the final hours," Senator Nicholas Spano, a Westchester Republican, said.
Many Republicans contend that Mr. Silver, the state's most powerful Democrat, wants the laws to expire on the theory that frightened tenants will punish Mr. Pataki and other Republican officials at the polls for any pain, panic or problems that might ensue after June 15.
Aides to Mr. Silver, while acknowledging that they think Republicans will bear the brunt of voters' wrath if the laws lapse, deny any partisan motivations, saying the Democrats are simply fighting to protect the rent laws.

HEADLINE: Giddings & Lewis Accepts $675 Million Merger Bid From Thyssen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Escaping a hostile takeover bid, Giddings & Lewis Inc., a Wisconsin maker of machine tools and assembly line equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by Thyssen A.G. for $675 million.
Thyssen, a diversified German steelmaker, offered $21 a share in a bid endorsed by Giddings's directors. Thyssen also will assume the debt of the company, which Giddings said was $25 million to $35 million. 
 The offer tops a $631 million bid made by Harnischfeger Industries, also a Wisconsin maker of machine tools, that was rejected last month.
The acquisition would give Thyssen a manufacturing base in the United States, while Giddings would benefit from the larger company's global presence and common ties to the automobile industry.
"The deal will allow Giddings management to continue their strategy of selling machine tools globally," Donald Liptak, an analyst with Barrington Research, said.
The Thyssen bid represents an 11 percent premium over yesterday's closing price for Giddings stock. Shares of Giddings rose $1.7344, to $20.7344, on the Nasdaq yesterday.
Harnischfeger will not pursue its tender offer "if Thyssen's bid for $21 per share proves bona fide to us," Harnischfeger's chief executive, Jeffrey Grade, said yesterday.
Harnischfeger began a $19-a-share hostile takeover bid on April 28, when Giddings shares were trading at $13.675.
Giddings and Thyssen began negotiating soon after, said Giddings's chief executive, Marvin Isles. While Giddings could still consider other offers, he added, it would have to pay a $23 million fee to cancel the agreement.
Directors unanimously accepted the Thyssen bid, Mr. Isles said.
The acquisition is part of Thyssen's strategy to expand internationally to offset Germany's sluggish economy. The transaction would give its Thyssen Industrie capital goods unit its first manufacturing plant in the United States, where labor costs are lower than in Germany.
Thyssen had sales of $26.2 billion last year, including $3.2 billion in the United States.
Giddings, with a 1996 loss of $12.5 million on sales of $700 million, makes assembly line machinery, primarily for auto makers including the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation.
The loss last year is not a concern because Giddings has a solid balance sheet, Ann-Pascale Wiedenroth, a Thyssen spokeswoman, said.
"G.& L. had some problems, but we believe these are largely behind them," she said. "We certainly expect them to be profitable this year."
Under the purchase agreement, Giddings will continue to operate under its own name although management control will rest with Thyssen Industrie.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Retail Sales Slow, Helping Markets Rise Again
Retail sales dropped unexpectedly last month and have now declined for three months in a row, the Government said. 
 Economists and investors are still debating whether this slowdown is permanent or just a breather before another surge in consumer spending. But investors took the view that the economy was slowing from a potentially inflationary pace of growth, pushing the stock and bond markets higher. [Page D3.]
 
The bull market has been driven in large part by the surge in the popularity of mutual funds. American investors have now committed more than half of their fund assets to stocks, double the level at the beginning of the decade. And foreign investors, too, have significantly raised their holdings of American stocks. [A1.]
 
The decline in retail sales eased bond traders' worries about the possibility that the Fed might raise interest rates next month. Treasury prices rose sharply, and the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 6.77 percent from 6.83. [D18.]
 
Electrolux Plans Big Cutbacks
Electrolux of Sweden, the maker of Frigidaire appliances, said it would lay off about 12,000 workers and close 24 factories and 50 warehouses. The restructuring, which will focus on Europe, where the company is the largest appliance maker, reflects a trend in which global manufacturers are consolidating operations there. [D2.]
 
Dressed for the Street
Shares in Polo Ralph Lauren surged when trading began yesterday. The shares closed at $31.50, 21 percent higher than the initial public offering price of $26, and they were the most active issue on American markets. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Thyssen to Buy U.S. Tool Maker
Giddings & Lewis, a Wisconsin tool maker, agreed to be acquired by Thyssen of Germany for $675 million. The deal tops a hostile bid of $631 million from Harnischfeger Industries of Wisconsin. An acquisition would give Thyssen, a steelmaker, a manufacturing base in the United States. [D4.]
 
Support for a Tobacco Settlement
Four major public health organizations offered their strongest support yet for a legal settlement with the nation's cigarette manufacturers, creating further divisions in the already discordant body of anti-smoking advocates. [A12.]
 
Dollar Rebounds Against Yen
The dollar snapped a weeklong decline with the biggest one-day jump against the yen in nearly two years after Japan's top foreign-exchange policy maker said the yen was too strong. The dollar rose by 3.05 yen, or 2.7 percent. [D15.]
 
Wheat prices fell sharply after the Government said a late frost left the winter wheat crop largely undamaged. [D15.]
Drug Giants in Biotechnology Deals
Schering-Plough and Eli Lilly signed deals with small biotechnology companies -- Corvas International, in Schering's case, and Vertex Pharmaceuticals, in Lilly's -- to co-develop drugs for the treatment of hepatitis C. [D6.]
 
Spanish Financier Is Acquitted
The former president of the Rumasa business empire of Spain was acquitted on two counts of forgery. The ruling could put to rest a long-running legal battle over the once-giant conglomerate, taken over 14 years ago by a Government that said the company was on the verge of failure. [D8.]
 
Health-Program Overhaul Advances
A Congressional committee approved major changes in Medicare and Medicaid, including new protections for the elderly and the poor who enroll in health maintenance organizations. [A22.]

HEADLINE: Lawmaker Says Huang Passed Secret Data

BYLINE: By DON VAN NATTA Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
A Republican Congressman said today that intelligence information showed that while working at the Commerce Department, John Huang, who has become a central figure in the Democratic fund-raising scandal, passed classified Government data to his former employer, the Lippo Group of Indonesia.
The Congressman, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of New York, accused Mr. Huang of breaching the United States' national security and committing "economic espionage." 
 The accusation is the first in which a Government official has publicly alleged strong intelligence evidence that any figure in the fund-raising scandal passed along official secrets, an issue that is under investigation by the Justice Department and five Congressional committees, including the House Rules Committee, headed by Mr. Solomon.
The accusation was leveled by Mr. Solomon in a statement issued by his office.
"I have received reports from Government sources," the statement said, "that say there are electronic intercepts which provide evidence confirming what I suspected all along, that John Huang committed economic espionage and breached our national security by passing classified information to his former employer, the Lippo Group."
The statement did not give the sources of the electronic messages, when they were intercepted, the particular information Mr. Huang is suspected of disclosing or the identity of the "Government sources" cited by Mr. Solomon. "I can't go any farther than that," his statement said.
Bill Teator, an aide to Mr. Solomon, said that in fact the Congressman had not been told any more about the messages.
"That is the next phase" of the Rules Committee's investigation, Mr. Teator said. "We want to find out how much farther this went, and whom exactly did the information go to, and what precisely the information was."
Ty Cobb and John C. Keeney Jr., Mr. Huang's lawyers, did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
Mr. Huang held a mid-level job atthe Commerce Department before becoming a leading fund-raiser for the Democratic National Committee during the 1996 Presidential campaign. He left the committee last October, and, although he has denied through his lawyers that he is guilty of any wrongdoing, he has otherwise declined to comment about the mounting number of accusations against him, among them that he illegally funneled foreign money to the party.
Mr. Solomon's further accusation today took many investigators by surprise. Several senators declined to discuss it.
At her weekly news conference, Attorney General Janet Reno was asked whether the new development would bring either a heightened inquiry into Mr. Huang's activities or a new inquiry, into Mr. Solomon's disclosure of what the Congressman described as intelligence information.
"I have just heard about the Congressman's comments," Ms. Reno replied, "so I couldn't really say one way or the other. People should not comment about pending investigations and pending prosecutions."
While the new accusation by Mr. Solomon was something of a milestone, he had already been in hot pursuit of Mr. Huang for some time. He had previously said that phone logs and other records turned over to his committee showed that while at the Commerce Department, Mr. Huang often telephoned the Lippo Group's Los Angeles office within hours of receiving classified data.
And in a letter sent on Tuesday to Louis J. Freeh, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Mr. Solomon asked for a "damage assessment."
"Mr. Huang may have had even more exposure to classified information than we had previously known," the Congressman wrote. "Apparently, Mr. Huang not only had access to classified information at the White House, but also to State Department message traffic through a computer network of the Commerce Department because of his political appointment."
While working for 18 months as a Clinton Administration appointee at Commerce, Mr. Huang held a "top secret" security clearance. Officials of the department have told Mr. Solomon's committee that Mr. Huang attended 109 meetings at which classified information may have been discussed, including 37 intelligence briefings.
Mr. Solomon's aides said today that it was assumed Mr. Huang passed on classified information to Lippo during this time. Before joining the Commerce Department, Mr. Huang had been the chief of American operations for Lippo, a $12 billion financial conglomerate run by the Riady family of Indonesia, longtime political supporters of President Clinton.
In his job at Commerce, Mr. Huang was involved in developing commercial opportunities in his native Taiwan. But he was frustrated, colleagues say, because he had few dealings with the department's International Trade Administration on commercial relations with China, Indonesia and other major emerging markets.
Still, Mr. Huang frequently sat in on mid-level meetings on those markets, according to some records released by the department. He also regularly received classified briefings from the officers of the Central Intelligence Agency who were liaisons at Commerce. It is unclear whether the contents of some of those briefings are a subject of the current investigations.
Lippo has broad financial interests in Indonesia, Hong Kong and China, and may have been interested in information about major commercial ventures in any of those countries, although its own network of informers, many believe, was probably ahead of the Commerce Department.
"It's possible John was passing on something of value," one of his former colleagues said today. "Or it's possible he was simply trying to boast to Lippo about his access."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Twins Plan to Test The Marketplace

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, June 12

 BODY:
The Minnesota Twins, frustrated that the State Government has not approved a new park, received permission today from Major League Baseball to talk to buyers who might want to move the franchise after the 1998 season.
Calling the Metrodome an "economic albatross," the acting commissioner, Bud Selig, said new revenue-sharing rules had increased pressure to make more teams competitive. 
 "It's not possible to remain economically viable in the Metrodome," Selig said. "We can't sit and let a club sink into a morass of economic failure that dooms a franchise."
Carl Pohlad, the owner of the Twins, said he had not spoken with any buyers, and declined to say if he would keep the team and attempt to move it.
In the only significant action taken during the two-day meetings here, owners extended the contracts of the American League president, Gene Budig, and the National League president, Len Coleman, by three years, through 2002.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Cone, the Super Fan, Looking for a Playoff Atmosphere

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Appropriately and perhaps adeptly, David Cone will be the first Yankee to pitch in an interleague skirmish when New York opposes the Florida Marlins in Miami tonight. But if you listen to Cone discuss the event, he sounds more like a public relations director for the virtues of the American League against the National League than a pitcher in a historic game.
Over and over yesterday, Cone repeated his sermon about the tingly feelings he expects to experience and expects others to feel now that clubs from baseball's opposite leagues are playing games before the World Series for the first time. Cone sounded like a super flak who is a super fan. 
 "I think the fans are going to make it special," said Cone. "You're going to have a lot of electricity in the stands. The fans are going to be into it. To me, fans can dictate the atmosphere. They can make it a playoff-type atmosphere. They can pump up players."
Not every player shared Cone's sentiments.
"It's just another game," said Mariano Rivera. "It doesn't matter."
An unfazed Cecil Fielder added: "I'm not overjoyed about it. It's on the schedule so you go play."
But while several of Cone's teammates called the journey to Pro Player Stadium just another trip in a long season, the pitcher insisted there was something important about tonight's contest and something extraordinary about the three-game series with the Mets that begins Monday night at Yankee Stadium. Cone claimed fans will love the new matchups and he made an astounding 16 references to fans in a 10-minute interview. Such lavish attention to fans has not been voiced since an overzealous 12-year-old poked his glove over the right-field fence for a huge impact on last year's American League Championship Series.
"There's an element of excitement in the air," said Cone, who will oppose Al Leiter, a former Yankee. "I think the fans are into this experiment. I think the excitement will be up. I think the attendance will be up."
Cone has that right, for all three games in Miami this weekend and all three at Yankee Stadium next week are sold out. The Marlins have been averaging 28,229 fans a game, but the interleague contests will average 41,855, an inflation that was surely influenced by the Yankees' having trained in nearby Fort Lauderdale, Fla., from 1962 to 1995. The Yankees have averaged 25,369, but the encounters with the rival Mets in the Bronx will average 57,545.
"If you're a Yankee or a Met fan, you've been waiting for this for your whole life," said Joe Girardi, looking to Monday.
But before the Yankees tangle with the Mets in the series that George Steinbrenner -- and Steinbrenner alone -- probably considers the most pivotal of the season, they must tussle with Florida. The Marlins (37-26), who are in second place in the National League East, have a better record than the defending World Series champion Yankees (36-27), who are second in the American League East. But the records are not relevant.
"There are Yankee fans everywhere we go," said Cone. "You know there will be a lot of transplanted New Yorkers there."
Cone is the perfect pitcher in this spot because he has a National League background from six years with the Mets and because attention-grabbing games never bother him. But it might bother him to bat in a National League park; the last time he did that in a regular-season game was Aug. 23, 1992. Cone, who had 61 hits in 395 at-bats (.154 average) for the Mets, is not predicting miracles.
"The most important thing is getting down a bunt," Cone said. "The chances of our pitchers getting a hit is pretty remote."
There will be no designated hitter in the series, so Manager Joe Torre has the ticklish choice of picking between Fielder and Tino Martinez at first base. Since Leiter is the only left-hander starting for Florida, the right-handed Fielder (1 for 12 off Leiter) might start over Martinez (1 for 9) tonight.
"I'm not a fan of this," said Torre. "But I think it's going to be electric out there. I think the fans are going to be into it. As much against it as I am, I think this stuff is going to be fun."
 
INSIDE PITCH
General Manager BOB WATSON said DARRYL STRAWBERRY, who is testing his injured left knee at Class AAA Columbus, would not be activated this weekend. While Strawberry slugged a pair of homers in his first three games, he is still running cautiously because of inflamed cartilage and seems doubtful for the series with the Mets. . . . TIM RAINES (strained left hamstring) can be activated Tuesday and said he would join the Yankees on Sunday.

HEADLINE: Algeria's Vote Was Valid

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Algeria's Sham Election" (editorial, June 7) ignores the fact that Algerian voters courageously demonstrated their sovereign will. The international observers monitoring the June 5 legislative elections did not share your view, since they noted only a few minor shortcomings that did not affect the validity of the vote. 
 Contrary to what you recommend, the solution to the crisis in Algeria is the exclusive business of the Algerians themselves, and is now within reach. It stems naturally from advances made by the pluralistic democratic process, like the June 5 vote, from bold economic reforms and from maintaining the peace through the efforts of the state and the people. The Algeria of today and tomorrow has no room for terrorism and for those who use it as political leverage. It is regrettable that you again missed the opportunity to acknowledge the efforts and sacrifices that Algeria has made for democracy.
 
RAMTAME LAMAMRA
Washington, June 9, 1997
 
Ambassador of Algeria
