HEADLINE: Scots' Payoff in Labor's Victory Is Likely to Be Own Parliament

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: EDINBURGH

 BODY:
Are the Scots really different from the English? "You got a week to spend?" said Tim Russell, a 46-year-old construction worker in this city of wide avenues and deeply felt history, warming recently to one of his favorite subjects.
As he outlined his case against the English (they're cultural snobs and political bullies; they imposed the ill-fated poll tax on Scotland a year earlier than on the rest of Britain), he paused. 
 "It's bred deeply inside of us," he said, in a Scots accent so thick it all but proved his point. "Why are Americans American, and not English? It's the same principle."
For Scots like Mr. Russell, the resounding Labor victory in the general election last month did more than just sweep away a Conservative Government that was seen by many here as indifferent, if not hostile, to Scotland's singular culture and special needs. It also turned an old dream of a separate Scottish parliament into almost certain reality.
Many Scots argue that the current political system, in which Scotland is answerable to the national Parliament in London, puts them at a disadvantage. This feeling is compounded by the fact that in three successive elections the Scots voted overwhelmingly for the Labor Party, only to see the Conservatives return to power in London.
"The mistake the Tories made, and a grievous mistake it was, was to underestimate the Scots' desire for a change," said Magnus Linklater, a former editor of The Scotsman, a daily newspaper. "The more the Tories refused to bend, the more convinced the Scots became that they wanted their own parliament."
But Tony Blair, the new Labor Prime Minister, has made the issue one of his top priorities. Under Labor's plan, the Scots are to vote this fall in a referendum that poses two questions: Do you want a separate Scottish parliament? Should it have the power to tax?
Recent opinion polls show that a majority of people would vote yes on both counts, and that immediately raises a third, thornier question: how would power be divided between the new Scottish parliament and the Parliament in London?
"The worst mistake would be a timid wee Scottish parliament with no real powers and no ability to change anything," Mr. Linklater said. The new parliament, he said, must be strong enough to stand up to the arguments of Scottish nationalists, who favor a complete break from Britain.
Scottish nationalism has been on the increase in the last decade or so, gaining momentum as the period of Conservative rule wore on.
Scottish sports fans wear kilts, paint their faces in Scottish colors and sing "Flower of Scotland" instead of "God Save the Queen" at sports events. Artists and writers like James Kelman, who won the Booker Prize in 1994 for "How Late It Was, How Late," a novel written in dense Glaswegian dialect, have made the case for a separate Scottish culture, arguing that Scots are overlooked and condescended to by London's Anglocentric cultural elite.
Looming on a hill over Edinburgh is the Old Royal High School, renamed New Parliament House -- an empty building that awaits the convening of a Scottish parliament and stands as a stony, silent reminder of what many Scots aspire to. And the Scottish National Party, caught up in a tide that sees more and more Scots identifying themselves in polls as Scots first and Britons second, increased its presence in Parliament last month, winning six seats, up from four.
"We got very hostile treatment under the Thatcher Government," said John Swinney, one of the party's new members of Parliament. What separates the Scots from the English, he said, is their view that social justice is just as important as economic wealth.
"Now we're wrestling with the social problems created by the greedy society that Thatcher created, and there's a growing confidence in Scotland that we should be determining more of own own affairs," he said.
With a population of just 5.1 million people spread thinly over a land of rough terrain and harsh weather, Scotland has greater economic needs per capita than England, whose population is 48.9 million.
The British Government says the Scots receive more from the Treasury than they contribute. But the Scottish National Party, pointing to Scotland's expanding economy and rich natural resources, including gas and oil, says that is not true at all. In fact, argued Andrew Wilson, a party economist, from 1979 to 1995 Scotland paid some $43.2 billion more into the Treasury than it got back.
The nationalists' arguments play on Scotland and England's historical antagonism (after centuries of fighting, the two countries merged their crowns in 1603, and their parliaments a century later), and on some deeply held Scottish beliefs about the role of the state and political culture.
"Scots are somewhat more community oriented, more egalitarian and meritocratic," said Lindsay Patterson, a professor of educational policy at Heriot-Watt University here and the author of "The Autonomy of Modern Scotland." "In Scotland there is a greater skepticism of the state. Scots say that the state can be an agent to support volunteerism, in the tradition of Presbyterian democracy."
Members of the Scottish Conservative Party, still reeling from an election that cost them all of their seats in Parliament, play down the differences and emphasize the similarities between Scotland and England.
"The shared political institutions of the last 300 years have been more successful than perhaps in any other part of the world," said Malcolm Rifkind, who was the British Defense Secretary until the Tories were routed in last month's election. He also lost his seat in Parliament.
He and others say that a new parliament would actually strip Scotland of power, by inevitably bringing about a reduction in state financing. The Scottish Office, based in London, currently administers a budget of some $22.9 billion a year according to a population-based formula that was set in 1978 and that many feel is disproportionately generous to Scotland.
In addition, they say, Scotland might well lose some of its 72 seats in the British Parliament, and the Scottish Secretary, a powerful Cabinet minister who oversees the Scottish Office and is Scotland's most powerful champion in London, might see his authority pared down as well.
"Now, the Secretary of State for Scotland has a large civil service; he's got muscle," said Jackson Carlaw, deputy chairman of the Scottish Conservative Party. "Under these proposals, he'll sit there like an emperor without any clothes. He'll have no budget and no staff. Instead of a huge civil service, he'll have a chauffeur and company car."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Scottish nationalism has been on the rise in the last decade. At sports events, fans often wear kilts and paint their faces in Scottish colors. (Simon Bruty/Still Moving Picture Company)
 
Map showing the location of Edinburgh, Scotland: An old school building in Edinburgh awaits a new parliament.

HEADLINE: Bonds Surge for a Second Day As Producer Price Index Falls

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
An unexpected drop in the Producer Price Index for May sent bond prices surging yesterday for the second consecutive day. It also bolstered investor confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates next month.
Treasury securities rallied from the drop in the price index, a measure of prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers. The overall number, and the core number, which excludes food and energy, fell three-tenths of 1 percent in May from April. Analysts had expected a more modest decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. It was the first time since 1952 that the index had declined for five consecutive months. 
 The 30-year bond rose 20/32 , to a price of 9825/32 , and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.72 percent, from 6.77 percent on Thursday.
The Government also reported yesterday that business inventories rose three-tenths of 1 percent in April, more than the two-tenths of 1 percent analysts had expected.
And in another report, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment preliminary June index, rose to 103.4, from 103.2 a month earlier. Some market participants are worried that bubbling consumer confidence and a tight labor market could keep the economy from slowing, which could lead to a Fed tightening in the near term.
But as for inflation, the picture remained rosy. Kenneth J. McCarthy, the founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, an economic consulting and forecasting firm, said: "The inflationary pressures continue to recede as declining energy prices reversed their modest increase of 1996. The inflation environment remains as good as it has been in 30-plus years."
The decline in the price index, he said, was broad based, indicating that manufacturers' efforts to reduce costs were continuing even as wage rates were edging higher.
"It points out the fallacy of focusing too much on wages as a driver of inflation," Mr. McCarthy said. "Clearly, this report taken with yesterday's decline in May retail sales and the increase in April inventories shows an economy with slowing demand and not a hint of inflationary pressures."
Short-term interest rates, the most sensitive to changes in Fed policy, have fallen the most in recent days, widening the spread between shorter maturities and longer maturies. The spread between the two-year note and the 30-year bond was 69 basis points on Monday; yesterday that spread was 71 basis points. A basis points is one-hundredth of a percentage point. Traders say the spread widens when a growing number of market participants expect the Fed to stand pat or even reduce rates.
In the fixed-income market, South Africa and corporate issuers, including Pacalta Resources Ltd. and the Di Giorgio Corporation plan to sell a combined $1.4 billion in debt. Already in the last two weeks, $19 billion of corporate debt has been priced in the public market and even with the wave of new supply, corporate bonds have maintained their value, an indication of good demand.

HEADLINE: Election-Minded Republicans Try to Join Together

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 11

 BODY:
A national Republican political action committee that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman helped create and then led for five years has been refashioning itself in recent weeks, changing its name and its mission in an effort to broaden its appeal among Republicans.
Now known as the Republican Leadership Council, the organization is being reshaped in the image of the Democratic Leadership Council, the group started in 1985 by centrist Democrats who wanted to pull the party away from liberal influence toward the center of the political spectrum. The Republican council is trying to counter the conservative orthodoxies in its party and move it toward the center. 
 Organizers of the new council said that it was not set up to explore a potential Presidential bid for Mrs. Whitman or any other particular candidate. But they said they did hope that the group could duplicate the success of its Democratic counterpart, which helped to propel Bill Clinton into the White House.
"If we're successful, we'll be able to impact the selection of the next nominee and the election of a Presidential candidate," said Lewis M. Eisenberg, a financier who was appointed chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey by Governor Whitman and is now chairman of the new group.
A major part of the group's effort involves trying to unite party members despite their differing views on abortion -- the issue that has torn at the Republican Party's soul in recent years. The original organization, called the Committee for Responsible Government, supported a woman's right to choose an abortion. The new committee has recruited Republicans who oppose abortion, among them Gov. John Engler of Michigan and Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona.
The purpose, Mr. Engler said in a recent interview, is not to change any minds on the abortion issue, but to figure out how to win more elections. "Governor Whitman's position and Governor Engler's position are different" with regard to abortion, Mr. Engler said. "But I think we've moved beyond that. The goal now is to elect more Republicans."
Mr. Eisenberg agreed with Mr. Engler's analysis. "We're really trying to unite the Republican Party," he said. "The message that we're carrying is that the Republican Leadership Council consists of Republicans who are pro-life and pro-choice."
While trying to defuse the abortion issue, the council members say they want to emphasize that they stand for smaller and smarter government, lower taxes, environmental quality without onerous regulations, school vouchers and tough punishments for criminals.
The Republican organization, unlike its Democratic namesake, is a political action committee with the legal authority to raise money. Before it was reorganized, the group raised about $2 million over more than four years. In recent weeks, it raised about $1 million more as Mrs. Whitman and other political and financial leaders from around the country gathered for fund-raising events in Washington and New York.
The council intends, Mr. Eisenberg said, to give financial support -- both through direct contributions and campaign advertising -- to "common-sense conservatives." Given the party's rather tenuous hold on Congress, Mr. Eisenberg said he hoped the organization could have a major impact on elections in 1998, which he called "a major year in the House and Senate."
The organization's expansion also comes as the party's conservative wing is going through a transition. Ralph Reed, responsible for building the Christian Coalition from a fringe group into a powerful force in the Republican Party, has announced that he will leave as head of the group in September to start his own political consulting firm. He said his clientele would be Christian-oriented candidates who are "pro-family, pro-life, pro-free enterprise."
Because of her current re-election campaign and the potential for conflicts with New Jersey's campaign finance rules, Mrs. Whitman is not playing any official role in the new Republican Leadership Council. But along with Bob Dole, Mrs. Whitman was co-host at the organization's official inauguration in Washington in April. She also spoke to the 100 or so guests who attended the $1,000-a-ticket event, held at the home of Julie Finley, the chairwoman of the local Republican party.
Organizers of the group said that they expected Mrs. Whitman to become involved after this year's gubernatorial race. Asked about the new council and its potential to help Governor Whitman seek national office, a spokesman for Mrs. Whitman, Pete McDonough, said it was too early to say whether she might want to be part of a Presidential ticket in 2000. "Only time will tell," Mr. McDonough said. "Right now she doesn't have the fire in the belly."
What both the Republican and Democratic leadership councils have in common is their formation when members of their parties felt they were in danger of being seen as out of touch with a majority of American voters. By the early 1990's, when the Democratic council picked up party support, Democrats had not been in the White House for longer than a decade. Although Republicans now control both houses of Congress, their strength in the House weakened in the last election. And they have been closed out of the White House since 1992.
The Republican Leadership Council has its roots in the Republican National Convention of 1992 in Houston. As the party's right wing waged war on the convention floor before a national television audience, a group of Republican leaders from the mostly moderate Northeast winced at the influence of the party's hard-core conservatives. Mr. Eisenberg recalled the reaction of his two daughters, teen-agers at the time. "They were ready to become Democrats," he said.
Soon thereafter, Mr. Eisenberg, who was a major fund-raiser for Mrs. Whitman in 1993 and Mr. Dole's New Jersey finance chairman in 1996, joined Mrs. Whitman and other politicians from the region, including Susan Molinari, a Congresswoman from New York, and Richard A. Zimmer, then a New Jersey Congressman, to start a political action committee called the Committee for Responsible Government. Mrs. Whitman was chairwoman of the group's board of governors. Also on the board were William F. Weld, Governor of Massachusetts, and Connecticut's Governor, John G. Rowland. The group raised about $2 million, much of it from a 1995 event in New York at which Mrs. Whitman delivered the keynote speech.
But that organization said in its mission statement that "freedom of choice for women" on abortion was one of its "guiding principles." Now, many of the party's moderates have decided that it may be more pragmatic for them to figure out a way to get along despite their disparate views. The new group's "statement of direction" says it "believes in the importance of protecting individual rights and of promoting strong families," and makes no mention of the issue of choice.
At a meeting last month at the Upper East Side home of Henry R. Kravis, the financier, about 50 Republican politicians and well-heeled business people from 16 states -- including Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, Edgar Bronfman Sr., chairman of the Seagram Corporation, and Georgette Mosbacher, the socialite and beauty-products entrepreneur -- talked about "bringing the party back together and more toward the center," Mr. Kravis said later in an interview.
Mr. Kravis -- he is co-chairman of the organization along with John A. Moran, Bob Dole's 1996 campaign finance chairman -- said he had personally grown "very concerned that the party was being split apart," adding, "We were starting to become, because of the pull to the right, the party in which, if you didn't believe with the far right, there was no room for you." As a first step toward building the organization, the guests at Mr. Kravis's home pulled out their checkbooks. More than $750,000 was raised through donations and pledges at the event, according to council officials.
Still, this reconfigured and redefined organization has a big task ahead. Many Republicans see its members as wolves in sheep's clothing, liberals masquerading as Republicans. "Most of these folks describe themselves as economic conservatives and cultural liberals," said Gary Bauer, president of the Family Research Council, an antiabortion public policy group based in Washington. "The problem is, other than a few states in the Northeast, there's very little to show that that's a winning combination."
In addition to moving the Republican Party more toward the center, one of the council's other goals is to make the party more racially diverse. But so far only two of the 40 or so board and executive committee members are racial minorities. Gen. Colin L. Powell has refused an invitation. But Mr. Eisenberg said he planned to ask other members of minority groups to join. "Separate and apart from raising money," he said, "we have to reach out to women and minorities. In order to be a national party, we have to rid ourselves of the perceptions that scare away voters."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell Again in May

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The conventional wisdom that low unemployment leads inexorably to rising prices took another hit yesterday as the Government reported that an important measure intended to detect early signs of inflation fell in May, the fifth consecutive month to show a decline.
It was the first time the measure -- the Producer Price Index for finished goods -- had registered a five-month drop since 1952. This year's performance comes despite more than six years of uninterrupted growth that has pushed the jobless rate down to 4.8 percent. 
 Coupled with data released earlier this week showing continued weakness in retail sales, analysts said yesterday's inflation report made it more likely that policy makers at the Federal Reserve Board would keep short-term interest rates steady at their next scheduled meeting in early July.
"The Fed will look at these numbers as encouraging signs that there is not much inflation in the pipeline," said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "Inflation remains benign despite tight labor markets."
Led by steep decreases in the costs of automobiles and computers, prices paid to American manufacturers and other producers fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
The drop, which pulled inflation at the producer level down to just three-tenths of 1 percent over the last 12 months, set off another day of sharp rallies in financial markets. The Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 70 points to close at a record 7,782.04, while the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.72 percent, from 6.77 on Thursday. Most market analysts had been expecting the Producer Price Index to show a slight rise.
Even excluding food and energy prices, which can register sharp monthly fluctuations, the index still registered a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent.
So far this year, producer prices have declined at an annual rate of 3.9 percent, in contrast to an increase of 2.2 percent for the first five months of 1996.
The so-called core rate, which excludes food and energy prices, has fallen less sharply, but is still down seven-tenths of 1 percent at an annual rate. For the first five months of last year, the core rate rose at an annual rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
"This is a continuation of a pattern we have seen for some time, where finished-goods prices and the core rate are either very, very stable or slightly negative," said Kenneth Dalton, associate commissioner for prices and living conditions at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles and publishes the data on prices.
With producer prices down, the next report on consumer prices, scheduled to be released Tuesday, is also expected to be benign.
Before now, producer prices had not shown five months of decline since the period from August through December 1952.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said yesterday that stocks of unsold goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent in April, mainly because of a pileup of items on retailers' shelves that reflected the recently reported slowdown in sales at the nation's stores.
Even though economic growth is moderating from its torrid pace of 5.8 percent in the first quarter, analysts and traders in the financial markets have long been expecting inflation to start inching higher because very high levels of employment are putting pressure on wages. Higher wages, in turn, are supposed to lead to higher producer and consumer prices.
But to the surprise of many, if not most, economists, that has not happened so far.
"What business people have been saying appears to be true," said Richard Berner, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "They are saying they can't raise prices."
Yesterday's report did show some pockets of price strength. And while analysts said the last five months had to be characterized as a period of disinflation, in which the rate of inflation diminishes but prices do not fall in general, no one was willing to predict that the situation would continue.
For example, raw materials prices, including crude oil, increased by 1.3 percent in May, their first rise in four months. And wholesale food prices were up four-tenths of 1 percent, led by higher costs for fish, pork and beef.
"There is no question we are in a period of disinflation, but it may be ending," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University in Atlanta. "A number of items, like computers, are falling a lot. But prices aren't falling across the board."
The biggest contributors to the decline in the overall index last month were computer prices, which fell 4.6 percent; auto prices, down 1.6 percent, and energy prices, off 2.1 percent.
Although cheered by the continued good inflation news, Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said he remained convinced that at some point soon tight labor markets would result in stronger inflationary pressures.
"I don't think we have really had a test of the old rules," Mr. Roach said. "Inflation always lags, and the unemployment rate has only just breached the threshold of price stability, which is about 5.25 percent. In a rising-demand environment, that will take prices higher. It is only a question of when, not if."
But the performance of the economy over the last few years has generated challenges to that model.
A number of analysts argue that a strong dollar and global competition make it much easier to keep inflation well contained even as the economy continues to expand.
"The traditional inflation model can't explain how it can be that we have no producer price inflation and extremely strong manufacturing conditions," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Inc. "I think it is time to junk those models."
Mr. Yardeni said the principal new element in the equation was "global competition, which has intensified sharply since the Berlin wall came down in 1989."
According to this view, the rise in global competition not only keeps a damper on the prices of goods and services, but also on the price of labor. While employment conditions are tight in the United States, they are quite soft in many other nations, crimping wage increases everywhere.
"Inflation seems deader than a doornail everywhere you look, and I see it in my travels," said Mr. Roach, who recently returned from a trip to Italy, a country where the inflation rate is less than 2 percent.
If the Producer Price Index was to fall again in June, it would be the first time the index had declined for six consecutive months since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began compiling the data in April 1947, the bureau said yesterday.

HEADLINE: Pacificorp in Biggest Deal Yet for a British Utility

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Pacificorp became the latest American utility company to move into the British market, announcing yesterday an expected deal to acquire the Energy Group, an electricity distribution company, for about $5.8 billion in cash.
The deal, the biggest one yet for a British utility, demonstrates the allure of these highly profitable companies in the deregulating British market, even though the new Labor Party Government is preparing to levy a windfall profits tax that could cost each utility $200 million or more. 
 To help pay for the deal, Pacificorp confirmed that it would sell its telecommunications subsidiary, Pacific Telecom, for $1.5 billion. The buyer is Century Telephone Enterprises Inc., a local telephone company that provides service in 14 states.
Pacificorp's acquisition of the Energy Group, if approved by British regulators, would create an electricity giant with plenty of low-cost power in Britain and the United States and the marketing muscle needed to sell that power as utilities are forced to open up their service areas to competitors.
Pacificorp, which is based in Portland, Ore., owns Pacific Power and Light and Utah Power and Light, which serve seven Western states, as well as several power plants that produce low-cost electricity. It has been aggressively seeking a major marketer of electricity and natural gas across the country as the industry is deregulated in the United States.
Utility industry analysts said Pacificorp was paying a premium price for the Energy Group, especially in light of the expected windfall profits tax on privatized British utilities. The company will assume $3.8 billion of the Energy Group's debt and other obligations, bringing the total value of the deal to about $9.6 billion.
Pacificorp will pay 6.955, or about $11.35, a share for the Energy Group. The Energy Group's American depository receipts, which represent four ordinary British shares, slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $42 on the New York Stock Exchange, while Pacificorp's shares also edged down 12.5 cents, to $22.
The analysts said the high price tag for the Energy Group demonstrated the pressure on Pacificorp to stay competitive with the other large American utilities that have already acquired seven British distribution companies over the last two years. The analysts note that the British market, which is already opening itself up to competition, provides a preview of how a deregulated American market is likely to operate.
"A lot of the U.S. companies are using this as a training ground," said Edward J. Tirello Jr., a utility analyst for NatWest Securities. "They can draw on the expertise."
The Energy Group owns the Eastern Group, a big utility in southeastern Britain serving 3.1 million customers including a part of the greater London area. It also owns Peabody Coal, one of the world's biggest coal producers, which has contracts with many power plants across the United States. Pacificorp is expected to use this relationship to get the plants to sell excess low-cost power to its marketing arm, which would then resell it in states that are opening up their utility markets to competition.
Dennis Steinberg, senior vice president for global sales, marketing and energy trading for Pacificorp, said the strategic benefits of owning the Energy Group far outweighed the cost of a British windfall profits tax.
Penelope Adelmann, an analyst at Gruntal & Company, who on Thursday decided to recommend the stock, said it remained to be seen how well the Energy Group would fit into Pacificorp's corporate strategy.
"I want to see how well they can make it work," she said. "It's not just taking something over; you have to get it working together."
The British windfall profits tax became a virtual certainty with the election of the Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair in early May and it is expected to be included in the new British budget that will be introduced on July 2.
The goal of the tax is to raise about $8 billion to help the hard-core unemployed, many of whom lost their jobs when British companies were privatized by Conservative Party governments.
Some analysts estimated that the tax could take in on average $200 million to $300 million from each of the roughly 30 British utilities if all were included and equally taxed.
"It's a big hit," said Mark Spelman, a partner and head of utility strategy for Andersen Consulting in Chicago.
Fred D. Hafer, the president and chief executive of the General Public Utilities Corporation, a utility holding company with subsidiaries in Pennsylvania and New Jersey, said the windfall profits tax would have a significant impact on his company and others that bought British utilities, since it would divert profits that could otherwise go to pay off debt from the takeovers.
"Companies were expecting to have those additional earnings to help pay for the acquisitions," he said.
G.P.U., in a joint venture with the Cinergy Corporation, a utility holding company based in Cincinnati, agreed a year ago to buy Midlands Electricity P.L.C., a distribution company that serves 2.2 million customers.
But Mr. Hafer said G.P.U. remained committed to its investment in Britain and was looking to expand there. "The U.K. has fundamental strengths," he added. "We will look for more opportunities."
Pacificorp's sale of its subsidiary Pacific Telecom will enable the buyer, Century Telephone, to expand into seven more states in the West, including Alaska. Both companies offer similar services in their respective parts of the country. Century, which is based in Monroe, La., primarily serves rural areas in the central United States and offers wireless and Internet services.
Along with paying $1.5 billion for Pacific Telecom, Century Telephone will assume about $700 million of the company's debt. Century Telephone's shares gained 75 cents yesterday, closing at $32.50

HEADLINE: Dow Adds 70, And in Week Soars by 4.7%

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The good news keeps rolling in, and investors continue to see the stock market as the perfect outlet for their hopes and ambitions.
Yesterday, the market rallied after the Government said that producer prices fell for the fifth consecutive month, another indication that the economy was moderating and inflation under control.
The Dow Jones industrial average, now in the midst of one of its best runs in years, soared 70.57 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 7,782.04. It was the sixth consecutive record close for the Dow, and for the week, the blue-chip index gained 346 points, or about 4.7 percent.
"This is a market where bullishness is running rampant," said Larry Rice, the chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "The momentum players are playing and the foreign buyers are buying."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a record, gaining 9.79 points, or 1.1 percent, to 893.27. For the year, the Dow and the S.& P. 500 are both up nearly 21 percent.
As the case for a strong but moderating economy grows, investors are rushing into the market, fearing they will miss out on a big gain, analysts said. Yesterday, volume on the New York Stock Exchange surpassed 570 million shares for the second consecutive day, making it one of the busiest trading days of the year.
"Among portfolio managers, there's a concerted effort to get rid of cash by the end of the quarter," said William LeFevre of Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. "There's also a lot of shifting out of money market funds and into stocks."
The stock rally is also helping the dollar, which rose again yesterday, as foreign investors try to get their share of the rally. Doubts about the outlook for Europe's single currency is also helping the dollar.
The dollar rose as high as 1.7407 marks before settling in New York at 1.7386 marks, up from 1.7300 marks on Thursday and the highest since February 1994. The dollar rose to 114.89 yen from 114.25 yen. The pound rose to $1.6363 from $1.6316.
Wall Street analysts continue to express astonishment at this year's gains, but there is also talk of a "new era," one exemplified by robust economic growth, soaring profits and low inflation -- all of which have served to bolster stocks.
Even with unemployment at a 24-year low, analysts see few signs of inflationary pressure, and that view has led to falling interest rates and rising stock prices.
"There is this traditional relationship between low unemployment and inflation, which is pretty reliable since the 1970's and 1980's," said William Cheney, the chief economist at John Hancock. "But the dynamics of inflation seem to have changed."
While there are "whispers" about the possibility of the economy slowing enough to hurt earnings growth, most analysts said that investors had shifted their focus from fundamentals to a belief that the market would continue its tremendous ascent.
"Had investors focused on just fundamental valuations, they would have been left behind 500 points ago," said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., director of technical research at Janney Montgomery Scott. "There is something larger going on here."
Dow stocks were led by Caterpillar, which rose 3, to 108 3/4 -- a 52-week high. For the year, Caterpillar is up about 45 percent.
American Express rose 3 1/2, to 76 5/8, and Coca-Cola gained 1 7/8, to 71 7/8.
The brokerage firm Advest rose 5 1/8, to 23 1/4, after Business Week reported that two Boston banks were considering takeovers of the firm.
Technology and small company stocks have lagged behind the blue chips this year, but they have also seen strong gains. The Nasdaq composite, heavily weighted with technology issues, rose 11.71 points, to a record 1,423.03. And the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks gained 2.53 points, to a record 392.07.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Par For the Coarse

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
O.K., so I have some issues with golf.
I committed my first sin on a golf course. When I was 8, my girlfriend devised a game where we would hide in the woods at the Rock Creek golf course in Washington and wait for businessmen to hit over the hill. Then we'd run out and grab the balls and retreat to our bosky perch to watch the men search vainly for them. 
 When I confessed our ruse to the priest, he said my soul would never be clean unless I returned the golf balls to their rightful owners -- an impossible assignment. (If any of you guys are reading this, please E-mail.)
My opinion of the game did not improve when I grew up and covered this Maryland suburb for The Washington Star. My biggest story was a murder most fowl, a doctor at Congressional Country Club who got so angry at a goose honking while he was trying to play that he bludgeoned it to death.
Covering George Bush for The Times, my feelings grew bleaker. I was forced, on many a summer morning, to rise at 6 and lurch around the back nine, watching the President's manic play -- dubbed "golf-polo" -- and genial cheating. Once after I'd sat cross-legged and doleful as Mr. Bush teed off, he teed off to an aide that I was putting a "Hinayanistic" evil eye on him. (Yes, it's a real word.)
Even during my stint as a sports reporter, my attitude was much like the Young Man in a P. G. Wodehouse story who dismissed "gowf" as "a pestilential pastime," a "a blanked, infernal, fatheaded game." It seemed like premature senility, men with guts pretending they were exercising and giving themselves a fake sense of being in the wild.
I failed to see that those were its attractions. Baby boomers with a good economy and bad knees wanted to revert to the Eisenhower style now that the world was in their hands.
"Golf for guys is about getting away with it," says Sally Jenkins, a writer for Sports for Women magazine. "They like to sit in the clubhouse and drink gin and play card games.
"My dad," she continues, referring to the sportswriter Dan Jenkins, "goes to eat red meat, have a hot dog, which my mother does not allow him to do at home. Golf can be a sunrise-to-sunset deal if you play your cards right."
"The golf course is a haven for men to smoke cigars and tell dirty, sexist jokes," agrees John Feinstein, the sportswriter.
I began to see golf in a new light. A feminist light. A transgressive light. It suddenly seemed critically important to encourage "pink golf," as Ms. Jenkins dubbed the burgeoning number of women players, if only to give the men the dreaded yips and ruin their putts.
Consider that the laureled Tiger defended his swing coach for working at Lochinvar, a Houston club that does not allow women. "I can't be the champion of all causes," Mr. Woods said, adding about the club's rule, "that's just the way it is."
"Nike, American Express and Rolex," said Mr. Feinstein. "Those are the causes Tiger's fighting for."
Multiracial is easier, I guess, than multi-sexual.
I went out to the U.S. Open at Congressional to mingle among the rugged individualists smoking cigars, wearing Madras shorts and belts with sailboats, talking into their cell phones, chatting about their investment advisers, ordering $4 slices of focaccia and $4.50 glasses of iced cappuccino and visiting the A.T.M.'s.
I learned the arcana of the sport, that Tiger travels with an amulet from his dad -- a gold ball mark, fashioned from Earl Woods's melted-down bridgework.
And I learned some lingo. "The casual dropping of the phrase 'titanium shaft' can go a long way," says Tony Kornheiser, a sports columnist for The Washington Post.
Besides the traditional moaning and "oohhh"-ing and "You-the-man"-ing, here are some other lines guaranteed to frighten men into thinking we're invading the sacred precinct. They are best delivered with a Mae West (or Ru Paul) intonation:
"Half of driving it longer is in your head."
"Check out my great Big Bertha."
"Be the longest you can be."
"Don't rinse your ball."
"Are your spikes hard or soft?"
"I rolled it real good."
"I had a violent lip-out."
"Don't groove your waggle."
And once you've rattled them, you can go home and watch something with a more womanly speed. Like the Bulls game.

HEADLINE: A Russian's Rise From Car Dealer to Tycoon

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 13

 BODY:
In the ornate 19th-century merchant's mansion he restored as a sumptuous company club, Russia's most prominent 20th-century merchant was explaining how he put aside his first love, business, to serve the Russian state.
Boris A. Berezovsky, 51, the founder of Logovaz, a car dealership he built into a major communications and oil conglomerate, has worked for the last six months as deputy secretary of the National Security Council, mostly shuttling between Moscow and Grozny to help hammer out a peace agreement with the rebel republic of Chechnya. 
 The boundaries between public office and private wealth are notoriously blurred in Russia. A contentious figure and a natural target for charges of conflict of interest, Mr. Berezovsky put his assets and company stocks in trust after joining the Government. He said he completely divorced himself from the management of his many business interests. "I am not at all responsible for Logovaz today."
Seconds later an aide glided to his side and handed him a mobile phone. "Gluzhkov," he murmured.
Nikolai Gluzhkov is a co-founder and acting chairman of Logovaz, and Mr. Berezovsky's closest business associate. He is also chief financial officer of Russia's largest airline, Aeroflot. Logovaz, which hopes to acquire shares in Aeroflot when the Government reduces the 51 percent stake it has in the airline, has already taken over most of its management.
Mr. Berezovsky jumped out of his seat and took the call in an adjoining room.
In post-Communist Russia, the Politburo has been replaced by a deal-making oligarchy -- the dozen or so powerful, fiercely competitive businessmen who run the banks, oil companies and news organizations, and who banded together to bankroll President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election.
Mr. Berezovsky is public spokesman and chief lobbyist for this new elite, which moved from the shadows to respectability in a few short years.
Using his national security post as a springboard, he is now recasting himself as a statesman. He donated $3 million to charity last year and a major scientific association named him Philanthropist of the Year. He writes solemn editorials opposing NATO expansion. This week he canceled an appearance before the prestigious Council on Foreign Relations in New York and raced back to Grozny for urgent talks. He recently told a radio interviewer that the 20th-century figure he most admired was Henry Kissinger.
But even as he works to broaden his image, his complex business dealings have once again thrust his commercial interests, not his statecraft, into the limelight.
Like most of Russia's new rich, Mr. Berezovsky made his money mysteriously and fast. A mathematician who worked on decision-making theory for an institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, in 1989 he parlayed a relationship with the state-owned automobile giant Avtovaz to spin off Russia's first capitalist car dealership, Logovaz. By 1994 he had expanded that into a vast communications and oil conglomerate. Among other things, he owns a sizable portion of the nation's largest television network, ORT, as well as the seventh-largest oil company, Sibneft.
Following an example set by Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Berezovsky made available an income declaration. According to his calculations, he personally earned a relatively modest $500,000 last year. But outside estimates of Logovaz's worth range from $250 million to more than $1 billion.
Last month, a nasty closed-door battle for control of the state's remaining shares of Sibneft suggested that Mr. Berezovsky's companies remain aggressive players on the Russian business scene.
Behind closed doors, Finansoyava Neftyanaya Kompania, F.N.K., a company Mr. Berezovsky co-founded, managed to prevent KM-Invest, a subsidiary of one of Russia's most powerful banks, Onexim Bank, from bidding in an auction to buy shares of Sibneft. F.N.K., which managed the auction, ended up acquiring the shares for $110 million. Mr. Berezovsky expressed some glee over the feat but said he was not personally involved.
Mostly, the fracas underscored the fierce financial rivalry dividing the leading Russian businessmen Mr. Berezovsky says are united in a civic-minded crusade to promote economic reform and democracy.
Onexim Bank said it would take F.N.K. to court. As is increasingly common in Russia, the rival financial giants then raced to try the case in the newspapers they own.
Mr. Berezovsky's appointment to a national security post last November was widely criticized. There was a scandal when newspapers discovered that Mr. Berezovsky, who is Jewish, had taken Israeli citizenship in 1994 after an assassination attempt in which his driver was killed. He relinquished his dual citizenship before taking the job.
Some commentators suggested that Mr. Berezovsky's induction into government was a sinister plot to allow Mr. Berezovsky to use geopolitics to expand his oil interests.
Like many of the people in Russia who became very rich very fast, Mr. Berezovsky has been the subject of numerous press reports that suggest he relied on organized crime to build his business empire. A Forbes Magazine cover story last December made such a charge, prompting Mr. Berezovsky to sue Forbes for libel in Great Britain.
He hired the Washington-based firm Edelman Public Relations to improve his image overseas, making him perhaps the only the Russian government official to have an American publicist.
As far as anyone can detect, Mr. Berezovsky has spent money in Chechnya, not earned it. While taking part in the negotiations, he took 10 trips and spent a million dollars of Logovaz money hiring private planes and bulletproof cars. After a few early blunders, his skill in getting things done there won him the grudging respect of at least some of his colleagues in the Kremlin.
However, Ivan Rybkin, Secretary of the National Security Council, does not pretend that Mr. Berezovsky is just another subaltern. "The private sector here has huge significance," he said when asked to explain Mr. Berezovsky's duties. "Berezovsky's participation in the power structure is absolutely necessary." Mr. Rybkin said. He added dryly, "In your country, Mr. Perot wanted to be President."
Mr. Berezovsky has handled his outsized clout with grace. A compulsive mobile-phone user, Mr. Berezovsky even complied with Mr. Rybkin's ban on pagers or mobile phones in his office. Like a gunslinger surrendering his Colt .45's at the saloon door, Mr. Berezovsky anxiously but dutifully hands over his phones and pagers to the duty officer before each meeting.
In the gray corridors of the Russian Government, the rakish Mr. Berezovsky stands out.
He was the only member of the Russian negotiating team to meet with Chechnya's most radical and volatile terrorist, Salman Raduyev. He was also the only member of the Russian negotiating team to treat himself after the talks to some rest and relaxation at the Cannes Film Festival.
The only son of a nurse and a builder, Mr. Berezovsky did not grow up in the privileged world of the Soviet elite. His two eldest daughters attended Cambridge University. One now works at Premier SV, an advertising agency that sells all the media time at his network, ORT. The other works at ORT.
Engaging and bristling with drive, Mr. Berezovsky has a knack for networking. He always has. "He was different from the others in his energy and ability to establish business and other connections with people," said Vladimir Borzenko, a research scientist who worked closely with Mr. Berezovsky at the institute. "Everybody knew him and he knew everybody."
Mr. Berezovsky has also proven deft at discarding friends at the opportune time. By 1993, he had ingratiated himself with Mr. Yeltsin's powerful and shadowy chief of security, Aleksandr Korzhakov and another hawkish top adviser, Oleg Soskovets, both of whom proved helpful when Mr. Berezovsky began expanding the Logovaz empire.
When those two men fell from favor during the election campaign, Mr. Berezovsky landed on the right side of their chief rival, Anatoly B. Chubais, who has since become First Deputy Prime Minister. It was in a drawing room of Mr. Berezovsky's Club Logovaz that Mr. Chubais, Mr. Berezovsky and others plotted to oust the hawkish Mr. Korzhakov.
Mr. Berezovsky has grown close to Mr. Yeltsin's daughter Tatyana Dyachenko, whom he met only a year and a half ago. Last March he raced up to Nizhni Novgorod the same day as she did to persuade its popular, reform-minded young Governor, Boris Nemtsov, to join Mr. Chubais's economic team. His complex business dealings are a case study of the advantages of insider trading and Kremlin ties. But he casts himself as a free-market reformer.
Critics and friends alike debate whether Mr. Berezovsky is driven by greed or ego, or both. Mr. Borzenko had a simpler explanation.
"The rules of the game in Russia are such that when you have reached a certain level, you cannot stop," he said. "If you rest on your laurels, you will be kicked off your perch quite painfully. It's like a bicycle: you fall when you stop."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Climb Sharply To 6th Record Close in Row
The stock market extended its record-breaking run, as the Dow Jones industrial average soared another 70.57 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent. It was the sixth straight record close; for the week, the Dow gained 346 points, or about 4.7 percent. 
 A report showing a drop in prices paid to producers served as the fuel for yesterday's surge. As the case for a strong, but moderating, economy grows, investors continue to rush into the market: yesterday was one of the busiest trading days of the year. [Page 36.]
 
Bond prices also rose sharply on the drop in May producer prices. The 30-year bond rose 20/32 , to a price of 9825/32 , and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.72 percent, from 6.77 percent on Thursday. [49.]
 
Japan Speeds Up Liberalization
The Japanese Government plans to speed up its timetable for changes to its financial markets, called the Big Bang. Originally the revamping was scheduled for completion by the year 2001, but now the Government hopes to end controls on brokerage commissions, rules forbidding banks and securities firms to enter each other's business and other restrictions by the end of 1999. [38.]
 
Japan's economic output surged 1.6 percent in the first quarter. Japanese consumers were purchasing freely from January through March in anticipation of a tax increase that took effect on April 1. The higher taxes, however, are likely to slow the economy's growth for the rest of the year. [38.]
 
Judge Approves Barney's Fee
The judge overseeing the bankruptcy proceedings of Barney's Inc. has allowed the retailer to offer a $8.5 million breakup fee to a potential suitor. Two bids have been made so far: one by the Hong Kong retailer Dickson Concepts and the other by the parent of Saks Fifth Avenue. But Barney's creditors committee wants to attract higher bids. [38.]
 
Kohl Confident Of Deal on Euro
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, left, expressed confidence yesterday that there would be an agreement on preparations for the single European currency when European Union leaders meet next week in Amsterdam. Mr. Kohl rebuffed suggestions by France's new Socialist Government to revive plans for ambitious public works programs to reduce unemployment before the currency is introduced in 1999. [3.]
 
Europe and U.S. Reach a Deal
The European Union and the United States have reached an agreement to accept each other's product safety tests, removing impediments to more than $40 billion of trade. The pact involves products ranging from electrical appliances and medical equipment to telecommunications equipment and pleasure boats. [48.]
 
Third World Takes On Group of 7
The first conference of the Developing Eight, -- eight predominantly Muslim nations of Asia, Africa and the Middle East -- is scheduled for this weekend. And although expectations are subdued, the countries would like to find a way to form joint purchasing and manufacturing projects to save money and speed their domestic development. [38.]
 
Indonesian Car Project Challenged
The Clinton Administration plans to ask the World Trade Organization to rule against Indonesia's national car project, a program run by the son of President Suharto that is intended to put American and other foreign companies at a disadvantage in the country's potentially huge automobile market. [5.]

LENGTH: 1518 words

HEADLINE: Teacher, Friend . . . Victim?;
Shaken by Killing, Instructors Weigh the Risks of Caring

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
The students in Stephen Koss's 12th-grade class were more than a little impressed.
A Sunday afternoon in an elegant Colonial house in Westchester, with burnished furniture and a Steinway baby grand. A barbecue on the deck overlooking a sumptuous sweep of lawn, a terraced rock garden and a paved backyard basketball court. 
 For many of the students at the New York City Laboratory School, a public school in Manhattan, it was the first time they had been invited to such a place. It was also the first time many had been at a teacher's home.
"For this to happen, it's pretty amazing," said Nelson Santana, 18, a Roosevelt Islander who, with his mother, has lived on Social Security since his father died in a car accident. "I couldn't think of another person who would make a cookout for us at his house."
Mr. Koss is somewhat unusual in the city system. Three years ago, he shrugged off his six-figure management-consultant career and became a math teacher. He is one of a relative handful of teachers whose affluent backgrounds give them no economic motivation to take on the grindingly tough job of teaching in the New York City public schools.
The murder of Jonathan Levin, a public high school teacher in the Bronx who was the son of Time Warner's top executive, and the arrest last week of a former student, is causing Mr. Koss and many teachers to think about their relationships with students.
Lawyers for the former student, Corey Arthur, said earlier this week that he thought of Mr. Levin as a mentor and visited his home regularly. Prosecutors say Mr. Arthur used his relationship with Mr. Levin to gain entry to his apartment, where, the police say, the teacher was killed for his bank card.
For teachers, the killing has raised deep questions: Amid the race and class tensions so evident in New York, how should teachers go about reaching students with backgrounds distant from their own? How accessible should they make themselves? Should they invite students to their homes?
"I can count on one hand the number of times my students have been over to my apartment, but when this happened to Jonathan, all four of those incidents came into my mind," said Jeremy Chiappetta, who teaches social studies to eighth graders at Intermediate School 90 in Washington Heights. "If they called and asked for help and wanted to meet me, would I let them in the door? The answer is yes, I would."
Some teachers fear the murder could prompt teachers to pull back from their students and even discourage them from teaching in New York City. But some say Mr. Levin's death only underlines the need for teachers to make strong connections to their students, especially students whose rough-edged lives have made them hard, distrustful of adults and the knowledge they try to transmit.
The teachers union tells members to use their own judgment. "They should be cautious, but basically it depends on the style and the preference of the teacher as well as who their kids are," said Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers. "Many of the older teachers, who perhaps have been burned, caution younger teachers who want to have more contact. By burned I mean kids tracking them down at home, kids bothering them at home excessively."
Several teachers asked about their accessibility said they calibrate their behavior in different ways, balancing access with authority. One gives out his phone number, but not his address; another invites students to his Upper West Side apartment on occasion, but said he takes care not to wear his Rolex watch to school.
But all, including those from wealthy backgrounds -- some the only white faces in their classrooms -- said they believed spending time with students outside of school and making themselves available was a critical part of their teaching, one of the only ways to gain students' trust.
The teachers say it matters little to students if a teacher is affluent.
"They assume that if you're a teacher, you're rich, and in reality, making $30,000 a year is more than 99 percent of my kids' families make," Mr. Chiappetta said.
Mr. Chiappetta, 23, who grew up "not wanting for anything" as the son of a Pennsylvania real estate appraiser and investor, said he gives all 180 students his home number and gets calls all the time.
A few times, students have called him to say they are hungry and no one in their family is around. Mr. Chiappetta has met them and bought them dinner. He spends hours with students in the after-school chess club he started, has invited a few to his apartment, and once, when students were misbehaving, he got their parents' permission to punish them by having them take part in a Saturday clean-up of his neighborhood.
"Certainly, I've taken some precautions," said Mr. Chiappetta, who started as part of Teach for America, in which college graduates defer private-sector ambitions for a couple of years while they teach in urban schools. "I do have a caller I.D. box. I do have voice-mail. I have had prank phone calls made, and I am sure they're my students. But the reality is that these students, in order to be successful, need to know that I'm there for them."
Angel Rivera, 13, said Mr. Chiappetta's dedication transformed him from a D student into a member of the honor roll. "He made me get better grades," Angel said.
Marc Sternberg, another Teach for America recruit, whose father owned the Maison Blanche department stores in Louisiana, says he is more cautious. Still, he fields at least 5 or 10 phone calls a night from his fourth graders in Community School 66 in the South Bronx, calls their parents frequently and raised money to take 40 students to a summer school program at Princeton, his alma mater.
But Mr. Sternberg, 24, said that he does not invite students to his apartment, and that he would be hesitant to teach in high school "because of the safety question." He does not talk about his background much, having concluded that the gulf between him and his students is just too wide.
"I'm white, one of the few whites here," he said. "They know that I live in Manhattan. They assume that I'm rich and famous."
And, he added, prejudice goes both ways. "A lot of people who aren't from the Bronx have preconceived notions of people who are. The same is true of people from the Bronx -- especially their attitude toward white people."
Caroline Fraiser, 48, a seventh-grade social studies teacher at I.S. 90, says her own working-class background is an advantage. "I grew up in Harlem, and I live in Harlem," she said. "They respect me. I tell them there will be no pity parties here."
She is accessible to students after school and recently took a student to see a Minnesota private school, which had offered the girl a scholarship. She will give her home number to students who ask for it.
"I don't really push it on them," she said. "I don't want them to feel like they have to play up to me to get a grade."
But some teachers from wealthier or culturally different backgrounds feel they have to earn work harder to make a connection to their students.
"The economic gap, the racial gap, the cultural gap, they're all there and they're huge, gargantuan, much, much larger than I had ever anticipated," said Timothy Shriver, the son of the former Peace Corps director, Sargent Shriver, who taught for 10 years in the New Haven public schools. "I don't know that I was very good in the beginning. I don't think I understood where the kids were coming from."
Mr. Shriver, who left teaching several years ago to head the Special Olympics, said that he could not really have hidden his Kennedy-clan status, but that he dodged student questions because he didn't want to emphasize what made him different. He said he spent a lot of time visiting his students in their neighborhoods, going to their ball games, taking them to the movies.
"Kids have a very sharp lens on sincerity," he said. "They are very eager to know whether you care, do you give a damn. If you come from a place where people are always kowtowing to position and prestige and all that, it can be a refreshing thing. As one of my students said once, 'You like to be here because we treat you like a normal.' "
Mr. Koss, who grew up middle-class in Indianapolis, feels his self-made success can serve as an example to his students at the Lab School, a selective public school for children from all economic backgrounds.
"The kids knew I gave up a business career where I was making a lot of money," said Mr. Koss, who has also told his students about his wife's position as the president of commercial credit for Traveler's Group. His students say his background is evidence of his dedication.
"I think that teaching is a very sacrificing position," said one, Jean Leng, 18. "For him to do what he's doing, it makes a big difference."
Last Sunday, when Mr. Koss escorted his 12 calculus students to his home in Pelham for a barbecue, he was not only intending it as a graduation celebration.
"For them to come here and see this," Mr. Koss said, "hopefully it's motivating."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 2-5
 
Cambodian Minister Says Pol Pot Ordered Aide Killed
The First Prime Minister of Cambodia claimed that Pol Pot, the ailing leader of the Khmer Rouge, ordered the execution of a top lieutenant, his wife and 10 members of their family, and then fled his jungle hideout on a stretcher. The account could not be confirmed. 1 

Indonesian Project Challenged
The Clinton Administration said it would ask the World Trade Organization to rule against Indonesia's national car project. The move marks the first direct American challenge to the financial empire of President Suharto, whose son is in charge of the project, which imports cars from South Korea but is exempt from the high tariffs and taxes paid by other foreign producers. The European Union and Japan have already challenged the program. 5
 
Plutocrats Squabble in Russia
A fracas has broken out between Russian plutocrats whose exact interests and powers are clad in mystery. When a company controlled by Boris Berezovsky, deputy secretary of Russia's National Security Council and a self-proclaimed free market reformer, obtained shares in a state company, rivals alleged that his business empire testified to the advantages of insider trading and Kremlin ties. 3
 
No Treaty Accord in Europe
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany met with President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin of France, but no joint French-German accord was reached on whether to support a revision of the Treaty on European Union. Mr. Jospin, a Socialist, proposed public works programs to reduce unemployment but Mr. Kohl, a conservative, rebuffed the idea. 3
 
Somalia Photos Shock Italians
An Italian news magazine published photos showing what appeared to be Italian soldiers abusing unarmed civilians with electrodes and flares during an American-led mission to Somalia in 1993. The minister of defense, after first referring to the actions as "pranks," pledged an immediate investigation into the scandal, which has upset Italians' image of their armed forces as a gentle bastion of pageantry. 4
 
Taliban Attack in Afghanistan
Taliban soldiers in Afghanistan fired rockets and heavy artillery at a strategic city that it is trying to take back from opposition troops. The Taliban has sent thousands of troops to the city, Jebul Siraj, which lies on the only road linking northern and southern Afghanistan. The Taliban, which controls most of the country, lost Jebul Siraj three weeks ago; its last northern stronghold fell on Wednesday. (AP)
 
Talks on Salmon to Resume
The United States and Canada will resume talks on Wednesday in a long-running dispute over how to divide the Pacific salmon catch, a month after discussions collapsed in acrimony. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL 7-10, 22
 
McVeigh Condemned to Die For Oklahoma City Bombing
A Federal Court jury voted unanimously that Timothy J. McVeigh should be sentenced to die by lethal injection for the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building on April 19, 1995. 1
 
Tax-Cutting Bill Approved
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a Republican tax-cutting bill over unanimous Democratic opposition, setting Congress on a collision course with the Clinton Administration over how to divide the tax reductions agreed on in their balanced budget plan. 1
 
Change in Medicare Urged
Senate Republicans said that in their effort to balance the Federal budget they would try to increase the age of eligibility for Medicare and start charging elderly people $5 for each visit by a home health care agency. The American Association of Retired Persons promptly criticized both proposals. 10
 
Army Ends Harassment Line
The Army shut down a special telephone line that has received more than 1,300 sexual-harassment complaints since November because Army officials said anonymous tipsters were trying to use it to settle personal grudges. Army officials insisted they had been considering unplugging the number anyway because the calls had dwindled to a handful a day in recent weeks. 6
 
Simpson Lawyer Disciplined
The California State Bar announced that it had formally reprimanded one of the defense lawyers in the O. J. Simpson criminal trial and would soon censure a second. Carl E. Douglas was issued a public reproval after investigators determined that employees at Mr. Douglas's office had forged his name on two subpoenas sent to a potential witness in the Simpson trial 6
 
Nominee Has Easy Hearing
Eric H. Holder Jr., President Clinton's choice to be the deputy Attorney General, faced mild questioning about his opposition to the death penalty and other issues at a hearing as he headed toward an apparently easy confirmation. Both Democrats and Republicans praised the choice of Mr. Holder for the Justice Department's No. 2 post. 22
 
Donation Still in Dispute
Democratic Party officials said they were no longer certain of their assertion that a suspicious 1996 campaign donation had come from the account of a dead woman. The donor may have been another woman by the same name, but even that could not be determined with any certainty, party officials said. 10
 
Congress Files Finances
Congress released the financial disclosure statements of its members, drawing new attention to Speaker Newt Gingrich, whose book royalties more than doubled his income last year. 10
 
NEW YORK/REGION 23-27
 
No Accord on Rent Laws As Deadline Draws Near
Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders engaged in day-long negotiations trying to forge a compromise that would prevent state rent regulations from expiring tomorrow. The Governor and the other leaders said they had advanced a number of proposals intended to resolve major sticking points in the fight, but they declined to report any details from their five hours of talks. 1
 
Agent Suspected in Theft
The F.B.I. agent who supervised the investigation of Nicholas Corozzo, the apparent heir to John Gotti, is suspected of stealing a major piece of evidence -- almost $100,000 that prosecutors said were loan-sharking profits. Discussions about a possible plea bargain broke down when Mr. Corozzo's defense team learned of the allegations against the veteran agent, Jerome R. Sullivan, and defense lawyers said they would attack Mr. Sullivan's credibility and integrity in an effort to undermine the prosecution's evidence. 1

Members of the city's Muslim community said they had brought the Federal lawsuit a year and a half ago after they found that some districts and schools were refusing to include the symbol in holiday displays. 23

BUSINESS DAY 36-49
 
Inflation Mark Falls Again
The conventional wisdom that low unemployment leads inexorably to rising prices took another hit as the Government reported that an important measure designed to detect early signs of inflation fell in May for the fifth consecutive month. It was the first time the measure -- the Producer Price index for finished goods -- has fallen five months in row since 1952 and came despite more than six years of uninterrupted growth that has pushed the jobless rate down to 4.8 percent. 37
 
Japan Plans Market Makeover
The Japanese Government gave the clearest glimpse so far of its financial-market makeover and said it would speed up its timetable of changes, making the grand plan -- in theory at least -- more radical than the one-shot deregulatory measures that originally freed up the markets in London and New York. 38

HEADLINE: House Panel Votes Tax Cuts, But Fight Has Barely Begun

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a Republican tax-cutting bill over unanimous Democratic opposition early today, setting Congress on a collision course with the Clinton Administration over how to divide the tax reductions agreed on in their balanced-budget plan.
While Administration officials and some Congressional Democrats held out hope that the Senate would adopt a plan more acceptable to the President when it takes up its version of the legislation next week, the bill being prepared by Senate tax writers closely tracks the House bill in many ways, increasing the odds of Mr. Clinton's vetoing the final version. 
 The failure of the House committee's chairman, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, to secure any Democratic support for his plan shows that the partisan wrangling that dominated debates over taxes and spending for two years has returned, cutting short the respite since the White House and the Congressional leadership compromised on a budget blueprint last month.
Mr. Archer's plan, approved by a 22-to-16 vote in the early hours of the morning, would reduce tax bills for investors and many families, provide some tax breaks for college expenses, reduce Federal inheritance taxes and expand Individual Retirement Accounts.
The measure calls for $135 billion in tax cuts over five years, offset in part by nearly $50 billion in new revenues, generated largely by expanding existing taxes on airline tickets and closing loopholes.
But the White House and Democrats on the committee attacked the plan as heavily tilted in favor of the rich and as violating the budget deal by scaling back Mr. Clinton's proposed college tax breaks. They said that unless the legislation was changed substantially, the risks of a partisan standoff would be high.
White House officials have avoided explicit veto threats, but Mr. Clinton repeated his criticism of Mr. Archer's bill today, saying that among other problems it "would penalize the working poor and especially working poor mothers."
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Archer's legislation "is not the bill that will be signed into law."
Republican leaders said they expected the main components of Mr. Archer's bill, including a credit of up to $500 a child for families and a reduction in the capital gains tax, to be included in the final legislation -- after the Senate drafts its tax bill and the two chambers settle any differences between them.
But they said they were open to limited changes in the bill.
"We will negotiate to get a signed bill," Speaker Newt Gingrich said.
Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, the Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is scheduled to introduce his version of the tax bill next week. A draft of his plan given to Democrats on Thursday included provisions that are likely to prove unacceptable to the Administration, especially in the area of tax breaks for college expenses.
In the House, Mr. Archer's bill passed the Ways and Means Committee with only limited changes. Mr. Archer's proposal to tax Indian tribes for their business activities was stripped out of the bill early today by a combination of Democrats and Republicans, some of whom argued that the plan would amount to an unconstitutional tax on sovereign governments and others of whom sought to protect Indian constituencies in their states.
Mr. Archer's bill could go to a vote on the House floor as early as next week. It will be reviewed first by the House Rules Committee, which will be under pressure from Mr. Gingrich to strip out another provision that could cause political problems for many Republicans, a measure that would end subsidies for ethanol, a corn-based alternative fuel. Ethanol subsidies have long been protected by a bipartisan coalition of farm-state lawmakers, and some Republicans would prefer not to have to vote in favor of their party's tax bill at the cost of opposing ethanol subsidies.
Mr. Archer's bill contains the following provisions:
*A credit of up to $500 a child under age 17 for families with incomes up to $110,000, a key demand of the religious right. But the plan is structured in a way that would make many low- and moderate-income people who receive the earned income tax credit ineligible for the child credit, and it would limit the child credit for families that claim a credit for child-care expenses. As a result, the Administration argues that the credit does too much for relatively well-off families and not enough for lower-income working families.
*A tax credit for 50 percent of up to $3,000 in expenses for each of the first two years of college. The Administration continued to press for its plan, which would provide a $1,500 credit and would not reduce the credit even if the recipient were receiving a Federal student aid grant. The Republican plan contained only a limited version of Mr. Clinton's proposal for a deduction of up to $10,000 a year for college expenses. And the White House argued that the plan violated the budget agreement by allocating $3 billion less than the $35 billion set aside for the President's education initiatives.
*A reduction in the top rate on capital gains for individuals, to 20 percent from 28 percent. Mr. Archer's bill also included a provision to allow investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating their gains, starting in 2001.
*An expansion of Individual Retirement Accounts to allow people who do not qualify for tax-deductible deposits to make nondeductible deposits that would accrue interest tax free and be withdrawn tax free for retirement or purchase of a home. Such savers are already allowed to make nondeductible contributions to an I.R.A., but, as with all other I.R.A. holders, the earnings grow only tax-deferred -- they are taxed upon withdrawal -- rather than tax-free. Further, unless the account holder is prepared to pay a penalty to the Internal Revenue Service, under current law he may withdraw from the I.R.A. only for retirement, not for any other purpose like an earlier home purchase.
*A phased-in increase in the exemption from Federal estate taxes, to $1 million from the current $600,000.
The Senate bill being drafted by Mr. Roth has the same broad outlines, although it differs in many details, and could still change before it is formally introduced next week. But the Administration has long had a strained relationship with the ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, and it is unclear how closely the Democrats on the committee will work with the Administration to reshape the bill.
Mr. Roth's plan would create a $500 child credit, but parents with children from 13 to 16 would have to deposit the proceeds into an educational savings account. As in the House version, many recipients of the earned income tax credit would not be eligible for the full child credit.
The Senate bill would have a credit for the first two years of college nearly identical to that in the House bill, but it would not contain any version of the $10,000 college deduction supported by Mr. Clinton. Although the education package in the Senate bill contains several provisions with bipartisan support, including a restoration of deductibility of student loan interest, it allocates $30 billion rather than the $35 billion sought by Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Roth's proposal includes a reduction in the capital gains top rate to 20 percent, but does not include the inflation-adjustment provision in the House bill, and would not reduce the corporate capital gains rate, as Mr. Archer's bill does.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Police Say Man Admits Strangling a Beautician

 BODY:
The police arrested a Brooklyn man early yesterday morning and charged him with strangling a beautician whose body was found earlier this week stuffed above the ceiling of her family's Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment.
During routine questioning, the police said, the man, Kirt Nicholas, an unemployed construction worker, confessed to killing Maudlyn James, 27, almost two months ago. Detective Capt. Michael Muscatello said that the suspect was the boyfriend of Ms. James's 25-year-old sister. But the captain said that Mr. Nicholas, 28, of 299 Woodbine Street, could not explain his motive. 
 Captain Muscatello said that Mr. Nicholas, who moved to New York from Trinidad five years ago, had no police record and appeared to be in good standing with the James family.
Ms. James disappeared on April 21. A few days ago, the family noticed a foul smell in the apartment that seemed to come from a crawl space between the ceiling and roof. A police emergency services unit broke through the crawl space and discovered the body.
