HEADLINE: Brutal End for an Architect of Cambodian Brutality

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 13

 BODY:
Son Sen, the Khmer Rouge official who was reported today to have been executed by his leader, Pol Pot, was one of the earliest members of the radical Maoist movement, and one of its most brutal.
During the movement's four years in power in the late 1970's, Mr. Son Sen was Cambodia's Defense Minister and oversaw the torture and execution of more than 10,000 people at Tuol Sleng prison in Phnom Penh. They were among more than a million people who died during those years at the hands of the Khmer Rouge. 
 He was also the official who brought about the emptying of Phnom Penh in the immediate aftermath of the Khmer Rouge military victory in 1975, in an experiment in radical agrarianism that had ghastly results.
Mr. Son Sen's reported killing on Tuesday by his close comrades, following an accusation of spying and treason, seemed to close the circle on his role as an executioner during the purges at Tuol Sleng, in which the Khmer Rouge Government devoured itself.
From their early years in power, from 1975 to 1979, the Khmer Rouge under Mr. Pol Pot have been marked by paranoia, and the accusations of betrayal against Mr. Son Sen echo those levied against the thousands of people who died at his hands.
The radical Maoist group had its roots in the Vietnamese-led Communist movement that emerged in Indochina as the French colonial era came to an end in the early 1950's. It moved from underground agitation to jungle warfare to triumph in 1975 along with the Communist victory in Vietnam.
Now the inner circle appears to be narrowing almost to nothing, and it is not clear how many of Mr. Pol Pot's lieutenants remain loyal to him. In describing the events today, First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh said Mr. Pol Pot, in fleeing his jungle hideout on a stretcher, had taken with him three other members of his ruling group -- not as allies but as "hostages."
The first of a series of defections of thousands of guerrillas since last summer was led by Ieng Sary, another close comrade of Mr. Pol Pot's, who had served as Foreign Minister during the years of Khmer Rouge power.
"Ninety-five percent of the armed forces in Anlong Veng are determined to join the royal Government and are now surrounding Pol Pot," Mr. Ranariddh said, referring to the Khmer Rouge's stronghold.
Back in the 1950's, when the Khmer Rouge movement was forming, both Mr. Ieng Sary and Mr. Son Sen were among Mr. Pol Pot's earliest associates. All three studied in France and became converted to Marxism in those years.
A former schoolteacher like Mr. Pol Pot, Mr. Son Sen returned to Cambodia in 1956 after losing his scholarship and resumed teaching. He joined the Communist Party in 1960 and disappeared into the underground insurgency four years later.
He commanded the final Khmer Rouge assault on Phnom Penh in April 1975 and oversaw the first act of mass brutality of the new leadership: the forced evacuation of all city-dwellers into the countryside, where many quickly died of exhaustion, starvation or disease.
The Khmer Rouge proceeded to institute one of the world's most thorough and bloody experiments in radical Communism, reducing the nation to a primitive agrarian economy.
Urban life was abolished, education was curtailed, modern commerce and manufacturing were banned. Mass executions targeted intellectuals, teachers, civil servants, Buddhist monks and other "enemies" of the revolution.
In a newly published book, "Children of Cambodia's Killing Fields" (Yale University Press, 1997), Teeda Butt Mam, a survivor who now lives in the United States, lists some of those victims:
"The rebellious, the kind-hearted, the brave, the clever, the individuals, the people who wore glasses, the literate, the popular, the complainers, the lazy, those with talent, those with trouble getting along with others, those with soft hands."
After being driven from power in early 1979 by a Vietnamese invasion, the Khmer Rouge retreated to hideouts in the mountains and jungles along the Thai border, where they resumed their guerrilla war.
Mr. Son Sen became vice president of Democratic Kampuchea, a nominal government that retained its international recognition and its seat in the United Nations because of Western opposition to the Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia.
He was also president of the Defense Committee of a non-Communist insurgency in which the Khmer Rouge were allied with democratic forces to fight the Vietnamese.
When that decade-long war formally ended with the Paris peace accords in 1991, he led military negotiations with the United Nations as it brokered arrangements for elections that established a democratic Government.
But the Khmer Rouge leadership chose to boycott the elections themselves, in 1992, and went to war once again against the newly installed Government. In the end, it seems to have succumbed not to armed force but to its own internal divisions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pol Pot, left, marching in western Cambodia after his overthrow in 1979. ("The Pol Pot Regime," Yale University Press)
 
Chronology: "The Khmer Rouge and Cambodia: A Chronology"
 
1953: Cambodia gains independence from France; new government, a constitutional monarchy, is led by King Norodom Sihanouk.
 
1960: Saloth Sar, known by nom de guerre Pol Pot, helps set up Khmer Rouge, a Communist party.
 
1964: Khmer Rouge launch peasant uprising against Sihanouk.
 
1970: Right-wing coup, supported by United States and led by Prime Minister Lon Nol, topples Sihanouk, who joins with Khmer Rouge to launch resistance war. Khmer Rouge get Chinese and Vietnamese help.
 
1975: Khmer Rouge topple Lon Nol and begin doomed experiment in agrarian Communism. Purges begin among Khmer Rouge leadership, then extend to population. Over next four years, hundreds of thousands are executed or die of starvation or overwork.
 
1978: Vietnam invades Cambodia to stop Khmer Rouge border attacks.
 
1979: Phnom Penh falls to Vietnamese, who install client regime made up mostly of Khmer Rouge defectors led by Hun Sen. Khmer Rouge retreat to Thai border, set up guerrilla bases, pick up support from Thailand.
 
1982: Khmer Rouge and two non-communist groups form resistance coalition. Sihanouk serves as figurehead leader.
 
1989: Under international pressure, Vietnam withdraws last 26,000 troops.
 
1991: All Cambodian factions, including Khmer Rouge, sign peace agreement providing for U.N. peacekeeping and elections. Khmer Rouge President Khieu Samphan and military commander Son Sen return to Phnom Penh for first time since 1979, flee same day after mob tries to lynch Khieu Samphan.
 
1993: U.N.-supervised general election proceeds smoothly, despite Khmer Rouge boycott. Royalist party led by Norodom Ranariddh, Sihanouk's son, wins, but he is forced to share power with Hun Sen.
 
1996: Government announces split in Khmer Rouge. Pol Pot's brother-in-law, Ieng Sary, leads defections eventually totaling 3,000 to 4,000 guerrillas. According to some estimates, this represents one-half to three-quarters of the overall force.
 
1997: Ranariddh reports that Son Sen, his wife and relatives have been killed on Pol Pot's orders. Rebel radio calls Son Sen a traitor. Khmer Rouge appear broken into two or three factions. Pol Pot reportedly being pursued by rivals.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 39; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1124 words

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Yes, a Big Seller Can Have Footnotes

BYLINE: By James Shapiro; James Shapiro teaches English at Columbia University and writes a column on publishing for The Chronicle of Higher Education.

 BODY:
I have no illusions about the relative unpopularity of university press books. The notion of a university press "best seller" is, in the minds of many, an oxymoron. Of the $20 billion that was spent in this country on books last year, only a feeble $350 million, or 1.7 percent, was spent on those published by the hundred or so university presses; that's about a third of what Americans spent on religious books.
A look at what sells best among university press books doesn't change those numbers, but it calls into question some enduring myths. The first holds that university presses produce only expensive, unattractive, dry-as-dust academic monographs; the second, which contradicts the first, maintains that they have all but abandoned their traditional scholarly mission in pursuit of the latest post-structuralist, jargon-ridden trend. Central to both myths is the conviction that university press books are irrelevant to the lives of those outside academe. 
 When I recently asked some marketing directors what a current list of top-selling university press books might look like, they admitted that they didn't really know, and turned the conversation to "all time" big sellers: the Concise Oxford Dictionary (Oxford University), 11 million copies; Kate L. Turabian's "Manual for Writers of Term Papers, Theses and Dissertations" (University of Chicago), 5 million; and the New Oxford Annotated Bible (Oxford), 3 million. But this information says more about the past than it does about a present in which the rules have changed, when neither scholars nor libraries are buying the numbers of books that they once did, when university support for presses has withered, and when presses are finding themselves competing against tough-minded commercial publishers for authors and readers.
I decided to try compiling a list myself. Amazon.com (an on-line bookseller), half a dozen major independent bookstores and the Ingram Book Company, a leading wholesaler with 42,000 accounts, each gave me a ranked listing of its top-selling university press hardcover books for January of this year. (University presses are defined as those that have faculty review boards.) Books that appeared on more than two lists made the cut for my list. I'm confident that this was about as close as I could come to a fair list, while I'm aware that some of the books would have been replaced by others had I contacted a different set of bookstores.
Perhaps the biggest surprise was the dominance of books on science and history; law, criticism and writing guides rounded things out. Certain books fared better at different stores. Science books sold well at Amazon.com, while Walter Benjamin's collected essays ranked near the top at New York's Posman Books, the Harvard Book Store and Chicago's Seminary Co-op. (Benjamin wasn't even among the top 70 at Ingram, however, and wouldn't be on the final list if not for that endangered species, the independent bookstore.) And while university presses may be publishing many books about multiculturalism, they didn't sell as well as books focusing on Western Europe. "Florence," "Mary Through the Centuries," "The Measure of Reality," "The Scientific Revolution," "The Quotable Einstein," "Walter Benjamin: Selected Writings" and, most obviously, Norman Davies's vast survey, "Europe," testify to the strength of interest in Western cultural and scientific achievement.
The appearance of a book on the list by Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court may also signal a trend. Even as academic stars drawn by generous advances are turning to trade houses, prominent figures outside the academic world are looking to university or other academic presses. It's worth noting that the late Joseph Cardinal Bernardin's "Gift of Peace" was published by Loyola Press (an academic, though not a university, press); it was on the New York Times best-seller list for 16 weeks.
The list is also dominated by what are generally acknowledged to be major university presses: Harvard, Yale, Oxford, Chicago, Princeton and Cambridge. MIT, a smaller press, had a big seller by playing to its strengths in the sciences. Most of the books on the list have expensive four-color jackets; half are illustrated, three with color plates. But the claim that university presses have abandoned the defining feature of the scholarly book -- notes, bibliographies and indexes -- will find little support here. All are indexed, three include bibliographies and half the nonreference books have notes, including three -- "A Matter of Interpretation," "The Measure of Reality" and "The Scientific Revolution" -- that place these notes on the bottom of the page, rather than relegating them to the back of the book.
Most of these are hefty volumes, averaging just under 500 pages. But they cost on the average only about $27.50, just a few dollars more than their slimmer counterparts on The Times's hardcover nonfiction best-seller list. A couple -- notably the Chicago Manual of Style and the New Fowler's Modern English Usage -- may continue selling enough copies over the long haul for the presses to subsidize more specialized scholarly books, though the authors are unlikely to get rich from these titles. The odds of any of these books making a "real" best-seller list is not great, though Oxford continues to have high expectations for "Europe," with 100,000 copies now in print worldwide. For most of these books, though, a run of 12,000 to 15,000 will be a strong one, and some may struggle to break into five figures.
If this list is any indication, university presses are now producing, along with specialized scholarship, books that are handsome, competitively priced, accessibly written and committed to explaining to general readers fundamental historical, scientific, legal and literary issues. But it remains unclear whether this is enough to overcome suspicions on the part of booksellers, readers and reviewers about what's inside the cover of a university press book.
In 1996, a year in which more university press books were available to more readers (thanks to the superstores) than ever before, the rate of growth for university presses was a lowly 2.8 percent, well below the sluggish industry average of 4 percent. If the staggeringly high rate of "returns" from the superstores continues, this year's figures will probably be grimmer. Facing these economic prospects, university presses may well turn inward, redirecting resources into more dependable, if more modest, alternatives. It will be a shame if, at a time when the gulf between academe and the literate public threatens to grow ever wider, an opportunity to draw the two worlds together through crossover university press books is lost.

GRAPHIC: Table: University Press Hit Parade
An unofficial, alphabetized list of the top-selling hardcover books published by university presses. Sales were reported for the month of January 1997.

 THE CHICAGO MANUAL OF STYLE. (University of Chicago, $40.) The 14th edition of a writers' guide to usage, style and documentation.

 EUROPE: A History, by Norman Davies. (Oxford University, $39.95.) The Continent from its prehistory to the end of the 20th century.

 FLORENCE: A Portrait, by Michael Levey. (Harvard University, $35.) The art and culture of the city from the 13th through the 19th centuries.

 HAL'S LEGACY: 2001's Computer as Dream and Reality, edited by David G. Stork. (MIT, $22.50.) Essays comparing science fantasy with reality.

 INVENTION BY DESIGN: How Engineers Get From Thought to Thing, by Henry Petroski. (Harvard University, $24.95.) The nature of problem solving.

 MARY THROUGH THE CENTURIES: Her Place in the History of Culture, by Jaroslav Pelikan. (Yale University, $25.) A study of Marian devotion.

 A MATTER OF INTERPRETATION: Federal Courts and the Law, by Antonin Scalia. (Princeton University, $19.95.) A critique of the idea that judicial interpretation should be guided by legislative intent.

HEADLINE: The New Japans

BYLINE: By Alan Tonelson; Alan Tonelson is a research fellow at the United States Business and Industrial Council Educational Foundation.

 BODY:

THE BIG TEN
 The Big Emerging Markets
 and How They Will Change Our Lives.
 By Jeffrey E. Garten.
 232 pp. New York:
 Basic Books. $24. 
 Until recently, when Americans worried about economic competition from abroad they focused on advanced industrialized democracies like Japan and Germany. Today, we are likelier to become embroiled in trade disputes with third world countries like China and Mexico. According to Jeffrey E. Garten, a former top trade policy adviser to President Clinton and now the dean of the Yale School of Management, this change heralds a new era for the world economy.
"The Big Ten" identifies the main agents of the change as a group of 10 countries that are in the process of becoming important enough to affect the entire world economy. Along with China and Mexico, they are Argentina, Brazil, India, Indonesia, Poland, South Africa, South Korea and Turkey.
The good news, Mr. Garten argues, is that his "Big Ten" are so potentially wealthy that they may provide producers everywhere with huge new markets -- and hence opportunities for profits and job creation. Especially encouraging, in the author's view, is their rapid adoption of free market practices. The bad news, he warns, is that the 10 don't always agree with the United States on many of the issues that could make or break the world's economic future: for example, how extensively governments should influence trade and investment flows; what rights workers and consumers can legitimately claim; how to insure that further global growth doesn't ruin the environment.
As Mr. Garten observes, several of these emerging powers will also play key roles in solving or aggravating many noneconomic problems, like terrorism and nuclear weapons proliferation. At the same time, most of the 10 are themselves powder kegs, struggling, often unsuccessfully, to contain the pro-democracy pressures generated by greater economic freedom and the greater economic inequality it usually breeds.
Yet Washington is generally unprepared to meet these countries' multidimensional challenges. Even the Administration he served in, Mr. Garten contends, has taken only the first small steps.
For the most part, the Clinton Administration and others urging breakneck trade expansion with the 10 have portrayed them in Polyanna-ish terms. All of these countries, they insist, are steadily liberalizing economically and politically. Mexico is nearly a full-fledged industrialized democracy. China will move toward reform and pluralism through greater trade and investment flows. And all except the worst-educated, least-prepared Americans will profit handsomely from increased trade with these growing economies.
"The Big Ten" is a welcome, though partial, corrective to such views. Over the long term, Mr. Garten believes, the power of technology and free markets, as well as the appeal of political liberty, will turn the emerging market countries into reliable economic and political partners. Yet he realizes that the equally important short and medium terms could be perilous. In fact, he foresees such formidable obstacles ahead that he advises American leaders to play down the goal of global stability and think harder about coping with greater instability. In addition, he repeatedly warns that the growing ability of the 10 to produce sophisticated goods and services at rock-bottom prices could drag down the living standards of even affluent, well-educated Americans -- a prospect widely pooh-poohed by trade enthusiasts in and out of government.
The virtues of "The Big Ten," however, don't outweigh its flaws. Despite their rapid growth, most of these countries are still small change, especially as markets for American products. In fact, Mr. Garten's claim that "the United States now exports more in goods and services to the 10 big emerging markets than to all of Europe and Japan combined" is simply untrue. In 1995, the last year for which a complete geographic breakdown is available, total American exports to Europe and Japan were nearly double those to the 10 (even counting Hong Kong as part of China).
Nor are American exports to many of the 10 growing very fast. Indeed, goods exports to booming China hardly increased at all in 1996, and are lower than goods exports to tiny, stagnating Belgium.
Mr. Garten overlooks the many reasons why consumer markets in these emerging countries are likely to stay small for decades, even if formal trade barriers come down. Two reasons stand out. First, largely because most of these nations have huge foreign debts to pay off, and therefore need to discourage consumption by their populations, they are pursuing export-led growth strategies. Second, if they don't keep wages and purchasing power low, they will have difficulty attracting the foreign investment they require, both to service debt and to finance growth. China, the biggest of the 10, has made it abundantly clear that it has no intention of becoming a major importer; it aims eventually to satisfy most of its own needs.
Where these countries are playing truly significant global economic roles is as production sites for multinational companies seeking to cut costs on the products they sell to the industrialized countries -- especially the wide-open American market. Yet Mr. Garten pays scant attention to these corporations, or to the immense power they wield over American trade policy, especially toward the 10.
Because he exaggerates the power of these countries, Mr. Garten underestimates Washington's influence over them. As a result, he winds up recommending almost wholly ineffectual policy responses. Americans, he warns, can no longer act as if "others need us more than we need them," and he suggests that the only hope for influencing the 10 is in essence to ask them politely to behave themselves.
Actually, it is the United States that holds most of the cards. The 10 need American technology, they need American capital and they desperately need to sell to the American market (which represents fully 25 percent of the world economy). Recognizing this power, nurturing it actively and using it to protect our economic and security interests is the key to coping successfully with these countries -- not the sophisticated defeatism of Mr. Garten's "solutions."

HEADLINE: ECO-TOURISM;
A River Runs Clearer

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is chief of the Denver bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
SPANISH Colonial explorers, who traveled without inflatable rubber rafts, halted their northern advance on the banks of the Arkansas River. Blocked by roiling whitewater, they called it a day, declaring this fast-flowing river the northernmost border of an empire that stretched 8,000 miles down to Argentina. Impressed by the region's reddish cliffs, the 17th-century Spanish named this land Colorado.
The Upper Arkansas, once a barrier to the Spanish, became an industrial sewer to 19th-century American miners, flushing away acid wastes from the gold, lead and silver mines that honeycombed the Rocky Mountain headwaters. 
 More recently, the Arkansas has become a recreational thoroughfare, plied each summer by as many as 200,000 people who take commercial raft trips. Now Colorado's most popular rafting river, the Arkansas is clean again, protected in large part by the huge constituency that has grown up around river rafting.
In late May, when my 7-year-old son, James, toppled overboard near the start of a two-hour trip from Salida, my concern was not about contamination, but about exposure to 50-degree water. Fished out in a flash, James soon warmed up with a pullover and a hat provided by our boatman, 32-year-old Greg Felt.
When we stopped on a sand bar to wring out James's wet suit, Greg explained how tourists and fishermen are placing a premium on clean water coursing down from the mountains.
"When half a million people a year go out on these raft trips, it has an impact on the politicians," said Greg, who last year served as chairman of the Colorado River Outfitters Association, a group that represents about half of the 120 licensed rafting companies in the state.
This river lobby, along with other groups, successfully pressured members of Congress from Colorado to win Federal money to stop acid drainage from abandoned mines in Leadville, near the headwaters of the Arkansas. Because of the cleanup, started in the early 90's, brown trout and rainbow trout are thriving once again.
"It's quite an ecological success story -- the fishing has really improved," according to Greg, who owns Canyon Marine Whitewater Expeditions, one of a dozen Colorado outfitters that offer fishing as well as recreational rafting trips.
Rafting is part of a boom in summer tourism in Colorado, a state long associated with skiing. Today, golf courses carpet Vail valley, and almost every mountain ski town holds a summer music or dance festival. Summer tourists ride mountain bikes down ski slopes, go on Jeep tours on old logging roads, or ride rafts down boulder-strewn rivers.
 WITH the steep mountains of the Continental Divide serving as headwaters for three major rivers -- the Arkansas, the Colorado and the Platte -- Colorado has seen the number of rafters carried by commercial companies double, from 208,000 in 1988 to 428,000 in 1995. This summer, rafting is expected to pump $83 million into rural Colorado, according to an estimate by the Outfitters Association. Outfitters must observe certain ecological regulations in order to qualify for permits, such as keeping camps a certain distance from the river, and packing up their trash.
Today, every major Colorado ski town offers summer rafting on a nearby river. For Vail, it is the Eagle River; for Aspen, it is the Roaring Fork; for Steamboat, it is the Yampa; for Breckenridge, it is the Blue; for Telluride, it is the San Miguel; for Crested Butte, it is the Taylor; and for Gunnison, it is the Gunnison.
This spring, the levels of unmelted snow were about 30 percent above average in the Colorado Rockies, setting the stage for a busy -- and boisterous -- river running season.
In Salida, an 1880's mining and railroad junction town, motel rooms that fill up with elk hunters in the fall, with skiers in the winter and with fishermen in the spring now fill with rafting families in the summer. Many instructors from Monarch Ski Area, 20 miles west of Salida, now have summer employment, earning as much as $120 a day, including tips, by guiding raftloads of tourists down rapids.
"In the West, rivers used to be where you threw things," said Steve Reese, park manager of the Arkansas Headwaters Recreation Area, an intergovernmental agency set up almost a decade ago to manage recreation on a 148-mile stretch of the river, from Leadville to Pueblo. "Now, houses face the river. Yards go down to the river."
Reflecting these changing attitudes, Pueblo, which was heavily damaged by an Arkansas flood in 1921, started a $26 million project this spring to channel part of the river through a new downtown Riverwalk, a 26-acre park complete with an amphitheater and water taxis.
In Salida, this new river community could be seen on May 17, when 320 volunteers turned out to do a job that local governments could never afford to do -- scouring a 125-mile section of the Arkansas for trash.
With each of about 30 participating raft companies taking a river section, volunteers removed tons of garbage, planted about 350 trees and bushes, to create habitat for wildlife and minimize river-bank erosion, and installed about 30 birdhouses for bluebirds.
"We pulled out a 55-gallon oil drum, a shopping cart, sheet metal, a bunch of fencing, and furniture," Greg Felt said of his company's participation in the annual cleanup day. "We filled the back of a pickup truck."
At the end of the day, the volunteers gathered at Salida's River Park for a free barbecue, with music, sponsored by the Colorado Lottery.
One week after the cleanup, our nine-mile float downriver from Salida showed how the community has turned toward its waterway. Suited up with wet suits and life jackets, Greg and the five Brookes pushed off from the Salida boat ramp, uncomfortably close to a local geographic feature, Tenderfoot Hill. Immediately, we ducked our heads to avoid a series of poles strung over the river to create an urban slalom course for kayakers.
With Greg pushing at the oars to guide our ungainly craft, we passed backyards that reflected a cultural split in this town of 5,000 people. Some yards were used to park dead snowmobiles. Others had been landscaped, with walks leading down to fishing platforms or canoeing docks.
About 60 percent of the river-bank frontage in the Recreation Area is privately owned. Because of the increased use of the river, No Trespassing signs are now a frequent sight. Although some rafters have complained of bumping into other rafts on the crowded river, we never saw another raft during our two-hour float.
Our solitude on a Saturday afternoon may have been because of our choice of water -- Class II rapids, described in a brochure as "fun for the whole family." Our 5-year-old twins, Alexander and William, barely cleared the 35-pound minimum that most rafting companies impose on children.
The Upper Arkansas, which drops almost a vertical mile in its 150-mile navigable stretch, offers rapids of all classes. Class III stretches are generally for rafters 12 years and over. Class IV is usually "adults only." In mid-May, Robert Walmer, a ski instructor at Monarch, drowned while kayaking in his own boat through one of the most difficult rapids on the Upper Arkansas, a stretch that alternates between Class V and Class VI. Guidebooks define Class VI as "being at risk of life and limb." As more Colorado athletes jump into kayaks, casualties are mounting. Four others died last year on the Arkansas.
On the Canyon Marine raft on May 24, the biggest risk seemed to be of catching a cold. In the bow, a drenching spray combined with a brisk upriver breeze to make for a bone-chilling cold. But by late June, when the busy rafting season begins, water temperatures hover around a balmy 60 degrees. By August, the average flow can fall to 700 cubic feet per second, easily navigable, but one-third the volumes of late May.
As small waves slapped our turquoise craft, we passed corrals of a cattle auction house, then a remarkably mild-smelling municipal sewage plant. Then the scenery gradually became more rural. To our right rose snow-streaked peaks of the northern end of the Sangre de Cristo mountain chain. In nearby foothills, the abandoned workings of a gold mine could occasionally be spotted, its fine trail of tailings looking like termite dust seeping from a log. Along river banks, cottonwoods, willows and junipers flourished. Here and there, beavers had gnawed into the trunk of a leafy tree.
Small black swallows darted back and forth, skimming the water's surface for insects carried by the powerful spring runoff. Once, we spotted the telltale flash of a red-winged blackbird and the regal sail of a golden eagle.
On the left bank, we watched a fisherman land a brown trout. On another stretch, a weekend miner sluiced river dirt, searching for flecks of gold.
 OUR floating reverie was broken by the racket of a freight train, rumbling down the Union Pacific tracks that border most of the Upper Arkansas. But with industrial mining dying out around here, the railroad plans to stop freight service this October. If another railroad does not step forward in coming weeks, the tracks are to be torn out next summer.
Completing this region's economic shift from industry to recreation, state planners intend to convert the century-old rail route into a trail for hikers, mountain bikers and horseback riders.
"Rafters learn appreciation for clean water, for the environment," said Steve Reese, an advocate for green tourism in the Arkansas River valley. "You don't leave footprints when you are in a boat."
Canyon Marine Whitewater Expeditions, 135 West Rainbow (Highway 50), Salida, Colo. 81201, (800) 643-0707 or (719) 539-7476, fax (719) 539 7621, offers half-day rafting trips from mid-April to Sept. 21 from $29 to $49 a person for adults; $23 for children. For a full day, the price is $59 to $98 a person for adults; $45 for children. Fishing trips, from late April through October, are $95 for a half day, $165 for a full day. Reservations recommended.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
'Beach and Beast' Resort Planned for Mozambique

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
The Government of Mozambique has given the go-ahead for an eccentric American millionaire to try to realize his dream: turning a stretch of unspoiled Mozambican coastline into a huge game reserve.
The goal of James Ulysses Blanchard 3d is to make about 900 square miles of southern Mozambique, including a 56-mile swath of white sand dunes, a "beast and beach" paradise -- that is, a reserve where tourists could see everything from elephants to flamingos and also swim, sail and scuba dive in warm Indian Ocean waters. 
 Right now, the area is sparsely populated and fairly pristine, despite being just south of the capital, Maputo, and a day's drive from Johannesburg, the crowded economic hub of South Africa.
The human and animal populations were both devastated by Mozambique's 17-year civil war -- most of the big mammals in the Maputo Elephant Reserve were killed for food or for their horns and tusks, while most of the people around the reserve were driven away by the back-and-forth fighting between Frelimo, the dominant party in the current Government, and Renamo, the rebel movement that opposed it. About 10,000 have returned to the area, in helter-skelter fashion: two small coastal towns have revived, living off fishing and scuba tourists from South Africa, and subsistence farmers have chopped and burned tiny plots in and outside the elephant reserve.
Mr. Blanchard's plans include million-dollar homes, game lodges, golf courses and marinas. His architects are musing about a floating casino, seaside hotels in the shape of beached cruise ships and an elegant steam railway on a 100-mile loop. The whole project as envisioned will take more than 10 years and $800 million to finish.
Getting Government permission and fighting off a rival proposal by a South African paper company to turn the area into a eucalyptus-tree plantation were only the first steps. Mr. Blanchard now has to raise the money, which he hopes to do from a circle of wealthy friends and by offering shares to emerging-market mutual funds and hotel chains.
Mr. Blanchard, a 53-year-old Louisiana native, is a controversial figure in Mozambique, but certainly good at raising money. Starting as a numismatist who wanted to buy and sell gold coins at a time when private ownership of the metal was illegal for Americans, he made a fortune in newsletters, mutual funds and conferences for gold investors. An outspoken libertarian and supporter of anti-Communist causes, he donated money, medical supplies and radios to Renamo, the rebel movement.
He has made his peace with the Frelimo-dominated Government and is now one of a handful of foreign investors seriously interested in Mozambique, which is desperately short of simple things like electric power and drivable roads.
"I'm accused of being a naive visionary, but I don't think the world can stand by and write off Africa," he said. "The amount of money needed to create jobs and property is so small." His reserve would eventually create 12,000 jobs, he said. Local residents, many of whom earn less than $100 a year, would be given shares and first crack at the jobs created.
But before that, big game, the element that draws tourists, has to be brought back. In the next few weeks, said Eugene Gouws, the chief ecological planner for Mr. Blanchard, the first 12 miles of electrified fence will be built for $135,000 to keep the remaining elephants out of local farms. There will still be time before the hot weather returns in October to move in nyala (an antelope with spiraling horns), buffalo and giraffe. "We'll keep to game that's territorial and won't run all over the show," Mr. Gouws said. Some of the remaining elephants got out recently and devastated local cropland.
Eventually, the five-year game-stocking plan will kick in. Zebras are cheap at $400 apiece, and young adult elephants are a steal at $2,130, but endangered black rhinos run $32,000. And with most species, you can't buy just one. The starter buffalo herd will be 120 animals at $2,100 apiece.
The first accommodations, in a tent camp near the beach, where visitors can go diving and deep-sea fishing, will be up by mid-July, Mr. Gouws said. Their primary use will be to entertain potential investors, but paying guests will be able to use them on weekends, "for perhaps $200 a night," he said.
Also, efforts to win over local people will speed up. Mr. Blanchard has said he will put in clinics, bore new wells and build a lakeside village with shops and schools as employees are hired.
Hotel chains and other operators invited in will have to adhere to the master plan, which covers everything from architectural design to hiring and training local people.
Mia Cuoto, a Mozambican biologist retained by the Government to evaluate Mr. Blanchard's plan, said the Government remained a bit nervous about such mega-projects, but found the plan preferable to proposals to turn the area into tree farms for pulp mills.
"The area's vocation is eco-tourism," he said, and the Government's main concern is for dislocated residents. Those who don't get jobs will need firewood and cropland, and those who do will still need occasional access to forest groves and graveyards that are sacred to them.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Learning How To Tread Lightly

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
RESPONSIBLE tourism does not safeguard only plants and animals. With the boom in eco-tourism (as well as in adventure and educational travel), trips to areas where indigenous peoples live apart from the industrial world are of increasing concern.
A number of watchdog organizations have sprung up to offer guidance to tour operators and independent travelers who want to leave only footprints and to avoid even that, if footprints might disturb. There are also books to guide the conscientious. 
 The nonprofit Eco-Tourism Society, a five-year-old group in North Bennington, Vt., considers eco-tourism a segment of the nature tourism market, and offers this definition: "Responsible travel to natural areas that conserves the environment and sustains the well-being of local people." This group does not operate tours; it wants to help people find their way instead of taking them by the hand. Like other organizations, it stresses the informed consent and participation of local residents as the starting point for responsible tourism in less developed areas.
Don Montague, head of the 20-year-old South American Explorers Club, a membership group for individual travelers, says a prime issue is how much of the tourist dollar goes to the local people. The club does not offer tours, but distributes first-person reports on tours or independent trips taken by other members.
Dr. David Pearson, a professor of zoology at Arizona State University in Tempe, discussed two projects in Ecuador as illustrating the crucial nature of local participation. One is the Limoncocha Biological Reserve in eastern Ecuador. In the 1970's, this area was accessible only by missionary plane or canoe; it then had breathtaking views of Amazonian flora and fauna. A road was built in the late 1980's, bringing colonists, and although the Government declared the site a biological reserve, the use of dynamite in fishing wiped out the fish and alligators in the lake. This site is now a sad memory, Professor Pearson said, one that "I do not want to see again."
 
Rejecting Roads
 Recently, he said, an awareness has developed that the formula "if you build it, they will come" is not a recipe for sustainable development. He cited the Kapawi area, near Ecuador's southeastern border, where the Achuar Indians rejected roads and cattle as part of development. Professor Pearson said the Achuar knew change was inevitable but wanted to control it. An Ecuadorean company, Canadros, approached the Indians' president, offering $2 million to develop tourism, agreeing, for instance, to build without nails so that when things rotted, they would return wholly to the earth. "They did not cut corners," Professor Pearson said.
"They said they would teach the local people how to make beds and how to mix martinis and how to lead a nature tour, things they had not thought of," he added. "At the end of 15 years, the agreement says, the whole development will be turned over to the local people."
Kapawi started receiving tourists in April, Professor Pearson said. The project will be included in a new edition of a book by Professor Pearson and David Middleton, "The New Key to Ecuador and the Galapagos." It is due in August from Ulysses Press in Berkeley, Calif.; (510) 601-8301.
The South American Explorers Club distributes first-person reports it receives from members. Not all reports are circulated, Mr. Montague said, because the organization believes some peoples should be visited only by anthropologists.
Mr. Montague sells a book he considers "a model of things to come" in guides: "The Eco-Tourist's Guide to the Ecuadorian Amazon: Napo Province." It was prepared by Prof. Rolf Wesche of the University of Ottawa and 13 geography students and published in 1995 by the Pan American Center for Geographical Studies in Quito.
The authors describe Napo Province as offering one of the widest ranges of facilities and programs in the Amazon Basin and opportunities for sustainable tourism as an alternative to oil, agriculture and lumber. The 106-page guide, with a thick pocket of topographical maps, is dense with data: bus schedules and lists of cabana quarters, guided tours and indigenous eco-tourism projects in each area. The book costs $29, plus $6.50 for postage, or $25, plus $4.50, for members. Regular membership is $40 a year. South American Explorers Club, 126 Indian Creek Road, Ithaca, N.Y. 14850; (607) 277-0488; E-mail explorer@samexplo.org; the Web site is www.samexplo.org.
 
Organized Communities
 A human rights organization, Survival International, with offices in London, Paris, Milan and Madrid, is preparing a publication that will come out later this year listing a very few tribal communities that have organized to accommodate tourists while safeguarding their native lands and cultures. A spokesman in London, Richard Garside, estimates that 200 such community organizations exist, probably 100 of them in Australia.
One task the human-rights group undertakes is monitoring the way a people is presented to the world. Isolated tribes that are advertised by tour operators as exotic or Stone Age survivors, he pointed out, do not take long to catch on to what arriving tourists expect and may ornament themselves or invent rituals to earn money, jeopardizing their historic culture. Survival International, 11-15 Emerald Street, London WC1N 3QL, England; (44-171) 242-1441.
The Eco-Tourism Society will provide a list of 60 to 80 member organizations on request; enclose an addressed envelope with two 32-cent stamps. The organizations sign a pledge on joining, according to its president, Megan Epler Wood, but she stressed that the society neither accredits nor endorses any tours. Memberships cost $35 a year for an individual who does not want to be listed in the membership directory. The Eco-Tourism Society, Post Office Box 755, North Bennington, Vt. 05257; (802) 447-2121; E-mail, ecomail@ecotourism.org.
The American Museum of Natural History in New York and its Discovery Tours are on the society's list. According to Dick Houghton, a museum spokesman, almost all of its 60 programs for this year, including trips to Botswana, Ethiopia and the Rift Valley in the Middle East and Africa, are sold out. The catalogue for 1998 has 46 tours. Like almost all tours offered by nonprofit groups, the tours are actually run by commercial operators. The Natural History brochure says that "to insure ethical behavior toward local eco-systems and peoples," it selects operators with a "demonstrated history of responsible tourism."
The 1998 catalogue lists a tour to Papua New Guinea Jan. 28 to Feb. 10. For a maximum of 40, it includes a five-day catamaran trip on the Sepik River; it is run by High Country Passage of Palo Alto, Calif., which serves nonprofit groups only. Depending on the cruise cabin, the price is $6,970 to $8,770, including San Francisco-Hong Kong flights. American Museum of Natural History-Discovery Tours, Central Park West at 79th Street, New York, N.Y. 10024; (212) 769-5700 or (800) 462-8687.
Lisle Inc. is a 60-year-old volunteer organization "committed to a more just social order" that seeks to bring diverse people together through cooperative, democratic leadership and participation. The members travel and interact with local groups that share their views of a need for change.
The organization is offering four trips this year, all conducted by Lisle members. A trip to India to visit two ashrams and work with leaders on their social goals is scheduled for Dec. 13 to Jan. 4. Dianne Brause, a vice president and a former Peace Corps member who writes on alternative travel, said the maximum would probably be 20 and the cost would probably be $1,295, not including air fare to New Delhi. A visit in late December to co-operatives that are creating development projects and eco-lodges in Costa Rica is expected to run $1,200 to $2,000 without air fare. Lisle, in care of Mark Kinney, 433 West Sterns Road, Temperance, Mich. 48182; (800) 477-1538; fax (419) 530-1245; E-mail mkinney@utnet.utoledo.edu; Web site http://www.lisle.utoledo.edu.
Earthwatch, 25 years old, sends out volunteers to participate in various projects, from folklore to agriculture; the volunteers pay relatively stiff fees, which support the project and pay operating expenses for Earthwatch, a nonprofit organization. The catalogue of projects may be seen on the Internet at http://www.earthwatch.org. One free catalogue may also be ordered by phone or mail. Membership, for $35 a year, brings catalogues and newsletters. Earthwatch, 680 Mount Auburn Street, Post Office Box 9104, Watertown, Mass. 02272; (800) 776-0188; E-mail info@earthwatch.org.
Among the more fragile environments are the remainders of the historic native American cultures in the United States. Painted Desert Productions in Scottsdale, Ariz., offers up to eight Southwest tours a year designed for museums and universities. These include visits to pueblos and cultural sites.
Bonnie Lewis, the president of the company, said that native Americans controlled access to their pueblos and ceremonies, and each year a few more places exclude visitors because of failure to observe the rules. Ms. Lewis said the company spent a lot of time preparing clients for trips into pueblos or venerated sites. "All of our tours have an anthropologist," she said.

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Yes, Italian Fare, and Hearty Portions, Too

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS 

 BODY:
WHILE dining at Bellissimo in Waterbury, we found ourselves thinking of a recent letter in which the writer asked, "Why do you only review Italian restaurants?" Anyone who keeps track knows that isn't the case, but it sometimes does seem that every other new restaurant in Connecticut is Italian. This says a lot about economics (the relatively low costs of pasta and pizza) and also about contemporary taste preferences.
Though Bellissimo is more ambitious than the average pizza-and-pasta place, it does have 14 pasta dishes (no pizzas). There are other Italian standards, like veal Marsala, calamari friti, chicken cacciatora and scampi fra diavolo. 
 Many dishes have a decidedly modern spin, such as vitello Bellissimo. Herb-coated escalopes of tender veal, pan-seared, then topped with roasted red peppers and fresh mozzarella, came in a seductively tangy sauce. The tang was provided by combining herbs, shallots, balsamic vinegar and veal broth, with results that tantalized our taste buds.
As is often the case at Italian restaurants, Bellissimo was profligate in most of its portions, especially the entrees. Even a starter like portobello Bellissimo might have doubled as a light supper. A big bowl arrived full of pan-seared mushroom slices, roasted red pepper strips and garlic, and an herb-rich broth, topped with wisps of crisp-fried onions. Tucked beneath all the vegetables were wedges of polenta, softened by the broth but soul-satisfying nonetheless, mushy or not. Gamberi alla griglia was just as generous and as robust. Several pan-seared jumbo shrimp, tossed with pancetta bits, white beans and fresh garlic atop a bed of wilted greens, came in a flavorful white wine bath.
Garlic was a dominant player throughout our meal, beginning with the bulb of roasted garlic buds served with olive oil and warm Italian bread (a boringly commercial type) and focaccia (good). Garlic also appeared in a delicious version of clams casino (vongole alla casino), along with chopped red peppers, onions, bacon and three cheeses. Garlic was a given in the spinaci and salsiccia (spinach and sausauge) that swam in a watery broth.
All entrees were Gargantuan, obviating the need for three courses, especially since a light green salad, with a perky Parmesan-black pepper dressing, was included in meals. (Starters were too zesty to skip, the rather mundane desserts -- except for a rich tiramisu -- were easier.)
In addition to the above-mentioned vitello Bellissimo, salmone alla citrus was a successful main course, lightly grilled, not overcooked. The fish didn't really need both the mountain of mashed potatoes (dried-out, unfortunately) and shredded red cabbage that were served with it.
Pollo Michelina was a fine pasta choice. A large bowl of penne was profuse with grilled chicken strips, wild mushrooms, artichoke hearts, roasted red peppers and herbs, sauteed with chopped tomatoes, olive oil and chicken stock.
Misto D'Andrea was peppy and just as bountiful, though more of a mishmash: chicken, veal and hot sausage jumbled with plum tomatoes, caramelized onions, wild mushrooms, roasted garlic, hot peppers and other vegetables in a veal stock sauce.
Dinner for two, three courses apiece, came to $56.70, before tax, tip and drinks. The wine list -- 21 reds and 10 whites -- of Italian and California vintages, runs from $15 to $45, with many options in the $20 range. A small, but intriguing beer list includes Watertown-brewed Hammer & Nails.
Bellissimo with its simple, attractive black and white decor and cheerful, upbeat service, provides many hearty, well-made dishes, making dinner bella, though not bellissimo yet.
 
Bellissimo
Good
 
 625 Chase Avenue, Waterbury. (203) 754-3898.
Atmosphere: Medium-small space divided into non- smoking and smoking rooms, with booths, black and white decor, photographs of Italy.
Service: Jovial, quick and accommodating.
Recommended dishes: Portobello Bellissimo, vongole alla casino, gamberi alla griglia, salmone alla citrus, vitello Bellissimo, pollo Michelina, tiramisu.
Price range: Lunch $6.95-$10.95, dinner $8.95-$24.95.
Credit cards: All major cards.
Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Monday through Saturday, 4 to 10 P.M. Monday through Saturday, noon to 8 P.M. Sunday.
Reservations: Accepted.
Wheelchair accessibility: Dining room at ground level, restrooms at dining room level.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

BYLINE: By SUZANNE MacNEILLE

 BODY:

September in Paris
 
Q. I plan to be in Paris this September and would like a calendar of cultural events. Where can I find one? -- Seymour Dunn, Hollywood, Fla.
 
A. Paris Selection, a free monthly publication put out by the Paris Tourist Office, probably contains the most thorough listing of cultural events. It comes out two weeks before the first of each month, and in your case, the best bet would be to contact the office directly around the first week of August. The mailing address is Service Courrier, Paris Tourist Office, 127 Avenue des Champs-Elysees, 75008 Paris. Call (33-1) 49.52.53.54; fax (33-1) 49.52.53.00. Recorded information in English is available by calling (33-1) 49.52.53.56.
You can also find event listings, some with critical commentary, in local newspapers and magazines. For instance, Pariscope, a weekly publication in French, is available at kiosks for about 50 cents. 
 Among the cultural offerings you will find in Paris this September is a retrospective of 220 paintings and drawings by Fernand Leger (1881-1955) at the Georges Pompidou Center, on view until Sept. 29. Admission is $8, at 5.56 francs to $1; students $5.40; children under 16 free. The center is open weekdays (except Tuesday) from noon to 10 P.M., weekends from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.
At the Opera Bastille there will be a production of Giacomo Puccini's "Turandot," directed by Francesca Zambello, with Sharon Sweet as Turandot and Charles Burles as Altoum. Performances are on Sept. 8 at 3 P.M., and Sept. 22 and 25 at 7:30 P.M. Tickets range from $26 to $114. Information: (33-1) 44.73.13.00.
At the Theatre des Champs-Elysees, a series of dances will be performed by Bejart Ballet Lausanne on Sept. 19 to 24. The program's three dances include the Islamic-themed "Voyage by Night," "Crucifixion," danced to music by Igor Stravinsky; and "Dibouk," with traditional Jewish music. Information: (33-1) 49.52.50.50. Tickets from $20 to $63.
 
Saxon Churches
 
Q. Do you have information on existing Saxon buildings in England? -- Virginia Wilhelm, New York, N.Y.
 
A. Practically all the buildings in England that contain fragments of Anglo-Saxon architecture -- the period between the end of the Roman occupation of England during the fifth century and the Norman Conquest in the 11th century -- are churches. Among those that have a significant amount of Saxon architecture is Worth Church in Crawley, West Sussex, about six miles from London's Gatwick airport, or about 35 miles south of London. Archaeological work in 1987 confirmed that 95 percent of the walls of the nave, the two transepts and the main arches are original Saxon work from the 10th and 11th centuries. The Reverend Andrew Piper at Worth says visitors are welcome. Information: (44-1293) 882229.
English Heritage, the conservation organization for the British Government, recommends Odda's Chapel at Deerhurst in Gloucestershire, 140 miles west of London. It is described as a rare Anglo-Saxon chapel that is unusual because it is attached to a half-timbered farmhouse. It is open daily until Sept. 30 from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., and from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M the rest of the year. Admission is free. Another English Heritage site, St. Augustine's Abbey in Canterbury, Kent, 62 miles southeast of London, contains remains of the foundations of the original sixth-century church. It is open the same hours as Odda's Chapel. Admission is $2.50. Canterbury Cathedral contains examples of Anglo-Saxon sculpture in the crypt. For information, call the English Heritage offices at (44-171) 973 3434.
Geoffrey Claridge, an architect who is an adviser to the Historic Churches Preservation Trust, recommends the late Saxon church in Sompting, West Sussex, 60 miles south of London, which contains Saxon carpentry in its helm roof and fragments of Saxon carving. Open from 7 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. daily. Information: Worthing Tourist Information Center (44-1903) 210022.
Shire Archaeology publishes two guides that may be of interest: "Anglo-Saxon Pottery" by David H. Kennett; and "Anglo-Saxon Sculpture" by James Lang. They cost $8.40 each, plus 1 pound postage (at $1.70 to one pound), and can be ordered. Orders can be sent with a credit card number to Shire Publications Limited, Cromwell House, Church Street, Princes Risborough, Buckinghamshire HP27 9AA; telephone (44-1844) 344301.
 
A Uruguayan Resort
 
Q. Please provide information on luxury hotels in Punta del Este, Uruguay. Also, what is the best way to get there from Buenos Aires? -- George Thimot, Canton Center, Conn.
 
A. Until the end of World War II, the narrow peninsula of Punta del Este was little more than a fishing village with a lighthouse and a few summer homes. Today, this southern Uruguayan resort -- with some 30 miles of sandy beaches surrounded by acres of eucalyptus and pine trees -- draws more than 300,000 visitors during the summer, which begins in December. Most of the visitors are Argentines and other South Americans, with an increasing number of Americans and Europeans.
Among the luxury hotels in Punta del Este is the new Conrad Resort and Casino, a flamboyant Las Vegas- style hotel. The hotel, which took its first guests last month, will be fully operational in October. It has 302 rooms, 24 suites, a 24-hour casino, shopping arcade, 5 restaurants and a pool. Prices range from $200 for a double room in low season (from May to October) to $350 in the high season. Information: (598-42) 91111.
Set in pine trees close to the San Rafael casino and two blocks from the Brava beach is Hotel L'Auberge. Its distinctive tower, where waffles and hot chocolate are served at tea time, gives the hotel the appearance of a medieval castle. Some of its 40 rooms are small, but cozy. A three-year-old wing has larger rooms. Doubles range from $140 during the low season, to $250 in January. Larger rooms in the new wing range from $190 (low season) to $350 (high). Information: (598-42) 82601, fax (598-42) 83408.
By far the quickest and easiest way to get to Punta del Este from Buenos Aires, which is about 200 miles to the west, is by plane. In season there are frequent daily flights on Pluna, the Uruguayan airline, or Aerolineas Argentinas. A recent round-trip economy fare on both airlines was $180. SUZANNE MacNEILLE

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Joanne Lorange;
Sorting Out Issues of Abuse in the Home

BYLINE: By ROBIN F. DEMATTIA 

 BODY:
THURSDAY was the third anniversary of Nicole Brown Simpson's murder. While her death received attention for its attachment to celebrity, thousands of other women quietly suffer similar abuses, including 28 women in Connecticut who were killed in 1996, a 33 percent increase from 1995.
Joanne Lorange is working to change those statistics. For eight years she has served as executive director of the Women's Crisis Center in Norwalk. She is a former president and current board member of the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence, an 18-agency consortium, and she serves on the steering committee of Eve's Fund, which raises money for domestic violence education programs. 
 Ms. Lorange recently discussed the problems associated domestic violence. Following are excerpts from the conversation.
Q. How prevalent is domestic violence?
A. Eight years ago we said every 15 seconds a woman is battered in the United States by a husband, boyfriend or live-in partner. Now we say it's every 9 seconds.
In Connecticut for fiscal year 1995-96, the 18 domestic violence agencies had a total of 23,937 hot line calls; provided 906 women and 1,295 children under 18 with shelter services, and helped 16,995 adult victims and 2,584 children with non-shelter services.
Through our victim advocate program, we helped 20,297 in the court system. And 66,196 people attended community education programs. These figures represent a 10 percent increase over the past five years.
Q. What are the causes of domestic violence?
A. The root cause is really one person's need to have power and control over another person. And 95 percent of the victims are women, so a lot of it has to do with a person who really sees women as objects and as secondary citizens.
Q. Are there secondary factors?
A. Drug and alcohol abuse can precipitate the violence. Sometimes people who don't understand domestic violence think that if you're upset because you are unemployed or upset about something else, you might become an abuser, but it really is socially learned behavior.
Q. How is the abuse manifested?
A. It's mainly emotional abuse, which doesn't necessarily mean it will go into physical abuse. But when there's physical abuse, more likely there is emotional and sexual abuse. A lot of women dismiss emotional abuse and say they don't really think they are abused. They are very ashamed, and often times in affluent communities it's even more shameful. The women think "we're educated, we should know better," or "he's a prominent member of the community and I don't want to tell this terrible secret." In more affluent communities, where houses are further apart, the secret can go on longer because others can't hear the yelling and screaming.
Q. Why do people stay in abusive relationships?
A. Women stay because the abuser controls and dominates them so much that their self-esteem is whittled away and they begin to believe they cannot make it on their own. Often the abuser tells the partner "If you leave me I will kill myself," and the victim doesn't want that on her conscience.
Oftentimes the abuse involves financial control, so the person has no inner or outer resources to make it on their own. They may not work, or have credit in their own name. The abuser has made them think they are hopeless and inadequate. And it's hard to go out on your own. It's very expensive, and there's a great fear of becoming homeless.
Q. Is that fear warranted?
A. Absolutely. Statistics from 1991 estimated that 50 percent of all homeless women and children are fleeing from domestic violence.
Q. Were perpetrators of domestic violence abused themselves?
A. A good percentage of abusers have either been abused or grew up in an abusive household and watched their mothers being abused. It is more likely that a male who grows up in that type of environment will grow up to be an abuser. Girls may grow up and marry an abuser because that's the way they think intimate relationships are supposed to be. The notion that women should be passive, and are there for men, is repeated in another generation.
Q. What are the effects of domestic violence on an abused women?
A. Her self-esteem is lessened. She oftentimes is isolated, not able to pursue career or job interests. She is financially trapped, and physically, emotionally and sexually hurt. And the domestic violence not only has immediate effects but also long-term effects. One victim was held at gunpoint and stabbed. She said the physical wounds, as bad as they were, would heal, but it was the emotional wounds she was afraid would never heal.
Q. What are the effects on children in the family?
A. When women are injured emotionally and physically, they oftentimes are unable to care for their children. Children who are in abusive homes, whether or not they are physically injured, are still affected by the violence because the emotional effects can be just as devastating as the physical. So often the children feel responsible for the violence. If Dad says to Mom, "You'd better keep those kids quiet or I'll beat you," kids think "If only I had listened to my mother she wouldn't be beaten." They also feel helpless because they can't stop the violence.
Children suffer from all kinds of ailments -- headaches, ulcers, rashes, stomach aches -- because they are constantly anxious, fearing when the next beating will happen. Children at younger ages may have developmental delays, hearing problems and language problems. They may have behavioral problems at school because they may choose to resolve their conflicts by fighting because that's what they see at home. Older children are at risk for juvenile delinquency, teen pregnancy and alcohol and drug abuse.
Q. What percentage of children in abusive homes are abused?
A. Nationally, 3.3 million children witness domestic violence, and 41 to 50 percent are there when police intervene. Of those cases in 1995 where an abuser was arrested, 14 percent of the children had sustained physical injuries.
Q. What is the significance of the Violence Against Women Act?
A. Passed in 1994, the national act says domestic violence is a crime and unacceptable. It really emphasizes collaborate work between domestic violence agencies, law enforcement and the legal system to protect victims. Legislation is key to saying loud and clear that whether you're assaulted on the street or in the home it's a crime and that behavior should not be accepted. If we don't make the abuser accountable, we'll never stop domestic violence.
Q. What services are provided by the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence?
A. Our ultimate goal is to break the cycle of violence, so we help families and individuals that are in abusive relationships to free themselves from physical, emotional, verbal and sexual abuse.
We offer a confidential 24-hour hot line; individual counseling to women, men and children; short-term and long-term therapy; support groups; emergency shelters, and victim advocacy and child advocacy.
We run an after-school program for kindergarten through high school children, talking about communication skills, conflict resolution and healthy relationships.
We train law enforcement personnel on protocols for referring people to domestic violence agencies, and provide training for the clergy and other social service providers. We also conduct community education for civic groups.
Q. How often do couples resolve their situation and stay together?
A. If we intervene early enough and the abuser is willing to deal with having a problem, we may be successful. But more often than not the abuser does not want to admit he has a problem.
Q. What is your advice to people in domestic violence situations?
A. Our whole philosophy is one of empowerment. We help people get as much information as possible, learn about the patterns and root causes of abuse, and let them make up their minds. Women know best if their lives have been threatened or if the abuser will act on their threat.
One of most important things we do is help individuals or families make safety plans.
Kids learn how to call for help if there is danger, and how to identify adults who are safe to talk to.
Women make sure they have somebody in the neighborhood with whom they have a signal: turning the light on outside of house means she's in trouble and call the police.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Joanne Lorange, executive director of the Women's Crisis Center in Norwalk, talks about personal empowerment. (Janet Durrans for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cable TV Finds A Stamford Home

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
THE year was 1982 and along the Stamford oceanfront complaints were springing up about the tall building on Harbor Drive that glowed brightly through the night. The tenant, the broadcasting arm of Westinghouse known as Group W, was launching its all-news cable network, Satellite News Channel.
"We were operating 24 hours a day, and we were lit up like a Christmas tree," the then-senior executive at Group W, Lloyd A. Werner, recalled. "We had to hire off-duty cops to shut the blinds at night. People were protesting outside, waving placards." 
 Satellite News Channel went dark for good the following year, vanquished by arch-rival Cable Network News. Cable television has since become one of the nation's major growth industries, with hundreds of channels either already launched or in the process of doing so.
Mr. Werner, now vice president of sales and marketing with CBS Cable, which emerged from Group W after Westinghouse bought CBS, still believes that if Satellite News Channel had held on a little longer it would have outlasted CNN and Ted Turner. "Stamford would have been what Atlanta is today," he said.
Would Stamford like a second crack at playing host to a major cable channel? You bet.
In the last few months, the city has avidly courted potential cable companies, to the point of running a telemarketing campaign with neighboring Fairfield County towns.
Stamford's economic planning director, Kip Bergstrom, notes that cable television fits in with other kinds of high-tech businesses that the city has successfully wooed, among them the investment banking giant SBC Warburg and the software leader Hyperion.
"Cable's not the most desirable tenant," Mr. Bergstrom said. "I wouldn't want to overstate it. But it's an important part of the mix. There are a lot of television companies starting up or expanding. TV stations are looking for a home, and they're having difficulty finding it in Manhattan." There is also the potential for enjoying the residual glamour of a successful local cable network. Call it the "Bristol Syndrome," after another Connecticut town that is plugged frequently by its resident cable operation, the sports channel ESPN. Having celebrities like Roger Clemens and Cam Neely mentioning a city's name on national television offers the kind of publicity a chamber of commerce can't buy.
"That is an additional byproduct, that your name can be broadcast," said the Stamford Mayor, Dannel P. Malloy. "It's not the reason for wanting cable networks, but it's nice."
Perhaps more a reason is the business a local studio operation can generate in its community: new customers for everything from video production centers to art shops to all-night diners. It also means employment for hundreds of producers, writers, camera operators, and others not only in Stamford but also throughout Fairfield County.
Stamford already has some of the largest multichannel businesses in the nation. Time/Warner Cable, the second-largest cable operator in the country with 12 million subscribers, has its corporate headquarters in town. So does Alphastar, a pioneering direct-to-home satellite television service owned by Tee-Comm Electronics, Inc. of Canada. While not producers of cable broadcasts, Time/Warner in particular has been one of its most successful distributors.
Then there is Group W, which has hardly lain fallow in the wake of the Satellite News Channel's demise. The Disney Channel began as a joint venture between Group W and the Disney Corporation, and The Nashville Network, started by Group W in 1982, is now the eighth-largest cable network in the country. "The Nashville Network is the engine which drives this company," Mr. Werner said.
The purchase of CBS by Westinghouse in 1995 brought with it the rights to one of broadcasting's most-revered call letters. Not surprisingly, Group W has taken advantage of it. After renaming itself CBS Cable, the company begun its first new network, CBS Eye on People, last March.
CBS Cable is unusually positioned to launch cable channels from its Stamford perch. Three miles north of Harbor Drive, in Glenbrook, lies what may be the largest video earth station in the United States, from which the CBS Cable subsidiary Group W Network Services transmits satellite signals for a wide range of television networks, including CBS, ABC, NBC and Fox.
The head of Group W Network Services, Altan C. Stalker, said the broad range of clientele was why the older name was retained by his division even as the rest of his company took up the CBS mantle. "Even though everyone in this business is very sophisticated, you have to be sensitive," he said.
Nearly a dozen other Group W clients lease in-house services such as playback and post-production suites. They include the Discovery Channel, the History Channel and the Learning Channel. In addition to leasing similar suites from Group W, the Arts & Entertainment network placed its entire operations staff in the same building as CBS Cable.
CBS Eye on People, managed from CBS Cable's Stamford offices but produced mostly at CBS Studios in Manhattan, represents the first real step into the cable industry by the basic-channel network.
Not surprisingly, CBS plays to its long-regarded strength, network news. The president of Eye on People, Geoffrey Darby, takes pains to dismiss the notion of another news channel, calling it a "broad-based entertainment network based on reality programming."
Still, the network features news personalities like Dan Rather and Mike Wallace, not to mention programs like "60 Minutes More" and "Another 48 Hours," that augment and update episodes of "60 Minutes" and "48 Hours," which aired on CBS.
About 200 people are employed by CBS Eye on People, according to the president of CBS Cable, Don Mitzner, but less than a dozen of them work in Stamford. Most of the rest, including production workers and on-air talent, are based at CBS News studios in Manhattan.
"I think if we had gotten the whole thing, it would have given us greater bragging rights," Mr. Bergstrom said. "But having the bigger piece, CBS Cable, here is very significant."
As CBS Eye on People begins to grow, Mr. Bergstrom said he hoped the network would look for a complex of its own closer to CBS Cable headquarters. One ideal location, he said, is an now-vacant television studio near the Darien line previously operated by Xerox's in-house corporate television network. But with so much interaction occurring between CBS and CBS Eye on People, there is little likelihood of such a move happening any time soon, Mr. Mitzner said.
There are many reasons for being in Stamford, CBS Cable executives say. The city is only a short distance away from Manhattan. Since Connecticut is a right-to-work state, cable networks can hire employees and not pay union wages. Finally, there is the bucolic nature of the place, an urban hub and suburb all-in-one.
"Stamford is a great place to work," Mr. Mitzner said. "And what we've seen, others have seen also."
Having CBS Cable, in particular Group W Network Services, buttresses the city's appeal. When Roger L. Werner Jr., former head of ESPN, was seeking a site for two fledging cable channels in early 1995, he opted for Stamford in part, he said, because he enjoyed "a good working relationship" with Group W.
"Stamford's an attractive place, at a convenient distance to New York airports and New York City itself," he said. "The cost of operating a business is less. If you're looking to locate in the New York City area, southern Connecticut is the most attractive place."
Mr. Werner's networks, Speedvision and Outdoor Life, deal with specific niche markets, motor racing and nature recreation respectively, which he said are underrepresented by more broad-based networks like ESPN. While other cable channels have full-package deals with Group W, Speedvision and Outdoor Life go a step further, renting out studio space at Harbor Drive. The two networks use opposite ends of the same studio, one built originally for the Satellite News Channel.
Both networks have a lot of growing left to do. Mr. Werner said Speedvision has 10 million subscribers and Outdoor Life nine million. Stamford's own cable distributor, Cablevision, does not carry either one. But Mr. Werner said the growth of his networks has exceeded expectations, adding he hopes they will have 20 million subscribers by 1998 and thus become eligible for Nielsen ratings. For the moment the networks may be "small potatoes" to Stamford, as Mr. Werner put it, but the city is hardly turning up its nose. CBS Eye on People has only 2 million subscribers. Mr. Bergstrom said the city is quite willing to take what it can get.
"Cable TV is not an industry of large players," he said. "I would love to get an established channel to relocate here. What's more like to happen is a new channel will arrive, then grow."
CBS Eye on People is one such candidate for growth. Mr. Darby said the network may do some taping at CBS Cable's Stamford studios later this year, albeit on a limited basis. The network is already adding programs to its 15-show weekly schedule, and boasting the presence of such top CBS talent as Mr. Rather, Mr. Wallace, and Charles Kuralt, who came to CBS Eye on People after leaving CBS and thus qualifies as the new network's first exclusive on-air personality.
A desire for "face time" has spurred the appearances of veteran CBS News personnel, Mr. Darby said, along with a commitment to join the cable revolution.
"We clearly are offering a real alternative to other programming," said Paula Zahn, who anchors CBS Eye on People's "Fast Forward," a show that updates the stories of people made famous by events from the past. "There's nothing frivolous about it."
Ms. Zahn, the former host of "CBS This Morning" who now anchors "CBS Evening News" on Saturdays and contributes to other CBS programs, said one nice thing about CBS Eye on People is the opportunity to "break out of a four-minute time constraint."
"Nine-minute spots are more the rule on 'Fast Forward,' " she said. "That gives me a lot of flexibility."
Stamford is no bed of roses, Mr. Mitzner said. Zoning difficulties have delayed the addition of more satellite dishes at Glenbrook, he noted, to the point where he now will look elsewhere when it comes time to plan a new series of dishes. "It's just too laborious," he said.
Also vexing is the state of the area's main transportation artery, Interstate 95. Mr. Mitzner, a commuter from Long Island, calls I-95 worse than the Long Island Expressway (known to many in the tri-state area as the world's longest parking lot).
"The L.I.E. is a nightmare, but this is worse," he said. "In 11 years the construction has never stopped. Even the things that are finished are redone."
But the city's attributes outweigh the bumps, he said. "The most important thing is the people who are here. They're well-educated, success-oriented, and they care about each other."
And perhaps even more tolerant of the sort of situations that irked them in the early 1980's.
Mr. Malloy, a Stamford resident familiar with the Satellite News Channel controversy, insists sight-pollution issues are an issue of the past. "All people work longer hours today than they did in 1981 and 1982," he said. "The population has caught up. No one is surprised by lit office buildings at night anymore."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Aviation Week, a cable TV program, is produced in Stamford. Bill Patrick, standing, and Reg Abbiss are anchors.
