PUB-DATE: June 15, 1997

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4357 words

HEADLINE: It's, You Know, About Opinions and Stuff

BYLINE: By Tad Friend; Tad Friend is a contributor to GQ, Vogue and Outside.

 BODY:
If you want to blazon a name as a young television pundit, you can learn from Laura Ingraham. The ubiquitous 33-year-old conservative plies her trade at, among other places, the MSNBC cable network, the cradle of the new commentary, where 19 all-purpose pundits called contributors stand by to kick around the hot topic in the news. In a recent MSNBC colloquy about whether Sports Illustrated's swimsuit issue was sexist, Jef Pollock, a Democratic pollster, argued that the images of women were an "objectification." Instantly Ingraham barked: "What does that mean? What does that mean?" Pollock opened his mouth. "What does that mean?" she repeated -- five times in all before declaring, "No one wants to see fat people on the cover of magazines in swimsuits."
 Ingraham represents everything the old pundits fear. She's loud, ambitious and much better looking than the Rumpelstiltskins who dominate public-affairs shows -- and she's unstained by journalistic ink. "When Laura Ingraham was still a lawyer she went to see Robert Novak for career advice," says Fred Barnes, 53, a longtime print reporter and a regular on "The McLaughlin Group." "He told her, 'I started in Omaha, Neb., as an A.P. reporter,' then recited the litany of his reporting career for 30 years before he started going on 'McLaughlin,' 
 Before he came up with 'The Capital Gang.' She didn't listen. That's not what she wanted to do, or needed to do, when on television her opinion is valued as much as mine."
 Novak, 66, is a regular on "The Capital Gang," "Evans and Novak" and, until recently, "Crossfire," which celebrates its 15th anniversary this week. "Producers want to appeal to the X Generation -- they're tired of the old geezers," he says. "But most of the young people don't know what they're talking about."
 Responds Ingraham: "It's not just like I showed up blond and in a miniskirt and said, 'Hire me!' " (Two years ago, for an article about young conservatives, she did show up blond and in a miniskirt for a cover shoot for this magazine.) "If I'd known it was going to be that easy, I never would have clerked for the Supreme Court and worked for a prestigious firm and written as much as I have. All that's as valuable as covering fires in Des Moines." She breathes, then switches to attack: "Those old white males don't speak to a lot of America -- what does Fred Barnes know about my world? You don't hear male anchors and reporters being criticized for being good-looking. No one wants to see Quasimodo up there." Or fat people on the cover of magazines.
 Like Ingraham, many of MSNBC's contributors are young (average age: 35) and don't come from news. They are bankers, law professors, consultants, Congress of Racial Equality leaders -- a visual and philosophical Benetton ad. "We have a group that looks like America," says Eric Alterman, another contributor, "if you kill off everyone over 45."
 But even more striking, and more of a challenge to the old guard than Ingraham's brassy savvy, is the contributors' emerging political perspective, which reflects the concerns of the nearly 80 million Americans born between 1961 and 1981. This is a generation of people who, to judge by a survey conducted by the college magazine Link, consider themselves, by a 3-to-2 margin, neither Republicans nor Democrats but "other." A generation that believes more that U.F.O.'s exist than that Social Security will still exist when they retire. They are fearful for their economic future, yet deeply skeptical that the sort of politicians who shadowed their childhoods with the ghosts of Vietnam and Watergate are in any position to help. They are a group whose grass-roots movements have "yeah, sure" names like Lead or Leave, Do Something and Who Cares, a group to whom R. J. Reynolds, in a spectacular botch, tried and failed to successfully market a premium cigarette called Politix. (If you don't like it in a bicameral legislature, try it in a nicotine-delivery system!)
 "The generation up to 35 rejects traditional politics," says Frank Luntz, a 35-year-old Republican pollster. "They don't trust government, don't like Washington, don't vote, don't read newspapers. They view themselves not as members of political parties but as a generational group. They want less taxes, less regulation, less government and less moral interjection."
 This constellation of beliefs -- suspicion of power; championing of individual rights; the conviction that free markets, rather than government regulation, create a model society -- is neither left nor right. If anything, it is libertarian, and on MSNBC it tends to produce a calming political consensus. In a recent contributors' segment about gun control, Jef Pollock and John Fund, an editorial writer at The Wall Street Journal, began in violent disagreement, then forged an astonishingly swift truce: law-abiding people should be allowed guns for protection, but criminals who use them should receive harsh sentences, and computerized lists of felons should be updated at the state and local levels. The last four exchanges began "I totally agree with John," "I'll agree," "It's very true" and "I agree."
 On most Washington shows, Surgeon General Dr. Joycelyn Elders's suggestion that the topic of masturbation be included in schools' sex-education programs was blasted by the right and bolstered by the left. On MSNBC, Eric Alterman, who agreed with Elders, spoke firmly from the new center. "What?" he asked. "You think most everyone in this studio doesn't masturbate?"
 In other words, while MSNBC's contributors are hardly offering a graduate seminar in John Locke and Milton Friedman, their approach augurs a
sea change. The contributors have by and large gravitated to a generational world view in which Tupac Shakur and Howard Stern matter as much as Newt Gingrich and in which personal feeling is as important as big-picture strategizing, whether the topic is cloning, Congo or Paula Corbin Jones.
 Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's discovery of her Jewish heritage, for example, sparked a discussion not of whether the revelation would affect American foreign policy but, in the case of two Jewish contributors, of how it made them feel. This approach doesn't always work. "It's kind of like marathon dancing," says the NBC anchor Tom Brokaw. "It's interesting that they can do it for so long, but it's not that fun to do it or watch it."
 But where the older Washington pundits follow a Congressional template -- partisan fury, then a vote -- the contributors, with more divergent backgrounds, paradoxically come much closer to a coffeehouse consensus. They see Washington not as a glittering prize to be conquered by polemics but
 as a bad sitcom to be clicked off. Change the channel, watch something else.
 Says one contributor: "One is more likely to say, 'I work on MSNBC,' because that's TV, that's cool, than say, 'I'm a political analyst.' Why? Because everyone views politics as reprehensible."
 Omar wasow, another msnbc contributor, is a perfect ambassador for the new pundits. Once a week, he joins two other contributors at the Secaucus, N.J., studio for short discussion segments throughout the day that provide context to the flow of reporting and videotape from around the world. It's the news network's op-ed page. And here he is, emerging from a dressing room, prepared to tell the world what to think.
 Makeup has turned Wasow's caffe latte skin a ghostly porcelain; he wears a dark suit and a blue shirt with the top button secured -- nerd chic. "I wear the suits because while I want to look like a bit of a bad boy -- and the visual trope of my hair certifies me as an outsider -- I also want to be taken seriously," he says. "A friend of mine says, 'You're behaving like a 13-year-old girl hitting puberty.' It scares me a little." At 26, Wasow is the second-youngest contributor. But his well-researched ruminations win almost universal praise, as does his calm willingness to admit "I don't know."
 "I don't know" is unheard of in traditional punditry. But in conversation Wasow often revisits questions weeks later, saying, "I've been thinking . ..." before eagerly refuting his own prior contentions. "You get one Jew in a room and you've got three arguments," he says, laughing.
 Yet, as the old joke has it, he doesn't look Jewish, and his sense of who he is remains flexible. The child of a white Jewish father and a black mother, Wasow thinks of himself as black. And Jewish. Or black and Jewish. He has spoken of himself on the air as both and is comfortable being whatever the conversation calls for: one-stop multicultural shopping. "My identity forms my positions," Wasow says, "but doesn't define them. Unlike older black leaders, I don't want black unity. I want to help poor people out of poverty."
 But the idea that you need an appropriate-looking messenger is an MSNBC dictum: image is identity. The day punitive damages were to be awarded at O. J. Simpson's civil trial, Steve Lewis, a senior producer, felt he needed "a black person in every group today -- not out of political correctness, but because over 70 percent of blacks think O. J. didn't get a fair trial, and blacks know they can get [expletive] by the police." It is hard to overstate how big a change this is. "The unspoken cultural reference point of all the Washington shows," says Michael Kinsley, the former "Crossfire" host, "is, 'As a white man in a suit, I believe. . . .' "
 As a black man in a suit, Wasow's cultural reference point is that of an entrepreneur. New York Online, his seven-person company, has built Web sites for Consumer Reports, The New Yorker and the Government of Martinique, grossing about $400,000 last year, all from his Brooklyn apartment. Wasow believes in free markets yet is strongly pro-abortion rights and pro-civil liberties. His fiercest passion is reserved for supporting school vouchers and the decriminalization of drugs.
 Wasow plans a book, "Cusp," that will lasso these ideas into a platform for his rising generation. "But being able to argue this ideology on television, to a mass audience, is the most important way we can make the dead left come alive," he says. (This view of television's reach is shared by, among others, George Stephanopoulos. "I, personally, can do more for the progressive cause as a commentator in the next four years than I could in the White House," says Stephanopoulos, 36, who has traded being Clinton's senior adviser for regular slots on "Good Morning America" and "This Week.")
 The floor producer fetches Wasow, Jennifer Grossman and Brian Jones to a set that evokes a software start-up cum Starbucks for a discussion about welfare. Not surprisingly, perhaps, Grossman and Jones, who are on the conservative side of the spectrum, amiably (and rather boringly) agree with Wasow that private programs are better than Federal ones at moving people into the work force. "But a majority of the discussions on MSNBC are not polarized," Wasow says afterward. Such consensus is the bane of Washington shows. "They shout fire and brimstone on issues like gun control and abortion," Wasow says, "but they totally miss the point. Most people aren't enthusiastic about abortion, but they're not enthusiastic about heavily regulating it, either. They don't want guns around, but they don't think regulating them will do much.
 "Eric Alterman," -- whose background is left-liberal -- "John Fund and I all agreed recently that people had the right to contract privately to buy cancer drugs outside the F.D.A.-approved process, that the Government should stay out of it. The libertarian consensus stunned us. Bizarre but meaningful coalitions form around ideas. Ideas!"
 Traditionally -- that is, for the last 15 years -- television pundits have been Washington journalists willing to play the role of die-hard partisans. "Ultimately these issues must be put to a simple vote -- up or down?" says John McLaughlin, 70, the blustery eminence of "The McLaughlin Group," the show that practically invented political commentary as entertainment. "We have to cover five topics in 22 minutes, which makes 10 seconds an eternity. So I edit as I go by being quite ruthless and rude and uncivilized. MSNBC's pacing is a little slow, which is easier. Our panelists get to the point faster. And say something they probably shouldn't: what they really think."
 In return for confining themselves to a lean diet of insults and canned bon mots, Washington pundits get huge name recognition: "Through television you can become a conglomerate, where you do writing, TV and speeches," says Fred Barnes. "You make more money, you have more visibility and you can affect the game, which is what the political community in Washington is working out every day."
 Print journalists say they do television because it's where the audience and the action are. Yet unlike Wasow, they don't believe anyone outside the Beltway is really paying attention. "We have an audience," Barnes says, "but we don't have influence." So the older TV pundits are a sheepish oddity: performers in a visual medium who only believe what they read. The sense of slumming is apparent during the "out" shots as a show like "Crossfire" goes to commercials after a fierce exchange and we see the panelists laughing and shaking their heads, as if to say, "What the hell was that about?"
 "I had a bad experience on 'Crossfire' a few years ago," says George Stephanopoulos. "John Sununu said to me, 'Liar, liar, pants on fire!' " He shakes his head. "How are you going to respond to that? 'Fat pig!'?" Says Robert Novak: "The viewer might think you're ready to strangle each other, but the heat is done for television. It's a little like professional wrestling."
 Now the networks are modifying those tactics to woo the famously diffident younger audience, though none have gone as far as MSNBC. ABC picked up "Politically Incorrect" from Comedy Central, which features four celebrities like G. Gordon Liddy and Harvey Fierstein irreverently discussing national affairs. "You've got to fish where the fish are," says Bill Maher, a comedian and the show's host. "Are we doing justice to issues the way 'Firing Line' is? No. But who's watching 'Firing Line'?"
 Typically, as for all public-affairs shows, a 55-year-old white man. Margaret Carlson of CNN's "Capital Gang" reports, "All the mash notes I get are from prisoners and old men with shaky handwriting." In 1995 Howard Polskin, vice president of CNN, set out to change that, eventually leading the network to hire the 20-somethings Farai Chideya and Kellyanne Fitzpatrick together as "Gen X Team" campaign analysts. "That's so cool!" Fitzpatrick said at the time, high-fiving Chideya in, she now ruefully admits, "typical Gen X fashion." The two appeared on "Inside Politics" throughout the campaign. "Seeing is the first step to believing," says Fitzpatrick, an earnest Republican pollster, now 30. "Young people saw me on the air and maybe thought, 'Perhaps there's a role for me.' "
 But Farai Chideya, a 27-year-old liberal, felt that CNN didn't take advantage of the generational perspective she could offer. In the end, "Our analysis was no different than anyone else's," Chideya says. "When Bernie Shaw and Judy Woodruff asked us questions, it was like: 'Here's our little pipsqueaks! They're so cute!' And we'd make a Pearl Jam reference, playing up to Gen-X-pectations. You could never say: 'Time out on the horse race. Let's talk about the real impact of educational tax cuts on the young.' And the 'Gen X Team' was corny, embarrassing -- we should have had thongs and breastplates. It was just marketing, getting boomers to think the station is hip."
 Hipness is all. TV ads for "Nightline" now feature a dude who pauses long enough from sailboarding to say, " 'Nightline' is as cool as land sailing." John McLaughlin has been auditioning 30-somethings for his show, and "This Week" has hired William Kristol and George Stephanopoulos as "new blood." Only the new Fox News Channel, on which Monica Crowley, 28, is the sole pundit under age 35, isn't playing. "I'm a little surprised by the notion that to attract younger viewers you have to have young people on the air," says John Moody, the channel's vice president of news editorial -- disavowing the whole rationale for Fox shows like "Beverly Hills 90210."
 The fatal flaw of most network attempts at hipness -- even MSNBC's -- argues a former MTV political analyst, Alex Abrams, 31, is that they employ younger faces without having an editorial shift to address younger-skewing issues. "Our MTV election poll showed the top five issues for 17- to 29-year-olds are: strengthening the economy and creating new jobs, fighting crime, making higher education more affordable, preserving Social Security and Medicare for future generations and making health care affordable. That's what MSNBC should be talking about, not about Bosnia."
 Christopher Cuomo, 26, a lawyer and the youngest son of the former New York Governor Mario Cuomo, agrees. "You have to sell our generation a reason to believe," he says. He is currently working on "Live Bait," a Gen X interview show in development that would skew young but also capitalize on traditional right-left friction by pairing him with Kellyanne Fitzpatrick, whom he impolitically dismisses as an old soul. "All the media marketers say we don't vote, don't participate -- and it's true that all we know about Sam Donaldson is his freaky hair," Cuomo says. "But if we're such losers, then why are we fighting for the environment, why do we jump on Americorps, why do we overrun Teach for America with applications? Unfortunately, on television we're just represented by George Stephanopoulos, who has no clue because all the young people he knows are politicians.
 "The truth is," the politician's son concludes, putting a new spin on Tip O'Neill's famous aphorism, "all politics is identity politics."
 In october 1995, the president of NBC news, Andrew Lack, began noodling around with an idea for talk segments on his new 24-hour cable network (backed by $500 million pledged for the first five years by NBC and Microsoft). He wanted to woo the young, and he felt that the era of "McLaughlin-like shouting" was done. "So I came up with the idea for 'The Friends,' " a term still used in-house, who would "recreate the relaxed feeling of a bull session with journalist friends."
 Before MSNBC debuted last July, Lack and his producers auditioned more than 100 potential Friends, looking for types almost as if they were casting a huge sitcom. Eric Alterman, 37, a squirrel-cheeked media columnist for The Nation, is well aware of his role in the Friends ensemble: "They told me to be myself -- you know, a wise-guy liberal New York Jew." Alterman, in fact, had written a 1992 book, "Sound and Fury: The Washington Punditocracy and the Collapse of American Politics," that eviscerated talking heads for being a cynical, clownish elite: "The number who manage to present a coherent contextual viewpoint on television is zero," he wrote in one of his milder observations. Alterman acknowledges the appearance of hypocrisy in his current role but says, "Look, I tried to do something about this with my book, and nobody cared."
 Many of the usual Washington suspects weren't interested in traveling to New Jersey every week for an average of $30,000 a year. And that left open the role of the wacky-looking but reasonable Internet guy for Omar Wasow, whose first audition, frankly, bombed. But after a second audition, Wasow was signed part time, and he soon worked his way up to regular duty by reviewing tapes of his segments, learning how to appear natural on the job. Wasow discovered that when he hunches his shoulders he resembles Nixon saying, "I am not a crook." He remembered to sit up straight, to be more aggressive and to make two crisp points and then shut up.
 The big question about technique is, Where do you stop? Rather than appearing simply natural, why not try for truly striking? So you wear a navy blue jacket, which looks splendid on television, and sit on the tail so it doesn't bunch. You cut your hair: close-ups require smaller hair. You lean slightly forward if you want to jump in -- if you're a woman, you even touch the speaker's hand. You speak for 40 seconds to a minute 15 seconds, tops: after that no one's listening.
 And what if someone else has already made your point? It looks lame just to agree, so you reposition. Television, which renders genuine emotion frightening and complexity confusing, militates against saying what you really think. And once you have abandoned sincerity, it's a short step to ending up like Arianna Huffington, who delivered commentary in bed during Comedy Central's "Indecision '96." The older pundits tried to make Washington politics a show but only helped turn it -- and themselves -- into a sideshow. "Once the journalist talk shows defined their appeal as being fundamentally entertainment," says James Fallows, the editor of U.S. News and World Report and a media critic, "they guaranteed they'd be run out of business by a new generation that looks better and doesn't feel sheepish about being on TV."
 Asked to pick the strongest panel for a show, a longtime Fox news producer, Tammy Haddad, says, "I'd have Rosie O'Donnell, Alec Baldwin, the rapper Coolio and President Clinton as the anchor, because he has an incredible grasp of facts and he's likable -- the most important thing." He is also the perfect poll-driven President, channeling the anti-government consensus and rebroadcasting it as the new post-partisan politics. But where are the journalists and partisans? "You said strongest show," Haddad replies. "A girl's got to get an audience."
 The discussion topic is a 13-year-old who sold some- one crack, shot him and set him on fire. Wasow is on with Don Walter, a Republican media strategist from Virginia and something of a conservative firecracker. "Yes, he should go to jail," Walter says. "The people want it."
 "Fine," Wasow replies. "I'm not going to try to make the case that violent criminals deserve more freedom." Then, over Walter's interruptions, Wasow tries to make a more complicated point about the cost to taxpayers of incarceration and the fact that the majority of Federal prisoners are nonviolent offenders. "So let's not just say, 'Lock everybody up.' "
 Walter interrupts, a small smile playing on his lips: "Are you currently on parole right now? You feel so passionate about this." Wasow rocks back in his chair, stammers briefly, then says, "I feel passionate about this because we're bankrupting our states." "No, no, no -- Omar, you're a policy wonk," Walter says. "You live in New York City. People in the real world, who live in communities where bad guys live, if they want to lock 'em up, let 'em lock 'em up."
 Wasow looks calm as the camera swoops to a commercial, but he's seething. "That's a recurring joke Don has with me, the 'What are you smoking, Omar?' thing," he says after the broadcast. "It strikes me as out of line, but it's a very powerful mode of argument, because I don't even want to enter the discussion of 'Am I on parole or not?' "
 I mention to Don Walter that Wasow finds his personal remarks difficult to counter. "You're giving me all the information I need to take him out," Walter responds, laughing. "It's a cruel, hard world and I'm looking for sound bites, because we're in the business of retaining viewers."
 A few days later, upon further reflection, Wasow acknowledges that the exchange with Walter exposed "a weak spot for me. It's my insecurity about being perceived as a hippie, as the pot-smoking Rastafarian that I appear. Symbols truly are stronger than any other kind of narrative on TV. So Don probably wins that discussion, because his points are so much more informal and easy to grasp. I felt like an old academic arguing with a young slickster."
 The paradox is precisely this, of course: Walter is 36, a decade older, and has more television experience. Television punditry turns its young thinkers into young slicksters, who discover that partisan pummeling makes for livelier television than consensus. Ground-breaking though the MSNBC experiment may be, its average audience is tiny: 20,000 to 30,000 households. "Crossfire" draws 637,000; "McLaughlin," 4.5 million. No doubt some of the discrepancy can be attributed to the fact that MSNBC is still in its infancy. But what if audiences actually like old-fashioned, pie-in-the-face conflict? This possibility is not lost on the Friends. "I'm trying to come up with some zingers for the conservatives," Wasow says. " 'What are you smoking?' Or 'Are you high?' It's pathetic that I have to think them up ahead of time, but when the audience is keeping score, if you can't dish it out with the best of them, you're not really in the game."
 John Gibson, an MSNBC anchor, says, "Lying, spin and salesmanship are the hallmarks of the people who want to be on television." His jaundice is laced with melancholy. "The contributors will tell you it's a 70-30 ratio of communicating their important beliefs versus working on their chops, their technique, getting known. When they look back, they're going to see that it's exactly 30-70 the other way."
 Wasow has already begun to take note. "There's something incredibly titillating about the money and the adulation of television," he says slowly, "but it has nothing to do with rising to the moral issue of your day. . . . It's probably not enough to simply articulate ideas on TV. . . ." He slows even more, feeling his way. "Is there some point at which I do something real, like helping bring school vouchers to New York City?"
 We're sitting in Wasow's company office at the end of a long day, surrounded by the computer monitors that have been his window onto the world till now. "But I've been seduced," he admits at last, ever forthright. And he grins as if preparing to confess something truly shameful. "What I'd really love is to do a Gen X 'McLaughlin Group.' "

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Live at 11: Death

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
Most local television stations interrupted their customary tales of murder and mayhem long enough recently to cover Carol Marin's noisy but decidedly nonviolent protest. Why?
Marin, as you must have heard, quit her job as an anchor at WMAQ in Chicago because of growing frustration with the quality of the news she was required to read. Her patience snapped when the station signed Jerry Springer, of late a TV merchant of programs like "Women With Watermelon Breasts," to join her program as a commentator. Her resignation evoked so much audience protest that Springer, too, had to quit two days later 
 Television anchors everywhere jumped on this story with obvious sympathy and envy. Most of them must share Marin's disgust with the journalism they are forced to practice, yet most cannot afford to quit. They could not even afford to emphasize the most dramatic aspect of the Chicago dust-up: the public's reaction. As soon as Springer came on the air, half the program's customary audience tuned out. There is promise in that discontent, but not enough broadcasters seem prepared to exploit it.
The idea of tapping Springer's freak-show appeal for the local news sprang from the head of WMAQ's new vice president, Joel Cheatwood, who had made his mark with fire and brimstone as news director at WSVN in Miami. His pyrotechnics earned the highest ratings in Miami and inspired much imitation. During its third annual analysis of 100 newscasts in 55 markets last February, Rocky Mountain Media Watch caught WSVN employing spooky music, blood-red graphics and ear-splitting sound effects to serve up a drumbeat of death, danger and destruction surrounding two long murder tales:

Subject	Length	Murder/suicide victims identified as fireman and wife	(3:22)	Arrests made at crack house	(0:18)	House fire put out	(0:15)	Suspect surrenders in shooting and robbery of tourist	(0:13)	Teacher suspended for carrying	 	concealed weapon after attack	(0:59)	Fire in Everglades almost out	(0:27)	Boat capsizes; one dead, one missing	(0:18)	Lifeguards rescue 50 people today	 	because of strong riptides	(0:17)	Giant sinkhole still not repaired	(0:14)	Seeking tips on racist graffiti	(0:25)	Robbers nabbed outside grocery store	(0:23)	Runaway boy found	(0:21)	Child killed in car crash	(0:16)	JonBenet Ramsey murder; former	 	Miss America compares their lives	(3:25)	Was Atlanta bombing part of a series?	(0:23)	Empire State Building assassin left a note	(0:23)	Lincoln bedroom sleep-over flap	(1:16)	Flooding in Illinois	(0:16)	Attack of the tumbleweeds in New Mexico	(0:12)	
Such was the diet of information fed to a region of more than three million people last Feb. 26, the end of a "sweeps" month when the size of the audience determines the prices that can be charged for commercials. There were no major catastrophes anywhere in America that day. The Dow Jones average stood near 7,000. There was time, therefore, to explore the local economy, or the performance of government agencies, or some new cultural attractions, or the good works of volunteers and the needs of poor people. Yet 72 of the lead stories at 100 stations in 35 states were about crime and violence, mostly murder.
Indeed, fully one-third of all the news on local TV that night dealt with crime, and mostly murder. And so it goes every night, according to another survey made over six months by an academic consortium directed from the University of Miami. Although violent crime has been dropping sharply for two years now in almost every American city, this mayhem machine just keeps on producing its reckless distortions of life for two or three hours a day. Even if death were the only subject capable of grabbing a mass audience, why dwell only on homicide? There are more suicides in America (30,000, not even counting smoking) than murders (25,000) every year, and still more deaths in auto accidents (40,000), half due to alcohol.
It is sadly true, as a Newseum/Roper Center survey reported last month that more than half of all Americans watch the local TV news every day, that more than half think it's good and that nearly 70 percent are "extremely" or "very" interested in the news of crime. But how could they be interested in much else when no one offers much else? Only a single public television station (KTCA in Twin Cities, Minn.) carries a nightly local news program, and only a handful of others are rebelling against sensation.
The Rocky Mountain survey's most encouraging finding came in Austin, Tex., where KVUE avoids most crime stories but still outdraws two competitors hooked on mayhem. KVUE reports only crimes that produce a significant effect or threat in the community. On the survey night, its main stories dealt with falling gasoline prices, poor sidewalks for children and the handicapped, new rules for recycling and a backlog of paternity cases requiring DNA tests.
If other stations are to be emboldened to follow this example, other anchors need to join Carol Marin in finding ways to protest against their customary scripts. The Roper poll reported that more than half of all Americans trust "all" or "most" of what local newscasters say (while less than a third have that much faith in newspaper reporters). That trust attaches to the faces on the screen, not to the stations or the backstage news directors. And as Marin proved, it can be a formidable weapon.
No need for all anchors to resign; just balk a bit. Stop showing such enthusiasm for "breaking" stories when the facts are clouded and the images are immaterial. (On survey night, KWGN in Denver began by shouting about a "riot" at a local high school; it became a "fight" in midprogram and a mere "disturbance" by the end.) Also, stop bragging about "live" feeds that usually catch reporters outside closed doors waiting to be fed minutiae. Start asking, "So what?" and "Why are we doing this?" and "Which is the bigger crime -- that pathetic murder or our report of it?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Like Old Times: Steel Plant Coming to New Haven

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN capturing the first newly built large-scale industrial plant in Connecticut in more than 20 years, and the first basic manufacturing company to enter the state in 50 years, New Haven has negotiated a reversal of industrial emigration, what Mayor John DeStefano Jr. calls "a contrarian occurrence."
Williams Specialty Steel of Buffalo has chosen a site in the northern part of the city on which to build a $200 million, 225,000-square-foot plant to make stainless steel slabs. Capable of turning out 500,000 tons a year, the plant will have national impact and negligible competition. Donald Reed, senior vice president of the Connecticut Development Authority, said: "About three million tons are made nationally by about 25 plants. But capacity is less than demand, so at least 25 percent is imported. By the time this plant opens two or three years from now, the demand will be 15 percent higher. Williams will be cutting into imports." 
 Since World War II, Connecticut has been drained of hundreds of manufacturing companies lured south by cheaper operating costs, and its military industries have been downsized. New Haven's heaviest loss was U.S. Steel, which moved away in 1980, laying off 1,200 people. Over the last few years about 25 small manufacturing companies have moved into existing buildings in various towns, "but nothing has been built new or approaching the size of the Williams project," said John Paul, director of business recruitment for the state.
Since the 1960's, demand for stainless steel has been growing by 5.5 percent to 7 percent a year, said Mark Sabers, vice president of Williams. "This is our first venture into stainless, a market that represents a very good opportunity for growth. We owned a carbon steel company at one time, but sold it 10 years ago."
Mayor DeStefano, a Democrat in his second term, outlined the city's role in financing the venture. "We will assist them in placing $55 million in bonds for construction costs," he said, "but the net cost to the city will be $10 million in abated real estate taxes for the first five years."
A total of $2 million to $2.5 million in machinery and equipment taxes will be paid annually by the company. "A balloon payment on the balance of the debt will come due after five years," the Mayor said, "when they can place the debt elsewhere if they can't pay it."
The company is also receiving a 25-year loan of $9.75 million at 6 percent from the Connecticut Development Authority, and an additional $1 million from the Connecticut Department of Community and Economic Development for training 350 permanent workers, all that will be needed in the highly automated operation.
A service valued at $5 million will also be provided without charge by United Illuminating. "We will build an electric substation for them," said Anthony Vallillo, vice president of client services, "that we normally charge for." Of all U.I.'s customers in 17 Fairfield and New Haven County towns, Williams will be the biggest.
"Their primary electric arc furnace generates a tremendous amount of heat to melt the scrap steel for making stainless," Mr. Vallillo said. He estimated that the plant would consume 300 million kilowatt-hours a year, compared with the 6,000 to 8,000 kilowatt-hours used by the average house. Residential customers pay nine cents a kilowatt-hour, but the plant will have a reduced rate.
A gap in financing, city officials say, is the only thing that might threaten the deal. "There have been many expressions of interest from Wall Street," Mr. Reed said. Harry Williams, chairman of the company and a multimillionaire with more than a dozen enterprises, is expected to invest a substantial sum.
He controls businesses in real estate, leasing, telecommunications, electronics, construction and environmental services. His core business is Integrated Waste Systems of Buffalo. Some New Haven officials say he has bought and sold as many as 54 businesses in the last 30 years.
MAYOR DeSTEFANO is unconcerned about possible volatility. "I'm impressed with his ability to deliver on what he says he's going to do," the Mayor said, "and with his track record and his balance sheet."
The Williams company was also "impressed, with the incentives, and the speed and quality of response by state and city governments," Mr. Sabers said. "We looked in Indiana, Maryland, several other states, and considered Buffalo before deciding on New Haven."
Andrew Anastasio Jr., who owns the plant site and will be Williams's landlord, met Harry Williams five years ago while investigating a business opportunity in New Jersey. "We've known Harry and Tony Uzzo for years, but the state deserves the credit for putting us all together," Mr. Anastasio said. Mr. Uzzo is an economic development specialist for United Illuminating, who suggested that part of Mr. Anastasio's 100 acres would be ideal for the Williams operation. A 50-year sublease of 25 to 27 acres of the Anastasio property is being negotiated.
For the last 10 years, the Anastasio family has used the property for an outdoor trucking and distribution center for milled lumber, steel, building materials and telephone poles, under a 99-year lease from Conrail. A Conrail switching station is at the north end of the site and two rail lines run down the east and west sides, serving several spurs up to six times a week. The plant will be built close to Interstate 91 on the banks of the Quinnipiac River, which empties into New Haven Harbor, providing rail, water and highway access that the Williams company found attractive.
Bruce Blakey, corporate economist for Northeast Utilities, which has no connection with the project, enumerated its regional benefits. "New construction," he said, citing a Federal Department of Commerce formula, "has a multiplier of about two and a half, so the 3,000 construction workers from around the state who will spend two years or more on the job will generate 7,500 total jobs in housing, cement, lumber, food and so on. The 350 permanent jobs will produce 950 to 1,000 jobs. If unemployed people get those jobs, they will contribute to the economy. If they are employed and switch, their old jobs will be filled by others. If the plant takes off, it will bring in supplier companies and more jobs."
"Williams is obligated to give New Haven residents first shot at the 350 steel jobs," said Sal Brancati, New Haven's director of business development. The city has an unemployment rate of just under 5 percent.
Bonds are expected to be issued in the fall, and applications for site plan review and environmental permits await completion of building plans.
Mr. Brancati said that New Haven's downtown was beginning to show signs of improvement. "The new $27 million Omni Hotel at Yale is almost completed and taking reservations for December," he said. "First class office space is filled, and we are beginning to absorb second class space."
Demolition of Malley's department store starting next week will open up office possibilities, and some vintage office buildings are being converted into 700 market-rate apartments, for which there are waiting lists. Developers are submitting alternative proposals for the vacant Macy's, and negotiations for property required to build a big mall at Long Wharf are nearing completion.
But it is the steel plant that has lifted spirits. "It's nice to have Swiss Bank and Zurich Re in Stamford," Edward Deak, professor of economics at Fairfield University, said, "but it's very nice to see a manufacturing entity come into the state."

HEADLINE: Taking the Measure Of Lead-Paint Hazards

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS, government officials, doctors and advocates for children have presented a compelling case for the dangers of lead-based paint to children, a danger present in an estimated 64 million homes, in wealthy suburbs as well as inner cities.
But since Federal regulations designed to promote disclosure of lead-paint hazards went into effect last December, they have, regulators agree, had little impact on the buyers and potential buyers whom they were designed to protect. 
 "I don't think that people are fully aware of the importance of this issue," said Clarence Lewis, chief of the National Program Chemicals Assistance Branch of the Environmental Protection Agency.
According to the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, nearly a million children have unacceptably high levels of lead in their blood, which can result in behavioral and growth problems, learning disabilities, low attention span and reduced IQ levels.
But understanding what hazards may actually exist in a home in which lead paint is present -- which means most houses and apartments built before 1978 -- is only the first step in a process that includes examining the wide range of possible actions to resolve any problems.
"Most houses don't poison most children," said David Jacobs, director of the Office of Lead Hazard Control in the Department of Housing and Urban Development. "But it's always in a homeowner's best interest to know where potential problems are so that future problem can be avoided."
Mr. Jacobs pointed out that there is a distinction between houses that contain lead-based paint and those that contain lead-based paint hazards.
"A hazard means that the paint has deteriorated or that there is contaminated dust or soil on the property," he said. "So while it's true that there are 64 million houses that have lead-based paint in them, our estimates are that something like 20 million contain lead hazards."
But, Mr. Jacobs said, evidence suggests that many children are exposed to lead-based paint hazards as the result of renovation projects in well-maintained homes that contain lead-based paint -- homes that would otherwise be considered safe.
Moreover, he said, many homeowners are unaware that even minor projects -- like paint removal and sanding or scraping of painted surfaces -- can be hazardous if the surface contains lead-based paint.
"All of these activities create fumes or dust," Mr. Jacobs said. "It is possible even for homeowners with the best of intentions to create problems where none formerly existed."
Anne Guthrie, deputy director of the Alliance to End Childhood Lead Poisoning, an advocacy group based in Washington, agreed. "For suburban homeowners whose houses are in otherwise good condition, this is the area of greatest risk," she said. "I know of many parents who thought they were doing the right thing by renovating their homes who inadvertently ended up poisoning their children."
Typical physical symptoms of severe lead poisoning include stomach pain, seizures, headaches and growth problems. And while all young children are susceptible to lead poisoning the risk is greatest for children under the age of 2. "That's when they are most likely to be crawling and exploring and putting everything they see into their mouths," Ms. Guthrie said.
She added that virtually invisible particles of lead dust from friction surfaces like windows and doors can be ingested by children chewing on windowsills or crawling around floors and transferring the substance from hand to mouth.
It was to control such dangers that the final regulations of the Residential Lead-based Paint Hazard Reduction Act went into effect last December. The Federal measure requires property owners of virtually all housing built before 1978 to disclose to prospective buyers or renters whatever they know about the presence of lead-based paint in their properties and to permit buyers to have a lead-hazard inspection conducted.
OVER the seven months that the law has been in effect, however, officials have made an unsettling observation: While buyers are being advised of their right to have a lead hazard inspection conducted, relatively few seem inclined to do so.
With that in mind, the Environmental Protection Agency called a meeting of lead-based paint experts from around the country last month to determine why buyers seem to be ignoring the Government's efforts to increase awareness of the hazards associated with lead based paint.
Several of those experts, interviewed for this article, say that the reason more people are not getting lead-based paint inspections is because many buyers -- indeed, many homeowners -- harbor some basic misconceptions about the issue.
Many homeowners, for example, erroneously believe that lead-based paint is an "inner city" problem. In fact, experts say, there is lead-based paint in about two-thirds of the nation's housing stock. And wherever lead paint is present, they say, so, too, is the potential for problems.
Another misconception is that even if lead-based paint is present in a house, it poses no danger as long as the paint is not chipping or peeling off walls or ceilings. Indeed, specialists say, while intact surfaces are safe as long as they remain intact, they can easily become hazardous if they are abraded by regular use -- such as by opening and closing windows and doors -- or by renovation efforts like tearing down walls and removing or stripping woodwork.
And finally, those who have studied the problem say, a good number of homeowners are under the mistaken impression that to render a home safe from lead-based paint hazards requires nothing less than removal of every last bit of lead in the house -- an extraordinarily expensive solution that is out of the question for most homeowners.
Abatement contractors point out, however, that the best way to deal with existing lead-based paint is to remove what can easily be removed and cover or maintain what cannot -- options that are relatively inexpensive and generally safe.
If concerns about the ingestion of some floor dust by otherwise healthy children seems to be a well-intentioned exaggeration of the hazard posed by lead, consider the following illustration of the problem provided by Lee Wasserman, president of Lew Corporation, a lead inspection and risk assessment company based in Livingston, N.J.
Under current law, Mr. Wasserman said, the "action level" for lead dust on surfaces -- the point at which that surface is deemed to represent a potential hazard -- is 100 micrograms per square foot.
One microgram, Mr. Wasserman explained, is one one-millionth of a gram. One gram, he said, is roughly the equivalent to the contents of one small packet of Equal, the artificial sweetener.
"That means that if you had one gram of lead dust in a 10,000-square-foot house, and you could distribute that dust evenly over every floor in every room in the house, then every square foot of every single room would fail the Federal and state action levels," Mr. Wasserman said.
Dr. Herbert Needleman, professor of Psychiatry and Pediatrics at the University of Pittsburgh Medical School, pointed out that there was essentially no safe amount of lead that a child can ingest. "There's clear evidence that changes in children's' cognitive function can begin with concentrations as low as 10 micrograms -- that's 10 millionths of a gram -- in about 3 ounces of blood," Dr. Needleman said. "That's like a teaspoon in a swimming pool."
Some early lead paints that were used, he said, contain as much as 50 percent lead.
"That means that a paint chip as big as your fingernail could contain as much as 500,000 micrograms of lead," he said. "So if you have lead-based paint on every windowsill and every door frame, and you determine that they're shedding lead dust, the wise thing to do is to get it taken care of."
And that, Federal regulators and health experts say, is what underscores the need for an inspection to detect the presence of lead-based paint and an assessment of any hazards that may exist.
"The whole purpose of a lead inspection is to say to the consumer, 'Here is a blueprint of your house that points out where there is and where there isn't lead based paint,' " said Mr. Wasserman of the Lew Corporation.
A properly conducted inspection, he said, begins with a visual inspection of the entire premises. That, he said, will identify areas that could represent a problem if lead-based paint is found on such a surface.
Then, he said, all painted surfaces in the house should be tested for the presence of lead-based paint. And since leaded paint is frequently buried under several layers of nonleaded paint, most inspectors will use X-Ray fluorescence equipment to essentially take an X-ray of the surface to be tested. With such equipment, Mr. Wasserman said, highly accurate readings can be obtained without removing paint from the surface and sending samples to a laboratory.
"Every surface in every room should be tested," Mr. Wasserman said, adding that it was not unusual for an inspector to take as many as 200 separate readings in an average house.
A thorough inspection, he said, should also include "dust wipes" taken from floors, window sills and window wells; soil samples taken from exterior areas -- particularly children's play areas -- and water samples taken from the tap. Those samples are then sent to a laboratory to determine whether they contain unacceptable levels of lead.
AFTER the inspection has been completed and lab results have been obtained, Mr. Wasserman said, a report should be provided to the homeowner indicating the lead content of every surface tested. Finally, he said, homeowners should make sure the report contains a "risk assessment" section that describes the relative risks associated with any lead-based paint that is found in the house.
"Risk assessment is critical," Mr. Wasserman said, explaining that a thorough inspection and careful assessment provides a homeowner with a blueprint and an action plan for dealing with lead-based paint.
An intact wall surface with a top coat of high-quality, nonleaded paint, for example, is generally safe as long as the surface is properly maintained. A window or door that gets constant use, on the other hand, could constitute a potential hazard because friction can wear away outer coatings and turn long-hidden lead paint to dust that accumulates on sills and floors.
"Should lead paint in a house scare the living daylights out of everyone?" Mr. Wasserman asked rhetorically. "I would say 'No.' " "If it's intact, you probably just have to maintain it. Lead in a wall is not going to jump out and bite you."
Mark Androsiglio, president of Environmental Diagnostic Tech, a lead-abatement contractor based in Neptune, N.J., agreed.
"We try to prioritize," Mr. Androsiglio said. "If there is lead paint on a ceiling or wall and we can stabilize it and the homeowner can maintain it, that's what we'll suggest. If there is a problem with lead dust on windows and doors, then we'll suggest replacing the windows and doors."
Generally, he said, the cost to have a lead-abatement contractor perform renovations in a house will run about 75 percent more than an ordinary contractor. So, for example, if an ordinary contractor would charge $200 to replace a window, a lead-abatement contractor might charge $350.
There is a reason, however, for the additional expense.
"You can't just take a crowbar and whack out windows and doors that have lead-based paint," Mr. Androsiglio said, explaining that whenever a lead-bearing surface is disturbed, precautions must be taken to insure that the abatement or renovation itself doesn't create additional contamination.
The first thing a competent abatement contractor will do, he said, is seal off the area being worked on to prevent dust from migrating to other areas of the house.
In most cases, Mr. Androsiglio said, workers wear protective jump suits and respirators to avoid ingesting or breathing airborne lead particles. That should be a signal to homeowners to avoid the work area while work is in progress. And whenever lead-bearing surfaces are being disturbed, he said, children and pregnant women should be out of the house.
Proper cleanup of the work area is also important. "First of all, you have to use a HEPA-Vac," Mr. Androsiglio said. Such vacuums, he noted, utilize high-efficiency filters that trap minute particles that standard household and shop vacuums would miss. In fact, cleanup with an ordinary vacuum can often increase contamination.
"With a regular vacuum, the dust is not only not trapped, but it's blown out all over the place," he said.
Once the area has been vacuumed, Mr. Androsiglio said, all surfaces must be wet-wiped with a solution containing either tri-sodium phosphate -- commonly known as TSP -- or Ledizolve, an industrial cleaner. Unless such chemicals are used, Mr. Androsiglio said, lead particles will simply be sloshed around and then left on the floor.
Finally, Mr. Androsiglio said, when all surfaces have been thoroughly cleaned, a competent contractor call in an inspector to take samples of dust and have them tested.
"It's called a final clearance criteria," Mr. Androsiglio said. "It's the final testing to insure that the house is safe."
There are, of course, homes that do contain chipping and peeling paint on walls, ceilings and woodwork. In such cases, homeowners have several options available: total or partial abatement of lead-bearing surfaces; enclosure or encapsulation of such surfaces; removal and replacement of friction surfaces and stabilization, maintenance and in-place management.
Total abatement, of course, is the most effective way to eliminate lead hazards. It is also the most expensive. It is not unusual, for example, for a total abatement job in an averaged-sized house to cost anywhere from $50,000 and up.
Enclosure, which entails covering lead-bearing surfaces with sheetrock, is less expensive than abatement but can still run into tens of thousands of dollars -- more than most homeowners are prepared or able to spend.
PARTIAL abatement, however, when accompanied by in-place management, often makes sense. With partial abatement, for example, only surfaces that pose the greatest hazards are abated. Window frames and door jambs can be replaced or stripped chemically. Those surfaces that cannot be removed or stripped can sometimes be rendered safe in other ways.
"We ended up getting replacement windows," said Dr. Jane Kanowitz, an oncologist who recently bought a house in Maplewood, N.J. Dr. Kanowitz, who has a 6-month old child, said that when she and her husband had the house they were buying inspected, the inspection disclosed lead-based paint throughout the house -- including the friction surfaces of the windows.
"It made a tremendous difference to us," Dr. Kanowitz said, adding that while she and her husband could feel comfortable with the covered and intact lead-based paint on the ceilings, walls and woodwork, the windows had to go.
"I'm looking at this as a parent, not as a physician," she said. "Our concern might have been less if we didn't have a child."
Yet another alternative to abatement, enclosure or replacement is encapsulation.
George Keefe, president of Global Encasement, an industrial coating manufacturer based in Manhattan, said that his company's product, known as LeadLock, is a liquid encapsulate that can be warranted for 20 years when properly applied.
"Management in place is now more of an acceptable solution," Mr. Keefe said, explaining that as long as a lead-bearing surface can be maintained in sound condition, it is considered safe. LeadLock, which is thicker and more durable than paint, can be brushed, sprayed or rolled onto just about any surface.
The product, which costs from 42 to 80 cents per square foot applied, recently won the second-prize award for "best new products" at the 1997 Buildings/NY trade show in Manhattan.
"It comes in either flat or gloss finish," Mr. Keefe said. "And we can make just about any color you want."
Even homeowners who can afford to spend little or nothing on lead-based paint remediation, experts say, can take steps to reduce the danger to their children.
"We particularly worry about first-time home buyers," said Nick Farr, executive director of the Center for Lead Safe Housing in Columbia, Md. "They are typically buying older houses that need a lot of renovation and if they run into a problem with lead-based paint, they may not have the money to deal with it properly."
However, Mr. Farr said, with careful monitoring of surfaces that contain lead based paint and regular cleaning of floors, window sills and window wells with TSP or Ledizolve, homes without seriously deteriorated surfaces can be made fairly safe.
"Lead poisoning can be prevented if you're careful," Mr. Farr said. "Why take a chance?"

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Hudson Square;
Trinity Church Reinvents a Neighborhood - Again

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
LOOKING for more space for his company, Cyber Dialogue Inc., Andrew Watt found what he liked at 304 Hudson Street in an area to the south of Greenwich Village, east of SoHo and north of TriBeCa. The fact that he lives in TriBeCa was not irrelevant.
With 3,000 square feet of space, he is not exactly a major tenant of Trinity Real Estate, which owns 5.5 million square feet of space in commercial buildings, most of it in an area it is marketing as the Hudson Square neighborhood. 
 But Mr. Watt's business is exactly the kind of hip, high-technology company Trinity is seeking to rejuvenate a faded manufacturing district. Cyber Dialogue is an Internet data base consulting company operating on the forefront of new communications systems.
"We help people understand who is visiting their Web sites," said Mr. Watt, the company's chief executive. "If a company has a Web site and wants to tell its advertisers who its customers are, we help them work it out."
Mr. Watt said he looked at both the East and West Sides of Manhattan after outgrowing space on Maiden Lane downtown before settling on the Hudson Street location and moving in January. "It was nice loft space at a reasonable price," he said.
Trinity is the major landlord in an area bounded by the Hudson River, Canal Street to the south, the Avenue of the Americas to the east and Morton Street to the north, owning about 45 percent of the commercial property. The company, which is owned by the 300-year-old Trinity Church near Wall Street, comes by its real estate assets in an unusual way: they are the result of a land grant by Queen Anne of England in 1705.
For almost a hundred years, this was a manufacturing district, with graphic arts and printing companies operating in structures sturdily built to support heavy, vibrating printing presses. Many of the buildings can support 225 pounds per square foot, compared with 90 to 100 pounds in typical office buildings, Trinity officials said.
For many years, Trinity collected rents and turned the money over to the church to support its charitable programs. But changing technology and the stock market crash a decade ago dealt a heavy blow to the printing industry. With fewer rush jobs from securities companies, the companies had to cut their costs to bid more effectively for the remaining work.
"Three things happened to the printing industry," said Joseph T. Palombi, executive vice president of Trinity Real Estate. "New technology meant less space was needed to operate a print shop, many companies moved their operations to lower-cost, nonunion locations in New Jersey, Long Island and Queens and many companies started to do a lot of their own printing."
The impact on Trinity was substantial. Companies leasing 3 million of the Trinity's 5.5 million square feet failed. Observing that manufacturing in general was shrinking in Manhattan, Trinity officials decided to remake the neighborhood, seeking companies in the advertising, publishing, telecommunications and the high-technology, new-media industries.
Since noisy, vibrating, dirty printing operations do not make good neighbors to office tenants, the remaining printers were consolidated into three buildings on Vestry, Hudson and Canal Streets with 800,000 to 900,000 square feet of space.
"TRINITY decided to invent a neighborhood," said Stephen D. Heyman, who joined the company earlier this year as director of commercial leasing. "To do that, it was important to create an identity for an area that was thought of as SoHo west. So they dusted of some maps from the 1800's, and found the term Hudson Square and decided to apply the name to a larger area." (The actual square, now vanished, was below Canal Street and outside Trinity's holdings.)
The conversion program appears to be working. Tenants in all the targeted categories have arrived, most notably the Saatchi & Saatchi advertising agency, which moved into a new building developed by Tishman Speyer on land owned by Trinity. Older buildings have been renovated to obscure their industrial past with new lobbies and upgraded elevators and air-conditioning.
The amount of vacant square footage has dwindled to 887,000, according to Mr. Heyman, with leases pending on almost 500,000 square feet of that. "At the end of the day, we are only going to have about 150,000 square feet of office space available," Mr. Palombi said. "The rest is mostly storage, basement and retail space."
Brokers say Trinity has been largely successful turning an industrial area into one of mixed commercial uses. (No housing, however, since the zoning does not permit it.)
"It is perceived as a niche area that derives some of the cachet of SoHo and TriBeCa, and Trinity has a reputation for operating well-managed buildings." said Bruce E. Surry, a senior managing director of Insignia/Edward S. Gordon. "They have, in fact, transformed the neighborhood by refusing to renew the leases of the printers in some buildings and grouping them elsewhere."
He said asking rents, under $20 a square foot 18 months ago, had risen recently to an average of $23.50.
"Trinity has done a good job marketing the area and they are seeing a lot of activity," said Vincent J. Peters, a vice chairman of Cushman & Wakefield. Mr. Peters said Trinity's reputation helped the marketing effort. "You can't find a better landlord in the city," he said. "They are conservative, but take a lot of pride in what they do."
It should not be surprising that this church-owned real estate company has been successful in converting a neighborhood. Trinity has been doing it for a long time.
The original grant of land was intended to provide financial support for the church by its use as a farm. It was bounded roughly by Broadway on the east, the Hudson River on the west, Fulton Street on the south and Christopher Street on the north. Over the years, the church gave away or sold large amounts of its land. Two notable recipients of land donations were Kings College, now Columbia University, and St. Vincent's Hospital.
Trinity officials say the Queen's grant is probably the largest contiguous piece of Manhattan land ever owned by one entity. Today, they say the church owns 3 to 4 percent of the original tract. As a farm, the land produced little income, but as the city expanded northward, the land came into demand for housing. The church leased the ground to landlords, some of whom built crowded, unsanitary tenements or used their buildings for even less savory purposes.
"BY the late 1800's, the church's leaders realized they owned the red-light district of New York," Mr. Heyman said. "So the rector decided to sell or trade those properties for locations where commercial buildings could provide the church with an economic base." By the late 1920's, the basic industrial nature of the neighborhood was established.
Trinity generally leased the land to developers who had the capital to build factory buildings. That arrangement worked fine during the early decades of the century, but during the Depression many building owners defaulted on their mortgages and the properties were in danger of being seized by the city for unpaid taxes.
A bank lent the church money to satisfy the tax payment, which is how Trinity came to own the buildings as well as the land.
The company is continuing its factory-to-office renovation program, with three buildings, two on Hudson Street and the other on the Avenue of the Americas, undergoing conversion. Trinity officials are also starting to think about new development.
"We have locations where we can expand as of right, although we're not ready to say much about our plans yet," Mr. Palombi said. He said these rights would allow the company to add extra floors to existing buildings to produce new space.
"The way it would work is that you would empty out a building, strip it down to the frame and add new stories," Mr. Heyman said. "That way you could turn a 250,000-square-foot building into one with 500,000 square feet."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Sarah Holmes and Eric Briggs

 BODY:
Sarah Burgwin Holmes, an intelligence officer for the Central Intelligence Agency in McLean, Va., was married yesterday to Steven Eric Briggs, the deputy director of the Strategic Studies Group for the Defense Secretary. The Rev. Louise J. Lusignan performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington.
Mrs. Briggs, 38, graduated from Yale University and received a master's degree in international relations from the London School of Economics. Her parents are Mr. and Mrs. George Burgwin Holmes of Washington. The bride's father retired as a member of the C.I.A. inspector general's staff in McLean. Her mother, Nancy Trowbridge Holmes, retired as an estate agent and antiques dealer in Washington. 
 Mr. Briggs, who is 51 and is known as Eric, is the director of the Defense Secretary's fellows program, which places military officers in American industry. He graduated from the University of Virginia and received a master's degree from the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, Calif. He retired from the Navy in 1995 as a captain. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.
His parents, Mr. and Mrs. Steven T. Briggs of Pueblo West, Colo., taught in the Indianapolis school system. The bridegroom's mother, Lilian B. Briggs, retired as a home economics teacher at Florence Fay Junior High School. His father taught English, speech and drama at T. C. Howe High School.
