SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2375 words

HEADLINE: Fill 'er Up? We Do.

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: LINDEN

 BODY:
IT'S just before 9 on a dazzling morning and the largest refinery on the East Coast is running full tilt, as it always is these days. The world's biggest catalytic cracker is cracking, crude and gas and diesel are surging through 675 miles of blue and gray pipe, the intermittent "psssht" of venting steam rises above the hum of compressor motors. And as Michael Karlovich, Bayway Refinery's head of community relations, stands on the deck of company headquarters admiring a surreal 300-foot-high skyline that looks like gargantuan thermos bottles and mixing bowls and flame-topped rocket-launching platforms, he is reminded of a recent conversation.
"We had some people from Liberty Science Center up here and one woman said, 'Is there a registry of national historic places that this is on?' I said I wish everybody else felt that way." 
 The fact that not everybody else does feel that way speaks volumes about New Jersey's love-hate relationship with its most visible industry and its crucial contribution to the region's economy. In Texas and Wyoming, they make a cultural fetish of their rigs and derricks. But New Jersey seems to be in a permanent state of apology for being home to the world's largest oil port -- of which Bayway, where on any given day there is enough gasoline on hand to drive a car to the sun and back 27 times, is only one part.
Every year, more than 28 billion gallons of petroleum in various forms flows in and out of the Port of New York, whose facilities are mostly in New Jersey. It sloshes in the holds of hundreds of town-sized tankers and thousands of barges that ply the Arthur Kill, rides on the backs of trains and trucks and rumbles along underground at 20 miles an hour through the eastern United States' largest oil pipeline, which ends a few hundred yards from Bayway's door.
And when it's not moving, of course, the stuff rests, in the big fat cylinders that make the flight approach to Newark International Airport look like an enormous checkerboard where white is beating the pants off black. In the northeast quarter of the state, mostly along the Arthur Kill, Newark Bay and the Hudson, Hackensack and Passaic rivers, roughly 700 king-size storage tanks hold more than 3 billion gallons of gas and oil awaiting processing or shipment all over New Jersey, New York, New England and Pennsylvania.
Just as important as New Jersey's capacity to move and store fuel is its capacity to make it. The state's six refineries -- besides Bayway, the others are a Hess plant in Woodbridge, a Chevron asphalt plant in Perth Amboy, and plants run by Mobil, Coastal and Citgo along the Delaware River near Paulsboro, south of Camden -- account about half of the Eastern Seaboard's refinery output.
And for the past 10 years, New Jersey's refineries have been getting busier. They now process about 30 million gallons of crude oil a day, up from 19 million a day in 1987 and more than enough to meet New Jersey's 25-million-gallon-a-day appetite for fuel if it all stayed in-state. Even with the increased production, though, refinery jobs, which pay top scale of about $20 an hour, are disappearing just as fast as other manufacturing jobs in New Jersey. The refineries now employ 5,200 people, down 23 percent since 1990 and down by more than half since 1919, when New Jersey was the nation's leading refinery employer.
Much of the increased production is at Bayway, whose parent company, the Tosco Corporation, has doubled processing capacity to 12 million gallons a day since it bought the plant from Exxon in 1992 for a paltry $157 million (Mr. Karlovich estimated the whole refinery would cost $2 billion to replace). Tosco, based in Stamford, Conn., has become one of the nation's biggest independent refiners by buying up refineries that others no longer find profitable.
The local refineries help keep fuel prices low in New Jersey, in part because they have to compete against imports that come into the Port of New York, which receives more than half of the nation's imported petroleum products, and against Gulf Coast refiners that use the Colonial Pipeline, which supplies more than half of the region's fuel and terminates in Linden. The main reason, though, for New Jersey's low prices at the pump, is the fact that the state has the nation's fourth-lowest gasoline tax.

'You Have to Burn Fuel to Make Fuel'
Of course there are drawbacks to this petrochemical wealth. The fourth-, fifth- and sixth-biggest polluters in the state are all oil refineries, according to the Department of Environmental Protection. The top three are all utility generating stations. In 1995, Bayway, ranked No. 5, belched out 5,092 tons of the ingredients that make smog, 551 tons of carbon monoxide and 1,208 tons of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain.
But the refineries pollute far less than they used to -- no more burnt-popcorn smell as you drive up the New Jersey Turnpike -- and, with considerable prodding from state regulators, they are continuing to improve.
"I don't think there's any single industry that's more environmentally conscious than we are," said John Maxwell, associate director of the New Jersey Petroleum Council.
Besides, said Ray Papalski, the supervising environmental specialist in the D.E.P.'s Bureau of Air Quality Planning: "Somebody's got to be the largest. These are big facilities that have a lot of employees and a lot of pieces of equipment and process a lot of product, and they do stuff that by its inherent nature causes air contaminants. You have to burn fuel to make fuel."
At Bayway, crude oil from any number of places, including the North Sea, South America and several African countries, is pumped off a tanker at the company's dock on the Arthur Kill. It travels two miles through pipes, under the turnpike to a tank field, where it is blended with other types of crude and piped to a furnace.
There, it is boiled at about 650 degrees and sent to a distillation tower. The resulting vapors rise to the top of the tower, and as each of the compounds that make up the crude cools below its boiling point, it condenses to a liquid and flows down through a series of trays. Heavier components with higher boiling points -- asphalt, fuel oil, jet fuel, diesel, heating oil, and the raw ingredients of rubber and plastic -- condense first and flow to lower levels. Lighter products -- gasoline components and lighter-than-air gases like propane and butane -- collect higher up.
The black, arm-like sidepipes that reach out of the tower at regular intervals pull the components off and send them on their way. Some, such as jet fuel, require no further processing and proceed directly to storage tanks. Others require more processing.
Because the demand for gasoline, compared to other petroleum products, is much greater than the supply that naturally occurs from distillation, some of the heavier components are sent on to the catalytic cracking unit, commonly known as the cat cracker. In the cracker, long, heavy oil molecules are bombarded with a finely powdered, 1,300-degree catalyst that breaks them into smaller molecules of gasoline or light heating oil.
"It's like a big kitchen," Mr. Karlovich said. "We're heating, we're cooling, we're mixing, we're blending, changing things from ingredients to finished product." The journey from the crude ship to the gasoline storage tank takes about four days.
The finished product is liable to wind up just about anywhere in the Northeast. BP, Getty and Amoco tanker trucks fill up at Bayway's rack with custom-blended gasoline. Barges pick up heating oil and haul it to tank farms on Long Island or bring it to New Haven Harbor, where it is distributed throughout New England.
And much of Bayway's product is delivered to the Buckeye Pipeline's Linden station, which connects to pipelines at the Station Manifold, a mansion-sized labyrinth of pipes and almost 800 valves. The Buckeye receives fuel from the Bayway and Hess refineries, a handful of storage terminals, the Colonial Pipeline and the Harbor Pipeline along the Delaware Bay, and sends it as far west as Pittsburgh and Buffalo. Buckeye also pumps fuel under the Hudson to New York City and pipes jet fuel to Newark, Kennedy and La Guardia airports.
Storage terminals or tank farms, which make up much of the visible oil landscape in New Jersey, come in two varieties: those owned by an oil company that supply a single brand fuel, and those that rent out storage space to oil distributors and are essentially fuel warehouses. The 17-tank Amoco Terminal in Carteret, for instance, which fills 100 Amoco trucks a day and dispatches barges across the Arthur Kill to Staten Island or up the river to Mount Vernon, often takes deliveries from the independent G.A.T.X. terminal across the street.
"If you decide you want to go into business and you want to buy 130,000 barrels of product coming in from, say, Venezuela," said Amoco's terminal manager, Lou Romano, "you call up G.A.T.X., they store it for you and ship it out based on your instructions."
One drawback of the enormous concentration of oil tanks in the harbor is the small but ever-present risk of sabotage or attack. "It's one of those unquestioned questions," Mr. Romano said. "Everybody knows where they are; you can't hide them. We do have alerts when there are heightened tensions between the U.S. and other countries. Otherwise, it's a concern but not an overriding factor."

How to Make Money In a Competitive Market
For Tosco, operating an oil refinery in the middle of the world's biggest petroleum market has its pros and cons. Obviously, it cuts transportation costs to be where the customers are. But the endless supply coming in on tankers from Europe, barges from the Gulf of Mexico and the Colonial Pipeline means prices must be kept low. At the same time, electricity in Texas costs half of what it does here, Mr. Maxwell of the New Jersey Petroleum Council said, and labor -- the Bayway refinery has 950 employees -- is considerably cheaper.
Then there is added cost of doing business in New Jersey, which has some of the nation's strictest air regulations. And there is the ongoing problem of silt buildup in the harbor, which keeps out bigger tankers and forces many boats to unload some cargo at sea in order to become light enough to make it into the harbor. (Tosco got tired of waiting for the silt problem to be solved and commissioned a fleet of extra-wide tankers that hold 20 percent more than a conventional tanker of the same draft.)
All of this has meant that Tosco has had to be lean and mean, and it has. In the process, industry analysts say, Tosco is making about 12 percent profit off a refinery that lost money for Exxon. "Tosco's purchase of that refinery was good news for New Jersey, for Tosco, and for Exxon," said Fredrick Leuffer, an analyst with Bear Stearns.
The only people who do not seem completely thrilled are the members of Teamsters Local 877. Tosco renegotiated the union contract when it took over and, according to the local president, Curt Greder, got rid of about 100 workers.
"They basically trashed our contract," Mr. Greder said. "They try to make the contract as vague as they possibly can, eliminate work rules so they have a more or less free hand in dealing with labor. That allows them to hold the sword of Damocles over you and make you hope they don't do anything else."
Labor relations notwithstanding, Bayway takes great pains to maintain its public image and cope with the headaches that come with running a mammoth factory along the state's main road.
Earlier this year, as part of its effort to improve the plant's esthetics, Bayway began dismantling a rusting 50-foot-high propane storage sphere just beyond the Turnpike fence. Not long after, Mr. Karlovich said, the company got a call from a state trooper who said the Governor wanted to know if there was anything wrong.
Mr. Karlovich is particularly annoyed that Bayway's $22 million wet gas scrubber, which vents clouds of water vapor -- not smoke -- as it pulls waste gas and dust particles out of the emission stream, has somehow managed to become the news industry's stock shot of New Jersey pollution. "It's like a hex on us," he said. "Every time there's some kind of chemical calamity or pharmaceutical scandal, they show our scrubber."
Mr. Karlovich pointed out on a tour that Bayway's sprawling property -- at 2.1 square miles, it is roughly twice the size of Hoboken -- includes a lot more than pipes and towers. There are three named streams -- Peach Orchard Brook, West Brook and Morses Creek -- a reservoir, a modest birch forest, the Morse family's 18th-century burial ground, and a surprising amount of wildlife even in the most barren-looking places. A snow-white egret pecks along the gravel-lined banks of a cooling-water return channel. Geese and goslings swim in the rain puddles that pool in old tank pits. Cormorants sun their wings in the reservoir.
One place where Bayway does not need to improve its image is in Linden itself, where the company is the biggest taxpayer and one of the few remaining industrial employers. It is also so active in the city's civic life that it received a state Good Neighbor award last week.
"They've been very generous to our cultural heritage committee and our Golden Gloves boxing program," said the longtime Mayor, John Gregorio. "And anytime anything happens out there, they call us immediately and let us know."
Last December, the refinery released a cloud of oily soot that settled on cars and houses. The next day, Bayway hired power-washers to clean off roofs and porches and offered free car washes to all those affected.
Mr. Gregorio, who is 70, said he did not think the refinery was an environmental hazard. "The oldest citizens we have live in Tremley Point, right in the middle of the tank fields," he said. "I don't suspect the people in Linden are being hurt at all by any of the industry here."
And as for the thick refinery smell that once permeated the town, Mr. Gregorio said those days appeared to be gone for good.
"I don't smell anything," he said. "Besides, the prevailing winds go east, so Staten Island would get the smell if there was any."

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Make the Modern Modern? How Very Rash!

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp 

 BODY:
MODERN ART IS BETTER than ever! At least, it's just as scary. This is the awful truth disclosed by Rem Koolhaas's proposal for the expansion of the Museum of Modern Art's midtown campus. Youthful, even bratty, shimmering with bright new ways to frighten the horses, Koolhaas's design would literally burst the old Modern apart at the seams.
The design could destroy the place, and possibly save it. Koolhaas's proposal can be glimpsed, but barely, in an exhibition now in the museum's top-floor galleries of architecture and design. "Toward the New Museum of Modern Art: Sketchbooks by 10 Architects" presents the results of the first round in the competition to design the expansion. Koolhaas, at one time regarded as a leading contender for the commission, did not place among the three finalists. 
 The three proposals, all as tasteful as table water biscuits, are by Pierre Herzog and Jacques de Meuron of Switzerland, Yoshio Taniguchi of Japan and Bernard Tschumi of New York. A winner will be chosen by the end of the year. As the show's title suggests, these are not fully worked-out designs but concepts, some quite rough in form.
Koolhaas presented his proposal in the form of a nearly 400-page hard-bound book. Like "S, M, L, XL," the massive tome Koolhaas brought out in 1995, this volume is a stylish production that reproduces the texture of an architect's thought. Sketches, hard-line drawings, photomontages, images of models, renderings, philosophical musings, jokes visual and verbal, are organized with a cinematic sense of pace.
At the museum, unfortunately, Koolhaas's book is displayed behind glass; visitors can't peruse its contents. As much a philosophical critique of the museum as a plan for its physical enlargement, the book deserves wider circulation. In years to come, many will look back on it as the Modern that could have been.
Koolhaas begins by reviewing the museum's history and analyzing its present situation. This makes for a sweet and sour show-and-tell. With deftly chosen images and quotations from the museum's founders, Koolhaas evokes the days when the Modern was new and its novelty stood in sharp contrast -- philosophically and architecturally -- to the world around it.
The contrast has grown fuzzy. Instead of a crisp frame enclosing intimate galleries, the museum is now an unfocused blur. As Koolhaas puts it: "The old part of MOMA is shabby. The new part of MOMA is tacky." He supports these views with color pictures that coolly capture the museum's physical shortcomings.
Koolhaas's design does not propose to restore the museum to its original purity. Nor does he rail against the museum's fall from artistic purity. He takes as a given that the Modern has many functions other than esthetic contemplation. It sells watches. It throws parties. It courts the media. It makes deals. These functions, Koolhaas believes, could be architecturally expressed.
A garden surrounds Koolhaas's museum. To create it, he takes a can opener to the existing buildings on West 53d Street and slices off the ground floor, turning them into a floating slab. On the West 54th Street side, Koolhaas sinks Philip Johnson's much-loved sculpture garden, intact, to basement level, allowing visual contact between the garden and the street. At the eastern end of the garden, now occupied by the museum restaurant, Koolhaas places what he calls the Forum. This he envisions as a Miesian "universal space" enclosed by glass, to be used for lectures, concerts, conferences, temporary shows and social events.
The museum's six curatorial departments -- offices for curators, support staff, preparers -- would be based, one department per floor, in the original museum building, designed by Edward Durell Stone and Philip L. Goodwin, and completed in 1939. A new seven-story tower for administrative offices would be built atop Johnson's 1964 addition, the site of the present bookstore. Koolhaas calls this tower "MOMA Inc.," as if the museum were an industry whose chief product is cultural prestige.
The museum's main galleries would be contained within a new six-story building, to the west of Cesar Pelli's 1985 residential Museum Tower. It would run the full block, from 53d to 54th Street. Atop this generic box, Koolhaas proposes to plant a slim 16-story triangular spire, its shape and dimensions conforming to the zoning envelope of allowable development the museum would acquire by tearing down the Dorset Hotel. A multi-use structure, the triangle would contain study centers, private viewing rooms, restaurants.
Koolhaas conceives these structures as episodes in an architectural narrative. Or call it a flow chart, a diagram of circulation. Money and power, accumulated by MOMA Inc., are converted into energy that is channeled into the curatorial departments. Here, artifacts are selected, then hauled out of storage and put on public display.
Just as the 1939 building derived its esthetic from industrial architecture, so Koolhaas proposes, in effect, a factory for the post-industrial city, an urban center geared for the manufacture of culture. Inside the building, Koolhaas proposes to make visible other museum operations that are ordinarily screened from view. Circulation -- of artworks and people -- gets big play here.
IN PLACE OF THE SHOPPING MALL escalators in Pelli's garden hall, Koolhaas proposes a grand moving staircase. He includes, as well, provisions for a new mode of transport. Developed by Otis, the Odyssey transport system is a cross between an elevator and a funicular tram. The same car can move vertically, horizontally and diagonally.
Some design elements extend familiar Koolhaas preoccupations. His esthetic has been described as a synthesis of Miesian classicism and the romantic imagery of Wallace K. Harrison; both sources are in evidence here. The architect's renderings of the museum's interiors echo the photomontages Mies himself devised for several museum projects. The triangle and square tower recall Harrison's pairings of different forms, like the Trylon and Perisphere, or the General Assembly and Secretariat Buildings at the United Nations Headquarters. Like Koolhaas's Piranesian Space at the Chunnel station in the French city of Lille, the Odyssey system expresses Koolhaas's weakness for technologically assisted disorientation.
Koolhaas's vertical forms hark back to the "culture of congestion," the theme of his legendary 1978 book, "Delirious New York." Unlike the other proposals, Koolhaas's design for the Modern actually embraces the Museum Tower instead of ignoring it. You get the sense that he'd want to put a residential high-rise on the site even if one weren't already there, and that just like Pelli, Koolhaas would also clad it with a glass skin inspired by Mondrian.
This plan is not easy to love. It doesn't begin to be elegant. It lacks the grace of formal simplicity. With or without Harrison as precedent, Koolhaas's vertical forms don't rhyme in the mind. His cutaway ground floor brings to mind the gloomy space beneath the floating garden slab of Lever House. His sunken garden will elicit shudders of recognition from those who've suffered the damp sculpture moat at the Whitney. The whiffs of technology, like the automated painting retrieval system, summon forth memories of French rinky-dink modernism from the 1960's.
And then Koolhaas has such a cheeky attitude. MOMA Inc., indeed. Trustees support art museums to bestow gentility upon money, power and social ambition, not to have the mask ripped away. Koolhaas rubs in his social commentary with images of stuffy Gilded Age dinner parties, complete with crystal chandeliers. In one collage, a seated woman turns a cold shoulder to a Matisse. The woman is Jessica Mitford, as depicted on the jacket of her book "The American Way of Death."
Because of these and other digs, some people have interpreted Koolhaas's submission as a sendup of the competition rather than a serious bid to win it. As those who've heard the architect lecture will recognize, however, this is just the way Koolhaas thinks. Here, in what is, after all, a sketchbook, prepared in less than a month, Koolhaas is simply thinking out loud.
His jokes are serious, and on target. The chandeliers and the Stanford White dinner party are visual shorthand for the overbred curatorial intelligence that has often haunted the halls of the Museum of Modern Art -- including this competition. Isn't this, more or less, what the finalists propose to give us: polite Gilded Age dinner spaces, reclad in the International Style?
WHY INVITE KOOLHAAS to the party and expect him to be anything less than Koolhaas? Nothing in his proposal should surprise anyone who has leafed through "S, M, L, XL." Isn't anyone at the Modern curious to see where Koolhaas might take his ideas? Yet the truth is that to make something successful from this proposal would take a client with more strength of will than the Modern is presently able to muster. It would take a client with the capacity to think yes and no simultaneously: Yes, your mind is working. No, you may not sink our garden into the basement. No, you can't cut away the ground floor. You may not use robots. Cut the cute stuff about MOMA Inc. Nix the chandeliers. Can the Odyssey. Got any more ideas?
If Koolhaas ever was a favored contender for this project, it was not because he was best known of the 10 architects, or because he was hot, or because he had put out an 800-pound book, all of which happen to be true. He was favored because no architect had a more focused view of the post-industrial city and of architecture's role in its cultural development.
As his attempts to wed Mies and Harrison suggest, Koolhaas collapses dualistic ways of thinking. His esthetic probes the lines that allegedly separate reason and folly, subjectivity and objectivity, world and dream. It seeks relationships more complex, in other words, than the simple old-versus-new opposition embodied in the Museum of Modern Art's original design.
Even the old Modern, however, challenged one of Western culture's most vexing dualisms, the one between art and life. That's why the architecture and design department was created. It's easy to overlook how successful the department's mission turned out to be: not in remaking the world according to the tenets of Good Design, but rather (like Duchamp or Warhol) in calling into question the difference between art and other things.
The culture has taken that idea and run with it, leaving the Modern behind in the dust of a concept it pioneered. The Koolhaas proposal, even in unbuilt form, clears away the dust. Rude, brash, aiming a deflationary arrow at our willingness to puff milquetoast as risky, his proposal slaps the museum awake from a deep post-modern slumber.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ASTORIA;
Putting Damper on Housing In Former Steinway Factory

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
A developer's plan to convert the old Steinway piano factory in Astoria into a 275-unit rental building was defeated recently after Community Board 1 rejected the proposal during a tumultuous public meeting.
The developer, Nikos Kefalidis of Manhattan, had asked the board to rezone the building, at 45th Street and Ditmars Boulevard, to residential from commercial. 
 He said he planned to finance the $30 million conversion through a city-sponsored program that grants low-interest loans to developers who set aside at least 20 percent of units for low-income residents.
Mr. Kefalides said that his rezoning request will go to the City Council for a vote but that without community board support there is virtually no chance it will be approved. "It is zoned for manufacturing," he said, "so I will put something appropriate in its place."
"I don't care if they put in a crematorium or a chicken slaughterhouse in its place," said the president of the Astoria/Ditmars Homeowners and Tenants Civic Association, Rudy Sarchese. "We won't put up with an apartment house."
Mr. Sarchese and other residents complained that the building, intended for an estimated 400 dwellers, would ruin the flavor of their middle-class neighborhood of one- and two-family homes. "Astoria already bears its fair share of problems," Mr. Sarchese said, citing congestion from La Guardia Airport and Rikers Island, both nearby, as well as overcrowded schools and a lack of parking. "How much are we supposed to take? No more."
The crumbling six-story brick factory, built in 1901 by the Steinway family, has been empty for six years. Its most recent tenant was Stern's department store, which used it as a furniture warehouse.
Community Board 1's chairman, Vinicio Donato, said Mr. Kefalidis had promised to give the elderly priority for the low-income apartments. Mr. Donato and the board's district manager, George Delis, said that although most board members thought the rezoning and conversion would benefit the area because of the opportunity for more housing for the elderly, they voted 25 to 6 against the plan after 600 people, many shouting their opposition to the plan, attended the board meeting on June 4.
"The community board members gave the people what they wanted," Mr. Delis said. "But they voted out of fear. We all know the greatest need in this community is senior housing."
Queens, which has absorbed many immigrants to the city in the last decade, has an apartment vacancy rate of 3 percent, compared with 4 percent citywide, according to the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
Mr. Kefalidis, a Greek imigrant who settled in Astoria 20 years ago, said he thought objections to his plan centered not on overcrowding but bigotry. "It's an old argument," he said. "These people are afraid that welfare families would move in. They don't want people with dark skin or the last name "Rivera" living in their neighborhood."
Mr. Sarchese denied that assertion. "There's no racial overtone to this at all," he insisted. "Not at all." CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Coming to a Laggard's Aid

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
The $2.2 billion Vanguard Explorer fund is changing its management structure after a couple years of disappointing performance.
Effective Aug. 1, the current managers, Wellington Management and Granahan Investment Management, will manage roughly 60 to 70 percent of the portfolio. The balance will be divided evenly between two new advisers: Chartwell Investment Partners and Vanguard Core Management Group. 
 Chartwell was founded in April by former employees of the Delaware Management Company. It is led by Edward N. Antoian, former manager of the Delaware Trend and Delaware Delcap funds.
Vanguard Core Management will use a quantitative, or computer-based, approach to choose stocks that approximate a new small-company growth fund stock index constructed by Morningstar Inc. That index will be adopted as a benchmark for the fund, replacing the Russell 2000 index.
"We have a high degree of confidence that these four advisers in concert will improve the fund's performance," said John J. Brennan, Vanguard's president. Vanguard will also use stock futures to keep the fund more fully invested while allowing it to keep cash on hand for redemptions.
 
Sticker Shock On the Internet
Mutual fund companies are rushing to set up Internet sites in hopes of gaining an edge in a crowded marketplace. But the costs can be staggering, according to a recent report by Forrester Research, a technology research firm in Cambridge, Mass.
The report, "Transaction Site Sticker Shock," analyzed the cost of setting up and delivering financial services over the Internet. For its cost models, Forrester interviewed executives at 31 financial institutions whose Internet sites allow transactions, and it gathered cost information from site developers, systems integrators, software and hardware vendors and content providers.
The study found that combined start-up and first-year costs could run $5 million to $23 million a site, depending on the services offered.
A basic site that provides account information and permits financial transactions, like that of the Gabelli funds, is at the low end of the cost scale. Sales sites intended to attract new customers and high volume could cost $17 million initially. An example of such a program is that of Charles Schwab & Company.
Looking ahead, Forrester said that an advisory site with a high degree of individual attention, aimed at affluent customers and providing a wide range of personalized financial advice, would cost upward of $23 million. The company said that while no sites were now offering such a level of services, it expects big brokerage firms and large banks to begin doing so.
"Over time, I would expect the costs to continue to go up," said Karen Epper, author of the report.
 
New Managers
American Century Investments has made a series of manager changes to its American Century group of funds. John Schniedwind, a senior vice president for equity research, and Kurt Borgwardt, director of quantitative research, are the new lead managers for the Income and Growth fund, succeeding Dong Hao Zhang, who left the company. Mr. Zhang had also managed Equity Growth, which goes to Jeffrey Tyler, who will remain lead manager on the American Century Strategic Asset Allocation funds, and William Martin, who has served on the management teams for two American Century funds.
Mr. Borgwardt and Mr. Schniedwind will also take over American Century Utilities; it was previously run by Steven L. Colton, who had also been manager of the American Century Income and Growth and Equity Growth funds until last year.
Mr. Zhang will join Mr. Colton at Phoenix Duff & Phelps, where they will manage a new growth and income fund.
 
New Funds
The Victory Real Estate Investment fund aims for a high level of income and moderate long-term capital growth by investing in real estate investment trusts and publicly traded companies that own a variety of commercial properties, including shopping centers, apartments and office buildings.
Munder Capital Management has started three life style funds, which invest in a mix of the company's stock, bond and money market portfolios. The All-Season Maintenance fund seeks current income; All-Season Development aims for high total return by combining capital appreciation and current income, and All-Season Accumulation aims for long-term capital appreciation. The sales charge is 5.5 percent.
 
On the Web
Oppenheimer Funds has opened a World Wide Web site offering facts about the company and its products, daily net asset values and monthly performance for more than 40 funds. (www.oppenheimerfunds.com). Shareholders and advisers can review account transactions and balances; the site's interactive features include financial planning work sheets, and retirement and college planning calculators.
 
Openings and Closings
Putnam New Opportunities, opened in 1990, will close to new investors after June 23. Participants in 401(k) and other retirement plans and shareholders who make systematic investments will still be able to buy shares.
Oppenheimer Enterprise, which has been closed since March 29, 1996, has reopened the door.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FULTON FERRY;
Developer's Big Plans Have Seen Ups and Downs

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
In 1982, David Walentas was well on his way to creating an office and entertainment colossus on the sleepy Brooklyn waterfront between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges. The developer, 42 at the time, bought up a half dozen buildings and won city and state designation as the developer for the site.
Mr. Walentas's vision was big. Wall Street back offices would occupy more than two million square feet of new office space, visitors would survey the lower Manhattan skyline from a 330-foot observation tower and a luxury marina would hold 100 boats. 
 But in 1984, the city derailed Mr. Walentas's dream. Ruling that Mr. Walentas did not have sufficient financial backing for the project, officials removed him as the official developer. Mr. Walentas accused the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, Kenneth Lipper, of trying to destroy the project out of revenge.
In 1977, J. Frederick Byers, Mr. Walentas's business partner and Mr. Lipper's friend, had killed himself by jumping out a window of his Upper East Side apartment. Mr. Walentas said the Deputy Mayor blamed him for the suicide and had derailed the project to get back at him. Mr. Lipper dismissed the charge, saying that Mr. Walentas was being held to the same standards as any developer. Whatever the motives, Fulton Landing was dead.
Mr. Walentas's failure sparked a new push by the Brooklyn Heights Association and other groups for a park along the waterfront. After nearly a decade of lobbying, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo backed the creation of a Brooklyn Bridge Park during the 1994 gubernatorial campaign. But when Mr. Cuomo lost the election, the proposal died, too. Mr. Walentas, who had been waiting for a resurgence in the real-estate market, dusted off his plan. DAVID ROHDE

HEADLINE: The Wedding Gown: Revealing the Nation's Mood

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE GUTMANN 

 BODY:
IT may happen in the fitting room of a tony bridal salon or in a designer's atelier, or even in a mother's sewing room amid a sea of pins and pattern paper: There is a moment when the bride, after a long search and many false leads, first puts on The Dress, the one she realizes she will wear when she is married. "Usually somebody's crying in the room," said Rachel Leonard, the fashion editor of Brides magazine. "Your mother, your friend, even the bridal consultant."
The moment, Ms. Leonard said, has something to do with being plucked from ordinary life and suddenly becoming a symbol -- set apart but also connected in a long chain with one's mother, grandmothers and brides everywhere. 
 There is something iconic about the bride, but the actual elements of that image have shifted over the years. Wedding gowns have not always looked, as a character in the film "Four Weddings and a Funeral" put it, like "a big meringue," with bouffant skirt and clouds of tulle.
In the giddy 1920's, for example, a perfectly respectable wedding dress was short and straight, reflecting that decade's exuberance and fashion upheaval. Bustlines and natural waists disappeared under sacklike sheaths, and as compensation, shocking expanses of leg were revealed as wedding dresses shot up.
"New York Gets Married: Dressing for a Special Day, 1765-1997," at the Museum of the City of New York until Sept. 21, chronicles such shifting styles, in wedding pictures, memorabilia and, of course, dresses. There are 40 of them, from the Empire-waisted gowns of the early 19th century to the cacophony of styles of the 1990's.
Bridal gowns are always, Ms. Leonard said, a "reflection of the economic and social climate, the popular culture and fashion of the day."
 Some moments in history.
 
Age of Innocence
The bridal image has not always been white. Wedding dresses were virtually any color in the 1800's, said Phyllis Magidson, the curator of "New York Gets Married."
"It was simply the best dress your family had to offer, meant to be worn at special occasions thereafter," she said. A very wealthy woman might have her gown made at Maison Worth in Paris, where a dress could cost as much as a middle-class person's salary for a year, but for most people, Ms. Magidson added, "wearing something that was specifically and solely intended to be worn for the wedding -- the concept that we have of being a fairy princess -- is a fairly contemporary perception."
Queen Victoria's wedding in 1840 was the 19th-century equivalent of Lady Diana Spencer's extravaganza in 1982, and Victoria just happened to get married in white because she wanted her gown trimmed with a particularly rich lace. Her wedding-picture engravings were so widely circulated that the public began to associate white with weddings, Ms. Magidson said.
One may think of the speedy knockoff as a recent phenomenon, but at the turn of the century there were two developments -- the camera and the department store with its glass window -- that brought the dresses of the rich to the attention of the public. That helped move the concept of wedding dress from "best dress" to the modern state of pure costume, says Anne Hollander, author of the fashion history "Seeing Through Clothes" (Viking, 1978).
But even for the wealthy, it was considered socially acceptable to wear one's wedding dress for special occasions. In "The Age of Innocence" by Edith Wharton, which was set in the late 1800's, May Archer asks her new husband what to wear to a reception. He suggests her wedding dress, and she exclaims: "If only I had it here! But it's gone to Paris to be made over for next winter, and Worth hasn't sent it back."
 
Of Wally and War
Another flurry of wedding dress activity occurred in 1937, when Edward VIII abdicated his throne to marry Wallis Warfield Simpson. The populace swooned over this great romance -- and tried to get a piece of it by knocking off her $250 Mainbocher wedding ensemble, a form-fitting day dress. A newspaper article of the time, with the headline "The Descent of the 'Wally' Gown -- From Paris to New York's 14th Street in Six Weeks," traced the path of the dress, noting its appearance at "a swank shop on Fifth Avenue for $25" and at "Klein's Cash and Carry on 14th Street for $8.90" several days later.
But the 1940's put a stop to wedding dress excitement. Citizens were asked to conserve raw materials for the boys overseas. Though the United States did not adopt garment rationing as Britain did, the Government asked manufacturers to keep silhouettes lean and to avoid frills; most complied. A wedding was also likely to be rushed, so a bride might stand next to her soldier groom wearing something ordinary, tailored and Rosalind Russell-esque.
Armistice Day provided an unleashing of sartorial extravagance. "Women were feeling romantic because the men were home, and they were eager to get out of their Rosie the Riveter overalls," Ms. Magidson said. With a population ready to dress up, designers ended up pillaging "everything from the royal bag of tricks," Ms. Magidson added. "Boned and standing collars, puffed and melon sleeves, very full skirts, extended trains, even the crown gets resurrected."
 
Modern Brides
Compared with the relatively uneventful and sober 50's -- a time of bouffant gowns, narrow waists and full skirts -- the late 60's and early 70's were about rejection of tradition.
"The girls really didn't want wedding dresses at all," recalled Monica Hickey, the director of Custom/Couture Bridal at Saks Fifth Avenue, who served as a bridal consultant at Bergdorf Goodman in the 70's. "But most of them succumbed because Grandmother would cut them out of the will if they didn't."
Still, the ambivalence was expressed with "nonwedding wedding dresses." "I did barefoot brides in beautiful dresses from India in natural linen with beads and colored crewel work," Ms. Hickey said, "and dresses from Mexico that were all short and perky. We did a window at Bergdorf's where the bride was in this Indian embroidery and bare feet, holding sheaves of wheat. We were paying court to the hippies; rich hippies, anyway."
In the 80's, when ambivalence about wealth disappeared, the lavish wedding dress of great skirts and trains came into style, a trend crowned by what Ms. Hickey calls "the last great show on earth" -- the wedding of Lady Diana to the Prince of Wales. Elizabeth and David Emanuel's billowing creation, with its endless train (known as "cathedral length" because it suits the scale and pageantry of a big church wedding), "set up the idea that you spend an enormous amount of money on something that has nothing to do with the rest of your life so you can look like that for that moment," Ms. Hollander said. (Ms. Emanuel will introduce her new bridal collection in a trunk show on June 23 and 24 at Saks Fifth Avenue.)
What does the bride of the 90's look like? These days, "it's every man for himself," Ms. Hollander added, noting the diversity of designs.
Vera Wang, who opened shop on Madison Avenue and 77th Street in 1990, excised the frou-frou wedding cake embellishment and streamlined the shape. Now, top fashion designers who have tended to avoid bridal collections have jumped into the pool. Last year, Giorgio Armani started his first bridal-wear collection with such nontraditional outfits as tightly-fitted jacket and slit-skirt combinations, or tuxedo coat with mandarin collar, and a price range of $6,000 to $20,000. And at the same time, the team of Mark Badgley and James Mischka began a bridal collection that resembles elegant evening wear.
This season's bride won't necessarily wear white. Erisa Yuki is still doing gowns in black, and one of Ms. Wang's best sellers is pale sea green. The gown of a 90's bride might have corsetlike ties at the back or boning that seems taken from lingerie, or it might be trimmed with cowrie shells like the Afrocentric gowns of Therez Fleetwood.
Industry wide, the 90's bride is "more naked," said Ms. Wang, who is largely responsible for getting her that way with her plunging backs and cutout waists. (Her line costs $2,500 to $6,000.) Narciso Rodriguez showed lots of skin with a bias-cut slip dress for Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy that has been widely imitated.
One of Ms. Wang's best sellers is slim and columnar, with a fantail train that suggests an old-fashioned bustle. But at the same time, designers are also seeing a desire for "pomp and circumstance," said Ms. Wang, whose line includes the traditional bell skirt that still captures the popular imagination.
Ms. Wang said this redirection was about "the desire to be more bridal and more grand, more not like everyday life." And perhaps to be part of that great chain linking mother, grandmother and brides everyone.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Plymouth Breeze, Chevrolet Malibu and Ford Contour;
The Return of Detroit's 'Low Priced Three'

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB

 BODY:
DID somebody say "value"? With auto makers from Hyundai to Mercedes repeating that word like a mantra, its definition has grown fuzzy. But for many new-car shoppers of limited means, a good value means the biggest car for the money.
The three brands represented on this page, Chevrolet, Ford and Plymouth, were conceived as purveyors of high-value transportation, and they filled that role neatly for decades. Well into the 1960's they were the "Low Priced Three," the first rung up the automotive ladder for working people who wanted a roomy, reliable, economical car, with perhaps a little style thrown in. Over time, the three broadened their offerings and blurred that image, which brand-driven marketers are now trying to reclaim. 
 That strategy leans heavily on these cars: front-drive sedans that fit between Chevy's Cavalier and Lumina, between Ford's Escort and Taurus, between the Plymouth Neon and Chrysler's standard-size sedans like the Dodge Intrepid. The Chevy Malibu, Ford Contour and Plymouth Breeze are big enough for small families, easy on gasoline and generally well-behaved, but they are not as nimble as their smaller siblings, which also have more personality than these bland utilitarian sedans.
They are products of compromise, since they are aimed at a broad swath of the public but must inhabit a narrow price niche starting around $15,000. They have tight, solid bodies, but they can be noisy. With their standard four-cylinder engines they come close to being underpowered.
For any of these cars, consider a bigger, optional engine. Quieter, peppier V6's are available on the Contour (about $1,200) and Malibu (a bargain at $395), at little cost in fuel economy. A Breeze buyer should definitely spend an extra $450 for a 2.4-liter four cylinder; the standard 2-liter (the Neon's smallest engine) is inadequate for this car. The similar Dodge Stratus can be ordered with a 2.5-liter V6.
For this comparison I drove basic four-cylinder models with popular equipment: automatic transmissions and power windows, locks and mirrors. Air-conditioning is optional on the Contour but standard on the Breeze and Malibu, which also throws in anti-lock brakes.
With competition fierce in this segment, any buyer should be able to deal. (Current rebates include $1,000 on the Breeze and $500 on the Contour.) And there are plenty of other worthy competitors, from the smaller Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla to the Nissan Altima, which is being redesigned for 1998, and the Mazda 626. Still, the Big Three are getting ever better at making high-value sedans, as these three cars demonstrate:
 
A Rock-Solid Plymouth
The Plymouth Breeze feels relatively big and decidedly American, the opposite of the smaller, European-feeling Contour. Owners of traditional full-size cars will be most at home in the Plymouth's spacious cabin.
The Breeze is a plainer version of the Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Cirrus, and, like them, it is a triumph of cab-forward design. With the wheels moved out toward the corners, the cabin offers impressive room for five adults, though rear headroom is just adequate, and the trunk is spacious.
And the Breeze looks nice, with clean, modern lines and jazzy graphics. Inside, there are few frills, but nothing feels cheap: The controls are where you want them; the console has a storage bin under a comfortable armrest, along with coin slots and cup holders; the cloth upholstery seems durable. (Think "Days Inn love seat"; the Malibu fabric is more "Motel 6 bedspread.")
The body feels as solid as Plymouth Rock. Still, vibration and harshness from the
drivetrain, coupled with a lack of insulation, make the cabin a loud place indeed. Road noise rumbles up and the engine roars when the transmission kicks down, which is often. Wind hissing at the side windows adds to the cacophony. Expansion strips in elevated pavement boom through.
The 2-liter engine can handle the air-conditioner, or it can move the Breeze briskly onto an expressway, but it struggles at both tasks at once. The car lacks torque at moderate speeds. The steering is somewhat numb, but the Breeze handles well in town and is a pleasant highway cruiser -- if you can stand the noise.
The Plymouth would benefit from other refinements. The headlamps cast a short, splotchy beam. An oval defroster panel struggles to cover the huge windshield, and on one wintry day the side windows never cleared. The side mirrors affixed to twin stalks do not flex, putting them in grave danger in cramped Manhattan garages.
The Breeze's brilliant concept is undermined by weak execution, with a drivetrain that doesn't measure up to the overall design and details that need more attention. As a result, the Plymouth comes up short against its better-balanced rivals.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Less than you may have bargained for.
 
A Chevy Without Apologies
For those who've so disdained G.M.'s small cars that they've stood at the car-rental counter pleading for something -- anything -- else, the Malibu's arrival is as welcome as springtime. Look beyond the bland styling, the unsupportive seats and a few tacky trim pieces and you'll find a practical car that works surprisingly well.
The 2.4-liter engine was the peppiest four-cylinder in this group, moving the car smartly from a stop and merging it neatly into traffic, and the four-speed automatic was the smoothest transmission. The engine is noisy, however, whining on acceleration.
Though it didn't track as true as the Breeze at 70 miles an hour, and it doesn't command winding roads like the Contour, the Malibu handled well. There was not a trace of "wheel hop" on rough pavement, and the Chevy inspired confidence on a twisting, rain-slick mountain road. Though not a car you would want to push hard, the Malibu remained unflappable when driven as fast as its buyers are likely to go.
Inside, a lot of thought went into the controls, which are well placed and operate smoothly. The ignition switch and trunk-release buttons are handy on the dash. The optional AM/FM/cassette stereo was the best in this group, both for its rich sound and for its excellent knobs and buttons. Ditto for the softly lit window, lock and mirror controls, perfectly situated at a slight angle on the driver's door.
A tachometer is standard, in contrast to the Contour, but sunny days produced glare on the instruments. There are useful storage spaces and a comfortable center armrest. The air vents include almost-face-high outlets on the windshield pillars.
Alas, this Cinderella has warts. The slippery steering wheel looks and feels cheap; the front seats are almost flat, with little side support. The back of the bottom cushion was thin and uncomfortable.
A strip of faux granite across the dashboard looked like Formica I rejected for my kitchen. Nearly everything that slides out or opens up was wobbly: A left-side cup holder is handy, but feels as cheap as a snap-together Batman toy. And like every other Malibu I've sat in, the center armrest in the test car jiggled like Jell-O at the touch.
There is room up front for almost anyone, and the back seat rivals the Breeze's, though it, too, is short on headroom. But the base model has no grab handles and the upholstery was thin; the rear armrest felt like a slab of foam wrapped in a sheet. The pop-out clothes hooks had a plastic-toy feel.
While the Malibu is devoid of personality, it is the most balanced, workmanlike car in this group. Its lack of panache puts me off -- G.M. marketers seem to think their target customers don't care about style -- and I can't imagine a Malibu in my own garage. But given its many features and low price, it may be the best deal for the budget-minded.
 
INSIDE TRACK: More than meets the eye.
 
The Taming of the Ford
The smallest car in this group, the Ford Contour, is the most agile. While the Breeze is an Interstate cruiser and the Malibu is a suburban runabout, the Contour is in its element in the city. With its compact dimensions and German manners, the Contour darts through traffic and brakes decisively.
Since it arrived as a '95 model, the Contour has been one of my favorite American sedans. One of the most engaging cars I drove last year was a bare-bones '96 with a stick shift, a $16,000 economy sedan posing as a low-budget BMW. Among the few things I'd have changed on that car was the stereo, with its infuriating rows of identical buttons (15 to 20, depending on the sound system). Adjusting the volume was distracting; setting a station could be hazardous.
Well, Ford has given the Contour and its fraternal twin, the Mercury Mystique, a makeover for 1998 -- they're on sale now -- and the old radio is still there, clunky as ever. What has changed are characteristics I'd have left alone: the suspension is softer, making the handling less crisp; the once-precise, on-center steering feels as if it has been injected with Novocaine; the driver's seat has a fold-down armrest, but it is too high even for a tall driver.
Ford still offers two excellent engines, the 2-liter Zetec four-cylinder, which now has variable cam timing for better economy and lower emissions, and a 2.5-liter Duratec V6. Either is happiest with the five-speed manual, which has a new cable shifter. The test car's Zetec-automatic combination had trouble handling the steep mountain road to my weekend house, a good test of a car's pulling ability. The Breeze also struggled, but the Malibu skittered up like a goat.
Since Ford now offers the high-performance Contour SVT for enthusiasts, it seems to have made run-of-the-mill Contours more mainstream, answering complaints of onetime Tempo owners who found the ride too harsh and the handling too direct. Indeed, the ride is smoother, though relatively new pavement on the Palisades Parkway made the car rock curiously from side to side.
The Ford leaned on turns and drifted in straight-ahead driving, requiring constant attention in moderate winds. The steering is heavy, and it conveyed less road feel than I'd like. The car bounced unpleasantly over bumps on the Tappan Zee Bridge.
After reviewing my notes on the '96 ("a hoot to drive, tracks straight, good on-center feel") I wondered if something about the '98 test car, like misinflated tires, was the culprit. A spin in a '98 Mystique indicated otherwise. That V6 model did handle better with its bigger 15-inch wheels, but its steering also felt numb and needed correcting.
Not that the '98 Contour is bad -- it's just not as sharp as before. Of this group, its body is the most rigid, its seats are the best, its rakish dash is the sportiest (though there is no tachometer on cheaper models). I still like the Contour, especially with a stick shift, but I liked the old one better.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A good car better left alone.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1015 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Sector Fund Quandary: Right Place, Wrong Time

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
JUST take note of what's hot and what's not -- that is the simple precept behind the trading of specialized stock funds.
Technology may be the market darling for a while, but then financial or health care or some other group of stocks grabs the lead. Surely, catching one of these waves early on will pay off. Or so people often think in their eagerness to graduate from the buy-and-hold school of investing, tried and true though it may be. 
 But so-called sector investing is not quite so simple in real life, as some who practice this type of trading have shown recently. Even though the stock market has been increasingly volatile this year -- smacking of opportunity for quick-draw McGraws -- the sector timers have failed to keep up with the broad market averages.
Select Timing Service, which advises subscribers when to buy and sell Fidelity Investments' sector funds through its Web site and E-mail, is doing poorly in this boom year for domestic stocks. Select Timing (reachable at www.dollarlink.com) eked out a 4.3 percent gain for the year, through June 10, compared with a 16.8 percent rise for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Factoring in transaction costs and sales charges would further reduce the service's return.
A rival portfolio recommended by All Star Funds Newsletter of Austin, Tex., was down 1.5 percent through June 6. Because Fidelity is the dominant company in sector funds, All Star also chooses among its funds.
Though both fund pickers assert that they have far better long-term records, their recent shortcomings expose the difficulty of jumping in and out of the right sectors at the right time in today's stock market.
"Markets are becoming more efficient," said Jack Bowers, who recommends sector shifts in Fidelity Monitor, a newsletter published in Rocklin, Calif. "Whereas in the past you could ride these momentum systems for a good four or five weeks, now it all happens in four or five days. This may ultimately become as difficult as doing market timing, and we all know how difficult that has become."
On the surface, sector rotation is an attempt to raise profits by anticipating changes in the business cycle, perhaps investing in auto stocks during a recession, when sales are weak, and selling them at their peak. Carried to its extreme, sector investing can mean trading not over the course of years or months, but of weeks or days or even hours.
NO matter the time period, sector trading is a cousin of market timing, which is the effort to anticipate big market moves by being heavily invested during market rallies and absent during routs.
Timing has been a largely futile exercise since the great bull market began in 1982. "Any strategy that called for anything other than being fully invested hasn't looked good," said Robert Markman, who operates a group of funds under his name from Minneapolis.
Sector rotation has scarcely done better of late. On their best day, proponents of the approach face practical problems:
* Funds that specialize in specific industries and stock sectors are relatively few in number. Fidelity has the broadest array of offerings, at 36, but even many of those are clustered in one sector, technology.
* Transaction costs can be high. For most people, Fidelity imposes a sales charge of 3 percent on its Select, or sector, funds, and a redemption fee of 0.75 percent of assets for shares held less than 30 days. A transaction fee of $7.50 also applies to exchanges or sales of these funds.
* Frequent trading leads to additional costs, like taxes on short-term capital gains. "It's not a tax-efficient strategy," said Ronald E. Rowland, editor of All Star Funds. "It's better for a tax-deferred account," like a retirement fund.
To avoid redemption fees, most sector timers use systems built around holding their fund shares at least 30 days. That restriction may be part of their problem, if Mr. Bowers is right about the shorter and shorter nature of stock cycles.
The ultimate problem, though, is not choosing sectors wisely. Stan Lekach, a mathematician with a statistical approach to investing who makes the choices at Select Timing in San Francisco, said his poor showing this year could be attributed entirely to one false move.
His methodology, based on spotting sudden upward moves in a sector's share prices, led him to recommend Fidelity Select Medical Delivery Fund in March, just before a spate of negative publicity depressed the price of Columbia/HCA Healthcare, one of the fund's biggest positions. "That fund dropped about 10 percent in two weeks," said Mr. Lekach, owner of Dollarlink Software, parent of the timing service. As a money manager, Mr. Lekach handles a scant $3 million in private accounts.
Furthermore, opportunities to exploit shifts in the relative fortunes of industrial sectors are shrinking. For one thing, swings in the business cycle have become progressively less extreme since the Depression, behaving like a pendulum winding down.
THE tendency toward short spurts of volatility has led Mr. Bowers to stop picking sectors based on their momentum. Instead of looking at what is moving up, he finds sectors with relatively low valuations. To do that, he compares an industry group's price-to-book ratio with its historical average. His model portfolio, which invests in multiple sectors at once, recently dropped the Fidelity Chemicals, Defense and Aerospace and Industrial Equipment funds, and added the Insurance, Health Care and Transportation funds.
This value approach, which has paid off in the overall stock market in recent days, has left Mr. Bowers in better stead than many sector rotators. His Fidelity Select portfolio had gained 10.8 percent as of June 10, lagging behind the S.& P. 500 by six percentage points.
But for the little guy, at least, buy and hold remains the investment strategy to beat.
"Unsophisticated investors are not going to be extremely successful doing sector rotation," said Charles Carlson, commentary editor of Dow Theory Forecasts, a newsletter in Hammond, Ind. "It's hard to be a trader."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Lots of Moves, Little Gains"

Even excluding transaction costs and sales charges on such transactions, investors would have done better to buy and hold a broad basket of stocks. HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
In These Ratings, Paradise Is in the Eye of the Beholder

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
THE July issues of Worth and Money magazines offer strikingly different snapshots of the "best" places to live in America. But some second and third thoughts may be in order before you start packing.
Worth's rating is focused on money, dependent solely on median home prices -- with the assumption that whatever else makes the living good will follow in the wake of wealth. Money's rankings are based on statistics and survey results in nine categories: the economy, health care, crime, affordable housing, education, weather, transportation, leisure activities and the arts. The results are sometimes quirky. 
 John Koten, Worth's editor, defended his magazine's second annual survey, "The Richest Towns," against reader criticism last year that such an article didn't belong in an investing magazine.
"Where to reside is one of the most important financial decisions anyone can make," Mr. Koten writes. "That means the towns we include are those that the market has, for one reason or another, deemed among the most desirable. They're valuable places to live because they provide connections to society's movers and shakers; because they're (usually) near places where fortunes are being made, and because they offer privacy, prestige and comfort. These are all things that help successful people become even more successful -- certainly one definition of a worthy investment."
Worth says the richest town is Matinecock, population 880, on the North Shore of Long Island. The town's median home price is $1.5 million and there are seven local country clubs. But don't rush to call your real estate agent; Worth says homes there rarely come on the market.
The others in the top 10, along with median home prices, are: Aspen, Colo., $1.4 million; Rolling Hills, Calif., $1.1 million; Centre Island, N..Y., $999,000; Snowmass Village, Colo., $975,000; Rancho Sante Fe, Calif., $970,000; Atherton, Calif., $967,500; Hillsborough, Calif., $931,500; Jupiter Island, Fla., $922,500, and Kapalua, on Maui in Hawaii, $900,000. These are all small places, ranging from a population of 12,300 in Rancho Santa Fe (yes, the site of the Heaven's Gate suicides) to 408 in Kapalua.
The list includes 238 towns -- wealthy areas of larger cities are not counted -- and the cutoff point for home value is $300,000.
Unlike the 1996 ratings, this year's do not take household income into account. States with the most rich towns are California, 78; New York, 55, and New Jersey, 24. Most of the high-priced real estate can be found near San Francisco (Silicon Valley money), Los Angeles (Hollywood megabucks) and New York (Wall Street wealth).
The whole exercise is a paean to money. The writer, Jane Berentson, senior editor of Worth, waxes enthusiastically that Aspen's home values get "a boost from wealthy celebrities, people like former Playboy cover girl Barbi Benton and her husband, George 'Mobile-Home King' Gradow."
Money magazine takes a broader, more statistical approach in "The Best Places to Live Today," by Carla Fried with Jeanhee Kim and Amanda Walmac. It ranks 300 towns, cities and areas, big and small.
The winner is Nashua, N.H., where a four-bedroom house costs $125,000 (and the property tax is $3,700), the unemployment rate is 2.3 percent and there is no sales tax or state and local income tax. The rest of the top 10, in order, are: Rochester, Minn.; Monmouth and Ocean Counties, N.J.; Punta Gorda, Fla.; Portsmouth, N.H.; Manchester, N.H.; Madison, Wis.; San Jose, Calif.; Jacksonville, Fla., and Fort Walton Beach, Fla.
Dead last on the list is Davenport, Iowa, and Money all but apologizes for it. "Residents feel their place is a pretty darn fine spot to live," the article says. But despite 42 miles of picturesque bike trails, six museums and three riverboat gambling casinos, the city still comes up short. The region's overall violent crime rate, an important factor in Money's poll of readers, is 27 percent higher than the national average. And it's a three-hour trek to Chicago for top restaurants and major league sports.
BUSY BANDWAGON The crowded field of personal-finance magazines is beginning to breed look-alikes -- at least on their covers. Forbes and Fortune, which have long had sections dealing with personal finance, appear to have joined the fray.
Forbes's June 16 issue, containing an annual investment guide, has a cover article on second careers as the key to successful retirement. The cover could have been designed by Money; the photograph shows an aerobics instructor going through her paces. No cigar-chomping cable-TV mogul here.
Fortune's June 23 cover has a teaser headline --"Nine Stocks to Bank On" -- that reads like it came from Smart Money's playbook. Even the venerable Economist, on its May 31-June 6 cover, features a cartoonlike drawing of a tax collector chasing a man with a cellular phone around a spinning globe. It illustrates an article titled"The Disappearing Taxpayer," about the difficulty of assessing and collecting taxes in a global, high-technology economy.
LISTEN UP, FED David Hackett Fischer, a professor of history at Brandeis University, argues in the July-August issue of Bloomberg Personal that the Federal Reserve is obsessed with inflation fears and runs the risk of prompting a world depression.
CREDIT WHERE DUE Kiplinger's and Money see bright spots for women in terms of credit and pensions. Kiplinger's notes that for the first time men and women who are business owners have about the same access to business capital, according to the Census Bureau and the National Foundation for Women Business Owners. Money says women could get bigger pensions under proposals in Congress, including one that would expand the so-called homemaker individual retirement account.
 
ON THE WEB Money's World Wide Web site (www.money.com) offers links to what it considers top Internet spots for information on stocks, mutual funds, financial calculators and the like. Smart Money, in its June Issue, had a cover on its 10 favorite Web sites, but they are not linked to a central site like Money's. Money articles and advice are also available on line through Compuserve.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A Threat to a Tax Break For College Employees

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
NEXT year, Christopher Anderson will be a senior at Ohio Wesleyan University, with a triple major in music, philosophy and 20th-century studies. With a grade-point average of nearly 3.8, he aspires to join the Phi Beta Kappa honor society.
Yet if it were not for a tax break that allows colleges and universities to give employees tax-free tuition assistance, he might not be able to afford Ohio Wesleyan at all. And that tax provision is now under attack in Washington. 
 Mr. Anderson's mother, Pamela B. Anderson, a purchasing assistant at the school, said: "Like a lot of people out there, my husband and I earn too much to get financial assistance, not enough to pay for tuition. Without the tuition assistance, my kids might have gone to college somewhere, but not here."
The tax break that lets Mr. Anderson attend Ohio Wesleyan, and will allow his sister, Kylie, to attend next year, is called the qualified tuition reduction exclusion. It allows college employees to escape taxes on the value of the tuition the college gives them. The tuition breaks can be granted either at the employee's home college, at another in the same conference, at a school with a reciprocal agreement, or -- in some instances -- in the form of a grant that can be used at any accredited institution.
But a bill that has cleared the House Ways and Means Committee would tax the value of the tuition as income.
The change was included in Republican tax proposals issued last Monday by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the committee chairman. A revenue-raising part of the Archer plan would require employees of colleges and universities to pay taxes on the value of tuition breaks received by their children.
Those who would eliminate the tax break say the issue is one of fairness. "Tuition costs are rising like crazy, and who sets the tuition price? People who work at universities," said Kenneth J. Kies, chief of staff at the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. "And who are the only people who don't pay tuition? People who work at universities. The object here is to get comprehensive rules that put everyone on an even playing field."
Opponents of the tax break say it benefits college administrators who earn hundreds of thousands of dollars a year -- and who could easily afford their children's education without such help.
While the tuition break is used by administrators, it is also used by employees whose salaries are less -- and who sometimes get a break that is a percentage of the tuition bill, not the total amount.
For the Anderson family, which will have two children receiving a total of $50,640 in tuition benefits and free room and board next year, the additional taxes would total $14,000 a year.
"Here at Ohio Wesleyan, we have 412 full-time employees, and 59 take remission tuition," said Thomas B. Courtice, president of the school. Of the 59 recipients, 32 are professors or administrators and 27 are hourly employees like clerical workers, groundskeepers and maintenance staff.
Matthew W. Hamill, a lobbyist for the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, said, "That percent is about what you would find across the country." Mr. Hamill's organization represents 900 private universities.
The universities say a loss of the tax break would make it harder to recruit top teaching talent and to finance graduate students who work as teaching assistants.
"These are students who make salaries of $10,000," said Ruth Flower, director of government relations for the American Association of University Professors, "and if they go to a school where the tuition is $30,000, they may have to pay $6,000 tax on that. All they would have left of their cash income is $4,000."
According to a 1996 study by the College and University Personnel Association, about 85 percent of the schools surveyed offered tuition assistance to all employee groups.
"Losing tuition remission will upset the whole economy of the university," Ms. Flower said.

HEADLINE: AT THE GATE;
A Stylish REIT Offering Could Stand a Little Trim

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
MORTIMER B. ZUCKERMAN is a well-connected publisher and tabloid columnist, but his biggest business is a real estate company many analysts regard as the Tiffany of its field. When he takes the enterprise public this week, however, some investors may be reluctant to pay the premium price he will ask.
It's not that the deal is insignificant -- far from it. Mr. Zuckerman and his partner, Edward H. Linde, plan to raise $785 million by selling 31.4 million shares of the company, Boston Properties, at an expected price of $24 to $26 a share. That makes this offering, 62.7 percent of the enterprise, the biggest ever for a real estate investment trust that is focused on commercial properties. 
 And the company, founded in 1970, has a sterling roster of properties scattered across the Northeast. It owns 63 office buildings, including the 24-acre Cambridge Center complex in Massachusetts and the International Trade Commission Building in Washington, as well as nine industrial properties, two Marriott hotels and a parking garage. And its three major markets -- Boston, New York and Washington -- are thriving. Rents are rising in all of them, especially in Boston, where they have jumped more than 9 percent since 1995. Moreover, given the high cost of development in those cities, rents are unlikely to be driven down by a flood of new office space.
Even critics of the offering say Mr. Linde and Mr. Zuckerman, who owns The Daily News in New York, U.S. News and World Report and The Atlantic Monthly, are one of the best development teams in the country. Boston Properties weathered a harsh real estate recession in the early 1990's, and the company says its average annual return has been about 14.2 percent the last five years. And, in a feature that makes REIT's a favorite of defensive investors, Boston Properties will carry a dividend that is high relative to most non-REIT stocks: $1.62 a share, or 6.5 percent of the $25 share price.
Nevertheless, some aspects of the offering, which is primarily underwritten by Merrill Lynch and Goldman, Sachs, may give investors pause. Although virtually all the proceeds would be used to reduce the debt on 14 buildings, Boston Properties would still carry big debts compared with similar REIT's.
Its preferred measure of indebtedness, the ratio of debt to market capitalization, gives it a score of 37.6 percent after the offering. But the average for office REIT's is 24 percent, making Boston Properties' ratio 57 percent higher than its peers'.
Such debt can hamper growth. "The deal is being priced at a premium because it's Mort Zuckerman," said Ryan Jacob, director of research for IPO Value Monitor. "But we felt that it's going to be difficult for Boston Properties to continue to develop and acquire properties with the constraints of a highly leveraged balance sheet."
Moreover, as office REIT's compete with hedge funds and investment banks for real estate in a resurgent market, prices for office buildings have shot up. Since last August, the average price for a square foot of office space in the Northeast has risen 21.5 percent, to more than $103, according to the Property Information Exchange, a real estate research service. Such a jump can greatly narrow the trusts' profit margins.
"We're at a point in the real estate cycle where returns on acquisitions are not as high as they were a year ago," said Samuel A. Lieber, manager of the Evergreen equity funds in Purchase, N.Y., which has $320 million invested in real estate stocks. "That's one reason office REIT's are not flying as high as they were a year ago."
Indeed, after achieving total returns of 49.8 percent in 1996, office REIT's have returned negative 3.3 percent so far in 1997.
For a leveraged company like Boston Properties, rising prices can make it hard to compete; growth means borrowing money, and debt levels are one factor that lenders look at hard. The company's fans suggest that its debt load is more than offset by blue-chip tenants at buildings like 599 Lexington Avenue, a million-square-foot tower at 53d Street in Manhattan. But as much as 14 percent of the company's space is leased to the General Services Administration, which, like most Government tenants, tends to trade its creditworthiness for lower rents.
True, like most REIT's, the company expects to grow through acquisition, mostly stock swaps with old-line real estate moguls who might appreciate the trusts' tax-deferred status. (The trusts do not pay income taxes as long as they distribute 95 percent of income to shareholders.) But Mr. Zuckerman would need to make $500 million to $800 million in office deals annually to generate significant growth for a company as big as Boston Properties, some analysts say.
And the industry is becoming crowded. Since 1994, the number of office REIT's has grown from 1 to 15, with more on the way.
For example, Sam Zell, the Chicago investor, plans an offering for Equity Office Properties in July. It is for just $345 million, but the underlying company is the nation's largest, most diversified office REIT, with an estimated value of more than $3 billion and 90 office buildings comprising 32.2 million square feet spread over 47 markets.
By contrast, Boston Properties has 75 properties worth an estimated $2 billion and containing 11 million square feet.
"There are a lot of high-quality office companies out there," said Joe Harvey, senior vice president of Cohen & Steers Capital Management, which manages $4.7 billion in publicly traded real estate securities. "So there are a lot of choices."
So some investors may wonder if Mr. Zuckerman has been somewhat aggressive in pricing his shares. With REIT's, price levels are measured using funds from operations -- the industry's rough equivalent of net income. On average, the shares of office REIT's trade at about 11.8 times their estimated 1997 funds from operations, per share. But Boston Properties shares would sell at about 12.2 times, a modest premium.
Some people who otherwise like Boston Properties balk at this price. "It's a great company with excellent properties," said Mr. Lieber. "What more could you want?"
His answer to this rhetorical question: "A fair price. I think there's positive growth in this portfolio, but it's not dramatic. The way we look at it, there has to be a haircut on the price to guarantee that it'll be a strong performer in the aftermarket."
Of course, a price trim would dilute the value of the shares earmarked for Mr. Zuckerman and Mr. Linde. But since their holdings would be worth about $440 million at the $25 price, maybe there's room to cut.
