HEADLINE: Vallone Seeks Sanctions on Nations Persecuting Christians

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
In an effort that has alarmed many New York City business leaders, the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, has introduced a measure that would bar the city from doing business with companies that operate in 15 countries that he says routinely persecute Christians, including China, Egypt, Indonesia and Saudi Arabia.
The measure, introduced last month, also calls for the city to withdraw deposits and investments from banks that do business with those countries. If passed, the bill would make more than one-third of the world's business population off-limits to the city, which has the fourth-largest governmental budget in the country. Only the Federal Government, California and New York State have larger budgets. 
 Business leaders have begun a campaign to fight the bill, saying the city's economy could be devastated if businesses were forced to choose between their global markets and their New York City contracts.
But to Mr. Vallone, the most urgent concerns are moral, not financial. He said that the 15 countries named in his bill frequently imprison, torture, enslave or kill Christians for practicing their faith, and that the city should use its economic might to stop the persecution.
With the backing of the influential Mr. Vallone, the bill is likely to make its way onto Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's desk. Aides to the Mayor said he generally supported the bill's intentions but would not commit to details until after hearings had been held and he could determine the full scope of the problem and the impact on businesses.
Mr. Vallone, a Roman Catholic who keeps plaques engraved with Bible quotations on his desk, is keeping step with a national movement to draw attention to the persecution of Christians in Communist and some Muslim nations. His bill is actually stronger than a measure introduced last month in Congress, which calls for narrow Federal sanctions against offending countries.
New York officials have long sought to curry favor with the city's immigrant population by issuing resolutions condemning renegade governments. And the city has occasionally put economic weight behind its principles. The city's municipal pension fund is among the investors that subscribe to the MacBride Principles, antidiscrimination guidelines for companies that do business in Northern Ireland. And in the 1980's, the City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, worked to have city pension funds divest themselves of investments in companies doing business in South Africa.
Now, with measures like the Vallone bill and a similar bill enacted last month against the military regime in Myanmar, the City Council is again trying to use economic muscle to promote human rights.
If approved, the bill would effectively ban the city from working with business powerhouses like Time Warner, Pepsico, General Motors, Mobil and Chase Manhattan, business leaders and city officials said. It would also prohibit the city from working with some of world's largest design and engineering companies, like Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and Skanska, a worldwide construction company based in Stockholm with offices in New York, officials from the industry said.
"No business in New York City would go unaffected if this bill is passed," said Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, who said he planned to meet with city leaders to lobby against it.
"Once again," Mr. Kiley said, "businesses are being singled out as the bad guy. If they can't get at the offending country at the City Council base, they're taking it out on companies. This is a kind of old and not very desirable tradition of isolationism and know-nothingism cloaked in morality."
But New York City is not alone in its efforts. Last month, New York joined 18 other cities and states in passing legislation to restrict their governments from doing business with banks and other companies in Myanmar because of abuses by its military Government.
When Mayor Giuliani signed the bill several weeks ago, he pointed out that the city has tremendous economic power to pressure oppressive foreign regimes to change. He said that as soon as the city saw changes in Myanmar, the city's relationship with companies that do business there would resume.
But business leaders say they are being wrongly singled out, saying companies have indicated that they would rather give up city contracts to stay competitive worldwide.
Richard T. Anderson, president of the New York Building Congress, which represents 300 members in the design, construction and real estate industry, said that in his industry alone more than $2 billion in annual export business would be compromised by the Myanmar bill. "The city's building industry certainly is not in favor of the actions of some foreign governments, nor do we support corrupt or ruthless governments," Mr. Anderson said. "But local legislation in the city of New York is not the answer."
Besides China, Egypt, Indonesia and Saudi Arabia, the bill singles out Cuba, Iran, Iraq, Laos, Pakistan, Morocco, Nigeria, North Korea, the Sudan, Turkey and Vietnam. Under the law, city purchasers would be banned from buying cars, computers or petroleum from multinational corporations active in the countries.
City Councilman Thomas K. Duane, a Democrat of Manhattan, praised Mr. Vallone's efforts, calling it a moral issue for the city.
"Just like in South Africa and in Northern Ireland, New York City can stand as a leader in the battle for human rights around the world," Mr. Duane said.
Representatives of countries listed in the Vallone bill have been scrambling to deny that their Governments persecute Christians.
"We have many foreign workers in the Kingdom and they are treated as guests," Jamal I. Nasef, director of information at the Royal Embassy of Saudi Arabia in Washington, said recently in a written statement, "and every consideration is given for their needs, as long as they abide by the Sharia Law," a legal system based on the Koran.
Dan O'Flaherty, vice president of the National Trade Council in Washington, which represents more than 600 businesses, said that if the proliferation of local sanctions persisted, companies would consider banding together to file a lawsuit to determine whether the laws were legal.
"The Constitution reserved foreign policy decisions to the President and the executive branch," he said. "The argument would be that our relationships with all of these countries is a Presidential prerogative, not that of municipalities."
But Mr. Vallone has a clear vision of where the city stands with the Constitution. "To those who say, why are you meddling in foreign affairs, that's outrageous," he said. "No one can tell me or any other individual in this city how we can and should invest our money."

HEADLINE: Backtalk;
Another Act in the Baseball Follies

 BODY:
BOB COSTAS of NBC Sports lives in St. Louis and says he will be in attendance at today's Indians-Cardinals interleague game. Still, he has some misgivings about baseball's newest wrinkle and agreed to answer some questions about it. 

 Q. What are your thoughts on interleague play?
A.I favor the concept of interleague play but as part of a comprehensive plan that makes long-range sense, not this slapdash deal that baseball has thrown together with its usual lack of thought.
Q. What's wrong with the present plan?
A. First off, let's grant the obvious. These games do offer some novelty appeal, and some undeniably exciting and interesting matchups -- Mets versus Yanks, Orioles versus Braves, and so on. But over all, it's a hodgepodge. There are games played under two sets of rules, unequal numbers of home and road games for teams in the same division, different sets of opponents for teams competing for the same wild-card spot, a jagged travel schedule filled with two-game series created to accommodate the interleague schedule, a further diminishing of games played within your own division and a September schedule that includes interleague games at the expense of head-to-head divisional matchups.
This is part of a continuing disregard for the integrity of the pennant races, which the balanced schedule and wild cards have already made a mockery of. And even on its own terms, baseball can't get simple things right. If they are going to play these games right now, why use home-team rules? If the idea is to give fans a glimpse of the other league and its style of play, why not play interleague games without the designated hitter in Cleveland but with the d.h. in St. Louis?
Give fans a true look at the other league. This would be especially beneficial in National League parks, because without the d.h. rule some of the biggest American League stars -- players fans presumably want to see -- either won't play or must play out of position. A little thought could have led baseball to this conclusion, but a little thought seems to be too much to ask.
It reminds me of when baseball finally ended its bitter strike in the spring of 1995 and then announced a 144-game schedule, immediately transforming an already-damaged season into a historical anomaly. This in the sport most dependent upon records and history. How much thought and cooperation would it have taken to schedule 10 doubleheaders per team that season, label them two-for-the-price-of-one days as a "we're sorry" to the fans and thus create a 154-game season that would have had a quirky, throwback appeal?
Then, if Tony Gwynn had hit .400 that season, no problem -- it would have been in the same number of games as Ted Williams's .406 in 1941. And if Ken Griffey Jr. had hit 62 homers -- true, not the same schedule as Roger Maris's, but exactly the same as Babe Ruth's -- it would have been interesting and valid. Instead, baseball wound up with 144 games, which fit into no context at all.
Q. What, in your view, is the way to approach interleague play?
A. As part of a radical realignment. Thirty-two teams are inevitable, although it will further dilute play. Still, it's a workable number in terms of markets, divisions and scheduling. In fact, the owners should have held expansion back as a bargaining chip with the players, promising four new teams and 100 new jobs, but only in return for significant economic concessions and cooperation in other areas. But that's another story.
Anyway, they should go to 32 and pledge to hold it there for 20 years at a minimum. Some teams -- the Yankees, Mets, Red Sox, White Sox, Cubs, Cardinals and others -- should never lose their American League or National League identities, but the expansion teams and about a dozen existing teams can go anywhere that makes geographic and economic sense. A few teams that are truly not viable in their present locations should be allowed to move in the interest of long-term stability.
Once the 32 teams are in place, arrange them in four 8-team divisions (East and West in each league) as dictated by geography, history and potential rivalries. Agree on a unified set of rules regarding the d.h. and then play a schedule like this: 13 games against six of the seven teams in your division and 12 games against the seventh for a total of 90. Then add six games -- one series home and away each season -- against the eight teams in the other division of your league for a total of 48. And finally, to bring the grand total to 162, 24 interleague games played under a rotating, alternate-year format.
Under the rotation, teams would play three games against each of the eight teams in one division of the other league and then repeat the process against the other division the following year. For example, the Yankees would play four three-game series at home against National League West teams in a given year while visiting the other four teams in that division for three games apiece. The following season, they would play the National League East. And while the Yankees would play the Dodgers every other year, home-field rotation provides that each team visits the other's park once every four years.
This approach insures that every interleague series remains special, with the once-every-four-year visits by superstars truly anticipated. At the same time, the travel and scheduling makes sense, league and division identities still exist and it's fair, because all your division foes play the same schedule.
Obviously, we permit no wild cards, so you would have four true pennant races, with the winners advancing straight to the League Championship Series. Under this plan, you've modernized with major realignment and substantial interleague play, but you've preserved the concept of real pennant races, something that was once distinctive to baseball and should be restored.
Do I think this will happen? No chance. Baseball will go to 32 all right, but will break it up into eight 4-team divisions in which it will be impossible to play a meaningful division schedule and in which the significance, prestige and drama of winning will be virtually nonexistent. Then baseball will dismiss anyone who points out the absurdity of it all as a purist.
Q. You've been called a purist yourself.
A. This automatic labeling of people who have legitimate objections to the recent changes in baseball as purists or traditionalists is a mindless way to frame the issue. It is a caricature that keeps people from dealing with the substance of the argument, which is usually what people do when their own arguments are lacking in substance.
Now, is tradition more important in baseball than in any other team sport? Yes, and I think it's instructive that the only unqualified success in baseball in recent years is the movement to new/old parks like Camden Yards or Jacobs Field or the return to grass, and the feel of an earlier era, in St. Louis, which suggests that a significant part of the game's appeal is a connection to the past.
So, tradition should be respected, but that's not the same thing as being tradition-bound. My objection is not that baseball is changing. It should change, in some cases radically. My objection is that these new steps are so poorly thought out. Let's suppose there is a consensus that welfare reform or tax reform is needed. Does that mean there is no debate over the best way to go about it?
This is where baseball fails. The notion of change is fine, but that doesn't mean all changes are for the better or that simply labeling something progressive means that it has been well-conceived and executed. There are many intelligent and decent individuals in baseball, but collectively baseball's actions often reflect not insight but desperation, with little apparent belief in, or appreciation of, the uniqueness of its own game.
Accordingly, the silliest argument of all is the one that goes like this: "Baseball's in trouble. We've got to do something to revive it." Yes, baseball is in trouble, but not necessarily because it needed fundamental changes in its competitive structure. In 1993, just four years ago, with no interleague play, with four 7-team divisions and no wild cards, baseball broke all its attendance records (even discounting the expansion teams) and TV ratings were generally higher than they have been since.
Baseball is in trouble now mostly because of the sheer bungling of the owners and the shortsightedness and selfish agendas of the owners and players both. This finally caught up with them, and alienated millions of fans. Baseball is still paying for it.
Now we are supposed to accept unquestioningly the prescriptions for recovery offered by those who created the mess in the first place? This is like finding yourself in the emergency room, looking up, and discovering that the guy who poisoned you is now the attending physician. It's sort of funny, provided you don't care about the game.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL 3-12
 
European Currency Plan Approaches a Crisis Point
Plans for a single European currency have advanced further than most people thought possible, but now the euro is beginning to pull Europe apart. Rivalries and political realities are already causing a near meltdown, and bigger problems are looming. Within a month, the Germans may need to delay the euro, probably killing it, or to soften the strict standards that were supposed to provide confidence in the currency. 1
 
Pol Pot Reported in Flight
Cambodia's former dictator, responsible for more than a million deaths, was reported to be on the run in a remote jungle, pursued by guerrillas he once led. He took flight after ordering the killing of a top lieutenant. all part of an apparently fatal split of his movement, the Khmer Rouge. 1
 
Who Will Dance in Hong Kong?
With Hong Kong's return to China fast approaching, Asian and Western democracies are divided over how much to take part in the ceremony. American and British officials plan to attend the formal turnover, but to boycott the swearing-in of Hong Kong's new government. But Australia, Japan and others will show up. Reporter's Notebook. 6

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Clinton's Speech on Race in America

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, June 14

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the text of President Clinton's speech on race in America delivered today to graduates of the University of California, San Diego:
Today we celebrate your achievements at a truly golden moment for America. The cold war is over and freedom is now ascendant around the globe, with more than half of the people in this whole world living under governments of their choosing for the very first time. Our economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world. Our culture, our science, our technology promise unimagined advances and exciting new careers. Our social problems, from crime to poverty, are finally bending to our efforts. 
 Of course, there are still challenges for you out there. Beyond our borders, we must battle terrorism, organized crime and drug trafficking, the spread of weapons of mass destruction, the prospect of new diseases and environmental disaster. Here at home, we must ensure that every child has the chance you have had to develop your God-given capacities. We cannot wait for them to get in trouble to notice them.
We must continue to fight the scourge of gangs and crime and drugs. We must prepare for the retirement of the baby boom generation so that we can reduce that child poverty rate that Coleen talked about. We must harness the forces of science and technology for the public good, the entire American public.
But I believe the greatest challenge we face among all those that Coleen talked about is also our greatest opportunity. Of all the questions of discrimination and prejudice that still exist in our society, the most perplexing one is the oldest, and in some ways today the newest, the problem of race.
Can we fulfill the promise of America by embracing all our citizens of all races, not just at a university, where people have the benefit of enlightened teachers and the time to think and grow and get to know each other, but in the daily life of every American community? In short, can we become one America in the 21st century?
I know and I've said before that money cannot buy this goal. Power cannot compel it. Technology cannot create it. This is something that can come only from the human spirit, the spirit we saw when the choir of many races sang as a gospel choir. Today the state of Hawaii, which has a senator and a congresswoman present here, has no majority racial or ethnic group. It is a wonderful place of exuberance and friendship and patriotism.
Within the next three years here in California, no single race or ethnic group will make up a majority of the state's population. Already five of our largest school districts draw students from over 100 different racial and ethnic groups. At this campus, 12 Nobel Prize winners have taught or studied from nine different countries. A half-century from now, when your own grandchildren are in college, there will be no majority race in America.
Now, we know what we will look like. But what will we be like? Can we be one America, respecting, even celebrating our differences, but embracing even more what we have in common? Can we define what it means to be an American, not just in terms of the hyphens showing our ethnic origins, but in terms of our primary allegiance to the values America stands for and values we really live by?
Our hearts long to answer yes, but our history reminds us that it will be hard. The ideals that bind us together are as old as our nation, but so are the forces that pull us apart. Our founders sought to form a more perfect union. The humility and hope of that phrase is the story of America, and it is our mission today. . . .
Though minorities have more opportunities than ever today, we still see evidence of bigotry from the desecration of houses of worship, whether they be churches, synagogues or mosques, to demeaning talk in corporate suites. There is still much work to be done by you, members of the class of 1997.
But those who say we cannot transform the problem of prejudice into the promise of unity forget how far we have come, and I cannot believe they have ever seen a crowd like you. When I look at you, it is almost impossible for me even to remember my own life. I grew up in the high drama of the cold war in the patriotic South. Black and white southerners alike wore our nation's uniform in defense of freedom against communism, and they fought and died together from Korea to Vietnam. But back home, I went to segregated schools, swam in segregated public pools, sat in all-white sections at the movies, and traveled through small towns in my state that still marked restrooms and water fountains "White" and "Colored."
By the grace of God, I had a grandfather with just a grade-school education, but the heart of a true American, who taught me that it was wrong. And by the grace of God, there were brave African-Americans like Congressman John Lewis, who risked their lives time and time again to make it right. And there were white Americans like Congressman Bob Filner, a freedom rider on the bus with John Lewis, in the long, noble struggle for civil rights, who knew that it was a struggle to free white people, too. . . .
As you have shown us today, our diversity will enrich our lives in non-material ways, deepening our understanding of human nature and human differences, making our communities more exciting, more enjoyable, more meaningful.
That is why I have come here today, to ask the American people to join me in a great national effort to perfect the promise of America for this new time as we seek to build our more perfect union. . . .
Let me say that I know that for many white Americans, this conversation may seem to exclude them or threaten them. That must not be so. I believe white Americans have just as much to gain as anybody else from being a part of this endeavor, much to gain from an America where we finally take responsibility for all our children, so that they at last can be judged, as Martin Luther King hoped, not by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.
What is it that we must do? For four-and-a-half years now, I have worked to prepare America for the 21st century, with a strategy of opportunity for all, responsibility from all, and an American community of all our citizens. To succeed in each of these areas, we must deal with the realities and the perceptions affecting all racial groups in America.
First, we must continue to expand opportunity. Full participation in our strong and growing economy is the best antidote to envy, despair and racism. We must press forward to move millions more from poverty and welfare to work, to bring the spark of enterprise to inner cities, to redouble our efforts to reach those rural communities prosperity has passed by. And most important of all, we simply must give our young people the finest education in the world. . . .
In our efforts to extend economic and educational opportunity to all our citizens, we must consider the role of affirmative action. I know affirmative action has not been perfect in America. That's why, two years ago, we began an effort to fix the things that are wrong with it. But when used in the right way, it has worked. . . .
Over the coming year, I want to lead the American people in a great and unprecedented conversation about race. . . . What do I really hope we will achieve as a country? If we do nothing more than talk, it will be interesting, but it won't be enough. If we do nothing more than propose disconnected acts of policy, it will be helpful, but it won't be enough. . . .
We have torn down the barriers in our laws. Now we must break down the barriers in our lives, our minds and our hearts. More than 30 years ago, at the high tide of the civil rights movement, the Kerner Commission said we were becoming two Americas, one white, one black, separate and unequal. Today we face a different choice. Will we become not two, but many Americas, separate, unequal and isolated? Or will we draw strength from all our people and our ancient faith in equality and human dignity, to become the world's first truly multiracial democracy? That is the unfinished work of our times, to lift the burden of race and redeem the promise of America.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
No Realignment Proposal Can Satisfy the Wishes of Every Team

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Now isn't this another fine mess Major League Baseball has created.
The owners extract -- extort? -- $125 million from the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, who to everyone's knowledge will be located in the southeast corner of the United States, and tell them that when they begin play next year, geography will be turned on its head and they will play in a division that stretches to the northwest corner of the United States. 
 The owners take another $125 million from the Arizona Diamondbacks and, after a couple of years of effectively clever lobbying by their managing partner, tell them they can take their balls and bats and play in the National League, only now they want to say "never mind" and bounce them to the American League.
Both of these fledgling franchises have grounds for bitter complaint, the Diamondbacks if they are forced to play in the American League, the Devil Rays if they are forced to play in the A.L. West. But unless someone concocts a plan currently beyond the owners' imagination, one of these teams will begin life in the big leagues in a foul mood. Plans in debate would solve the Devil Rays' problem only if they create one for the Diamondbacks.
While these neophytes anxiously await their fate, there is an older franchise that really has become the forgotten child of Major League Baseball. No matter which way they turn, the Texas Rangers get the economic knife where it hurts.
The Rangers, with an address in the central time zone, play in a division with three teams whose clocks read Pacific time. Not only do the Rangers have to beam many of their games back home at hours that are late even for Texans, but they also can't play the team they want to play more than any other. While every other pair of geographical rivals play this season in the first interleague games in baseball history, the Rangers don't play the Houston Astros because they are out of alignment as far as the divisions go. The Rangers are in the A.L. West, the Astros in the N.L. Central and never their schedules shall meet.
"We made a giant mistake in baseball many years ago when we didn't put the two Texas teams together," said Tom Schieffer, the Rangers' president, who was not in baseball many years ago. "I would like to resolve it by both of us being in the same division. If we did that, we'd have a natural rivalry and that would be an advantage. It's a little hard to see how that's going to come about, but that's what I would hope."
Not everyone agrees that teams in geographical proximity should play in the same league. "Vince Namoli violently disagrees," Schieffer said, referring to the Devil Rays' managing partner, who wants his team to be the only A.L. team in the Southeast rather than create an N.L. Southeast rivalry. "But I think they would be much better off playing the Marlins and with Atlanta just up the road. He doesn't see it that way and it's his franchise, but I think he would develop much better rivalries.
"Texas is no different. The people in Houston think they do things better than the people in Dallas-Fort Worth and vice versa. That's what a rivalry is. If you put us in a situation where our fans could get in their car and drive down to Houston or Houston fans could drive up here and we were in a hot pennant race, it would help the rivalry."
Under one of the realignment plans in debate, the Astros would replace Arizona in the N.L. West. The Astros aren't leaping at the chance, but one baseball official said they are not as adamantly opposed to that idea as they are to changing leagues.
"Everybody has their desires, what their first choice is," the executive said. "We wouldn't want to switch leagues, but if that was necessary to make things work out, we would consider doing that."
The Rangers, though, remain opposed to another plan under discussions -- an unbalanced schedule, in which a team would play more games against division rivals and fewer against other teams. "We have been the ones primarily in opposition to it in the A.L.," Schieffer said. "They made a commitment to us when we went into the West Division that we wouldn't play an unbalanced schedule, at least not until 2000."
Playing even more games on the road against the Western teams would only make the Rangers' radio and TV schedule less desirable. "We have to deal with that issue some way," Schieffer said. "Hopefully, we can reach an agreement that will benefit everybody. We certainly don't want to stand in the way of what's best for baseball. At the same time, we have to consider what's best for our fans."
That, Schieffer said, would be realignment based on a North-South split, grouping teams in the same time zones. "If you did that," he added, "you'd have more games in prime time, and I think that would be of benefit to everyone."
The realignment committee, facing a ticklish task, is supposed to submit a report to the owners by the end of the month. To satisfy the Rangers, Devil Rays, Diamondbacks and others (Kansas City wants to be in the same division as St. Louis), it will have to practice prestidigitation.
 
Pinch-Hitting Philosophy
 Matt Franco, Jerry Lynch said, is to be congratulated.
"Tell him if he has a bad week, I had weeks where I was 0 for 7," Lynch said. "But you can't let it get you. The next week you can be 3 for 4. You wonder if you'll ever come through in the clutch again, but it happens."
Franco is the Mets' super pinch-hitter. Since having the precise stretch that Lynch mentioned, 0 for 7, Franco has had 11 hits in his last 16 pinch-hitting appearances, including 5 in his last 5. His pinch-hitting average is a dazzling .478.
Lynch knows about these things because in his day, a 13-year career with Pittsburgh and Cincinnati from 1954-66, he was a super pinch-hitter. He holds the National League record with 18 career pinch-hit home runs and is tied for the major league record with 25 runs batted in for one season.
"I had no choice," he said, explaining his career as a pinch-hitter. "I hurt my arm in 1956 with the Pirates and was on the disabled list most of the season. I went to Cincinnati in 1957 and Birdie Tebbetts said you have just become a professional pinch-hitter. With a wife and four kids to feed, I had no choice. You had to do anything if you wanted to stay in the big leagues."
Lynch, who lives in Georgia and watches the Braves on television, said a good pinch-hitter can be just as important as a relief pitcher. But he said he would draw the line at designated hitting.
"I'd hate that," he said. "Pop up, go sit on the bench, pop up again. Make four mistakes in a day. That would be awful. You can't get yourself primed up four times in a game. When you pinch-hit, the game is on the line."
 
Bonds Puts Team Before Self
 Barry Bonds is fully prepared to sacrifice himself for the good of the team. Given his way of thinking, he has already done a terrific job. The San Francisco Giants have been in first place since May 11, and before that they were either in first or no more than two games from first. Yet Bonds has struggled at bat, entering last night's game with a .261 average and 12 home runs.
"I'm not really concerned," Bonds said. "I've done well throughout my career and always come up short. I've put up big numbers and been in last place. If this is what it takes to win, I'm all for it."
No one really expected the Giants to be serious contenders, let alone be in first, especially after they traded Matt Williams last winter.
"Sure, I'd love to have Matt Williams," Bonds said. "Anybody who wouldn't might as well kill yourself. But you have to play with the parts given you. If you allow that to dictate your season, then you might as well turn in your uniform and not play."
The questions Bonds hears about the Giants' unexpected success -- not unexpected to him, he said -- do not bother him.
"I think you get more questions when you have a great team and you're not winning than when you have a team that isn't expected to win," he said. "We had a lot of unanswered questions when we had all of us and we were in last place."
 
Ryan Mulls a Run for Office
 Nolan Ryan retired four years ago but only from baseball. Ryan, who pitched 324 victories, including 7 no-hitters, and struck out 5,714 in 5,387 innings in his 26-year career, is busier than he was in his playing days. When he played, he worked every fourth or fifth day. Now he is involved with commercial endorsements, a bank, a cattle operation, the Rangers and the Texas parks and wildlife commission. Gov. George W. Bush appointed him to the commission. Ryan's next step in Texas politics may take him higher in state government.
"A lot of people are talking to me about being Commissioner of Agriculture," he said, discussing an elective state post. "I am visiting with people about it. I have no idea if I want to take on something like that. The election is next year and I have until March to make a decision."
If he runs, the 50-year-old Ryan said, it will be as a Republican. "I'm not a Republican," he said, setting the record straight. "I don't belong to either party. But I guess they consider me an independent Republican by nature."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 25; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Second Front

LENGTH: 1231 words

HEADLINE: Bilingualism At Hostos Is Receiving A Hard Look

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Thirty years ago, when Herman Badillo, as Bronx Borough President, first dreamed of opening a college in the economically depressed South Bronx, he wanted a college in which Spanish-speaking students could receive degrees as quickly as possible, learning English while taking other courses taught in Spanish.
Thus was born Eugenio Maria de Hostos Community College of the City University of New York, a rare experiment in bilingual higher education in America. 
 Today the success of that experiment is in question. City University's trustees, Mr. Badillo among them, accused Hostos last month of giving diplomas to students who do not know English, and voted that all university students must pass an English writing test to receive a degree.
"If you can't express yourself in English, you shouldn't graduate," said Mr. Badillo, who proposed the writing test requirement as vice chairman of the university's board of trustees and is Hostos's leading critic. "Bilingual means two languages, English and Spanish. You have to be fluent in English to have a career. No one would ever have approved Hostos if they thought it meant monolingual."
While bilingual education is widely used in elementary and secondary schools, few colleges have picked it up. In Florida, Texas and California, for example, all of which have large immigrant populations, college courses taught in English are the rule.
"We want students who are proficient in English," said David Spence, executive vice chancellor for the state university system of Florida, who said college bilingual education was not a big issue in his state.
And at Boricua College in upper Manhattan, which describes itself as the only four-year, bilingual liberal arts college in the United States, all classes are in English, although faculty members and administrators are required to be bilingual so they can help students with language problems.
"We don't believe we should give students the option of taking a degree in the United States of Spanish courses, because we don't believe it would be helpful to them," Roland Marrero, a student services official at the college, said.
At Hostos, which straddles the Grand Concourse in the Bronx just a mile from Yankee Stadium, and where more than three-quarters of the nearly 5,000 students are Hispanic, college officials defend their approach and say they are achieving their mission.
"The bilingual model has been effective in providing access to large numbers of students," the president of Hostos, Isaura Santiago Santiago, said in a recent interview in her office. "They've left here skilled. Our career programs are nationally recognized in a variety of fields. And we've been particularly effective in giving access to minorities."
"We should build on what people know, and teach them English," she added.
About 22 percent of the college's classes, mostly introductory subjects, are taught in Spanish, and many students spend term after term taking English-as-a-second-language courses. Some of the college's departments, like its highly respected health science programs, require that their students be proficient in English to enter.
Despite Hostos's success in areas like nursing and dental hygiene, where virtually all of its graduates pass state and national certification exams, English -- and passing the City University writing exam -- remains a stumbling block for many students. Although students at other City University colleges have similar difficulties, none of the other colleges have seen such large portions of its students repeatedly fail the university writing test. When the university offered the test to prospective Hostos graduates earlier this month, only 13 of the 125 who took it passed it.
Hostos is a tough place to run any education experiment. Not only do many students enter speaking little English, but many are poor and poorly educated.
On the writing placement examination given to all City University entering freshmen, fewer than 15 percent of Hostos's students passed last fall, a rate lower than at any other university college.
Teaching English to adults is not easy. Young children pick up new languages fairly naturally. Adults rarely, if ever, gain the proficiency that children do. Language experts have also found that adults who are more literate in their native language do better learning a second language than less educated adults.
"That's what makes this so complex," said Henry M. Levin, a Stanford University professor and expert in remedial education who is a visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation in New York. "It's the dirty little secret; it's more a literacy problem."
Many immigrants who enter City University with limited English do quite well, passing the university writing test, excelling in their studies, sometimes graduating at the top of their classes and going on to elite graduate schools.
As immigrant students have flooded their campuses, City University professors say, their methods of teaching English to nonnative speakers have improved. One approach that is winning increasing attention involves placing students in courses like biology or history as quickly as possible and pairing those courses with English-as-a-second-language classes.
As in the bilingual approach, this pairing allows students to accumulate college credits at the same time they master English. Vocabulary and grammar drills are keyed to the paired course, and in some cases the textbook in the paired course may be used as an English reading text. Teachers who have used this approach say students learn English more rapidly because the readings cover topics they want to learn.
In yet another approach, City University has begun to introduce language immersion centers. Some applaud them as programs that allow students who know little English to concentrate in an English-only environment for five hours a day, 25 hours a week, before formally starting college. But others say the typical City University student knows at least some English and does not need the immersion, and that the immersion does not allow students to improve their English in an academic context.
At Hostos, students offer mixed views about the bilingual approach.
Maria R. Bosora, a 22-year-old public administration major who grew up in the Dominican Republic, said she might be better off taking fewer courses in Spanish. "This is the problem," she said. "I little speak English. My problem is I don't practice. At home I speak Spanish. All my family speaks Spanish. I think I would be better off if I took all English for practice."
But Julio Alcantara, a 43-year-old Hostos student who came to New York from the Dominican Republic 10 years ago, said the college should not change. "The bilingual system is supposed to work," said Mr. Alcantara, who is president-elect of Hostos's student government.
For now, Hostos and its bilingual approach remain an option at City University, although the university's chairwoman, Anne A. Paolucci, has set up a task force headed by Mr. Badillo to study the college.
Mr. Badillo, for one, is still not ready to give up on the notion of a bilingual college, and says it can work better than it has.
"Just because people have corrupted the process, doesn't mean it can't be done well," he said. "This doesn't mean we should throw this baby out with the bath water."

HEADLINE: Forest Service Proposal Would Protect Alaska's Tongass Forest;
Losing on Timber

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Poor Deal for the Tongass" (editorial, June 8) is an even poorer deal for taxpayers. According to the General Accounting Office, the Forest Service lost $100 million in its sale of Tongass National Forest timber from 1992 to 1994. 
 The economics of Tongass timbering is now even worse than a few years ago. Both of the pulp mills that consumed most of the Tongass's timber are now closed, victims of a worldwide glut of pulp and refusal to invest in anti-pollution technology.
The Forest Service's own economists predict that timber demand has plummeted to less than 100 million board feet annually. Nonetheless, the Forest Service wants to market 267 million board feet every year -- not because it cares about local communities, which rely more on recreation, tourism, fisheries and services than timbering, but because it wants to save the jobs of its own bureaucrats.
 
ANDY STAHL
Eugene, Ore., June 13, 1997
 
The writer is executive director of Forest Service Employees for Environmental Ethics.

HEADLINE: Defending Affirmative Action, Clinton Urges Debate on Race

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, June 14

 BODY:
Speaking in a state that has led the movement against racial preference programs, President Clinton today made a broad appeal for racial reconciliation and vigorously defended affirmative action on college campuses. "We must not resegregate higher education," Mr. Clinton said.
In an address at the University of California at San Diego, Mr. Clinton began what he called a yearlong effort to lead America in a "great and unprecedented conversation about race" three decades after the Kerner Commission found that America was "moving towards two societies, one black, one white, separate and unequal." 
 The President acknowledged that there was still "old and unfinished business" between black and white Americans. But he sought to reframe the debate in the context of demographic changes that he said now pose "many dilemmas of race and ethnicity." Predicting that in half a century there would be "no majority race in America," Mr. Clinton posed a choice:
"Will we become not two but many Americas, separate, unequal and isolated?" he asked at the university's commencement ceremonies. "Or will we draw strength from all our people and our ancient faith in the quality of human dignity to become the world's first truly multiracial democracy?" [Excerpts, Page 16.]
Mr. Clinton chose to underscore his remarks by beginning his focus on race relations at a campus of the University of California, a university system that moved in 1995 to prohibit the use of race or sex in hiring and admissions.
In a separate action, Californians last year approved Proposition 209, which bans consideration of race and sex in state hiring, contracting and education. Although a Federal appeals court in San Francisco upheld the constitutionality of the initiative in April, its provisions have been stayed pending further court appeals.
"Let me say, I know that the people of California voted to repeal affirmative action without any ill motive," Mr. Clinton said. "The vast majority of them simply did it with a conviction that discrimination and isolation are no longer barriers to achievement."
But he pointed to reports that the University of California has seen a significant drop in applications from minority students and, more recently, in the number accepted. "Minority enrollments in law school and other graduate programs are plummeting for the first time in decades," he said. "Assuming the same will likely happen in undergraduate education, we must not resegregate higher education or leave it to the private universities to do the public's work."
Again and again, students in gowns and mortarboards applauded as Mr. Clinton said that affirmative action had produced "a whole generation of professionals in fields that used to be exclusive clubs" including more black, Hispanic and Asian-American lawyers, judges, scientists, engineers and accountants.
Mr. Clinton held up the military as an example of successful affirmative action. "So much for the argument that excellence and diversity do not go hand in hand," he said.
Mr. Clinton offered to listen to opponents of affirmative action if they could find an alternative way to keep campuses diverse. "I would embrace it if I could find a better way," he said. "And to those of us who still support it, I say we should continue to stand for it."
In fact, opponents of affirmative action were highly critical of the speech because of Mr. Clinton's adherence to racial preference programs. While Speaker Newt Gingrich told reporters in his home district in Georgia today that he would be willing to work with the President's newly appointed seven-member advisory panel on race, he also criticized its makeup and purpose: "I'm going to ask it to have hearings where folks who are different than the normal set of liberals are allowed to come and testify -- successful black businessmen and women, people who have risen on their own, people who are multiracial," Mr. Gingrich said. "It's Tiger Woods."
 A son of the south, Mr. Clinton has given long thought to questions of race in America and has called President Dwight D. Eisenhower's use of Federal troops to desegregate Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., the formative political experience of his youth. Some of the most striking speeches of Mr. Clinton's Presidency have concerned race.
Now stepping up his focus on race in his second term, the President has asked his advisory panel to work with him across the next year and also plans a series of town meetings and appearances such as one in September commemorating the integration of Central High School. At the end of the year, he promises to write a report to the nation.
Mr. Clinton made few concrete proposals today beyond a call for Congress to provide more financing for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. But he has indicated that he wants the year to produce proposals to deal with housing, education and economic opportunity, as well as the administration of justice.
"If we do nothing more than talk, it will be interesting but it won't be enough," he said today. "If we do nothing more than propose disconnected acts of policy it would be helpful but it won't be enough. But if 10 years from now people can look back and see that this year's honest dialogue and concerted action helped to lift the burdens of race from our children's future we will have given a precious gift to America."
The reaction to Mr. Clinton's speech demonstrated the vast division of opinion on matters of race. Aside from the conservatives' criticism, civil rights groups called his speech a first step that needed to be followed with actions that go beyond sentiment and talk.
"An immediate and appropriate follow-up to the President's speech would be an increased effort by the Administration to enforce existing Federal civil rights protections that are being violated" by anti-affirmative action measures like the university system's new rules, said Thomas A. Saenz, the Los Angeles regional counsel for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund.
In addition to Mr. Gingrich's remarks today, he also called the President's speech a "missed opportunity," in a joint opinion piece in Sunday's edition of The New York Times. He and Ward Connerly, a University of California regent who led the charge against affirmative action programs in the state, said in the article that Mr. Clinton should have laid out a plan for real education reform.
Mr.Connerly attended the President's speech and was sitting on a dignitaries platform.
Much of Mr. Clinton's speech was devoted to a sweeping review of the nation's history of discrimination from European settlers pushing Indians off their lands, to slavery to the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.
Mr. Clinton also vividly recalled his own childhood experience of segregation. "I grew up in the high drama of the cold war, in the patriotic South," he said. "Black and white Southerners alike wore our nation's uniform in defense of freedom against communism. They fought and died together, from Korea to Vietnam. But back home, I went to segregated schools, swam in segregated public pools, sat in all white sections at the movies and traveled through small towns in my state that marked restrooms and water fountains 'white' and 'colored."'
A Gallup Poll released earlier this week found that 58 percent of whites surveyed thought that the quality of life for black Americans had become better over the past decade, while only 33 percent of black respondents thought that it had. Asked if the Federal Government should make "every possible effort" to improve the social and economic position of minority groups, 59 percent of blacks, but only 34 percent of whites, said yes.
The White House has been considering the race initiative for months. Mr. Clinton examined data on racial attitudes assembled by his pollsters, and this week he had an array of scholars and civil rights leaders at the White House. Across the past week he and his speech writers have gone through draft after draft of his address, with the President sometimes rewriting passages and sometimes dictating the words he wanted into a tape recorder.
The President was polishing his final draft past midnight, aides said. Mr. Clinton said that early this morning his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, called him with her own last-minute criticisms of the final draft "which is a routine I have come to look forward to in life."

HEADLINE: The Times Rolls Its Presses In Manhattan One Last Time

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
The curtain rang down last night on the longest-running production on Broadway.
After 146 years, 93 of them in Times Square, The New York Times was printed in Manhattan for the final time. 
 In the culmination of planning begun in the 1980's to increase press capacity, add new sections and offer later news for readers in the metropolitan region, the pressroom under 43d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues rumbled its last.
At the end, where nine huge Goss presses whirred as recently as six months ago, there roared only a single half-century-old press tended by a crew of a baker's dozen, turning out about 5 percent of the news sections of the 1.64 million copies of the Sunday paper.
In all, some 80 pressmen, paper handlers, machinists, electricians, mailers, drivers and managers were involved in the final night of what had been the largest manufacturing operation in Manhattan.
Beginning today, The Times, with a weekday circulation of 1.1 million, will be printed for metropolitan area readers at its new $350 million, five-press plant in College Point, Queens, and at a $450 million, six-press plant in Edison, N.J., which has been operating since 1993.
The headquarters of The Times's news, editorial and business offices will remain at 229 West 43d Street.
Commenting on the transfer of production from Manhattan to College Point, where The Times employs about 500 people, Charles Millard, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said: "This should remind everyone that economic development in New York City includes five boroughs, not just one."
The city gave The Times $21.5 million in tax credits, grants and purchase options for the new plant. The long-term tax breaks were intended to keep the jobs in the city.
The conclusion of an era on 43d Street was tinged with sadness for many employees of The Times.
"The emotional portion of it is very difficult," said Tom Walber, the plant manager responsible for production. "There are tough guys in here, and they're crying."
Raymond Kelly, 57, a pressman for 40 years and the assistant general foreman of all pressroom operations for The Times, echoed Mr. Walber. "It's heartbreaking," Mr. Kelly said. "It's my adult lifetime."
In a formal statement to the entire staff on Friday, Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher, took note of the inclination to sorrow over the end of production on 43d Street. "But," he wrote, "our history is one of constant renewal, and it teaches us that the passing of one tradition also marks the birth of a new and exciting era."
The Times, founded in 1851, has been printed since 1904 in Times Square and since 1913 at 229 West 43d Street. The final press run in Manhattan came on a night when the Disney Company's parade across West 42d Street and up Fifth Avenue underscored the profound changes that have reshaped the neighborhood in recent years.
"They're not going to change the name to Disney Square," Mr. Sulzberger asserted as he walked through the newsroom on Friday.
Gone are the decrepit movie theaters on 42d Street on the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. They have been replaced by rebuilt and renovated legitimate playhouses and an array of new shops and eating places calculated to attract family trade to a street whose past habitues gave it an unsavory reputation.
On West 43d Street, traffic will no longer be halted by huge Times tractor-trailers and smaller trucks tracing arabesques on the narrow thoroughfare before bucking backward into the loading bays to pick up their cargoes of newspapers.
"A lot of memories," said James Donald, 61, a Times driver for 25 years, as he contemplated his final night of driving out of 43d Street. "I don't want to go."
He recalled good times, jokes and gags with co-workers as he spoke of the ambience of the block where, he said, an impatient motorist once took a baseball bat to the windshield of a Times truck, where a decoy police officer baited thieves with a dangling camera while slumped in a supposedly drunken stupor on the street and where prostitutes and transvestites added to the scenery. "That's a show right there," Mr. Donald said.
Four months ago, The Times began printing at plants outside Boston and Washington for 110,000 Times buyers from Maine to Virginia who previously received the New York edition. Beginning in September, as a result of the addition of the College Point plant, The Times will expand its four-section New York regional edition to six sections on most weekdays, adding color photography and color advertising seven days a week. In the meantime, the newspaper, also printed at other plants around the nation, is building its circulation elsewhere in the country, which has reached 268,000 on weekdays and 376,000 on Sundays.
The end of The Times's printing operations in Manhattan leaves only The New York Post among the city's three major dailies to print in the borough. The Daily News is printed at its Liberty View production plant in Jersey City.
 In other editions, the caption with a picture showing a pressroom supervisor reaching up to two streams of printed paper coming off the press misidentified him. He was Harry Barrett, not Patrick O'Sullivan. The caption also misstated the time of the action pictured. It was Friday night, not Saturday.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 17, 1997, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption on Sunday about the transfer of The New York Times's printing operation out of Manhattan referred incorrectly in some editions to the length of time the paper was printed on West 43d Street. It was 84 years, ended on Saturday, not the 146 years since The Times's founding.

HEADLINE: 2% Tax Proposed to Preserve Open Land

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
AS a building boom supplants farms and open space onthe East End, a new coalition of environmental, business and civic groups is promoting a 2 percent real-estate transfer tax to preserve open lands.
Influential real-estate and builders' groups strongly oppose the proposal, complaining that it would unfairly penalize buyers. 
 The new coalition -- whose leaders include environmentalists, individual farmers, some builders and real-estate and bank officials -- said the tax was urgently needed to enhance preservation programs that they contend are falling short.
Officials in East Hampton are moving to submit the tax to a vote in November.
The tax, which would apply to transactions of more than $250,000 for house sales and $100,000 for unimproved land, would finance measures like buying land and development rights.
The proposal would mean that a buyer paying $500,000 for a house would pay a transfer tax of $5,000. A buyer of a $1 million house would pay $15,000. The money would go to a fund in that town.
The tax, which would not apply to sales less than the thresholds, would be tailored to exempt transactions where land remains in agriculture.
Supporters said the tax would be modeled after a similar tax on Nantucket that they said had been successful in preserving that resort island. The proponents said the tax would wrest benefit from a tide of development that threatens to rob the area of character, environmental and esthetic assets and rural ways of life.
"The premise is that you capture the real-estate-market activity in each of the East End towns, so that if there is a hot market there will be more money available for preservation," said Kevin McDonald, vice president of the Group for the South Fork, an environmental group in Bridgehampton.
Mr. McDonald said the coalition estimated that it would cost $375 million to preserve significant areas of farms and open spaces that make up 35 percent of the total land area in the five towns.
In addition to East Hampton, the towns include Riverhead, Southampton, Southold and Shelter Island.
Imposing the tax would require state permission and approval by a majority of local residents in town-by-town referendums. Last week, in a major advance for the tax, the East Hampton Town Board requested state permission for a referendum. Supervisor Catherine H. Lester said she expected broad support from voters who had backed other preservation programs.
One-third of the land in the town is protected, Mrs. Lester said, adding, "Right now, with the building boom on the East End, it's more critical than ever to take steps to maintain our character."
Money from the transfer tax would protect "our open space, drinking water, harbors, bays and farmlands," she added.
State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, Republican of Port Jefferson, said he was introducing a bill in Albany that would authorize the referendum in East Hampton.
A companion bill is to be introduced in the Assembly with backing from Fred W. Thiele Jr., Republican of Sag Harbor, and Thomas P. DiNapoli, Democrat of Thomaston.
Mr. LaValle said if East Hampton approved the tax that could be a model for other East End towns, none of which have requested permission for a referendum.
"We chose East Hampton because we had the greatest support there from government, real-estate and development people," Mr. LaValle said. "The other towns need to go through a longer gestation period. But East Hampton seemed poised to go ahead."
The Long Island Builders Institute, the Long Island Board of Realtors and their statewide parent organizations have pledged to fight the bills. Officials of the groups said that the tax could spread to other parts of the state and country and that it might finance programs other than preservation.
The executive director of the Long Island Builders Institute, Robert A. Wieboldt, said the tax was an admission fee charged to new buyers, at no cost to landowners or residents. "It's so easy to pass something like this," Mr. Wieboldt said. "You are taxing people that aren't there yet."
Mr. Wieboldt said programs that transferred development rights from areas to be preserved to areas that would be developed more intensively had proved successful in preserving 45,000 acres in Montgomery County, Md., where he recently took coalition members on a tour.
He said transferring development rights, already in use on the East End, was a way to preserve space without taxes or public spending.
Mr. McDonald, who went to Montgomery County, said it was disingenuous to suggest that the transfer of rights was a solution. "We are headed for suburbia with a few spots of open space in between," he said. "And the people who are opposed to measures like the transfer tax know that, and they are content to let it happen."
In Southampton, where development has been the most rapid, Supervisor Vincent J. Cannuscio, a Republican, said he would decide soon whether to support the tax.
"I will probably come down on the side of supporting it, but with certain limitations," said Mr. Cannuscio, adding that they included a time limit on the tax or provisions that it would be suspended if the market cooled.
He also said that Southampton had taken significant steps to protect land, including approval in November of a $5 million bond for open space and farm preservation. "We have already demonstrated our commitment, and now some individuals are saying on top of that do the transfer tax," he said.
Mr. McDonald noted that 13 percent of the remaining 6,000 acres of farmland in Southampton was the subject of applications for subdivisions. "The problem is that time is our enemy," he said. "If we wait the land won't be there."
Another coalition member, Edwin M. Schwenk of East End Forever, said the vote in East Hampton would give "us a leg up to start applying pressure on the Town Board in Southampton and the other communities."
"East Hampton is going forward, and Southampton, I hope, won't want to be left in second place," said Mr. Schwenk, who lives in Southampton. He predicted that residents would overwhelmingly support the tax.
Mr. Schwenk said he had resigned as executive director of the Builders Institute because the group would not support the tax, which he had espoused.
"They think it is a regressive tax," Mr. Schwenk said. "I don't agree. With all the second-home owners coming out here, it's the sort of thing that preserves our quality of life."
Another coalition member, Paul C. Brennan, vice president of Sotheby's International Realty in Bridgehampton, said the tax would help preserve qualities that sustained the South Fork market.
"Over the years, all along Long Island you have seen suburbanization," Mr. Brennan said. "Resort communities of years past have now become major towns and suburbs. There is not much rural character left on Long Island anymore."
Mr. Brennan said that the tax would not dampen the South Fork market and that most local real-estate professionals would agree that the tax would be beneficial.
The tax is also adamantly opposed by statewide real-estate organizations that worked to defeat such measures in the past.
"A transfer tax is not only inequitable, it's downright evil," Joseph E. Mottola, chief executive officer of the Long Island Board of Realtors, said. "It is patently unfair to incoming residents, and it results in windfall profits for current property owners."
"There are Federal, state, county and local town funds allocated for open space, and nobody says there is anything wrong with that," said Fritz Mayer, an executive officer of the Hamptons and North Fork Realtors Association, Inc. "But this is a 'welcome stranger' tax, and we are opposed to it."
Coalition members said such views differed from East End sentiment for an economy built on preservation.
"The economic and environmental communities agree we must protect the landscape that makes eastern Long Island so special," Thomas Tobin, president of the Bridgehampton National Bank, wrote in a statement announcing coalition support for the tax.
"It's no longer the environmentalists vs. the economic community," Richard L. Amper Jr. of East End Forever said. "It's the East End environmental and economic community against the up-Island producers of suburban sprawl."
"It's only the East End if everyone works to preserve it," said Mr. Amper, who is also executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society. "It is only a treasure if everybody agrees that it is and keeps it special."
Members of the coalition said that officials in Southold and on Shelter Island had shown interest in the tax but that Riverhead had shown limited interest.
A member of the Southold Town Board, Joseph L. Townsend Jr., said he believed that the board would support asking the Legislature in Albany for permission for a referendum on the tax. Mr. Townsend said that the town had supported the tax in the 80's, but that the Legislature never approved the bills.
On Shelter Island, Supervisor Huson B. Sherman said there was support on the Town Board for a referendum. "Right now we are watching to see what the other East End towns are doing," Mr. Sherman said.
Deputy Supervisor Russell Kratoville of Riverhead said the details of the tax had "just come to fruition."
"The Town Board," he said, "has not yet had an opportunity to fully digest this proposal."

HEADLINE: Car Test May Bring Big Lines

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
LINES at gasoline stations, reminiscent of the oil crises of the 70's, may reappear after Nov. 15, retailers are warning.
"There will be a rude awakening on Nov. 15," the owner of the DJM Service Station on Deer Park Avenue in Deer Park, Mitchell S. Macy, said. "There will be long lines of cars up and down the block. It's going to be a real shock." 
 Mr. Macy said the lines would be caused by a miscalculation by the state, which is planning for most of the 4,700 downstate service stations that perform inspections to continue in the program after new testing equipment is required.
"No one I know, and I know 10 to 15 service station owners, will do it," said Mr. Macy.
The New York State Association of Service Stations and Repair Shops, with 3,500 members, said 60 to 65 percent of its members who did inspections would not participate.
"The overwhelming majority said they would not participate for either physical or financial reasons," the executive director of the group, Ralph Bombardiere, said. "The new inspection equipment ties up one bay. So it makes no sense for a two-bay location."
The $40,000 cost of the equipment, Mr. Bombardiere said, is prohibitive.
The executive director of the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association, Kathryn L. Pollane, said most of that group's 800 members in Nassau and Suffolk Counties were also balking at buying the equipment because of the expense.
"If we could get everybody collectively not to do the program, it won't happen," said Ms. Pollane.
A deputy environmental conservation commissioner, Dave Sterman, said the state believed that 3,000 to 3,500 stations would stay in the program. The state, Mr. Sterman added, realizes that some smaller sites would drop out, but that "it probably would not be economical for them to do the testing, anyway."
The state is trying to keep down the price of the equipment and is meeting vendors, Mr. Sterman said. The state has not certified equipment, and it is is watching a pilot program in California, expecting to approve the analyzer certified there in a "couple of weeks," he added.
The machine, Mr. Sterman said, would analyze three emissions instead of two and include safeguards against fraud. The program intends to have the state comply with Federal mandates in the Clean Air Act.
The state says the equipment will pay for itself in a year.
Mr. Bombardiere said that would be impossible.
"The inspection will take between 37 and 45 minutes, compared with 20 to 30 minutes now," he said. "You would need to do 160 inspections per month to make it economically feasible and seven years to pay it off. An average station now does only 80 inspections a month."
He said that each inspection would cost $35, instead of the present $19 and that the station would retain $31 instead of the present $15. The rest of the money will continue to go to the State Clean Air Fund for consumer protection and enforcement.
"We suggest an increase in the fee to $50," Mr. Bombardiere said. "That would be enough so our people would make some money, and even low-volume locations would buy the equipment."
As of Nov. 15, stations have to have whichever analyzer the state designates. Mr. Sterman said manufacturers would require the stations to sign agreements to buy the second half of the equipment, a dynamometer, that will be required for all inspections after Nov. 15, 1998.
Vendors will begin providing the dynamometers by year's end, he said. A dynamometer requires a car's tires to sit on rollers and places pressure on the tires as the rollers spin, simulating travel up and down hills.
Mr. Bombardiere pointed out that unlike the test in California, which spins the tires at a constant speed of 15 miles an hour under 50 pounds a square inch of pressure, the New York test will fluctuate the pressure and vary the speed, up to 37 miles an hour.
The president of the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association, Robert A. Santasiero, said one reason that he would not participate in the program was safety.
"The dynamometer will not work when it is snowing or raining and the tires of cars are wet," Mr. Santasiero said. "They would have to be dried before being placed on the rollers of the dynamometer, because they could slip off the rollers. That could damage the dynamometer and the car and be hazardous to the inspector. State officials just shrug their shoulders when you mention it to them."
Mr. Sterman said that concern was unwarranted. "I can't believe manufacturers would let a machine out the door without providing safeguards," he said. "These machines are running in other states. I spoke with the Ohio Commissioner, and he said they have been running a successful program using the dynamometer for a year or so and that they got past the initial problems quickly."
New York has decided against requiring inspections at state-operated sites.
"We went away from a centralized test, because all the service stations would lose out," Mr. Sterman said. "We had considered having 12 or 15 centralized stations in the state. But there was a potential for waiting in long lines."
In addition, stations that repair failing cars might not have the equipment to insure making the repairs.
That would result in a "Ping Pong effect," motorists going back and forth between the testing sites and repair shops, Mr. Sterman said, adding:
"That was another reason we decided to go with the decentralized program. Now they are yelling to have it the other way."
Mr. Bombardiere said his association had initially favored decentralized testing and repairs, but now preferred a centralized system, because "so many of our guys will not participate" in the new arrangement.
Even the owner of an inspection station that plans an upgrade said he would prefer centralized testing.
"Do you know of anybody who is going to give a state trooper a $50 bill to get an inspection sticker?" the owner, Richard F. Sayres of the Holbrook MTA Auto Service, asked.
Mr. Sayres said he would buy the new equipment because he "learned a long time ago that you can't fight City Hall."
"The sooner you get with the program, the better you are," he said. "It's just unfortunate that people with two or three bays will have to decide."
Mr. Sayres, with eight bays and two outside lifts, said he favored a system to combat fraud. A device, either a video or still camera, would take a picture of each car.
"It legitimizes the industry and takes me off the hook of being the bad guy" when refusing to falsify a test result, said Mr. Sayres.
"Unfortunately there is a cloud over the industry" because of cheating, he added.
Mr. Sterman, saying he could not quantify the cheating, added:
"One of the reasons we are not getting the kind of emission remediation we should get is because of the cheating component. This is the rationale for the Environmental Protection Administration not giving us as much emission reduction credit."
With photographs the state could prevent "golden Cadillacs," cars parked at shops to pass emissions tests in the place of cars in violation.
New York is one of 37 Eastern states that is trying to reduce up to 85 percent of nitrogen oxide emissions from power plants. Over the next two years, Mr. Sterman said, the state hopes to realize a 24 percent reduction in hydrocarbons released into the atmosphere based on 1990 levels.
"Hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide, when combined with the heat of sunlight, creates a chemical reaction that causes ozone or smog," he said.
The new vehicle inspections will be effective for the four and a half million cars on Long Island and in New York City, as well as in Westchester and Rockland Counties.
The state says that it expects most of the 11,000 upstate inspection stations to participate. Those areas already comply with the Federal ozone standards.
Mr. Santasiero, who has owned a Mobil station on West Old Country Road in Hicksville for 38 years, said he was not certain that the new program would work.
"We're all for clean air," he said. "I have kids, too. But we want to make sure we are doing this in a sensible way. If we knew this new program would bring the results we wanted, it would ease the pain a little."
The state plans to test the equipment for 18 months, Mr. Santasiero said, and it might require stations to spend an additional $20,000 on equipment.
"How stupid do they think the merchants are in the Northeast corridor?" he asked. "We just spent $12,000 to $15,000 for a new machine four and a half years ago that they are now telling us is obsolete. How can we have confidence in the people making the laws?"
Mr. Sterman said that the present equipment was certified in 1990 and that the new equipment would be used for a minimum of seven years.
Mr. Sayres said he believed that whoever "jumps on the bandwagon first" would benefit from the program.
"I think more than half of the guys are going to do it, because no one has a choice," he said. "You can't stop progress. It's the wave of the future."
The vice president of legislative and economic affairs for the Long Island Association, Mitchell H. Pally, said he believed that most stations would ultimately buy the machines, "because they know how important it is."
