HEADLINE: My Days Underground

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
SHE wore a brown cloth coat and little half-glasses, and she emerged from the side of the 14th Street platform with the light behind her, creating a halo effect around her hair, like an angel's. I never learned her name because she jumped onto an uptown No. 1 local train a minute later, but I will never forget her. She rescued a struggling musician in the grimmest moment of his first-ever afternoon playing for the passing throng of the New York transit system: she listened.
Every subway musician has a story like that about a resonant moment when performer and audience suddenly and unexpectedly connected. But how does it happen? How, in this least likely of places -- the subway -- where New Yorkers wrap their cloaks of anonymity and self-defense more tightly than almost anywhere else, does a subway musician break through? That's what I went underground with my guitar to find out. Is music that powerful a force? How does it persist, even thrive, in such a stony environment? 
 Some people might argue that subway music is one of New York City's lesser miracles. But no one can dismiss its power or its place in the culture of the nation's largest mass transit system. The producers of a CD compilation of subway musicians released last year counted more than 200 subway acts over several months as they toured the tunnels. On any given day, there are musicians and singers by the dozens, with dizzying degrees of talent: ragged players of ragged old guitars and austere practitioners of the pure-toned Chinese stringed instrument known as the erhu, and brave souls who stride forth with no more than a crosscut saw and a violin bow. There are bored-looking mariachi bands and intense jazz bands, and torch singers and crooners to make you weep or wince.
What they all have in common is their strange stage: an enclosed, cavernous place of sometimes vague menace, where people avoid eye contact and subconsciously calculate the amount of threat in any given pose or body language. Few people go to the subway for a good time, or to escape their worries and cares. And yet that is exactly what subway musicians must provide their audiences in order to succeed: they must be everything that the subway is not.
For a musician, it is a world of soaring emotional highs and plummeting psychic lows, none of which -- for better and for worse -- lasts longer than the average wait for a train. Indeed, after a while, all life seems measurable in blocks of about three to five minutes. A subway performer has that long, if not less, to win over an audience, and at the end of that time he or she is inevitably doomed to see the audience disappear. People and faces, like the trains, come and go in a constant blur. The ancient Greeks who posited the circular, ever-repeating universe would feel right at home.
Luke Ryan, a blues and rock performer who has been playing in the subway for 15 years, calls this effect the "constant audition." It's the only environment he knows, he said, where a performer wins hearts instantly, or fails completely, because there is no time for anything in between.
For most of my first afternoon on the subway stage, I was firmly in the failed category. I had played for perhaps half an hour without a single person's so much as acknowledging my existence, and was beginning to feel a growing, desperate expertise in the various postures of indifference: the opened newspaper, the opened paperback, the casual laughing conversation, the turned head, the turned back.
The woman in brown changed it all. She stepped out of the light, leaned in, listened, smiled, touched her forefinger and thumb together to signal, "O.K.," and threw a single quarter in the open guitar case. She brought hope.
I ultimately played and sang underground on two more occasions over a 10-day period at various times and stations around the city -- morning rush hour on the Upper West Side 72d Street downtown I.R.T. No. 1, 2 and 3 trains; afternoon into evening on Wall Street, uptown No. 4 and 5, as well as that afternoon on the 14th Street platform -- and through it all I was always trying to recreate that first moment of victory.
I played the song she liked, "Maybelline," by Chuck Berry, just about to death -- sometimes with success, sometimes not, but always with her in mind. I became a slave to what worked and a vicious editor of what I felt did not. Songs that survived my play list, like "Maybelline," or "Folsom Prison Blues," by Johnny Cash, did so through the most brutal and elemental forces of the marketplace: They sold, they connected, they produced a dollar in the guitar case.
The money, which all went to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, became in some ways doubly important for the symbolism it acquired, representing my pathetic little psychic ledger sheet. I began, inevitably perhaps, to measure my value by what passing and anonymous strangers would pull from their wallets and purses. I did not make much: exactly $61.39 for more than nine hours of physically exhausting work -- better than the minimum wage, though not by much.
But getting the money, after a while, was also beside the point. I played not so much to win, but to avoid losing. I tried to play exactly what people wanted, as many times as I thought it would work -- or as many times as I could stand -- because the alternative, to be ignored and treated as a thing without value, unworthy of attention or respect, was so grimly appalling. I had felt that once and I would do whatever it took to avoid feeling it again.
I tried dressing up in a shirt and tie, and dressing down in jeans and T-shirt. On the Upper West Side I tried Museum of Natural History humor, on the mistaken belief that references to the nearby museum might be mildly diverting at 7:45 A.M. Here's an old song, I would announce to the platform, that was "popular in the Devonian period among the early cartilaginous fishes." People looked blank. I dumped the Devonian jokes.
Still, I began to think after a while that I could read the various types of people who walked by. I would look at a particular man, well dressed, in his 40's, and think: Creedence Clearwater Revival. I imagined some drunken frat house Saturday night, circa 1973, and did my best to try to recapture for him the feeling of youth and freedom by playing "Have You Ever Seen the Rain?" or "Travelin' Band."
I would look at a particular woman and think, for no reason that now makes much sense: Neil Young. I would sing "After the Gold Rush" to her, or "Four Strong Winds." If she would not look at me, I sang to her back, trying to make her turn around. I saw late middle age and played Everly Brothers. I saw cowboy boots and played Buck Owens.
In retrospect, my song list probably limited my appeal, and it dated me. Growing up in Utah in the 1960's and 70's, I played with various bands, often country-tinged, from high school through college, and with only a few exceptions, everything I performed in the subway was frozen in that genre and era: three or four chords, a little country twang and composed before the first Reagan Administration. I tried to learn a Nirvana song, with deliberate demographics in mind, and couldn't make it sound right.
Still, there were some moments of indescribable sweetness. A man named Regeland Smith, who came to New York in 1960 from North Carolina to be a rock-and-roll singer (but who found God in 1967 and became a subway preacher instead) spontaneously stepped up and harmonized on the John Fogerty song "Up Around the Bend." A group of young women from Brooklyn danced before my guitar case. Mark Fulgione, a secret rocker who wears a suit on Wall Street, presented me with the gift of a guitar pick -- a brown Fender, thin gauge -- and made my day.
A beautiful 7-year-old girl named Bianca, missing both front teeth, sang "Old MacDonald had a Farm" with me and made up unusual animal farm inhabitants that included ghosts and snakes. Her gapped teeth allowed for the perfect sibilant reptile hiss.
Some subway performers become addicted to those kinds of encounters. Jim Graseck still vividly remembers the night in the late 1960's when, as a young Juilliard student, he was waiting for a Long Island Rail Road train to take him home. Acting on impulse, he took out his violin and played the Mendelssohn concerto he'd been practicing. He never quite got over what happened next, how the commuters gathered around him, moved by the music -- and how he made a quick $10. Mr. Graseck now records and plays with symphony orchestras, but still regularly goes back to the transit system, he said, because he cannot find the immediacy of the subway audience in any other forum.
"It's kept me in some ways inspired," he said. "I come away feeling younger, in spirit and in years."
Sometimes the bonds that grow between musicians and listeners endure beyond the next train.
Vince Hoare, an 81-year-old retired postal worker from Elizabeth, N.J., has been going into New York nearly every Saturday now for five years to hear a subway jazz band called the Ninth Street Stompers that he fell in love with one day. Mr. Hoare (pronounced hore-RAY) calls the band's leader and trumpet player, Ed Fennell, to find out where the band will be playing. He and Mr. Fennell exchange Christmas cards. He persists in putting a dollar in the collection box even though he's been politely told by the band that he shouldn't.
"You can't stop him," Mr. Fennell said.
There are also things that a performer can pick up only over time about how the underground stage works. Veterans say a couple on a date is often a happy sight, for example. Men like to look expansive or generous -- or at least not like cheapskates -- and will often dig into their wallets if only to show off. Wednesdays are often bad because many New Yorkers get their paychecks that day and won't feel flush until Thursday. And a police officer's song requests should, if possible, always be obliged.
Mr. Fennell said the music itself is also different in the subway. Unlike the audience in a jazz club, which expects subtle musical references and complicated meters, almost no one in the subway has gone there to hear jazz. Underground, he said, people don't have the patience for self-indulgent solos or musicians who play to impress other musicians. What sells is the mainstream: swing tunes, especially familiar ones, played clean and with an easy-to-follow beat.
It is one of greater mysteries of the subway music world that anything sells there at all, and that people will actually pay money for a performance that is by its nature free with the cost of a token. And the even greater wonder is that there seem to be real, if unwritten, rules about it all. In this least formal corner of the informal cash economy, there are rough standards of fairness about what is given and what is received.
Eye contact, for example, is a crucial threshold issue. If I got a person to look me in the eye in the middle of a song, a barrier was broken. One human being had acknowledged another. But in the subway musical code of fair exchange, it also meant, on a deeper level, that something offered had been accepted. It very often led to another dollar in the guitar case.
Ed Robinson, a plumber from Ridgefield Park, N.J., said he almost always gives to subway musicians. He counts off his favorites: the gospel singer near the Port Authority, the little girl singer at Grand Central, the blind guitarist who does Beatles tunes along with his friend on the recorder at Times Square. Mr. Robinson was just getting off work from a construction site in lower Manhattan when he approached me on the Wall Street platform. As a former rock-and-roller himself, who eventually "grew up," as he put it, Mr. Robinson said a donation is a matter of respect.
"I never liked a free ride," he said. "If somebody's playing music, I feel a responsibility, I guess."
But some exchanges go beyond money -- beyond words, even. There was a woman on 72d Street, for example, who stood rooted on the platform's edge perhaps 30 feet away. She never approached closer, never reached in her purse for a dollar, never said a word. But she was on some level a Neil Young type, I guess. I saw her turn to face me as I began one of Mr. Young's songs ("After the Gold Rush" for the umpteenth time), and as her downtown express train approached, I ended the tune and quickly began another, singing by now to her alone.
The noise level rose, drowning me out, but I kept singing, and right up to the moment the train doors opened, we stayed connected -- a performer and an audience of one. Just as she boarded, she gave me a nod, a slight slow bow of the head with her eyes closed. For that one brief shining second, it had all worked just right. The barricades had fallen.
Then she was gone.

HEADLINE: Whats Doing In;
Williamsburg

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER; DAVID E. SANGER is a correspondent for The Times in Washington.

 BODY:
Thomas Jefferson nearly killed off Williamsburg, and the Rockefellers saved it. It was Jefferson who moved the capital of Virginia to Richmond, leaving the genteel little town on the James River to slip into a century and a half of gradual decay. Nobody bothered the place, not even George McClellan, the Civil War Union general, who was supposed to.
Today Williamsburg is America's most famous Colonial restoration, and the kind of place that a decade ago I would have avoided -- smiling folks in tricorn hats offering a sanitized version of a pretty rough era. I was wrong. There are plenty of tricorn hats, but the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, created by John D. Rockefeller Jr. in the 1930's, has gone to extraordinary lengths to take off the varnish. Eighty-eight 18th-century buildings survive -- shops, taverns and houses -- and many more have been painstakingly recreated on original foundations. 
 And there's one more reason that my wife and I now find Williamsburg a marvelous retreat from Washington: Our son, Andrew, just shy of 3 years old, is at that age when booming muskets, tricorn hats and settlers' forts begin to fascinate.
Some sites are found in the nearby Jamestown settlement, where the first English settlers tried -- largely unsuccessfully -- to scratch out a living. Williamsburg, which bloomed 150 years later, marks the settlers' eventual triumph.
 
Events
 From June 23 to July 4, archeology courses ($390 for one week, $625 for two; lodging extra) will offer a chance to work at a dig within the historic area. Similar courses are scheduled from Sept. 1 through Sept. 12 and from Sept. 22 to Oct. 3. For reservations, call (800) 603-0948.
Lord Cornwallis will again occupy Williamsburg June 28 and 29, setting up a full British encampment on Market Square. Shoppers will have to pass checkpoints and risk court-martial. More encampments will be set up throughout the summer.
Every Friday from June 27 through Aug. 29, traditional African-American dance and music, drawing heavily on 18th-century Virginia, is performed at the Playbooth Theatre. Free with a Williamsburg ticket.
On July 27, the Bruton Parish Church re-enacts the nasty disagreements between the congregation and the vestry over choosing a new rector, a conflict that reverberated throughout the Colonies.
 
Sightseeing
 The wondrous thing about the restoration is its tranquillity, the tucked-away gardens behind Colonial houses where you find yourself -- and no one else -- admiring ivy gardens and aster walks. And when you watch visitors in shorts and T-shirts walking alongside the Benjamin Franklin look-alike in his formal vest and stockings, it is hard to say who seems more otherworldly.
For sheer immersion in the spirit of the times, stop by the papermaker's shop to see the art of marbling, and the silversmith's, attached to James Craig Jeweler, where an apprentice describes his life and his customers -- who would bring in their coins for transformation into silverware. Nearby on Duke of Gloucester Street, the Raleigh Tavern, one of the best in town in 1735, is now an exhibition hall; a tour runs from the public rooms to the not-so-private, where guests were stuffed two or three to a bed.
In the Fine Millinery Shop, a tailor fresh from London works on hooped petticoats while a young woman cuts fabric for pilches, the Colonial equivalent of plastic diaper covers. The saddlemaker gives a priceless accounting of how to work leather into something suitable for a governor. You can't buy anything in these two shops, but there are plenty of places where you can, like Tarpley and Company, which specializes in ladies' and girls' fine straw hats with satin ribbons and bows, starting around $40 to $50. There are also teas ($5 for a quarter-pound) and coffees ($11 a pound) blended to approximate flavors of the times. A jewelry shop is stocked with mostly locally made temptations -- delicate gold vermeil earrings ($40 to $50), silver bangles and pewter from the Williamsburg foundry. Most shops are open 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. daily.
The major sites are the Governor's Palace, the Capitol, with its hall of the House of Burgesses, and Bruton Parish Church, where there is often choral singing in the evenings.
Less visited, because it is out of the way on Francis Street, is Bassett Hall, John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s Williamsburg home, built in the 1930's and jammed with the Rockefellers' furnishings. Family members still use it, so reservations are required, at (757) 229-1000.
On a rainy morning we wandered into the DeWitt Wallace Gallery, a bright, airy and remarkably complete collection of early American furniture, intricately engraved muskets, imported porcelain and prints.
A one-day pass to the historic area is $25, or $15 for ages 6 to 12; for $29 (6 to 12, $17), you can get two days. The price includes all the buildings (save the Governor's Palace, for which you buy a pass costing an extra $8), the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Folk Art Center and the DeWitt Wallace Gallery. For information and hotel reservations, call the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation, (800) 447-8679.
After the crowds, the meticulous restorations and the organized events of Williamsburg, the starkness and simplicity of Jamestown -- the first permanent English settlement in North America, started in May 1607 -- is a welcome change. A quick nine-mile drive along the scenic Colonial Parkway from Williamsburg, Jamestown -- with its reconstructed Indian village, fort and ships -- is a sure hit with children.
Last fall, archeologists announced the discovery of the structure everyone knew lay at the edge of the James River: the fort that made up the first colony. These days, laid out in the tiny museum inside the National Park (admission $5; under age 17, free) is the remarkably preserved skeleton of one of the first settlers, a young man whose remains were found during excavation of the fort. His body was exhumed in September and will be reburied after archeologists poke at his bones and examine the musket-ball hole in his knee that probably led to his early death. Until then, he's the closest you will get to meeting one of the first settlers. Information: (757) 229-1733 (the National Park Service Visitor Center).
Jamestown Island, the site of the original settlement, is history in the raw -- the foundations of a few houses and statues of the more familiar figures of the Jamestown drama.
Just outside the gates of the National Park, the privately run Jamestown Settlement ($9.75; ages 6 to 12, $4.75) contains working reproductions of the ships that made the perilous trip with 144 Englishmen, and the first fort and community they built. On board the Susan Constant, the largest of the ships at 116 feet long, visitors can crawl through the mid-decks and check out the cramped captain's quarters. Other high points are the fort, with mud-and-wood reproductions of the first church and other buildings, and the Indian village. Information: (757) 253-4838 or (888) 593-4682.
On the way back on the parkway is Carter's Grove, a handsome 1750's brick mansion and plantation on the James River. The reconstructed slave quarters is a welcome feature because you get little sense of the life of African-Virginians from the refined precincts of Williamsburg. Admission is included when you pay the extra $8 on the Williamsburg pass.
 
Where to Stay
 There are several hotels outside the restoration, starting with the 295-room Marriott, (800) 228-9290, fax (757) 253-0541; and four Best Westerns, (800) 446-9228, with a total of 610 rooms, but all are a bit removed.
The restoration operates four places to stay, all linked by bus and all reachable at (800) 447-8679.
The Governors Inn is the most economical, starting at $84.
The Woodlands, just outside the restoration and near the visitor center, is on 44 acres. This is more motel-like, but family friendly, with swimming pools, playgrounds and biking. Summer doubles begin at $91.
The most famous of the lodgings is the 99-room Williamsburg Inn, the gracious Southern hotel with sweeping views across a spectacular golf course and two pools. The patio directly behind the main lobby is the best place for a sunset drink. Rooms start at $300. Reservations: (757) 229-1000; fax (757) 220-7096.
We took a room in one of the Inn's outbuildings, the Market Square Tavern, a 1749 Colonial house with a wood-paneled reading room and a wonderful bit of history: Thomas Jefferson lived there while studying law with Andrew Wythe. The house has been restored to that era, down to the old floorboards and leaded-glass windows. Our room was cozy (the bathroom was tucked into what appeared to be an old closet) and modestly furnished, with a view to a spectacularly maintained rear garden of asters. The front door delivers you right to the middle of Duke of Gloucester Street, conveniently across from the stockade if the kids act up. Rooms in the Market Square Tavern and other outbuildings of the Williamsburg Inn are about $180.
Across from the Inn is the modern Williamsburg Lodge, with a luxurious spa. The rooms are Hyatt-like; doubles from $159.
 
Where to Eat
 There are four taverns run by Colonial Williamsburg, and reservations for all of them -- and many contemporary restaurants -- can be made by calling (757) 229-2141.
Our favorite was Christiana Campbell's Tavern, named for a proprietress described by one client as "a little old woman about four feet high and equally thick." Today it is a seafood tavern, also known for sweet-potato muffins and hot spoon bread. George Washington never slept here, but he drank plenty, and his receipt from Mrs. Campbell is reproduced on the menu. There is a full chicken dinner with appetizer (recommended: the vegetable pasties in herb tomato sauce) and dessert. Crab cakes and salmon are specialties; dinner came to $60, without wine, for two adults and a child.
The Josiah Chowning Tavern, in the middle of Duke of Gloucester Street, is the most informal of the taverns. It serves simple tavern fare, like filling Welsh rarebit with well-spiced mustard, cheddar and beer We sat in the back garden, a quiet corner covered by a grape arbor. A wandering musician sings old Scottish tunes. Dinner for two and a half without wine came to $44. The King's Arms serves more standard Continental fare, in much the same atmosphere.
Quick snacks can be found at the Raleigh Tavern Bake Shop in the restored area, where gingerbread and apple cider are plentiful.
Just outside the restored area, in Market Square, are more-conventional restaurants: for burgers, sandwiches and other fare ranging from $6.50 to $16, try the Trellis, opposite the Toymaker of Williamsburg. Seasons Cafe has similar offerings but more room for outdoor dining. The Williamsburg Inn serves a sumptuous Sunday brunch for about $25 a person. A buffet breakfast (go for the pancakes) is $13.
 "If it was my kid, I would want them to keep trying," he says. "I think we were never going to stop."
 Ben's heart did begin to beat again, and he was transferred to Martin Memorial's intensive-care unit. The surgeon, who had know Ben since he was a baby, went with McLain to talk to Tammy Kolb. "There has been a serious problem with your son," McLain remembers telling the woman. "His heart stopped. We had to restart his heart. He is extremely critical, in a coma-like state."
 He winces at the memory: "You don't know how strong to be to get your point across. You want her to understand, but you can't stick a knife in her."
 At first, Tammy Kolb did not seem to understand. "I know he's going to wake up just fine," she said.
 "I don't -," McLain said.
 "I've seen this on TV. As soon as he wakes up I have a Christmas present for him. I brought it for him early."
 Ben reamined in a coma for nearly 24 hours. His parents and older sister remained at his bedside as their fog of denial slowly lifted. The next day they agreed that his ventilator should be removed, and he was declared brain dead. As with the death of Jose Martinez, a lot can be learned by what happened after Ben Kolb died.
 First, the hospital's risk manager, Doni Haas, had all the syringes and vials used on Ben locked away, then sent to an independent laboratory for analysis. Second, Haas promised Ben's parents that she "was going to find them an answer, if there was one."
 There was. Tests showed that there had been a mixup, a mistake, a human error in a system that made that error more likely. Ben Kolb, lab reports showed, was never injected with lidocaine at all. The syringe that was supposed to contain lidocaine actually contained adrenaline, a highly concentrated strength that was intended only for external use.
 Procedure in the Martin Memorial operating room at the time was for topical adrenaline to be poured into one cup, made of plastic, and lidocaine to be poured into a cup nearby, made of metal. The lidocaine syringe was then filled by placing it in the metal cup. It is a procedure used all over the country, a way of getting a drug from container to operating table. According to Richmond Harman, the hospital's C.E.O., "It has probably been done 100,000 times in our facility without error."
 But it is a flawed procedure, the hospital learned. It allows for the possibility that the solution can be poured into or drawn out of the wrong cup. Instead, a cap, called a spike, could be put on the vial of lidocaine, allowing the drug to be drawn directly out of the labeled bottle and into a labeled syringe. The elimination of one step eliminates one opportunity for the human factor to get in the way.
Haas received the lab results three weeks after Ben died. The family had hired an attorney by then, and Haas and McLain drove two hours and met with the Kolbs at Krupnick, Campbell, Malone, Roselli, Buster, Slama & Hancock.
 "It was very unusual," says Richard J. Roselli, one of Flordia's most successful malpractice lawyers and the president of the Academy of Florida Trial Lawyers. "This is the first occasion where I ever had a hospital step forward, admitting their responsibility and seeking to do everything they can to help the family."
 A financial settlement was reached by nightfall, but neither side will confirm the amount paid to the Kolbs.
 After the papers were signed, the family asked for a chance to talk with the doctors at the hospital. The first thing Ben's father, Tim, did when he entered the emotion-filled room was to hug his son's surgeon. Then came the torent of questions, questions that had kept the Kolbs awake at night, questions they might never have been able to ask had the case spent years in court.
 Was Ben scared when his heart rate started dropping? Was he in pain? How much did he suffer?
 The doctors explained what the Kolbs did not know, that Ben had been put under general anesthesia long before anything went wrong.
 "The decisions I made for him were the same I would have made if it were my child," McLain said.
 Just before the family left, they asked if it would be O.K. for them to continue to use Martin Memorial for their medical care.
 "Of course," Haas said, grateful and amazed.
 Would the hospital promise to spread the word about how Ben died, so that the procedure in question could be changed in other places?
 Haas promised.
 With that, the Kolb case was closed, but it wasn't over. Tim Kolb still coaches his son's soccer team. The family still grieves.
 The doctors in the operating room that day still have nightmares of their own. "I let that child's life slip through my fingers," McLain says. "They tell me there was nothing I could do. I know there was nothing I could do. But it's like I was a lifeguard and he died on my watch. There must have been something."
 And the lawyers at Krupnick, Campbell are still searching, too.
 "We're not done with this - yet," Roselli says. Why, he asks, was it possible to mix up the lidocaine and the adrenaline? Did the two bottles look alike? "We're still investigating the product liability aspect of it," he says. "The questions of packaging and labeling.
 JOANNE TURNBULL DID not fully realize she was part of a sea change until she was in a Palm Springs auditorium last October - two months after the death of Jose Martinez, nearly two years after the death of Betsy Lehman, one day after what would have been Ben Kolb's eighth birthday - and marveled at what was going on around her.
 At the front of the room were representatives from Martin Memorial Hospital. Keeping their promise to the Kolb family, the group spent nearly two hours retelling the story of how and why the boy died. In the audience, fighting tears as they took notes, were more than 300 doctors, nurses, pharmacists and administrators, each of whom had been given a smiling photograph of the child at the three-day conference on "Examining Errors in Health Care."
 "Five years ago if we'd held this conference, very few people would have come," Leape, of Harvard, said at the opening session. But the list of sponsors included not only the A.M.A. and the joint commission, but also four medical insurance organizations, three pharmaceutical groups and the American Hospital Association.
 "This is a miracle that this is happening," Turnbull remembers thinking as the session concluded. "Everyone's telling the truth."
 In the months since Jose Martinez died, Turnbull has become an expert herself on the world of human factors research. She has done her root-cause analysis for the joint commission and learned a lot more about what went wrong that night: that the hospital's pharmacy was short one technician because someone called insick and that policies there require that the phone be answered in four rings and visitors greeted within five seconds of their arrival; that the nurse who questioned the order was trained in a country where women rarely confront men and nurses rarely confront doctors; that the first resident was distracted by personal problems. Turnbull has made changes, too, ones she hopes will be strong enough to make such human imperfections matter less. Hermann Hospital's computer now flags questionable orders for the most dangerous drugs, including Digoxin. The hospital is looking into a paging system that alerts a caller when the person being paged has his beeper turned off. Double copies of a prescription are no longer sent to the pharmacy unless it is a prescription that must be filled within 15 minutes.
 Administrators even asked the joint commission to schedule its accreditation review for April, not August, to ease the stress during the hospital's busiest month. Two research experiments are being planned to increase error reporting.
 As a result of Turnbull's analysis, and the accompanying changes, Hermann Hospital is no longer under "accreditation watch." On Dec. 27, 1996, it was given full accreditation, with commendation, the highest designation given by the joint commission.
 That brings satisfaction, she says, but mostly she feels sadness for the little boy and his family and concern for the staff members who are also still burdened by the event. She is wary, too, because everything she has learned tells her that no institution can ever be certain that something like this will not happen again. And she feels a sense of responsibility, an understanding that this moment and movement might well be seen as a crossroads for medicine. "We've become part of something," she says. "We want to make sure it is something that's done right."
 
To Err Is Human, Even in Medicine
 The most unsettling lesson of human factors research is this: Despite all best efforts, mistakes happen. Careful planning can reduce the number, and mitigate the consequences, but it cannot completely prevent mistakes.
 The aviation industry has learned that in the decade since it began to confront human error head-on. Crew training was over-hauled, equipment modified and procedures changed. The number of crashes attributed to human error (distinct from insufficient maintenance and aging airplanes) decreased significantly. So impressive were the changes, says John Nance, an aviation analyst, that the industry was feeling pleased with itself. Then, in December 1995, an airplane crashed outside Cali, Colombia - which was result of human error. Even with all the changes, tragedies continue.
 Now medicine is starting to grapple with the same lesson. One morning this winter, I was observing a meeting of the pediatric oncology staff at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. Suddenly the session was interrupted with the news that a 6-year-old patient had erroneously been given a double dose of his chemo medication.
 Perhaps no institution has been more aggressive in error prevention than Dana-Farber. And yet somehow a pharmacist had misread a confusing recipe card for Cytarabine, a drug used to fight leukemia. The error was caught because the pharmacist was given the same prescription for a second patient a few hours later. When he mixed that second prescription a mental alarm bell rang, and he realized he had made a mistake earlir in the day.
 By the time word reached this meeting, the medicine had already been administered. The first thing the staff did was look for someone to blame, taking momentary comfort in the fact that the overdose was not actually given at Dana-Farber: the little boy had visited the Dana-Farber clinic that morning but had been sent across the street, to Boston Children's Hospital, which is affiliated with Dana-Farber and has made most of the same procedural changes.
 "It's not our problem - it's Children's problem," one pediatric oncology fellow volunteered.
 "It's our patient, it's our service, it's our problem," his attending, Dr. Amy Billett, said sharply.
 All energy then turned to a search of the available literature to see what effects a double dose of Cytarabine would have on the child. Five doctors crammed into a closet-size office, reading textbooks and jounral articles aloud. Eventually Billett found a 1979 article revealing that early patients were given far larger doses of the drug with no evidence of toxicity. Relieved, the doctors decided no remedial action was called for. Then, armed with reassuring knowledge, they told the family.
 "A mistake was made," Billett remembers saying. "Your son received too much medication." She then assured the parents that their son was well, and was likely to remain well, although he would be closely monitored.
 "We were able to offer them reassurances," Billett says. "They were not particularly concerned."
 An internal investigation was begun immediately. The preparation card was changed so that it was less confusing. For Billett, for everyone, it was a sobering lesson. The staff learned that all the recent changes, all the heightened awareness, while necessary and effective, were far from foolproof.
 "You can never design a truly perfect system," Billett says. "There are no guarantees."

The What's Doing column on June 15, about Williamsburg, Va., misstated the given name of a man with whom Thomas Jefferson studied law. He was George Wythe, not Andrew.
 The cover of The Times Magazine today and an article on page 28 about medical mistakes render a prescription figure incorrectly. The order for digoxin given for Jose Eric Martinez, a 2-month-old who died in Hermann Hospital in Houston, was written as .90 milligram (not 0.9 milligram, a different way of writing the same amount). The dosage the child was supposed to receive, under the original doctor's orders, was .09 milligram. The 0.9 rendering was supplied by the Houston hospital; the error was discovered after the article had gone to press.
An article on June 15 about medical mistakes misidentified a Representative who in 1995 challenged a bill that would limit awards in malpractice suits. He is John Bryant, a Democrat from Texas, and not Ed Bryant, a Republican. (The article also misidentified Ed Bryant's state; he represents Tennessee, not California.)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1734 words

HEADLINE: A Faster Mousetrap

BYLINE: By George F. Will; George F. Will is a nationally syndicated columnist. His next book, "The Woven Figure: Conservatism and America's Fabric, 1994-1997," will be published this fall.

 BODY:

THE ONE BEST WAY
 Frederick Winslow Taylor
 and the Enigma of Efficiency.
 By Robert Kanigel.
 675 pp. New York:
 Viking. $34.95. 
 In November 1910 some railroads were trying to prove, as it had recently become their burden to do, that they merited Federal permission for rate increases. Representing opponents was Louis Brandeis, the future Justice, who questioned railroad officials about their costs. Were new efficiencies in operations an alternative to rate increases? No, said the railroaders. How did they know? Brandeis asked. Trust us, they said.
But Brandeis was in no mood to trust people who trusted their hunches, intuitions and experiences rather than the rising clerisy of experts. He caused a sensation by asserting that the railroads could save $1 million a day -- serious money then -- by "scientific management." How did he know? He knew about Frederick Winslow Taylor, who was about to become famous, and frequently unhappy, for the remaining five years of his life.
Taylor is still renowned among historians of American business. Peter Drucker, the well-known student of management, says that Taylor, not Marx, deserves to be ranked with Darwin and Freud in the trinity of makers of the modern world and that Taylorism is perhaps "the most powerful as well as the most lasting contribution America has made to Western thought since the Federalist Papers." Robert Kanigel's judgment is more measured: "The coming of Taylorism made our age what it was going to become anyway -- only more so, more quickly, more irrevocably." However, Mr. Kanigel's richly detailed biography, "The One Best Way: Frederick Winslow Taylor and the Enigma of Efficiency," shows how much drama there was in the mundane when Taylor was making it the stuff of a new "science" of efficiency.
Taylor, whose life (1856-1915) coincided with America's period of pell-mell industrialization, was born into an affluent, landed family in suburban Philadelphia. At the age of 13, during extended travel with his parents in Europe, he watched his impatient father use the power of his purse to get reluctant local laborers to repair a bridge so the family's touring could proceed. This was, for young Fred, an intensely practical epiphany: money can make working men move faster.
He was to become one of those men, briefly, and would use his years on the factory floor to achieve moral ascendancy through downward mobility. For the rest of his life he would invoke his laboring experience to claim the moral high ground in fierce debates about whether he understood, respected and served working people. At Phillips Exeter Academy (where, the saying was, there were "no rules, only absolute freedom, tempered by expulsion") he passed Harvard's admission exam with distinction. However, he chose to work in a factory making iron castings. There he learned that life is real, life is earnest.
He entered what Mr. Kanigel calls a "world of wood, iron, rope, leather, cloth," a world of steam power transmitted through belts and pulleys that amplified human muscle, which was abundant. Abundant and hence, Taylor saw, squandered. As he rose quickly into the ranks of management, he could act on his one seminal idea: the key to productivity is knowledge, not muscle power -- although sometimes the most important knowledge is how to organize the use of muscles.
The instruments of organization included stopwatches, with dials marking tenths and hundredths of a minute for easy calculations. Taylor's interest was less in what could be done in 10 hours than in 10 seconds. How much time did it take to perform a properly analyzed task -- fill a wheelbarrow, drive a nail, shovel coal? Assembly lines, like Ford's, or even disassembly lines, like those of Chicago's meatpackers, required the disassembly of work. "Amid the blur of activity of human work," Mr. Kanigel writes, "where did one element end and another begin?" Well, time-and-motion studies would tell. "Now, gentlemen, shoveling is a great science compared with pig-iron handling," Taylor said to a Congressional committee in 1912.
The committee was hostile and Taylor was bewildered. Theatrical in temperament, brimful of certitudes and vehement in expressing them, he was not just offended, he was uncomprehending when politicians and other people reacted furiously to his statements like: "In our scheme, we do not ask the initiative of our men. We do not want any initiative. All we want of them is to obey the orders we give them, do what we say, and do it quick." Although he could address workers with appalling brutality ("I have you for your strength and mechanical ability, and we have other men paid for thinking"), he considered himself a progressive, as did Brandeis, Ida Tarbell and other reformers.
This was, after all, a time of self-conscious modernity, defined in part by faith in science. In 1912 the nation would elect a political scientist President. There was a strong paternalistic streak in the progressivism of Walter Lippmann; Herbert Croly, the founder of The New Republic and leader of progressivism; and others who believed that modern life was too complicated for the untutored masses to cope with. A tutoring class, in government and business, would lead the people up from backward practices. However, it now seems that such workplace paternalism often is, well, inefficient. The unending search for enhanced productivity now often leads to something like workplace democracy, empowering the workers to help organize their toils.
In Mr. Kanigel's telling, there is much pathos in Taylor's sense of being ill used by critics. He was sure his system would dissolve tensions between labor and capital by demonstrating that high wages are not a problem but a solution. His mantra was "Men will not do an extraordinary day's work for an ordinary day's pay." So pay better for workers who will pay the price in new techniques for enhanced productivity. However, that price included more than the heightened stress of a more revved-up workplace. It also involved the moral insult of diminished prestige inherent in the transfer of all thinking from labor to the new management class. The result was a world of work that felt and even sounded different. As Mr. Kanigel says, "Everything clacked and whirred faster."
Taylor passionately believed Taylorism would raise what has come to be called the "standard of living." However, the controversy that engulfed him demonstrated that that concept is too complex to be reduced to a few indexes of material betterment. The man who helped ratchet up the level of stress in modern life may have had his life shortened -- he died the day after his 59th birthday -- by the strain of living with the controversy he caused. This in spite of the fact that in his last years he stopped to smell the roses: one of his final searches was for the one best way to cultivate them.
In 1916, the year after Taylor's death, Lenin passed some of his time in Zurich annotating a German translation of a Taylor book. The year after that, America's entry into World War I secured the nation's embrace of efficiency as a sovereign value and of Taylor as a prophet. In the 1920's a Parisian cleric declared, "The love of God is the Taylor System of our spiritual life." In 1927, at the end of an Italian conference on scientific management, Mussolini gave Taylor's widow a photograph of himself in exchange for one of Taylor. In 1928 the United States elected as President an engineer who had written a report on waste in industry. It has been reported that when Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times," with its depiction of a man meshed with a machine and reduced to a machinelike jerkiness of movements, was shown to audiences in industrial Pittsburgh, they did not find it funny.
Mr. Kanigel is an award-winning science writer, but his prose could use an infusion of efficiency. (He uses "kid-glove" as a verb.) And he is not as attentive to intellectual history as he should be. His scanting of that allows his narrative to suggest that Taylorism triggered a spanking new anxiety about a Faustian bargain that degrades workers while making them materially better off. Actually, that anxiety is as old as industrialism. Mr. Kanigel does cite Adam Smith's famous hymn to the division of labor in that pin factory where "one man draws out the wire, another straightens it, a third cuts it, a fourth points it, a fifth grinds it at the top for receiving the head," a process "divided into about 18 distinct operations." Smith was sanguine about this because specialization increases a worker's "dexterity," and hence "the quality of the work he can perform." However, Marx thought the division of labor produces alienation but that all would be well under Communism, "where nobody has one exclusive sphere of activity." He was vague about the details.
Mr. Kanigel could have lengthened the pedigree of the controversy that engulfed Taylor had he considered the fact that in the second quarter of the 19th century, when American industrialism was in its infancy, Alexis de Tocqueville anticipated the ambivalence that Taylor catalyzed early in this century: "When a workman is unceasingly and exclusively engaged in the fabrication of one thing, he ultimately does his work with singular dexterity; but, at the same time, he loses the general faculty of applying his mind to the direction of the work. He every day becomes more adroit and less industrious; so that it may be said of him, that, in proportion as the workman improves, the man is degraded."
Taylor's critics worried about both "deskilling" and the creation of an "aristocracy of the capable," and about work becoming scarce because of what is now called "downsizing" -- a productive few displacing the less fit. Mr. Kanigel believes, reasonably, that Taylor's legacy -- a new kind of seriousness about enhancing workers' productivity -- has been, on balance, benign. It certainly came in handy when Hitler was rampant. Mr. Kanigel quotes Mr. Drucker: during the war, "by applying Taylor's Scientific Management, U.S. industry trained totally unskilled workers, many of them former sharecroppers raised in a pre-industrial environment, and converted them in 60 to 90 days into first-rate welders and ship-builders." One ship, launched in South Portland, Me., in 1942, was the 7,176-ton S.S. Frederick W. Taylor.

 CORRECTION:
A review in The Times Book Review today, about "The One Best Way: Frederick Winslow Taylor and the Enigma of Efficiency," by Robert Kanigel, refers erroneously on page 10 to Adam Smith's description of the division of labor in "The Wealth of Nations." The reference should read, "Smith was sanguine about this because specialization increases a worker's 'dexterity,' and hence 'the quantity of the work he can perform' " (not "the quality").
Because of an editing error in the review, on page 8, a quotation from Frederick Winslow Taylor omits a word; the sentence should read, "In our scheme, we do not ask for the initiative of our men" (not "ask the initiative").

SECTION: Section D; Page 12; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
In a further push into Latin America, DDB Needham is buying a stake in a Brazilian agency.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
MADISON AVENUE giant is singing along to the Carmen Miranda tune "South American Way" -- and just like her, with a Brazilian accent.
DDB Needham Worldwide in New York, one of the three global agencies of Omnicom Group, has agreed to acquire a majority interest in DM9 Publicidade, a privately held, creatively focused agency based in Sao Paulo, Brazil. DM9, known for award-winning work for clients from brewers to banks, was ranked -- appropriately -- No. 9 among Brazilian agencies by the trade publication Advertising Age, with billings of $209.3 million in 1996. 
 When ranked by 1996 income of $48.6 million, an increase of 63.8 percent from 1995, DM9, which also has an office in Brasilia, placed seventh in the Advertising Age listings.
Though financial terms of the deal were not disclosed, DDB Needham, the No. 5 worldwide agency with billings last year of $967.7 million, will acquire about 60 percent of DM9 from its top managers for cash and Omnicom stock. DM9, founded in 1989, will be renamed DM9 DDB as it becomes part of the DDB Needham network, which has 12 offices in 10 South American countries.
The acquisition, the most recent in a skein by Omnicom and Omnicom-owned shops, will more than double the size of DDB Needham's Latin American operations, said Darryl Lindberg, president of DDB South America in New York.
The deal, announced on Friday, is indicative of the growing attention being paid to Latin America by both ad agencies and the multinational marketers for which they create campaigns.
"Latin America is a key area of focus for our clients and our prospects, too," Mr. Lindberg said.
"And Brazil is the largest country with the largest economy," he added. "It's a fantastic growth area."
Similar ardor was expressed on Friday by Young & Rubicam Advertising, which is making the first pan-regional purchase of television commercial time in Latin America for the Colgate-Palmolive Company. The purchase, made by Y.& R. Latin America in Miami, is estimated at $3 million to $4 million and covers 11 cable networks.
Commercials for big brands like Colgate toothpaste and Mennen antiperspirant will run on networks like CNN en Espanol, owned by Time Warner Inc.; ESPN, part of the Walt Disney Company, and Fox Sports, a unit of the News Corporation.
The clients of DM9 include multinational advertisers like Levi Strauss & Company; Electrolux A.B., the Swedish appliance maker; Parmalat Finanziaria S.p.A., the Italian food and dairy company, and the Schering-Plough Corporation, the pharmaceutical company. The agency also handles accounts of Brazilian marketers like Banco Itau, the country's second-largest bank, and Companhia Antarctica Paulista, Brazil's second-largest brewer.
It was for an ad for an Antarctica brand, Antarctica Diet Guarana, that won DM9 the Grand Award for print ads in 1994 in an international competition sponsored by the New York Festivals. DM9 also won a Clio Award that year and three awards from the Art Directors Club.
This year, for the fifth consecutive year, DM9 won the most awards in the Brazilian Creative Club competition. And the agency was a finalist in the print and cinema/television categories in the prestigious One Show sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy.
Mary Warlick, executive director of the One Club in New York, praised DM9's work, describing it as typical of South American agencies in being "very visually driven."
One factor driving the deal between DM9 and DDB Needham was a shared client, the Budweiser beer brand brewed by Anheuser-Busch Inc. Budweiser is made and sold in Brazil by a joint venture that is 51 percent owned by Anheuser-Busch and 49 percent by Antarctica.
Another factor behind the transaction, Mr. Lindberg said, was the creative heritages of both agencies. A predecessor agency of DDB Needham, Doyle Dane Bernbach, created legendary campaigns for brands like Volkswagen, Avis and Sony.
Nizan Guanaes, president of DM9, who will remain in that post after the acquisition, paid tribute to a co-founder of Doyle Dane. "It's a great honor for a copywriter like me to be a partner in Bill Bernbach's agency," he said in a statement.
Mr. Lindberg compared DM9 to BMP DDB, the creatively focused British agency of DDB Needham. BMP DDB was the offspring of a deal made eight years ago, when Omnicom bought Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership. The London office of Boase Massimi, BMP Davidson Pearce, was merged with DDB Needham's London office to form BMP DDB, now the No. 4 British agency in billings, according to the trade publication Campaign.
Negotiations between DDB Needham and DM9 began "a few months ago," said Mr. Lindberg, who will oversee DM9 DDB. Mr. Lindberg reports to Bernard Brochand, president of the DDB Needham international division.

HEADLINE: Opening a Conversation on Race

 BODY:
In proposing a year-long national "conversation" about race, President Clinton put the nation's most important social problem where it belongs, at the top of the national agenda. His speech on Saturday at commencement exercises of the University of California at San Diego was a sermon with little sanctimonious preaching. He went beyond the obvious need for racial justice to the practical and even economic reasons why the United States must nurture its increasingly diverse society.
For a President with a reputation of trying hard to please, it took political audacity to stand up for affirmative action in the very state and university system that had begun dismantling this essential remedy against injustice. Reaching out to those on the other side of the issue, Mr. Clinton said Californians were doing this "without any ill motives" and from a sincere conviction that racial discrimination is no longer a significant barrier to success. But the President rightly implored Americans not to follow that path, which would only turn their public universities and private workplaces into segregated islands of privilege. 
 A generation ago, as Mr. Clinton noted, the Kerner Commission warned that the United States was in danger of becoming two nations, one black and one white. Today the country's ethnic difficulties are far more varied and subtle. In another generation, the President said, the United States will encompass ethnic minorities from across the world. It will be of great social and practical importance to harness such diversity to improve the quality of life for everyone and create an economy that can engage in an even more diverse global marketplace.
The President spoke at a time when ethnic and religious conflict has erupted throughout the world. He foresees a historic role for the United States, leading the way to a new definition of nationhood in which diversity is a strength, not a weakness.
President Clinton's speech evoked skepticism and criticism from partisans on both sides of the racial divide. Foes of affirmative action were disappointed that he did not reject what they consider to be the failed path of quotas and racial preferences. Advocates of more aggressive action on race and poverty were disappointed that he did not commit more resources for job-training and education. They express lingering bitterness over the welfare law enacted last year that is likely to deepen poverty and racial despair. The President focused on the future, however, and encouraged his newly appointed advisory panel, with the historian John Hope Franklin as its chairman, to listen before making recommendations.
The appreciative applause from the Californians at the graduation this weekend was a welcome sign that the issues of race, affirmative action and diversity can be discussed candidly. If Mr. Clinton's speech starts such a process, and leads to concrete actions, it could be remembered as a turning point for him and the country. Let the conversation proceed.

HEADLINE: Dutch Take 'Third Way' to Prosperity

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM

 BODY:
The Dutch are used to living with a potent mix of neighbors often seen here as more pushy or flamboyant than themselves. They watch the mighty Germans, the elitist French and the insular British and sometimes get a little sour about being ignored while others drive European affairs.
So it is with some amusement that the Dutch suddenly find themselves upheld as a model for the rest of Europe. 
 In the weeks preceding the meeting of European leaders that begins here on June 16, foreign economists, sociologists and union and political figures have visited seeking to understand what has kept the Netherlands so stable, prosperous and curiously without strikes.
 As Europeans wring their hands over what is usually presented as a choice between heartless American-style modernizing of their economies and preserving the old European social safety nets, many people say the Dutch have found a "third way" combining an open, vigorous market with generous social benefits and a measure of social justice.
Critics point to the high percentage of temporary jobs and social benefits that they say are still too expensive. But for the last five years the Dutch economy has grown faster than those of Britain, France and Germany, and unemployment -- at 6.5 percent -- is well below that of the large European countries.
The Dutch example has begun to gain wide attention with the approach of next year's deadline for the strict criteria countries must meet if they want to join the common European currency. Countries aspiring to use the currency, called the euro, are in the midst of austerity programs that have led to social unrest and antagonized voters. Leaders at the meeting here are expected to sign an accord aimed at insuring the euro's stability.
The Dutch say they have invented nothing new by keeping down wages, inflation and interest rates, and by easing the rules for hiring and firing and for opening new businesses.
But what is different here, often astonishing foreign analysts and investors, is the painstaking consensus building that has avoided social unrest and made wide changes possible. In contrast to the convulsions of bigger neighbors like Britain, France and Spain, the Dutch have worked on avoiding ideological confrontations and for more than a decade have sustained a pact between left and right. As long as unions accepted financial discipline, management has not demanded the dismantling of the welfare state as the price of investing and creating jobs.
In May, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based research organization of the industrialized nations, noted the Dutch success. It said the country had found a way to tackle unemployment and introduce reforms "through a consensual process, involving the social partners and clearly not threatening social cohesion."
A recent scene in Amsterdam would have been hard to imagine in London or Paris: the leader of the biggest labor confederation, addressing a workers' congress, declared with passion that it was vital to maintain the strength of the Dutch currency and of the planned European currency. In the front row was the president of the Netherlands central bank, Wim Duisenberg, who applauded, beaming.
"I might have phrased it a little differently," he said afterward, "but I could sign my name to this."
Such a fraternal scene is not unusual for this country, whose Prime Minister, Wim Kok, was himself a labor leader.
Now in the spotlight as the host for the European meeting, Mr. Kok has a reputation as a skillful negotiator. He is widely credited as the chief architect of the "social pact" between Government, employers and unions that has insured stability.
As the country's top labor leader, in 1982 he helped launch the pact under which labor federations kept to wage demands of 2 percent per year in exchange for shorter work weeks and more jobs. He stuck to austerity as the Finance Minister from 1989 to 1994, the year he became Prime Minister as leader of a left-right coalition. On a Continent where people are widely disgruntled with politicians, his approval ratings have remained high.
The Dutch say their achievements have come from tough negotiations. Cuts in unemployment benefits have pushed people back to work, and the large number of workers calling in sick dropped when new laws shifted the burden of sick pay to employers. As Cees Oudshoorn, an official at the Ministry of Economy put it, "The Dutch miracle, if it exists at all, is that our labor unions could be convinced to rally around a free-market economy."
Signs of a flourishing market abound. On the outskirts of Amsterdam and around Rotterdam, the world's busiest port, new office parks have drawn foreign companies. Consumers are driving up sales in stores, which only last year got permission to stay open after 6 and on Sundays.
One telling indicator is the growth of job agencies, which have expanded by 50 percent in the past four years. They advertise a plethora of vacancies in technical jobs, services, sales and health care.
To draw more people, especially women, into the work force, the Government has deregulated work hours, allowing previously unthinkable part-time and temporary contracts. This has made job agencies into a growth industry, now employing more than 12,000 people. Randstad, the largest temporary help chain, had a staff of 1,600 in 1993 and has 2,800 today.
"We know where the shortages are, and we help companies plan their work force," said Maarten den Ottolander, a Randstad director. "In the past, temporary jobs could last only six months, but now that they are unlimited, the agencies' role in the market is becoming very big."
One result of the new flexibility is that the Dutch now have Europe's most developed temporary job market. Critics complain that it is a serious weakness that one-third of Dutch jobs are now temporary or part-time. But part-timers still get benefits like vacation and health insurance, and after six months they begin accumulating pension rights.
Hersta de Goede, in her early 20's, is herself doing temporary work at Randstad and represents the view of many people just out of school. "I'd prefer to work full-time," she said. "But this is better than no work."
Nicolette Koopman, 23, works three days a week at an Amsterdam bookshop. She said she preferred this to full-time work. "It gives me time to do other things," she said. "If I need more money, I can get extra odd jobs."
The lively temporary job market seems indeed a boon for young people here, compared with France, where 27 percent of young people are unemployed. But things look worse for workers over 35. Specialists say that the easy-come, easy-go market makes it harder for older employees, because they are more expensive and seen as working less hard.
Skeptics say the Dutch still have a way to go before all the unaffordable fat from the welfare state is trimmed. Some 800,000 people in a population of 15 million draw disability pay for mild or vague ailments, including "stress." That is 100,000 fewer than three years ago, when the Government tightened the rules.
Other problems loom. Religious leaders have warned that inequality has risen with the more competitive market. An aging population means that today's benefits may not go on, as workers paying for them become proportionately fewer.
Yet other Europeans have said that they wish their statistics were as rosy as the Dutch, and that they were as skilled at avoiding political conflict. Whether the Dutch social contract is exportable is unclear. The country has long been governed by coalitions and may be more used to deal-making and compromise than other European countries.
The endless meetings and debates that come with the Dutch consensus model can seem exasperating to foreign businessmen. But some foreigners note that the lengthy sessions in which the Dutch thrash out ways to live together -- "a kind of never-ending group therapy," in the words of one diplomat -- have recognizable results. The approach has produced a level of trust in the system.
"It's enough to make politicians in France envious," one French resident said.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Take a personal computer. Shrink it. Add a Windows operating system. Now what?

BYLINE: By Michelle Slatalla 

 BODY:
THE first generation of hand-held computing devices using software that looks and feels like the familiar Microsoft Windows operating system is now on the market, with products from seven different hardware makers. In fact many of these products will be on display this week at the PC Expo industry bazaar in Manhattan. But many analysts say that at $500 or more, the Microsoft-based gadgets so far pose no serious challenge to the popular Palm Pilot by U.S. Robotics.
The reason is simple. The Palm Pilot, whose introduction last year revitalized the moribund hand-held computing market, relied on a radical idea: Stop trying to replace the personal computer and instead create a PC extension, an easy-to-use, fit-in-your-pocket device to automate the keeping of calendars, to-do lists and phone files and other workday data. And sell it for less than $300. 
 The Pilot strategy paid off. So far more than one million of the units have been sold, capturing about 70 percent of sales in the growing hand-held market and creating the kind of grass-roots support among programmers and hackers not seen since the early days of the PC.
By comparison, Microsoft's strategy of adapting its popular Windows operating system to a tiny new hardware platform has not impressed many analysts, who say the devices are too expensive and try too hard to emulate PC's -- but with inferior screens and cramped keyboards.
"They've just made a mini-PC, shrunk it down," said Tom Rhinelander, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "And maybe that's neat from an engineering perspective, but not from a user's perspective. But the Microsoft devices aren't going to be the successful devices, because of size and function and what they try to do. They're too big, they're not designed for what people will use really small mobile devices for."
While no one is willing to release early sales figures for the Microsoft-based hand-helds, recent market surveys by both Dataquest and PC Data Research Studies indicate that U.S. Robotics' Pilot still has a substantial lead over all competitors.
"The Pilot defined the market for a hand-held device," said Mike McGuire, Dataquest's senior industry analyst for mobile computing. "Is there room for Windows CE in the category? Perhaps. But the Pilot operating system, which was designed solely for that device, is almost Zen-like in the way it's built."
The lesson, in the case of the Pilot, is that a successful hand-held device is one that moves information back and forth from the desktop, not one that creates information. The Pilot does not even have a keyboard; users rely on hand-writing recognition and hook up the device to their PC's to download data or electronic-mail messages.
Users of Pilot can also jot down upcoming appointments, update contact lists and compose simple messages they want to send later. At the end of the day, users connect the Pilot to their PC's to transfer the information to their desktop machines.
"People said you can't do a product like this without wireless communications. But we tried to see through what people say they want, and give them what they really want," said Donna Dubinsky, general manager of the palm computing division of U.S. Robotics.
In contrast, the Microsoft devices support wireless communications, as well as spreadsheet and word-processing programs. The Microsoft devices also have the Internet TCP/IP software protocols built in, which give the user the capability to connect directly to the Net for sending and receiving E-mail and to browse the World Wide Web. Many analysts say, however, that those are activities better suited to the keyboards and screens of much larger computers.
But don't count Microsoft out. The mere fact of the software giant's announcement last year that it was entering the hand-held market with Windows CE (the CE stands for consumer electronics) lent legitimacy to a then-struggling industry.
Not only did major hardware vendors like Hewlett-Packard, NEC, Casio and Compaq sign deals to create Windows CE devices costing $500 to $700 apiece, but software developers took interest, too. That is because developers, who already know how to write applications for Windows, can use the same tools to create programs for CE devices -- which means plenty of programs to run equally well on all the different brands of CE hand-helds.
Still, while Microsoft is already focused on the second generation of hand-helds, code-named Griffin, the real success of Windows CE may come in a different arena altogether. The operating system is powerful and flexible enough to run any number of devices -- from digital telephones to television set-top boxes. (Remember Microsoft's deal in April to acquire Web TV?)
"We always had bigger purposes in mind for where Windows CE would be used, and hand-helds was just the first place where it wound up," said Jim Floyd, a product manager for hand-held PC's at Microsoft.
Microsoft is already working toward using Windows CE in a whole new category of computers that analysts call "ultra-ultra-portables." Such a unit would weigh about 2.5 pounds and cost less than $1,000, or about half the price and half the weight of today's portables.
Add a battery life of at least eight hours, and ultra-ultra-portables could replace notebooks and laptops for most mobile professionals. In a computer like that, with a full-size keyboard and monitor, users might welcome the chance to run Word and Excel and the other more sophisticated applications that CE supports.
As for the Pilot? Its makers are happy to stay put in the category the Pilot defined, thank you. "You can imagine us putting more functionality into more or less the same form or maybe reducing the size," Ms. Dubinsky said. "But we'll keep the same functionality."

HEADLINE: THE FINE PRINT: A close look at a tax break;
Tax Bill's Complexities Often Aid the Wealthy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
"Beset with invisible boomerangs."
That's the way the Justice Robert H. Jackson of the Supreme Court described the hidden dangers of tax laws in a 1952 opinion. 
 The bill the House Ways and Means Committee approved last week is a good illustration of just what Justice Jackson was talking about.
Take, for example, a provision in the bill that would exempt from capital gains taxation up to $500,000 of the profits a couple made from the sale of their home but would set the exemption for a single person at $250,000.
That caused great mirth among several of the lawyers, lobbyists and accountants who spent breaks in the committee's sessions this week trying to puzzle out unintended consequences in the bill the way other people might work on crosswords.
An accountant said he had an elderly client outside Philadelphia who had a house worth more than $1 million and who he knew would look for a marriage of convenience if the $500,000 exemption became law.
"I can just see this guy finding himself an old lady somewhere and getting married and selling his house and then dumping her like a sack of potatoes," the accountant said.
A lawyer thought of a corollary: "Say your husband's on his death bed and you've got this house with a big capital gain. You'd better sell it quick before he dies."
These people were mostly joking. But they also saw a more serious consequence that was being overlooked in the section of the bill dealing with capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments. The bill would lower the top capital gains tax rate, now 28 percent, to 10 percent for taxpayers with incomes below $41,200 and to 20 percent for those who were better off.
The main beneficiaries of the 10 percent rate, the tax experts said, would not be middle-income taxpayers selling a modest amount of mutual funds. Instead, it would be wealthy families who were selling stock to pay for their children's tuition. They could cut the taxes in half by giving their appreciated stock to their children and having the children sell it, rather than selling it themselves and paying the higher tax because of their higher income.
That is not the only instance in which the bill would give a better tax break to affluent people sending their children to college than it would give to taxpayers who were less well off.
The bill would allow parents to put money into an educational investment account, similar to an individual retirement account, in which interest and dividends would accumulate tax-free. The money could then be withdrawn to pay college expenses. The Democratic staff of the Ways and Means Committee calculated that a family that could afford to invest $50,000 in such an account when a child was 8 years old would save almost $4,000 a year in taxes on a $22,500 annual tuition bill when the child reached college age. Under the bill, a family that could not afford to put aside so much money in advance and had to meet the college costs from income and student loans would get a tax break of only $1,500 a year, and that would be available only for the first two years of college.
If all this sounds complicated, it is. That is somewhat embarrassing to the principal author of the bill, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, who has made a career of complaining about how complicated the income tax system is.
Mr. Archer commented on the paradox in his opening statement to the committee on Thursday evening. Holding up the 422-page bill, he said, "When you look at a tax bill that's this thick, you know it's not going to simplify things for the taxpayer."
Then, to make sure no one thought he had changed his stripes, he quickly added, "This in no way hinders my ultimate goal of abolishing the income tax system."
The most "fabulously complicated" part of the legislation, said Jeffery L. Yablon, a prominent tax lawyer here, is the provision that would allow investors to adjust the value of their capital gains to take account of inflation, a process known in tax lingo as indexation.
Here is how it would work. Say an investor bought stock for $100, held it for three years and then sold it for $110, and assume the inflation in overall prices in the economy was a total of 9 percent for the three years.
Under the law now, the investor would report a capital gain of $10. But if the law allowed indexation, the taxable gain would be only $1.
Sounds simple enough. But here is the problem. Many people buy stock with borrowed money and take a deduction for the interest they pay on their loan. So if the investor borrowed the money at an interest rate of 4 percent, his tax statement would show a loss of $3 ($1 profit minus $4 deduction), although he had actually made a profit on his investment even after adjusting for inflation.
"Borrowed money is a killer," Mr. Yablon said. "If you index the basis of assets, you have to index the basis of debt, and once you start doing that, you have insane, wild ramifications."
Not all of the boomerangs in the bill are invisible. One would require that labor unions report to their members on a special form the percentage of the members' dues that are used for political activities. The unions say this reporting would cost them more than $20 million.
Republicans concede that the provision was not put in the bill for tax reasons. It was added because Republican lawmakers were irritated by how active organized labor was on behalf of Democrats in last year's election. The Republicans think that union members would rebel if they knew how much of their dues was used for political purposes.
Another item in the bill would have completely expected consequences. The measure would allow some large bakery companies, like Pepperidge Farm, Freihofer's and Arnold, to designate certain drivers as independent contractors, which would mean that the companies would not be required to pay the drivers' Social Security, Medicare and unemployment compensation taxes.
Why should the bakers get something not available to butchers and candlestick makers?
"They have a better lobbyist," a Ways and Means Committee staff member explained.
Asked about this, Rob Mackie, a lobbyist for the American Bakers Association, replied, "I'd like to think we finally got our act together."
