HEADLINE: In America;
The Respect Divide

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Corey Arthur made virtually no effort to conceal his role in the murder of Jonathan Levin, investigators said.
Detectives believe that Mr. Arthur, 19 years old, bounced around on the subways in the day or two before Mr. Levin's death, trying to persuade first one and then another acquaintance to join him in the fatal scheme. 
 After the widely admired 31-year-old high school teacher had been stabbed, shot and robbed in his Upper West Side apartment, Mr. Arthur, like so many other young violent offenders, could hardly wait to tell friends what he had done, police said.
"He was boasting about it," said a veteran homicide detective. "They all do it. They want their peers to know."
Mr. Arthur left a message on Mr. Levin's telephone answering machine before the murder and reportedly left personal items in the apartment afterward. He never really tried to hide. He never fled.
"He even even kept the bloody clothes," the detective said. "For what? Souvenirs? He might as well have dialed 911 and said come get me."
Some people hit game-winning jump shots at the buzzer. Some save lives on the operating table. Some write hit songs. It doesn't matter what they do. It's all about respect. They want their peers to know.
In the world inhabited by Corey Arthur there are an extraordinary number of hapless individuals, mostly male, who roam the streets and ride the subways raging at their insignificance, at their isolation and chronic inability to deal successfully with the larger world, at the contempt and disdain with which they are viewed by so many, including themselves.
They are obsessed with gaining respect. Unable to achieve it in more conventional ways, many turn to violence. A Brooklyn teen-ager once said to me, "Nobody disses you when you've got a gun on 'em."
Corey Arthur (who has been indicted, along with a co-defendant, in Mr. Levin's murder) had very little going for him. He wanted to be a rap star but his talent was limited. He had a police record. He was expelled from William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx, where he first met Mr. Levin. He had a drug habit. An acquaintance quoted in a Times story said: "He always wanted to have money but never wanted to get a job. His M.O. was to stick black people up or whoever he can."
Mr. Arthur may not have known that Jonathan Levin had come from an extremely wealthy family, but it's a safe bet that he envied what he saw as his ex-teacher's exalted status. Jonathan Levin got lots of respect; Corey Arthur got none. Whatever happens to Mr. Arthur (the options range from acquittal to execution), it is in that deep and destructive divide that we need to be working if we want to prevent the many tragedies that flow from the sense of worthlessness that is felt by so many potentially violent youngsters.
It is the tallest of orders, and not at all for the faint of heart. Families have to be knitted back together and fathers brought back into the home. Children have to be taught to read and to reason in schools that are secure and in good repair. Attitudes have to be changed so that violence loses its cachet and teen-agers don't feel that after killing someone they are entitled to turn around and take a bow. Punishment for those who harm others should be swift and certain and severe.
Also, civil rights organizations, ever vigilant to external threats, need to devote at least as much energy to the enemies within. And the men and women with their hands on the levers of the economy need to be made aware that a saner, safer society depends on employment opportunities being available to everyone who can work.
Many people are already hard at work on these matters. (Jonathan Levin was one. He had a gift for honing the talents and ratcheting up the esteem of his students.) But the task is enormous and getting bigger. The demographers tell us a huge new wave of teen-agers is almost upon us. We can engage them and guide their energy and talents along constructive paths. Or we can ignore them, and wait for the weakest and most desperate among them to seek their measure of respect and the applause of their peers by squeezing the trigger of a gun.

HEADLINE: A Year Out of Bankruptcy, Orange County Hits the Road

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., June 15

 BODY:
A year after emerging from the nation's largest municipal bankruptcy, Orange County is heralding the anniversary with an itinerant coming-out party in five cities.
In presentations to investment fund managers, bond-rating agencies and insurers over the next three weeks, local officials will try to repair the county's junk-bond credit rating by describing its fiscal health, which is being aided by California's vibrant economy. 
 Five local officials, including William Steiner, the chairman of the county's board of supervisors, and Jan Mittermeier, the county's chief executive, are arguing that Wall Street should restore the county to its pre-bankruptcy investment-grade status because its government has improved oversight of investment decisions and because the region of 2.5 million residents is financially healthy. Onerous conditions imposed on the county's new debt securities in the wake of its fiscal crisis have cost taxpayers more than $30 million, Mrs. Mittermeier said.
"It's a good story," said John Pizzarelli, managing director of public finance for MBIA Inc., the nation's largest bond insurer, who heard the county's pitch in New York on Wednesday, the day before the one-year anniversary. "You've got a sizzling economy putting the wind in their sails."
In the aftermath of its $1.6 billion investment loss and December 1994 bankruptcy filing, Orange County issued $1.4 billion in bonds backed by MBIA insurance, but at three or four times the normal cost. Without insurance to buoy the creditworthiness of the county's notes, all the issues would have fallen below investment grade and would have to bear a higher interest rate to offset the higher risk for investors. Of the $180 billion in municipal bonds sold last year, 48 percent carried insurance, up from 43 percent in 1995.
Now, if MBIA was to insure an Orange County issue, "we would give them a break on pricing," Mr. Pizzarelli said, "because things have gotten better." He said he was reassured by the county's efforts to rein in expenses, impose more discipline on issuing new debt and its revenue boom from rising sales and property taxes. Still, "some people are going to need more convincing," he acknowledged.
Among the messages emphasized by local officials are a second wave of post-bankruptcy budget cuts that will trim 220 positions and $10 million in costs, effective July 1, and a credit management policy that includes a reserve fund to retire high-priced debt.
The county has no immediate plans to return to the capital markets for new debt, although refinancing of some issues may be considered, Mrs. Mittermeier said. These include $155 million in so-called Teeter notes, which are secured by delinquent property taxes.
"I don't think we should be in the market until the market feels more comfortable with us," Mrs. Mittermeier said. That, she said, would be signaled by a change in the county's investment rating, which now is below investment grade at Moody's and Standard & Poor's. "We think we should have investment- grade rating three or four years from now."
Stephanie Peterson, the vice president of municipal research for the Charles Schwab Corporation, agreed that Orange County's road show would probably improve Wall Street's comfort level. "They want the market to appreciate that Orange County has put the bankruptcy behind them," she said.
Others are skeptical that the county's story, no matter how good, is enough to erase the investor insecurity caused by the municipal crises. In the end, Orange County bondholders were paid in full without a taxpayer bailout. The county engineered an elaborate plan to repay its debts by diverting funds coming into some of the county's agencies. Some municipalities agreed to accept only 80 cents on the dollar for claims they had against losses in the county's investment pool, with the remainder to be made up from hoped-for proceeds of litigation filed by the county against its former financial advisers.
"There is a lingering issue of trust that takes time to restore," said Stephen B. Ward, Schwab's chief investment officer. "The county reached into a bag of tricks that others didn't. People will have to be convinced that that's really over. It will take a solid record over time. What will really dispel it is another recession. They recovered during a recovery."
One municipal bond portfolio manager, who spoke on condition of anonymity, predicted the county would be forced to pay slightly higher interest rates on its debt securities for up to 15 years, just like the penalty still attached to bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System, which defaulted on $2.3 billion in bonds on two nuclear power plants in 1983. "The stigma will not go away," he said.

HEADLINE: Voting Shows Croatia, in Effect, Annexed Bosnia Region

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: MOSTAR, Bosnia and Herzegovina, June 15

 BODY:
The red-and-white flags hanging along the tree-lined streets were Croatian. The posters of President Franjo Tudjman were the same as those plastered on billboards in the Croatian capital, Zagreb. And throngs of voters filed through the gate of the Mostar polling station today by showing their blue Croatian passports to the police.
In theory this region is part of the American-brokered federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In fact, it has been annexed by Croatia, in one of the most flagrant violations of the Dayton peace agreement. The Bosnian Croats vote in Croatian elections and have their local leadership as well as their military financed and directed by Zagreb. 
 In the voting for president, Mr. Tudjman, 75 and seriously ill with cancer, appeared tonight to be headed toward a landslide victory for a second five-year term. He has been increasingly criticized by Washington, and it was in this city that the raw intolerance of his hard-line nationalism and the duplicity of his dealings with the outside world were most visible.
"You have Bosnian Croats in the diaspora, who have never lived in Croatia, voting in this election," a Western diplomat said of the some 400,000 voters who live here and in other countries, "while hundreds of thousands of Serb citizens from Croatia, who spent their whole lives here, are denied the right to vote."
Croatia's economy, burdened by outdated industry and mismanagement, is limping along at 55 percent of the capacity it had before the Bosnian war. The currency is overvalued, the foreign trade deficit is widening, and unemployment is at least 20 percent.
Mr. Tudjman is, nevertheless, lionized as the man who in 1991 led Croatia's independence from the old Yugoslavia and created the modern Croatian state.
"He is the father of our country," said Drago Pezic, 76, a former platoon commander during the fascist Ustashe government that ruled Croatia in World War II. "He gave to us our state after 900 years of being ruled by others. He brought all Croats under one roof. He got rid of the Serbs. He finally won the war we started in 1941 and lost to the Communists."
In the process, Mr. Tudjman purged 500,000 of 600,000 ethnic Serbs from the country and carried out the de facto annexation of the largely Catholic region of Herzegovina. In short, he gave Croats an "ethnically pure" state.
"What have I promised that I have not fulfilled?" the President asked a cheering crowd in his last campaign rally on Thursday in Zagreb.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, during a visit to Croatia this month, strongly condemned recent violent attacks on remaining minority Serbs, most of them elderly, who were driven from their homes. She also expressed her displeasure with Mr. Tudjman's refusal to hand over indicted war criminals, may of whom have taken refuge in Mostar, to the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
Washington, which considered Zagreb an ally during the war in Bosnia, in large part because of its willingness to permit clandestine shipments of Iranian arms to the Bosnian Muslims, now appears to have lost patience.
Senior American officials say they intend to begin blocking development loans, applications into Western trade bodies and military alliances. A $13 million loan granted to Croatia a few days ago was approved several weeks ago and was not large enough to reconvene international lender organizations to block, they said.
"Most Croatians do not yet realize what this isolation will cost them in economic and security terms," a senior Western diplomat said.
The election campaign here has been as bombastic and stilted as those once waged by the Communists. The state-run media, including all nationwide radio and television stations, have slavishly exalted Mr. Tudjman and his governing Croatian Democratic Union.
While Mr. Tudjman was deified, his two opponents, who rarely appeared in the state-run media, were described as "enemies of the state."
If none of the candidates win more than 50 percent of the votes, the two top-placed finishers are scheduled to compete again on June 29. But such a runoff, given Mr. Tudjman's popularity, is unlikely.
The two opposition candidates are expected to receive no more than 30 percent of the vote when the final results are released on Monday.
Those beleaguered candidates, Vlado Gotovac of the Social Liberal Party and Zdravko Tomac of the Social Democrats, were even assaulted by enraged Croats during the campaign.
Mr. Gotovac, a 66-year-old poet who has called for the return of ethnic Serbs, was knocked unconscious and hospitalized by a captain in Mr. Tudjman's presidential guard at a rally in the city of Pula. During the assault, during which the officer punched Mr. Gotovac and beat him over the head with the metal buckle on his army belt, the officer shouted, "Long live Ante Pavelic!"
Mr. Pavelic was the fascist dictator who ruled Croatia in the Second World War and oversaw the slaughter of hundreds of thousands of Serbs, Gypsies, Jews and Croatian opposition leaders.
Mr. Tomac, the head of the reconstituted Communist Party, campaigned from a van, and his vehicle was stoned twice by angry mobs. He was denied a permit to hold a campaign rally in Zagreb on Friday.
Mr. Tudjman, during his second term, will oversee the reintegration of the last Serbian enclave, now administered by a United Nations mission, into Croatia. The enclave, called Eastern Slavonia, was seized by rebel Serbs at the start of the 1991 war. Two other rebel enclaves were taken by force in 1995 by the Croatian Army. During the capture, the army drove 250,000 Serbs who lived in the enclaves out of the country.
The refusal by Zagreb to permit all but a handful of the exiled Serbs to return home, as called for in the Dayton agreement, has led Washington to call for an extension of the United Nations mandate in Eastern Slavonia beyond the scheduled July 15 turnover date.
There are, however, other disturbing consequences of this unbridled nationalism.
The looting and seizure of tens of thousands of Serbian homes, especially in southern Croatia, has empowered a lawless and dangerously violent segment of Croatian society that has taken over cities like Mostar. The city remains divided between ethnic Croats and Muslims, who live in what is little more than an eastern ghetto and have no access to the Croatian section of Mostar.
Luxury cars, many stolen from Italy, German and Switzerland, according to international police monitors, clog Mostar's streets. And local mafias in Croat-controlled west Mostar, despite some arrests by Zagreb, collect protection money from shop owners, intimidate local officials and run vast prostitution, counterfeiting and drug rackets that reach into Milan and Frankfurt.
The leaders of Mr. Tudjman's party, including members of his family, along with this growing mafia, have acquired vast riches in the state's murky privatization program.

HEADLINE: Deep Anxiety Over the Coming Election in Albania

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: TIRANA, Albania, June 15

 BODY:
Preparations for parliamentary elections intended to put this chaotic country on the road to normalcy are in such a state of disarray that the voting could result in more chaos, European and Albanian officials said today.
Both sides said that despite the threat of violence, the elections, to be conducted in the presence of a European security force, should proceed on June 29. But each side blamed the other for the lack of such basics as candidate lists and for an atmosphere of disorder that seems likely to inhibit effective election-day monitoring, even with more than 6,000 European troops on hand. 
 "One thing is for sure, though some effort has been made, this bird doesn't fly," said Gerard Stoudmann, a Swiss diplomat who is leading the election assistance group here for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. "There are a lot of deficiencies in the preparations and there is nothing more we can do."
Mr. Stoudmann evidently wants to distance the 54-country European organization from what may happen on election day. He said he would tell participants in a meeting in Vienna on Wednesday that will include Franz Vranitzky, the former Austrian Chancellor and chief representative of the European group on the Albanian crisis, that the Albanians should bear the responsibility.
"There's been a truckload of advice given to them and they have not been in a position to do these things because of the state of the country," Mr. Stoudmann said.
But the chairman of the Albanian Central Election Commission, Kristaq Kume, said today that he had implored the European forces to help by escorting him and other election officials to dangerous parts of the country but had been turned down. "I'm worried about violence on election day," he said.
Much of Albania spiraled into armed rebellion in March over the collapse of spurious financial schemes that investors blamed on the authoritarian Government of President Sali Berisha. New elections were perceived by the United States and Western Europe as the most calming solution to the crisis.
Albania, which was run into the ground by 50 years of rigid Communist rule, is the poorest country in Europe and has a population of only three million.
But the State Department worries that the mass of armaments that were taken in raids on warehouses or given away to Mr. Berisha's supporters during the rebellion could filter into neighboring Kosovo in Yugoslavia and into Macedonia, which have large Albanian populations.
Italy, whose eastern coastline faces Albania across the Adriatic Sea, received 16,000 Albanian refugees during the crisis and wants to shut down the flow. Greece, where hundreds of thousands of illegal Albanian immigrants provide a cheap work force, is also concerned about an influx of more refugees.
The management of the Albanian situation has been a test case for the ability of the Europeans to deal with a crisis in their own backyard.
Italy, as the country with the most direct historical, economic and emotional interest in Albania, pressed to take the lead. But its role has been plagued with mishaps.
The European military force, dominated by the Italians, is seen by many Albanians as being too passive in the face of local violent crime and thuggery. One American diplomat criticized the force as behaving more like "Boy Scouts than soldiers."
Another American diplomat, who specializes in the Balkans, said the Europeans failed to realize that Albania was a "third world country that's having a meltdown" and that it needed stronger support than it was receiving.
The dispute over the role of the foreign military force is at the heart of the potential for trouble on election day. So far, Mr. Berisha has insisted that the polling places be allowed to stay open until 9 P.M.
But the Italian military has told election supervisors that its mandate does not allow it to accompany monitors or balloting results from polling places to local election headquarters after dark. The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe has said that in the armed environment of Albania it is too unsafe for monitors to be left at remote polling places without military escorts.
Thus, the European security organization, along with the Council of Europe and other monitoring organizations, is faced with not being able to guarantee the safety of monitors who stay at polling places while the vote is being counted. Other monitoring organizations agreed today with Mr. Stoudmann's conclusions.
The National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, a Government-funded group based in Washington that has been an observer in four Albanian elections, issued a report tonight saying its visiting delegation was not confident that "minimum conditions" would exist on election day. The institute said that Albania's "most-senior politicians" shared responsibility for the "profound crisis gripping the country and they have not yet done enough to instruct their respective supporters to lay down their weapons."
But it urged the European security organization and the military force to make more concerted efforts to distribute and collect election materials.
An official of the Council of Europe, Uwe Muller, said he was discouraged to find that during a spot check Friday, only 3 of 10 election commission stations here in the capital were functioning. Most did not have staff present, and one did not even have a sign, he said. Tirana is supposed to be the best-prepared for the elections.
Some major towns, particularly in the south where the insurrection started and where there is almost a total lack of either civilian or military authority, have not reported lists of candidates to the Central Election Commission, Mr. Kume said.
At his election commission headquarters this evening, Mr. Kume, a mathematics professor, broke into tears as he recounted how the driver of a bread delivery van in Mr. Kume's home town of Vlore was shot and killed yesterday.
The town was so out of control, he said, that everyone went inside at midday and locked the door, leaving the streets empty except for the armed gangsters. The same would happen on election day, whether the polls closed at 6 P.M. or 9 P.M., he predicted.

HEADLINE: Lott Calls Clinton 'Spoiled Brat' For Stand on Tax Cuts in Accord

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, today called President Clinton a "spoiled brat" for wanting his own way in divvying up proposed tax cuts.
"He acts like a spoiled brat," Mr. Lott said on the ABC News program "This Week." "He thinks he's got to have it his way or no way." 
 The President later ignored the remark, saying only of Mr. Lott, "I wish him a happy Father's Day."
Mr. Lott made his comments as part of a concerted Republican effort to try to regain some footing after the party's lengthy maneuverings against the Administration over the disaster-relief bill ended last week in a political fiasco.
The tax cuts referred to by Mr. Lott are part of a package approved last week by the House Ways and Means Committee. The proposal, for $85 billion in net tax cuts, promises reductions in capital gains taxes and estate taxes and other measures, including a child tax credit, as part of a deal to balance the budget by 2002.
But the White House and Congressional Democrats have objected to the Republicans' plan, mostly because they say it tends to favor the wealthy. One point of disagreement is over how to apply a $500-per-child tax credit. Republicans would exclude the poorest citizens because they pay no income tax. Democrats want to extend the credit to the poor, even to those who already receive an earned-income tax credit.
Mr. Lott and House Republicans took issue with the President's approach on various television programs this morning.
"I really think the President is not committed to giving working Americans, middle-class Americans, a tax cut," Mr. Lott said. "I think they are getting positioned to veto the tax-cut provision."
He that starting on Monday, "we're going on the offensive in trying to explain what's in the bill, why it's important to working Americans and what the President is up to."
Gene Sperling, who heads the National Economic Council, said in an interview, "Rather than engage in name-calling, the majority leader should explain why they specifically designed their child tax credit to give nothing to four million of our most-pressed, hardest-working families."
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, said Mr. Clinton's proposal on the tax credit would increase costs by giving a Government check to people who paid no income tax.
"Tax relief shouldn't go to people who don't pay any taxes," Mr. Archer said on "Fox News Sunday."
In a letter urging the President to reconsider, Mr. Archer said, "Your proposal in effect increases welfare spending, and does so by taking tax relief out of the hands of middle-income, taxpaying parents with teen-age children."

HEADLINE: Tax Plan Gives Most Relief to the Middle Class;
Tax Cuts Aid Growth

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I take great issue with the article "Cutting Taxes a Luxury Now With Consequences Deferred" (front page, June 11). You state as a premise: "Ever since economists and politicians discovered in 1982 that the tax cuts enacted the year before would lead to an explosion in the budget deficit . . ." This is a fallacious contention. 
 There are two sides to the budget: revenue and spending. The experience of the 1980's, like the experiences of the 1960's and the 1920's, shows that tax cuts lead to stronger economic growth and increased tax revenues (which are stable historically at about 19 to 20 percent of gross domestic product). The budget deficit of the 1980's was caused by uncontrolled government spending, not by tax cuts.
 
BRIAN G. BALUSEK
Winnetka, Ill., June 11, 1997

HEADLINE: High Court Backs Netanyahu in Influence-Peddling Case

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, June 15

 BODY:
The Israeli Supreme Court today upheld the decision of the Attorney General not to prosecute Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu or his Justice Minister in an influence-peddling case, thus lifting one burden from the embattled Government.
But the threat of a major confrontation with American Jews over rules for conversion to Judaism, the increasingly tense impasse in the Palestinian talks and a new rebellion within his coalition have compelled Mr. Netanyahu to cancel a planned trip to the United States. 
 The Supreme Court's decision effectively put an end to the political fallout from the six-month-old "Bar-On affair."
The case developed from allegations that the Prime Minister had appointed a lawyer named Roni Bar-On as Attorney General under pressure from a powerful politician seeking to gain respite from his own legal problems. Mr. Bar-On resigned after less than a day.
After a long investigation accompanied by extensive news reports, Attorney General Elyakim Rubinstein concluded in March that he had insufficient evidence to indict Mr. Netanyahu or Justice Minister Tzahi Hanegbi, though he recommended charges against the politician, Arieh Deri of the religious Shas Party.
By a 4-to-1 decision, the Supreme Court rejected petitions demanding that Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Hanegbi be indicted. The majority ruled that the court does not intervene in the Attorney General's decisions unless they are "extremely unreasonable."
"This affair is behind us," Mr. Netanyahu declared today. "I intend to move forward and to deal now with the problems connected to achieving peace and security and economic prosperity for the state of Israel."
But Mr. Netanyahu is still facing what has been shaping up to be a bitter showdown with American Jews over a law proposed by rigorously Orthodox Jews in Israel declaring that conversions performed in Israel must be done by Orthodox rabbis to be valid.
The bill has passed the first of three readings in Parliament and is expected to be brought to a vote by the end of the month.
This crisis evidently led Mr. Netanyahu to cancel a visit to the United States for the International Conference for the Environment.
Though the bill would confirm the unofficial status quo, Reform and Conservative Jews in the United States -- who account for about 84 percent of American Jews -- view the legislation as a humiliating attempt to relegate them to second-class status within Judaism. American Jews have responded with fury.
Israeli press reports say American Jewish donations to Israeli recipients -- about $230 million a year in the past -- are down 10 percent.
Politicians of the rigorously Orthodox factions say the conversion bill was prompted by a suit filed by Conservative Jews in Israel asking that the Interior Ministry recognize their conversions. The Interior Ministry is involved because conversion to Judaism opens the door to Israeli citizenship under the Law of Return.
For Mr. Netanyahu, the choice is bitter. If he blocks the bill, the religious parties could bring down his Government. If he supports it, he risks a serious rift with American Jews and, without their support, with the American Government.
Another factor that evidently prompted Mr. Netanyahu to forgo the trip to the United States was a worsening of the situation with the Palestinians. Efforts by Egypt to mediate a return to negotiations have brought no results so far, and a new wave of violent confrontations has erupted in Gaza and Hebron.
The daily Maariv said Israeli intelligence agencies had warned that the situation could worsen and that they had recommended that Mr. Netanyahu not leave the country for long periods.
In Hebron today, the Israeli police fired volley after volley of tear gas and rubber bullets to keep Palestinian stone throwers at bay in the second day of violence near the Jewish settlements in the center of the city. The Palestinian police were conspicuously absent.
Palestinian officials said the anger in the streets has been fanned by a nonbinding resolution adopted last week by the United States House of Representatives calling on President Clinton to affirm that Jerusalem is the undivided capital of Israel and earmarking $100 million to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
The resolution has drawn a tide of furious comments from Palestinian officials and organizations. It is perceived as further evidence that the United States is abandoning the role of an impartial broker.
On Friday, the Palestinian Authority of Yasir Arafat issued a statement that said, "The Palestinian leadership, which showed great flexibility and unlimited patience in order to preserve and protect the peace process from collapsing, cannot understand the reasons which made the Congress take such a dangerous decision in regard to Jerusalem."
Ami Ayalon, the director of Shin Bet, Israel's internal security agency, was reported to have warned at the Israeli Cabinet meeting on Friday that with the continual impasse, Mr. Arafat's position was being seriously eroded while Hamas, the Islamic militant movement, was gaining strength among Palestinians.
In addition to these problems, Mr. Netanyahu is facing sharp criticism from one of his strongest former supporters in the governing coalition, Trade and Industry Minister Natan Sharansky.
The immediate cause of the rift was evidently the appointment of a new Ambassador to Moscow, Herzl Anbar, instead of the candidate proposed by Mr. Sharansky's Russian immigrant party. Mr. Sharansky also charges that Mr. Netanyahu has failed to consult with a committee on Government appointments that he set up last winter after the Bar-On scandal and that the Prime Minister has reneged on other promises.
Mr. Sharansky is not expected to bolt the coalition. But late last week, in what was perceived to be a strong political signal, he held a well-publicized meeting with Ehud Barak, the newly elected leader of the opposition Labor Party.

HEADLINE: Clinton Feels Sure-Footed on the Tightrope of Race

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
President Clinton was in the Oval Office meeting with his new advisory panel on race on Friday when a journalist asked him about widespread skepticism among civil rights leaders that his initiative would go beyond talk.
"Anybody who looks at my entire public life can see that it's been dominated by three things: economics, education and race," Mr. Clinton shot back. "If there is any issue I ought to have credibility on, it is this one because it is a part of who I am and what I've done, and I don't feel the need to defend myself." 
 In fact, ever since he has appeared on the national stage, Mr. Clinton has been an intriguing political figure precisely because he has been trying to redefine racial politics for the Democratic Party.
Some of this has come from his heart -- as a white Southerner, he was deeply offended by the segregation he grew up with. Some of it has come from his pragmatic recognition that the Democratic Party was hemorrhaging white support because too many working-class and lower-middle-class whites thought that their interests were overlooked by liberals concerned about the interests of the black poor.
In his first four years as President, Mr. Clinton did much to build white support for the Democrats. He sought to end the party's identification with big spending, with welfare and with indulgent attitudes toward criminals --all issues that carried racial undertones in the political arena.
Now, with that groundwork behind him, Mr. Clinton seems to be embarking on an effort to build white support for a still undefined effort to help the minority groups that have been left behind in America's booming economy.
"I know that for many white Americans, this conversation may seem to exclude them or threaten them," he said on Saturday. "That must not be so. I believe white Americans have just as much to gain as anybody else from being part of this endeavor -- much to gain from an America where we finally take responsibility for all our children."
Usually the nation has embarked on these efforts only after times of turmoil. The assassination of John F. Kennedy generated a national mood that allowed President Lyndon B. Johnson to win passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The assassinations of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Senator Robert F. Kennedy and urban riots led to the Kerner Commission's report, which concluded that America was moving toward "two societies, one black, one white, separate and unequal."
But Mr. Clinton and his advisers say they believe that it is the very lack of turmoil right now that makes the time ripe to tackle race once more: that the good economy, the drop in crime and the decline in welfare rolls have all reduced white resentment enough for people to talk about race and related issues, like immigration and demographic changes.
Of course, as always with Mr. Clinton, it has been a bumpy journey to get to where he stands today. The President's support for affirmative action, so ringing on Saturday, seemed more tentative when he was facing a re-election campaign and the Republicans were viewing affirmative action as a social issue they could use against him.
In an appearance before California Democrats in 1995, he said: "We don't have to retreat from these affirmative action programs that have done great things for the American people and haven't hurt other people. We don't. But we do have to ask ourselves, Are they all working? Are they all fair? Has there been any kind of reverse discrimination?"
Three months later, Mr. Clinton, however, helped stem the Republican push against racial preferences with his "mend it, don't end it" speech, which civil rights leaders say forged a national consensus where none looked possible to protect affirmative action programs.
But the President rarely crusaded against California's Proposition 209, the anti-affirmative action initiative, when it was on the ballot during his re-election campaign last year, although he insisted today that he had opposed it "every time I was in California and every time I was asked about it."
"Where was the President when the issue was engaged?" William Bennett, the conservative strategist, asked on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "He was not going to anger anybody in California by coming out on the wrong side, or the right side, so he was silent. That's not political leadership."
It is also the case that Mr. Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it" helped unleash public demand for an overhaul that eventually led him to sign a Republican bill far more extreme than any he had originally envisioned.
And his support for the Republican goal of balancing the budget has left little money available for new Federal social programs of any sort, even though the President and his advisory board say they expect to end this year with proposals for programs to expand economic and educational opportunity, to improve housing for the poor and to end housing discrimination.
"He has painted himself into the corner where he has nothing he can do but exhortation," said Roger Wilkins, the Robinson Professor of History at George Mason University. "And I don't believe that exhortation -- when you are dealing with the poorest people in this society and the historical forces that created their desperation -- is going to do it."
But Mr. Clinton always keeps his critics -- on the left and the right -- - off balance, and his effort is just beginning. He has given himself a year to start changing the mood and attitudes of the country. He has lately been referring sporadically to the Democrats as the "progressive party," which could be a signal that he is on the ideological move once again. And today, in an appearance on CNN, he dismissed the idea that the big question that faces him in his second term is a fiscal one: preparing the Social Security and Medicare systems for the retirement of the baby boom generation.
"That's a serious issue, but it's largely a mathematics issue," he said, almost dismissively. "And I believe it'll be dealt with. I believe the most profound question facing us is whether we can become the world's first truly mutliracial democracy."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 19, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about a speech by President Clinton on race relations misstated the timing and events leading to creation of the National Commission on Civil Disorders, known as the Kerner Commission. The commission investigated the causes of the urban riots of the summer of 1967 and issued its report on March 1, 1968. The assassinations of Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. occurred after the report was completed.

HEADLINE: 5 Years After Environmental Summit in Rio, Little Progress

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, in the largest gathering of its kind in history, world leaders meeting at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro signed binding treaties designed to prevent dangerous human interference with the earth's climate system and to protect living species. They also adopted a nonbinding blueprint to guide countries in protecting a deteriorating global environment while at the same time promoting economic well-being.
Next Monday, 70 heads of state or government will gather at the United Nations to take stock of progress since Rio and to discuss where to go from here. But United Nations reports prepared for the meeting have already rendered a judgment: with some important exceptions, environmental trends have changed little since the Rio gathering. 
 The most notable exception, interestingly, is in an area not dealt with at Rio: population growth. Thanks to factors like contraception, education and the enhanced status of women, fertility rates are declining more rapidly than had been expected in all regions of the world. The latest United Nations projections show that the populations of many countries, including some developing ones, will stabilize within the next generation or two. But other countries still face high growth rates that will strain their resources, and the world population as a whole is expected to reach 11 billion before stabilizing some time in the 21st century. It now totals about 6 billion.
At the same time, according to the United Nations assessment, food production continues to rise, and most people are living longer and healthier lives. These gains are threatened, however, by a growing scarcity of fresh water and a loss of topsoil and productive farmland. According to the United Nations accounting, a third of the world's people do not have an adequate supply of clean water, and two-thirds will be deprived of it by 2010 unless action is taken. Some 3.7 billion acres of farmland -- nearly 30 percent of the world's vegetated surface -- are now degraded to some degree.
Air and water quality is generally improving in rich countries. But despite substantial reforestation in those countries and a recent slowing of deforestation globally, forest loss continues worldwide. Each year, according to the United Nations, an area the size of Nepal is cut or burned. Ocean pollution threatens the health and livelihood of the two-thirds of humanity living near coastlines, and about 60 percent of commercial fisheries are overfished or fully fished and in danger of depletion. Toxic chemicals still pose significant threats.
Under the two binding treaties signed at Rio, substantive progress has been scant. The Convention on Biodiversity has been ratified by 161 countries (not including the United States). This treaty obligates governments to take action to protect plant and animal species, but species are being extinguished and their habitats are being destroyed at what the United Nations calls an "unprecedented" rate.
The climate treaty has been ratified by 166 countries, including the United States. But few developed countries, also including the United States, are expected to meet the treaty's initial goal of capping emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide at 1990 levels by 2000. Despite that, talks are under way on even stronger steps that would further reduce emissions of the gases. Two more sessions of the talks are scheduled in Bonn before a final session in Kyoto, Japan, in December.
As the negotiations proceed, atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide continue to grow, and mainstream scientists say that if they are not reduced the world can expect a warmer climate and widespread climatic disruption in the next century.
On this page are snapshots of some major aspects of the global environmental picture.

GRAPHIC: Graph/Map: "Environmental Problems: A Report Card"
Since the Earth Summit five years ago, most environmental trends have continued, the United Nations reports. A major and surprising exception is that population is increasing at a somewhat slower rate. Other improvements, like food production gains, are threatened by continuing degradation of land and water.
 A map of the world shows what areas are increasing, decreasing, or remaining relatively stable when it comes to the usage of their natural resources. Graph tracks total fertility rates, water withdrawals and agricultural production in North America, Europe, Latin America, Asia and Africa, since the 40's, 50's, and 60's. HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Signs That Euro May Turn Out to Be Strong

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the mark yesterday, hurt by signs that Europe's planned single currency might be stronger than expected.
The dollar also fell against the yen amid anxiety that Japan's trade surplus would be a sensitive discussion topic when leaders of the leading industrial nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- meet in Denver. 
 The three-day Group of Seven meeting starts on Friday, a day after the Commerce Department issues its tally of April trade data, which is expected to show a sharp rise in Japan's exports to the United States. Clinton Administration officials have increasingly complained about the surplus in recent weeks and partly blamed the dollar's strength against the yen for the imbalance.
"The market is wondering if the new news on the trade front will put further downward pressure on the dollar," said Audrey McNiff, vice president for foreign exchange at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
In trading in New York, the dollar settled at 113.52 yen, down from 114.89 yen on Friday. The dollar fell to 1.7320 marks from 1.7386 marks. The pound rose to $1.6375 from $1.6363.
The dollar's weakness against European currencies partly reflected the broad demand for yen because of the anxiety over trade with the United States, as well as a rally yesterday in the Japanese stock market that pushed the Nikkei stock index to its highest level of the year.
But the dollar was also sold after European Union leaders meeting in Amsterdam approved an agreement yesterday on assuring stability in the euro without granting any major concessions demanded by France to stimulate job growth.
Traders had bought dollars last week on speculation that French demands might result in a more flexible stability pact that would undermine the euro's rigid fiscal requirements and make it a weak successor to the mark, the predominant currency in Europe.
"This was a case of buy the rumor and sell the fact," said Stephen Jury, managing director of foreign exchange at the Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. "People bought dollars on anticipation of an agreement. We did get an agreement and the dollar came off a bit."

HEADLINE: Observer;
We've Got to Talk

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Advance publicity said the President's speech on race would be "major." It is hard to guess what remains to be said in a "major" vein about race in the United States, so, not surprisingly, after saying it was a major problem, Mr. Clinton found himself at a loss for a new idea.
In the absence of a new idea, he endorsed an old one (affirmative action), said he was appointing a committee and called for an "honest dialogue." What constitutes honesty in a "dialogue" on this subject? The President let the question pass and lapsed into bromides, as politicians are apt to do when expected to orate in the "major" style about matters on which they have nothing to say. 
 Thus: "Honest dialogue will not be easy at first. We will have to get past defensiveness and fear and political correctness and other barriers to honesty." And, dipping into the Kennedy-Johnson summons-to-greatness style: "Emotions may be rubbed raw, but we must begin."
Presidents Kennedy and Johnson usually wanted us to begin something ambitious; Mr. Clinton summons us only to a national gabfest. He seems to believe this might result in "concerted action," which would help "lift the heavy burden of race from our children's future." As to what that "concerted action" might be, Mr. Clinton did not hazard a guess.
And so, having nothing of consequence to say, he dug into the national cliche anthology. He came up with, among other overworked phrases, "the classic American dilemma," "a great national effort to perfect the promise of America," the attempt "to build our more perfect union" and "one America respecting, even celebrating our differences."
This sounds more like bloviating than the opening of "honest dialogue," but it is only to be expected in the dead political air in which the country is becalmed. The only subject with which Washington is seriously engaged this year is the balanced-budget exercise.
Mr. Clinton had to make a commencement speech, an ancient literary form requiring inspirational rhetoric. A call to balanced-budgetary greatness would hardly fill the bill. Race, on the other hand, always offers excellent rhetorical opportunities.
Well, he was also speaking in California, where people have recently been voting bleak anti-black, anti-immigrant passions. Endorsing affirmative action in this benighted territory, the President could show his critics that there was at least one unpopular issue on which he would take a stand.
The mystery is why the President thinks we lack dialogue on race. A roaring dialogue on race has been going on here for 350 years.
Two hundred years ago the Constitution spoke honestly about the American position on race when it stated that a slave was to be officially considered only three-fifths of a human being. For cruelly honest dialogue on race it would be hard to improve on the Civil War. Lynchings, riots, murders, corrupt trials, unemployment statistics -- dialogue doesn't get any more honest than these.
Mr. Clinton didn't say how we could enjoy a more civilized dialogue. He seems to think that talking across the racial divide can produce genuine changes in people's "hearts and minds."
"Hearts and minds" -- the phrase speaks of the old idea that racial hostility is embedded in a part of the human psyche that cannot be changed by the forces of reason, education, politics or law.
The conviction that government action will never be able to change the human heart was President Eisenhower's reason for not supporting the civil rights movement 40 years ago. Fear that voters would be enraged by an effort to change their hearts and minds accounted for President Kennedy's hands-off policy on the civil rights movement.
When President Johnson boldly supported it anyhow, Richard Nixon's "Southern strategy" exploited the resulting anger to convert a once solid Democratic South into a now solid Republican South. Now Democrats cannot elect a President without a Southern accent, and even he must be wary when tinkering with hearts and minds.
In California Mr. Clinton was a wary President making a wary speech. A committee will now take over, and may even be heard of again.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The City And the Kingdom

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
A letter from the Embassy of Saudi Arabia in Washington:
"Regarding any information we might know of Christian persecution in Saudi Arabia, the answer is -- none. We have many foreign workers in the Kingdom and they are treated as guests, and every consideration is given for their needs, as long as they abide by the Shari'a law." 
 The letter was in answer to a New York Times reporter's inquiry for a story on legislation before the City Council of New York that would bar the city from doing business with companies operating in 15 countries named as persecuting Christians. The list includes China and other Communist countries and Saudi Arabia and other Muslim countries.
The assurance about foreign guests was printed on June 15 in an article about business opposition to the legislation. So now -- some facts about religious worship in the Kingdom.
Such information is easy to find about any of the 15. About Saudi Arabia it is impossible to escape. Denial is a lie.
The Shari'a is the Holy Law of Islam, derived from the Koran and Mohammed's teachings. The Saudi section in the State Department's most recent worldwide report on human rights, based on dispatches from U.S. embassies, is a good place to find out how the law is seen and enforced by the royal Government:
"Freedom of religion does not exist. Islam is the official religion and all citizens must be Muslims. The Government prohibits the practice of other religions."
Other information in the report:
For Christians caught worshiping, punishment can be arrest and lashing. Wearing religious symbols is prohibited. Christians wearing a cross or engaging in any other religious practice can be arrested, flogged and deported.
Conversion by Muslims to another religion is considered apostasy. Apostasy is punishable by execution.
Paul Marshall, a specialist on persecution of Christians, writes that occasionally citizens of important countries like Britain or the U.S. are allowed worship within embassy grounds, if they keep quiet about it.
Amnesty International has documented about 350 cases of Christian foreign workers arrested when they tried to worship -- in private, since church services are banned. But arrests of Christians from Asia, the Mideast and Africa, which supply most of the Kingdom's foreign workers, usually go unreported by their relatives and employers. They fear the reprisals: arrest and torture of the prisoners' families.
And, for Americans who think Saudi officials have any more respect for them than laborers from the third world: U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia during the gulf war were not allowed to wear any symbol of their faith. Since the war, religious oppression has increased. Saudi rulers are terrified that thoughts of religious freedom, or any other kind, linger from having had Americans around to protect them from Iraq.
American businessmen never worried about such Saudi ways and morals -- nor do they now. They do worry about the increasing American public revulsion against using government funds and contracts to enrich the persecutors. Nineteen cities and states are considering legislation to use local economic pressure against repression.
The opposition from business and persecutors will be stepped up in organization and funding. The focus will be on New York City, and particular pressure on two men: Council Speaker Peter Vallone, who introduced the legislation, and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, sympathetic but uncommitted, who will find it on his desk.
So it is increasingly critical for opponents of religious persecution to insist the evidence be spread out and denials examined instead of simply repeated and passed along.
The businessmen and their lobbyists, Americans who attend Saudi Embassy parties or take those velvet trips to Saudi Arabia arranged by its officials -- they all know about the religious persecution.
Perhaps like Robert Kiley, president of New York's Chamber of Commerce, they will say in public that local action against persecutions is just know-nothingism cloaked in morality. Maybe some will even say that in private, to themselves and God, as they worship. But it will be difficult, won't it, because we really do know, don't we?

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Advance Modestly as Investors Await Price Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly in light trading yesterday, as market participants waited for today's Government's report on consumer prices for last month.
The Consumer Price Index is expected to support recent signs that suggest the economic growth rate is slowing to a sustainable pace, removing any threat of inflation. 
 With the next meeting of the the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee a couple of weeks away, the growing feeling among market participants is that the Fed will not raise interest rates again as it did in March, when it made what Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, called a pre-emptive strike against inflation.
By late in the day, the price of the 30-year bond was up 13/32, to 99 6/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, slipped to 6.69 percent, from 6.72 percent on Friday -- the lowest since 6.65 percent on Feb. 25. But as most investors are well aware, thin volume often exaggerates market movement.
There was no significant news during the session; traders were just dealing with the aftermath of last week's rally and positioning ahead of today's data.
Dave Shabelman, Treasury market analyst with Standard & Poor's MMS, a San Francisco-based market research and analysis firm, predicted the market would have a relatively easy week with its full schedule of economic releases.
"The C.P.I. has become less of a threat since last Friday's weaker-than-expected Producer Price Index showed manufacturing prices less than a threat," Mr. Shabelman said. He expects the overall consumer index for May to be up one-tenth of 1 percent, with the core rate up about two-tenths of 1 percent, estimates that were lowered after last week's Producer Price Index.
He expects housing starts will remain at April levels, or about 1.47 million units, while May industrial production will be up about three-tenths of 1 percent.
"The wild card in Tuesday's trade could be the weekly retail sales reports if they show continued strength along the lines of last week's 2.3 percent increase in the Redbook survey," Mr. Shabelman said. "The market's positive tone continues to support price gains, and traders are reluctant to sell into the strength. There is a lot of money to be put to work with some $30 billion in cash management bills maturing tomorrow and upcoming data expected to be market-friendly. The odds that the Fed will announce a monetary policy change on July 2 have been severely reduced following last week's retail sales and P.P.I. reports."
Doug Burtnick, a fixed-income analyst with Technical Data of Boston, noted that the two-year maturity moved inside 6 percent, ending at 5.99 percent, with little fanfare "and for that matter very little investor buying." He said, "It will take some very constructive data to get it to go much further before July's Federal Open Market Committee meeting." But he said there were some factors shaping up positively at the long end of the yield curve, among them added buying by mortgage investors who are starting to get jittery about potential prepayment and early retirement of debt.
Yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills was about average, with the three-month bill sold at an average rate of 4.88 percent, down from 4.94 percent last week. The six-month bill was sold at an average rate of 5.10 percent, down from 5.20 percent.
On Thursday the Treasury plans to sell $13 billion of new 52-week bills. In the corporate market, more than a dozen borrowers are lining up to sell debt this week, while yields are still near four-months lows. Among them are the American Express Company, the Ames Financial Corporation and the Money Store Inc., which are planning to sell more than $2 billion of bonds backed by consumer loans.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With the Dow Falling 9.95

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with many investors taking a breather from last week's buying spree, which sent all the major indexes to record after record.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 9.95 points to close at 7,772.09 in light trading. That ended a streak of six consecutive record-setting performances. Last week the blue-chip average rose 346 points, or about 4.7 percent. 
 But the Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology issues, gained 8.92 points yesterday, to a record 1,431.95.
Analysts said that activity was light ahead of today's release of several economic indicators, including the May Consumer Price Index, and that investors had grown weary after last week's blistering run.
"This is a little bit of a case of lethargy," said Edward Collins, a market analyst at Daiwa Securities. "It's a little pause after a 350-point move last week."
To demonstrate just how busy last week was, nearly 2.7 billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, a 40 percent increase from the comparable week in 1996.
But yesterday, volume on the Big Board dropped to 419.2 million shares, from about 575.8 million shares on Friday.
So it came as no surprise that the Dow dipped slightly, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained a meager 0.63 point to close at a record 893.90.
"It was exactly the kind of market we expected," said Laszlo Birinyi, president of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm based in Greenwich, Conn.
Birinyi Associates has calculated that the Monday after a big weekly gain is typically weak -- often the Dow loses about 18 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Yesterday's loss was about 13 basis points.
Despite yesterday's pause, the market seems to be benefiting from a stream of good news, including signs that the economy's growth has slowed to a moderate, but sustainable, pace with no sign of inflation.
That has led to an improving interest rate environment. Yesterday, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.69 from 6.72 on Friday. Just a few weeks ago, on June 2, the yield was at 6.90. Many analysts now say the Federal Reserve is less likely to raise interest rates than was previously thought.
"A lot of people have taken a stance that the Fed is going to stand pat," said Arthur Hogan, a trader at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. "But today, it's just investors sitting on their hands."
Small stocks, however, rose modestly yesterday. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks was up 0.13 point, to a record 392.20.
After easily outpacing large-cap stocks in May, small-cap stocks have once again surrendered their leadership role to large caps this month. The Dow has risen about 6 percent this month, while the Russell has gained about 3 percent.
Technology issues, while lagging behind the larger market, made a strong showing yesterday.
The Nasdaq gained with the aid of three of its biggest computer names. Microsoft, up 59 percent this year, rose 1 3/4, to 131 3/8. Intel gained 2 1/2, to 147 1/4. And Dell Computer rose 4 1/4, to 115 3/8. On the year, Dell is up 118 percent.
After last week's gain -- the largest point gain ever for the Dow and the eighth largest in percentage terms -- the average was braked yesterday by Procter & Gamble, down 1 3/8, to 141 1/2, and the American Express Company, down 1 3/8, to 75 1/4.
Still, the Dow has climbed 20.5 percent on the year, and only one issue among the 30 -- AT&T -- has lost ground. But in the last month, shares of AT&T have soared 15 percent. For the year, however, the stock is still down 7 percent.
Not surprisingly, as of yesterday, more than two-thirds of the Dow's 30 component stocks were near their 52-week highs.

HEADLINE: An Un-Washington Sort of Guy Longs for Home

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Some White House chiefs of staff practically have to be dynamited out of office. Some resign discreetly for the good of the President. But Erskine B. Bowles, President Clinton's current chief of staff, has been advertising his departure for months.
Mr. Bowles is so open about saying that he longs to return to his family in North Carolina that now, just six months into his tenure, speculation about his successor is sweeping the city. Indeed, the constant demurrals of Mr. Bowles, a 51-year-old investment banker, that he is a "creature of the private sector" reached such a volume last month that the White House had to declare that his departure was not imminent. 
 Still, the expectation inside the White House is that Mr. Bowles will be gone as soon as the year's final budget bills are passed, sometime between Labor Day and New Year's, setting off more uncertainty and jockeying for position inside the Administration.
In a city where few people like to relinquish power, many see Mr. Bowles's yearning to depart as symptomatic not only of the toll it takes to work in Mr. Clinton's always embattled White House but also of a strangely deflated mood that has gripped the President's second term despite the continuing economic recovery and the achievement of a balanced-budget deal.
But Mr. Bowles, a multimillionaire who is working for $1 a year, insists that Mr. Clinton knew that he would only be a transitional figure with a list of finite goals.
"There's been no question in his mind since the first day," Mr. Bowles said in a recent interview in his West Wing office, where pictures of his three children line the walls. "This has not changed one iota. I came in for a limited period of time when he thought someone with a rather nonpartisan background could be helpful to him in accomplishing specific things."
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, said: "It is classically considered the wrong thing to do in Washington to announce that you're leaving. But Erskine is classically an un-Washington guy."
Mr. Clinton has never been fully comfortable himself with the culture of Washington. And the fact that Mr. Bowles shares that sensibility, many say, has proved to be both the chief of staff's strength and his shortcoming.
Unencumbered by traditional Washington alliances and thinking, Mr. Bowles was able to broker the balanced-budget deal with the Republicans. But, some Democrats say, he is not keenly political enough to help provide an overarching sense of direction for the second term that goes beyond economic issues.
Last fall, when Mr. Clinton began pursuing Mr. Bowles hard to return to Washington, some said the President was searching for a perfect synthesis between the total loyalty of Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the friend from childhood who was his first chief of staff, and the skill of Leon E. Panetta, the former California Congressman who was his second.
Mr. McLarty was considered well-meaning but ineffective. Mr. Panetta had years of Washington experience. But in Mr. Clinton's darkest moments after the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994, the President partly blamed his own aides, including Mr. Panetta, for having more allegiance to historical Democratic interest groups than to him.
With Mr. Bowles, White House officials said, the President felt confident that in a time when he wanted to work with a Republican Congress, he would have a tested chief of staff with no agenda but Mr. Clinton's own.
The President had already forged a bond with Mr. Bowles in his first term, in which the North Carolinian served as head of the Small Business Administration and then deputy White House chief of staff before leaving at the end of 1995.
In his 16 months as the deputy, it was Mr. Bowles who insisted that Mr. Clinton needed more private time for thought. And in a White House where staff gatherings too often could deteriorate into talkathons, he was known to run a no-nonsense meeting.
Perhaps more important, he and Mr. Clinton had a certain chemistry. Mr. Bowles, who has shared many a golf game with Mr. Clinton, attributes their rapport to the fact that "we're two Southern guys who are basically the same age, who grew up under vastly different circumstances but we enjoy the same things."
Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's former political strategist, said Mr. Bowles was attuned to Mr. Clinton's most enigmatic moods.
"I think the President really appreciates that Bowles listens hard for the slightest, smallest, silentest signal from him and takes it as an order," Mr. Morris said.
Mr. Bowles told colleagues he had three prime objectives: to make sure the right people served in the right positions in the second term, to impose discipline on a White House that had a tendency to meander, and most importantly, to broker the balanced-budget agreement with the Republican-controlled Congress.
Unlike Mr. Panetta, who ran a highly centralized White House managed from a list he kept on a yellow pad, Mr. Bowles has delegated responsibility.
"My approach has always been quite different," he noted earlier this year, comparing himself with Mr. Panetta."Not better or worse but different, and that is a more decentralized approach where we believe in delegating authority and responsibility but, by God, holding people accountable.
He has cut back the number of meetings in the White House, beginning each day with a 7:45 A.M. session for about 25 White House aides. Previously there had been a 7:30 A.M. meeting for senior staff members and an 8:15 session for a broader group. Mr. Bowles briefs Mr. Clinton each morning about 9:15 and runs the evening political strategy sessions that still occur every week or so in the White House residence.
Officials say he is in tune enough with the President that there is no longer the kind of confusion that prevailed in late 1995 when Mr. Clinton was moving toward embracing the idea of a balanced budget, when most of his aides were opposing it.
"We probably get a better sense of where Clinton's thinking is from Erskine," Mr. McCurry said, "but on the other hand Clinton got a better sense of what White House staff and Washington thinking was from Leon. There's a little bit of a tradeoff there."
Republicans in Congress have warmed to Mr. Bowles's efficient and direct style. Senator Jesse Helms, the conservative Republican from North Carolina who has so often been the Administration's nemesis, has said of the balanced-budget deal that there were "two words to describe that: Erskine Bowles."
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who heads the House Budget Committee, said: "He made it very clear he wanted to get this done."
Even some Democrats with grave misgivings about the budget deal praise Mr. Bowles.
"I find him to be a trustworthy friend with an agenda I wouldn't touch with a 10-foot pole," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan.
But some other Democrats point to the House Republicans' most recent tax cut plan, with its retreat from major elements of Mr. Clinton's proposals for tax breaks for higher education, as a sign that Mr. Bowles had not been politically skillful enough. Some White House aides and Democrats close to the White House also quietly complain that Mr. Bowles's formality and his concern with memorandums and process, has at times slowed decision-making. And his talk of leaving, they say, is another unneeded distraction to a staff that lost the sense of mission of the campaign and is contending with a steady stream of investigations into campaign finance issues and Whitewater.
Mr. Bowles acknowledges that he himself was troubled when he was called before a grand jury in Arkansas to testify about efforts he made to line up work for Webster L. Hubbell, the former Justice Department official and longtime Clinton friend who left the Government facing allegations that he had bilked his former law firm. He was later convicted of fraud and tax evasion.
But Mr. Bowles denies the accounts of some acquaintances that the grand jury experience sped up his timetable for departure. Instead, he cited the demands of his job: 15-hour days and separation from his wife, Crandall Close Bowles, who has remained in North Carolina where she is president of the textile giant, Springs Industries.
Mr. Bowles will not say precisely when he will go, saying it depends on how fast he accomplishes a list of goals he carries on a card. It is clear that Mr. Clinton's upcoming drive to improve race relations in the nation is an initiative that Mr. Bowles wanted to set in motion.
"This race initiative is something that I am probably as proud of as anything I have done in my life," he said.
At the White House, the names of possible successors are already starting to circulate, including Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser; John Hilley, the President's Congressional liaison; Representative Vic Fazio, Democrat of California, and Jack Quinn, the former White House counsel who is close to Vice President Al Gore. Also mentioned are the budget director, Franklin D. Raines; Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, and John Podesta, a deputy chief of staff.
And in what some White House aides describe as an effort to bring in new intellectual firepower, the political consultant Paul Begala will be returning to Mr. Clinton's side and the journalist Sydney Blumenthal is joining the communications team.
Mr. Bowles insisted that his leave taking would not be disruptive. But other White House officials say the prospect of another change in leadership is distracting.
"It just raises the issue of who will be at the center of the wheel," one Clinton aide said, "who will be at the top of the pyramid, who help keep some sense of order in the place."

HEADLINE: MacArthur Foundation Chooses Grant Winners

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Elouise Cobell had just landed at an airport in northern Montana last Friday when she was given two messages: her luggage was lost, and a philanthropy based in Chicago wanted to give her $310,000.
"I cried for three hours," said Ms. Cobell, the leading founder of the Blackfeet National Bank, the first bank organized by American Indians to be given a Federal charter. 
 Ms. Cobell, 51, who lives on the Blackfeet Reservation in northern Montana, was one of 23 winners of MacArthur Fellowships announced today by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago.
These are this year's other fellows:
