HEADLINE: Stocks Fall on Inflation News; Dow Off 11.31

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The stock market turned sluggish yesterday despite new data that showed benign inflation.
While yesterday's report on May consumer prices confirmed earlier indications that the economy was slowing, a separate report on industrial production suggested the economy could be gathering momentum once again. Investors, already giddy about what seemed to be a nicely balanced economy, drew a mixed reaction to the reports. 
 After plunging more than 65 points early in the day, the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 37 points, only to give up the gains late in the day and close down 11.31 points at 7,760.78.
"I saw the C.P.I. number and it was as expected, and I think the market got used to better-than-expected news," said Jerry Dombcik, managing director of research at McDonald & Company in Cleveland. "But nothing has really changed in the economy."
Despite yesterday's losses, Mr. Dombcik said the market continued to benefit from an ideal economic scenario. "You have to go back to the 1960's to see this kind of environment," he said.
Analysts and economists said the good news about the economy had already been factored in, however, resulting in colorless trading yesterday.
"I don't think these numbers added a lot of new information," said Stuart G. Hoffman, the chief economist at PNC Bank in Pittsburgh. "The market has been up quite a bit in the last week, and these numbers were good, but they weren't enough to propel the market much further."
Technology stocks, however, were among the best performers. The Nasdaq composite index, which is loaded with technology issues, rose 11.16 points, to a record 1,443.11. For the year, the Nasdaq is up 11.8 percent.
Many of its largest computer-related issues gained yesterday on expectations of better earnings and news of stronger demand for high-tech components in the Federal Reserve report on industrial production.
Shares of Dell Computer rose 5 1/2, to 120 7/8, after several analysts reiterated their high ratings of the computer maker.
Microsoft was up 2 13/16, to 134 3/16, and Intel was up 2 21/64, to 149 11/16. Compaq Computer was up 2 5/8, to 107 3/4.
Several other indexes also set records yesterday, but just barely. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.52 point, to 894.42 -- its ninth consecutive record-setting session. And the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks rose 0.35 point, to a record 392.55.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index also reached an all-time high, edging up 0.08 point to close at 465.09. Advancing and declining issues were evenly split in heavy trading of about 542.9 million shares.
Among Dow stocks, Procter & Gamble slid 1 7/8, to 139 5/8, and Johnson & Johnson fell 1 1/4, to 65. The best-performing Dow issue was Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which rose 2 1/4, to 100. For the year, the Dow is up 20.35 percent.
And with so many Dow component stocks trading at high valuations, some strategists are beginning to question whether market valuations are stretched.
But Mr. Dombcik at McDonald & Company said that while valuations were high, the greater threat to the market was inflation and higher interest rates.
"The valuations are high up there," he said. "But you don't have competition from interest rates. Besides, valuations alone don't destroy bull markets."

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Rises Only Slightly for 3d Straight Month

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Consumer Price Index rose by a barely noticeable one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department reported yesterday. It was the third straight month of such slight inflation, suggesting that the American economy is surprisingly free of pressures for price increases so late in an economic expansion.
Some economists who had warned just two months ago that inflation would soon rise now acknowledge that the country is passing through an unusually mild period -- one in which global and domestic forces are combining to hold down prices. 
 "We still expect inflation to appear in the future, once these temporary factors pass," said David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting service. He had urged the Federal Reserve's policy makers to raise interest rates at their May meeting, but now he and others are backing away from that recommendation when the policy makers next meet, in early July. "For 1997," Mr. Wyss said, "we actually expect inflation to be less than 1996."
The index has risen by only one-tenth of a percentage point in four of the five months so far this year. That has produced an annual inflation rate of just 1.4 percent through May, unusually low for an economic expansion in its seventh year. By comparison, inflation rose 3.3 percent in 1996.
The consumer price report came four days after the Labor Department had reported that producer prices for finished goods, measuring price levels for goods shipped from factories, had fallen in May, for the fifth consecutive month. The two reports, said Janet Yellen, head of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, show "that inflation remains well under control."
An assortment of factors appears to be holding down prices. For one thing, people no longer expect price increases, as they did in the 1980's, and that becomes self-fulfilling, said Patrick Jackman, chief of the C.P.I. division at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. Retailers in this atmosphere become reluctant to raise prices, fearing that they will annoy consumers and lose business.
The dollar and imports also play a role. A stronger dollar has reduced the prices of imported goods, just when foreign producers are especially eager to sell to Americans. Weaker economies in Japan and Western Europe have reduced sales in those countries, leaving companies abroad with goods on their hands to sell.
"With so many foreign producers in the wings," Mr. Jackman said, "domestic suppliers think twice about raising prices."
The inflation rate would normally be responding to the 4.8 percent unemployment rate, the lowest since 1973. The expectation had been that such low unemployment would create labor shortages, forcing employers to bid for workers and cover the cost of higher wages with higher prices. But job insecurity has made workers reluctant to press for wage increases, many economists say -- or at least not for wage increases big enough to force price rises.
After two quarters of strong growth, the economy is slowing in the second quarter, and the slower growth is likely to last into the summer, many economists say. That, too, eases the pressure on prices, though other economic data issued yesterday suggested, inconclusively, both weaker and stronger growth.
Industrial production, for example, rose in May by a strong four-tenths of a percentage point, and capacity utilization rose to 83.7 percent -- the highest since September 1995 -- from 83.6 percent in April, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. Previous readings of more than 85 percent have indicated that the nation's factories, mines and utilities are operating nearly flat out, with little room to increase production and avoid shortages. That measure is less significant today, though, given that many overseas companies, running plants below capacity, can supplement American production.
Separately, the Commerce Department said that housing starts, measuring the start of construction of single and multifamily homes, fell in May by 4.8 percent, to an annual rate of 1.397 million units. It was the third consecutive monthly decline, suggesting a weaker economy.
The consumer price report issued yesterday showed only a scattering of price increases in May, particularly for coffee. Prices also rose for fresh vegetables, beef, poultry, fish and eggs and housing. Gasoline prices fell by 4.1 percent, the largest drop since March 1991, and airline fares and tobacco prices also fell. The so-called core inflation rate, excluding volatile food and energy prices, rose by two-tenths of a percentage point in May.
The index rose by 2.2 percent for the 12-month period ended in May, the lowest such rise in a decade. The annual rate has fallen from a 3.3 percent level in December and 3 percent in January and February. Excluding food and energy, the index rose by 2.5 percent for the 12-month period through May. Since December, the annual rate has ranged between 2.5 percent and 2.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Clinton Proposes Incentives For Free Market in Africa

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Just days before the summit meeting of the major industrial nations in Denver, President Clinton joined with bipartisan members of Congress today to promote a series of trade measures with Africa intended to encourage free-market reforms of the continent's most promising economies.
Mr. Clinton marshaled a group that spanned the ideological spectrum from New York City's former Democratic Mayor David N. Dinkins, to Jack F. Kemp, the defeated Republican candidate for vice president, to demonstrate support for an Africa policy designed to turn countries from dependents into trading partners. 
 Mr. Clinton plans to call on the nations gathered at the summit later this week to take steps to help Africa, including urging the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to forgive some of the international debt burdening some of the poorest nations. Uganda recently qualified for about $385 million in such debt relief.
Africa had received sporadic attention during the first four years of the Clinton Administration. But Hillary Rodham Clinton, the First Lady, visited the continent this year and in the past few months the White House has been working with Congress on legislation, involving little new spending, that would lower tariffs for African countries that are reforming their economies and promote private investment in Africa.
"Our initiative opens the door to real positive change," Mr. Clinton said. "Only nations carrying out serious reforms will reap the full benefits. Those who strengthen their democracies and invest in their people will see their efforts pay off in increased trade that will create new jobs, increase wages, spur growth and improve the quality of lives of people who have suffered some of the world's worst poverty."
White House officials said the measures supported by the President would complement traditional foreign aid for Africa. Such aid amounted to $655 million in the current fiscal year and Mr. Clinton has called for it to rise to $700 million in the coming fiscal year.
Mr. Clinton indicated that he was working with lawmakers of both parties to pass legislation that would give the poorest countries in Africa duty-free access to American markets for an additional 1,800 products.
In addition, a bill sponsored by Representative Philip M. Crane, an Illinois Republican, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, would grant further tariff reductions on additional products for countries that are liberalizing their economies. The measure is expected to be considered in the fall.
Mr. Clinton said the Administration was also using government guarantees through the Overseas Private Investment Corporation to leverage $150 million in private funds for investment in Africa and another $500 million for investment in African infrastructure projects like telecommunications projects. He said the United States would also eliminate bilateral debt in the cases of the poorest nations.
The Clinton Administration and members of Congress said the approach was intended to help Africa escape from its dependence on foreign aid.
"Americans want us to move from a donor-recipient relationship with Africa," said Representative Jim McDermott, a Washington Democrat. "They want us to start treating Africa like we treat the rest of the world, as economic partners."
The President's announcement was welcomed by several African nations. "It is going to create an environment that will assist in bringing confidence to American corporations," said the Ugandan Ambassador, Edith Ssempala. "American businesses have not been interested enough."
Seeking to encourage American businesses to step up private investment in Africa, the Administration noted that 30 countries in Africa recorded positive growth rates last year, with some nations attaining growth rates as high as 12 percent.
Officials say a majority of Africa's 48 nations have embarked on market-oriented economic and political reforms in the past decade.

HEADLINE: Waiting for Yeltsin, Shaper of a City

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 17

 BODY:
During the cold war, the only thing Denverites expected to see coming from Moscow was a nuclear-tipped missile.
But when Russia's Presidential jet touches down here on Thursday for an international summit meeting, it will bring Boris Yeltsin, and he will find an American heartland city reshaped, in an odd way, by Boris Yeltsin. 
 In the six years since the Russian President faced down a Communist coup attempt, the shock waves of the Soviet Union's collapse have rippled halfway around the globe. Today, with the disappearance of the Soviet threat, four out of Denver's five military installations are being dismantled, destined to become golf courses, suburban housing developments, a medical research center, a biotech industrial park, a college campus and an urban wildlife refuge 20 times the size of Central Park in New York.
"Boris has affected us more than we realize," said Thomas J. Noel, a history professor at the University of Colorado. "During the 1950's, the fear of Russia probably was the biggest single growth stimulant here."
At the time, local politicians eagerly, and successfully, pitched this interior city to Pentagon planners, calling it "the Rocky Mountain Fortress," safe from the reach of Soviet bombers. And so, at the height of the cold war, Denverites made sarin gas for chemical warfare and plutonium triggers for atom bombs. Denver was home to a training base for Air Force bomber pilots and to one of the nation's largest Army hospitals.
But today, as welcoming banners in Russian and other languages of the summit meeting bedeck Denver's downtown pedestrian mall, participants at this weekend's "Summit of the Eight" -- a meeting of the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia and the United States -- will see a very different Denver.
At Lowry, an Air Force training base until 1994, a 12-ton steel guillotine has been chopping up runways into concrete chunks that will be recycled to pave streets for a suburban housing development. As a B-52 bomber stands marooned in a static museum display, a nearby hangar is being converted into the Big Bear Ice Arena, complete with two indoor and one outdoor skating rinks.
In a nod to Lowry's military tradition, former base housing is now marketed to renters as a community called "Landings At Lowry."
"In 15 years, we are going to have a mixed-used community with 10,000 residents, 10,000 to 12,000 jobs, and 10,000 students at our college campus," James E. Meadows, executive director of the Lowry Redevelopment Authority, said as he pressed on a visitor a cheery promotional video: "Lowry: Live, Learn, Work and Play."
In Denver, where housing costs have risen by 50 percent since 1990, real-estate developers see a bonanza in the transfer from military to civilian use of three square miles only 15 minutes from downtown. Contracts are being signed for the construction of 3,200 new homes, ranging in price from $100,000 to $600,000. Although no new houses have been built yet, developers are so confident that they agreed last week to make Lowry the site of the city 1998 Parade of Homes, a decorator showcase of new houses.
About one-third of the area is to remain open space, largely golf courses and playing fields. Old Air Force training buildings are being converted into a community college specializing in technology training. Fifteen years and $1.3 billion from now, the only recognizable feature from the old base may be a small white clapboard chapel, known as the Eisenhower Chapel. President Dwight D. Eisenhower served in Denver as a military officer before World War II and was married to a Denverite, Mamie Doud.
The demilitarization of Denver is part of a wider, post-cold-war phenomenon. Since the Berlin Wall fell in 1989, American military spending has fallen by about one-third in constant terms, to about $254 billion today. During the same period, the number of American active duty military personnel has also fallen by about one-third, to 1.4 million today.
Two miles northeast of Lowry, Paul E. Tauer, Mayor of Aurora, jubilantly paced the roof of a massive beige brick building on a recent afternoon. Once the centerpiece of Fitzsimmons Army Medical Center, the 450,000-square-foot building was the largest in Colorado when it was built in 1941. Six weeks ago, the Army leased the building to the city of Aurora, Denver's eastern neighbor and Colorado's third largest city.
"It's going to be a phenomenal economic development engine," said Mayor Tauer. "We are going to have four times the jobs on this site."
The Mayor's prediction is backed by the University of Colorado's decision to move its Health Sciences Center from a congested residential neighborhood in Denver to the one-square-mile suburban site. Committed to occupying about one-third of Fitzsimmons, the university plans to spend $20 million to renovate the main building, and another $23 million to build a cancer treatment center.
"Ten bioscience companies need space as soon as we can give it to them," Robert E. Olson, executive director of the Fitzsimmons Redevelopment Authority, said, referring to a section of the former Army base that is to become a "bioscience research park."
About $1.5 billion is to be invested in renovating Fitzsimmons, leaving untouched only an eighth-floor hospital room where President Eisenhower spent seven weeks recovering from a heart attack in the late 1950's.
There, as in Lowry, officials recognize that the changes in suburban Denver can be traced to geopolitics.
"If those hostilities still existed, this would not be happening," Mayor Tauer said from the rooftop of the old Army medical center.
Three miles to the north, the demilitarization of Denver is even more striking at a 27-mile square expanse once known as Rocky Mountain Arsenal.
"It's up to Hitler and Tojo now," The Denver Post trumpeted in 1943, at the opening there of the Army's main production plant for mustard gas and incendiary bombs. Assembly lines at the Arsenal produced the napalm and phosgene used in the March 1945 firebombings of Tokyo. And during the cold war, the Arsenal was the only production site outside of the Soviet Union for sarin, a highly toxic nerve gas.
Today, the site has been rebaptized the Rocky Mountain Arsenal National Wildlife Refuge. Almost halfway through a 20-year, $2 billion cleanup, the former chemical weapons plant is to be reborn by 2010 as one of the nation's largest urban wildlife refuges.
Only 10 miles from downtown Denver, the refuge already has almost 300 wildlife species, including bald eagles, pronghorn antelope, prairie dogs and white-tailed deer. Specializing in environmental education, the refuge is to offer a visitor learning center, an open air-nature tram, hiking and bicycling trails and picknicking sites.
An even more expensive cleanup, costing around $7 billion, is under way in a northwest Denver suburb where plutonium triggers for America's atom bombs were made until 1989. Surrounded by a 10-square-mile buffer zone, Rocky Flats was once Denver's second largest employer. As the collapse of the Soviet Union became an irreversible fact, the plant's mission shifted from standby for production to dismantlement and its name became Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site.
"We are deactivating rooms, we are decontaminating buildings, we are cleaning up disposal trenches," said Jesse Robberson, site manager for the Department of Energy.
Depending on the flow of Federal money, the cleanup will be completed 10 to 15 years from now. As at the chemical weapons factory, a one-square-mile core will remain permanently off limits. But Denver's booming western suburbs will inherit 10 square miles of open space, largely bluegrass prairie.
With four of Denver's military installations converting to civilian use, the metropolitan area's last major military installation, Buckley Air National Guard Base, is now crowded with 23 military tenants, ranging from the Navy to the Marines to the Army National Guard.
Reflecting on the shift, John Spann, the base spokesman, said today, "With everybody shutting down, we are the only military presence in the area."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Lucent and Philips To Combine Phone-Making
Lucent Technologies and Philips Electronics have agreed to combine their telephone manufacturing operations into a joint venture with about $2.5 billion in annual revenue. The companies hope to create a global powerhouse in wireless telephones, the key growth area.
Lucent officials hope the venture will provide a strategy to revive the company's troubled consumer products business. And the deal addresses an important weakness in Philips's product line as that company focuses on consumer electronics. [Page D2.] 
 
Big Cruise Lines Consolidating
Royal Caribbean, a growing line that is still a distant second to Carnival Cruises, will buy Celebrity Cruise Lines, a well-regarded line, for $500 million in cash and stock. It will also assume $800 million in debt. [D2.]
 
Panel Votes to Ease Bank Rule
The House Banking Committee voted to permit a limited mixing of banking and commerce. The bill would let bank holding companies acquire nonfinancial companies, as long as they represented no greater than 15 percent of the banking company's gross domestic revenue. [D8.]
 
Barney's to Close Original Store
Barney's said it would close its original store on Seventh Avenue and 17th Street in Manhattan, along with other clothing stores in Houston, Dallas and Troy, Mich. [B1.]
 
Motorola Has New Satellite Plan
Motorola confirmed that it planned to build a $12.9 billion global satellite network to provide voice, data and video communications. [D10.]
 
American Eagle Orders Small Jets
American Eagle, the regional carrier affiliated with American Airlines, said it would buy 42 regional jets from Embraer of Brazil and 25 from Bombardier of Canada in contracts valued at $1.4 billion. [D4.]
 
TCI in Complex Stock Buyback
Tele-Communications Inc. announced a deal to buy back a block of stock owned by the estate of TCI's late founder, Bob Magness. The deal removes a threat that the Magness estate might sell its stake on the open market, and it will increase control of the company by John C. Malone, above. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Dow Average Slips; Nasdaq Rises
The stock market turned sluggish, despite benign inflation data. The Dow Jones industrial average gave up 11.31 points, closing at 7,760.78. But with technology stocks among the best performers, the Nasdaq index rose 11.16 points, to a record 1,443.11. [D10.]
 
Treasury prices fell, with the 30-year bond yield rising to 6.71 percent from 6.69. [D8.]
 
Japan's Trade Surplus Surges
Japan's trade surplus more than tripled in May, the Finance Ministry said in a report that fueled concerns that trade tensions with Japan's major partners could escalate. [D4.]
 
Senate Tax-Cut Bill Proposed
Less than a week after House Republicans pushed a package of tax cuts through their tax committee without a single Democratic vote, their Senate counterparts proposed a version that the Clinton Administration said was a slight improvement though still tilted too much to the wealthy. [A1.]
 
6.2% Ad-Spending Rise Seen
Robert J. Coen, a leading prognosticator of ad spending, predicts that marketers will spend a record $186 billion to advertise this year in the United States, up 6.2 percent from 1996. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D4.]
 
No Movement in Tobacco Talks
The talks on a settlement of tobacco litigation remained stalled as negotiators scrambled to unravel roadblocks over the issues of punitive damages and Federal nicotine regulation and as state attorneys general warned that the negotiations could break off soon if their demands were not met. [D22.]

HEADLINE: Rising Cost of College Imperils Nation, Report Says

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
The nation's colleges and universities need to cut costs dramatically or face a shortfall of funds that will increasingly shut out the poor from higher education and from economic opportunity as well, according to a blunt and far-ranging assessment of American higher education that was made public yesterday.
The report, by a panel of leading public and private university officials and corporate executives, says that rising costs, falling public spending and a coming surge in demand are making the economics of American higher education increasingly unsupportable. 
 If current enrollment, spending and financing trends continue, the report said, higher education will fall $38 billion short of what it needs to serve the expected student population in 2015. To sustain current spending, it said, tuition would have to double by 2015, effectively shutting off higher education to half of those who would want to pursue it.
The report focuses on one of the great unspoken dilemmas in President Clinton's push to make at least two years of college as common as a high school diploma: higher education is expensive, students pay only a small share of their costs and, while bringing increasing numbers of low-income students into higher education will have long-term economic benefits, it will also have enormous short-term economic costs.
On the other hand, the report said, with education increasingly crucial to economic advancement, cutting off access to education -- particularly to the poor and to immigrant groups who increasingly dominate the student population of states like California, Florida, New York and Texas -- would have enormous consequences for the nation's social fabric.
The report, "Breaking the Social Contract: The Fiscal Crisis in Higher Education," calls for a radical restructuring of universities, including an effort to overhaul university governance to limit the power of individual departments, redefining and often reducing the ambitions of different institutions and a sharing of resources between institutions.
The report also calls for more public financing, but it stresses that changes in the system should be prerequisites to any increases.
"The facts are irrefutable," said Thomas Kean, the former New Jersey Governor who is now president of Drew University and is a co-chairman of the panel that wrote the report. "We are heading for a crisis at the very time we can least afford one."
The panel, the Commission on National Investment in Higher Education, is made up of academic and business leaders convened by the Council for Aid to Education, an independent subsidiary of the Rand Corporation.
Experts say that higher education is already being reshaped by such forces as technology or competition from for-profit institutions, so that a straight-line extrapolation from current economic figures is difficult. And higher education is such a varied enterprise in the United States that a crisis for a public college in California does not necessarily mean a crisis for Harvard or Princeton.
Still, Roger Benjamin, president of the Council for Aid to Education, notes that even rich universities like Yale and Stanford have faced deficits and retrenchment in recent years.
And officials in state systems, which educate the majority of Americans, say the gap between resources and costs in higher education is becoming ever more daunting.
Charles Reed, chancellor of the State University System of Florida, said that over the next 10 years Florida would face an increase of nearly 50 percent in students at its public four-year institutions, to 300,000 from 210,000.
Barry Munitz, chancellor of the California State University System, said California was midway through a half-century of population growth and demographic change that would see the number of children in kindergarten through the 12th grade almost double, to about eight million, and go from about 75 percent white in 1970 to about 75 percent minority in 2020.
Population growth will only accelerate the financial problems facing higher education, the report said. It noted that the index measuring the increases in the price paid by colleges and universities for goods and services, like faculty salaries, rose more than sixfold from 1961 to 1995. The annual rate of growth in the cost of providing higher education exceeded the Consumer Price Index by more than a percentage point from 1980 to 1995, the report said.
And, while costs have gone up, public support has not. Since 1976, public support per student has just kept up with inflation, while real costs per student have grown by about 40 percent, the report said.
To make up the difference, tuition has risen dramatically, with tuition and fees doubling from 1976 to 1994. But the report said that a similar doubling between now and 2015 would have a catastrophic effect on access, pricing as many as 6.7 million students out of higher education.
"If you were to announce that, given fiscal pressures, the door to social mobility that was good enough for the old generation is really no longer needed by the new one, you might as well stick a ticking bomb inside the social fabric of this country," Chancellor Munitz said.
While calling for more public support, the report said that a solution to the fiscal imbalance had to start with colleges and universities themselves.
"Given the magnitude of the deficit facing American colleges and universities, it is surprising that these institutions have not taken more serious steps to increase productivity without sacrificing quality," the report said.
The report's recommendations for restructuring -- from sharing a library with other institutions to eliminating weak programs -- are not new, but there are enormous political and institutional barriers in the way of a major economic overhaul of higher education. Still, some experts say institutions have no option but to find ways to operate more efficiently.
"The ability to maximize revenue, given the competitive pressures for state dollars on the one hand and the resistance to future increases in tuition on the other, has about run its course," said Stanley Ikenberry, president of the American Council on Education, a leading advocacy group, which was not involved in the report. "All of that's putting more and more pressure on the operating side of the budget."

HEADLINE: City's Right to Bar Vendors From Streets Is Upheld

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 17

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani can banish sidewalk food vendors from congested streets in midtown Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.
The unanimous decision by the Court of Appeals reversed a mid-level appeals court ruling in February 1996 that said that the city had arbitrarily decided that certain streets in Manhattan and Brooklyn were too crowded to accommodate vendors, who hawk everything from bananas to burritos. 
 The ruling means the administration can now move ahead with a plan to stop vendors from operating on more than 20 midtown streets that a city panel had decided in August 1995 to close to vending either entirely or partly in a campaign to ease crowding in bustling areas of the city.
In a one-page statement, Rudy Washington, the city's Deputy Mayor for Community Development and Business Services, praised the Court of Appeals decision. He said the administration intended to begin enforcing the new restrictions on food vendors, though he did not specify when.
"While the city recognizes the importance of vendors to our economy," Mr. Washington said, "it is vital that restrictions be placed in areas where vending would diminish the quality of life and threaten public safety."
But the decision prompted dismay and anger among the city's 3,000 food peddlers, a group that has provided a service for New Yorkers who are forever on the run. Many vendors have said that the city's policy infringes on free enterprise and would almost certainly drive them out of business.
"I'm ready to move to India," said Jeff Cicio, president of the Big Apple Food Vendors Association, which represents 1,000 food vendors.
"The city has just been given carte blanche to close off streets to vendors and drive us out of New York. I used to believe there was such a thing as justice."
But the ruling was hailed as a victory by many midtown retailers and restaurant owners who have lobbied the city for years to restrict all street vendors, not just those who sell food.
The merchants complain that the vendors block sidewalks and streets, evade taxes and blemish the neighborhood's ambiance and appearance.
"The reason we are happy is that there are some really congested streets in midtown," said Daniel A. Biederman, the president of two business improvement districts, the Grand Central and 34th Street Partnerships.
"Many of the merchants and property owners will be very pleased."
The court's ruling centered on an August 1996 decision made by a city panel, called the Mayor's Street Vendor Review Panel, to restrict or ban food carts on some midtown streets and open new spots downtown and in Brooklyn and Queens.
The decision was reached after the members of the panel conducted a lengthy public-review process that included hearings intended to determine, among other things, the level of congestion on certain streets where vendors operate.
But the Big Apple Food Vendors Association sued to block the city's action, asserting that the panel had not used an objective standard to determine which streets were too crowded for vendors' carts. The lower courts eventually ordered the five-member panel to create a standard method of measuring pedestrian and vehicular congestion.
The courts also ordered the city to use that measure to decide where vendors could set up their carts, just as the city does when it decides where to permit newsstands and sidewalk cafes to operate.
But in the decision released today, the Court of Appeals overturned the lower court, saying that the city review panel was essentially a regulatory agency with the power to regulate the industry as it saw fit so long as it did so in accordance with the 1995 law that created it.
The panel, consisting of four representatives from city agencies and one from the City Council, was set up as part of a compromise between the Mayor and the Council after the Mayor vetoed a bill that would have lifted several restrictions on vendors enacted in 1983.
Today, food vendors reiterated their concerns about the way the panel made its decisions, saying that in the absence of such standards, powerful business groups could use their influence with the city to force vendors out of their neighborhoods.
"These are very powerful businesses," Mr. Cicio said. "In the next few months, you are going to see streets closed to vendors and vendors being pushed out of the city."
But the city has rejected that claim, saying that the panel attempts to balance competing needs and concerns of merchants and vendors when it decides where the vendors can do business.

HEADLINE: Gubernatorial Candidates Give Business Leaders Two Views of the Economy

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J., June 17

 BODY:
Appearing together for the first time since the primaries, New Jersey's gubernatorial candidates presented two starkly different assessments of the state's economy to a group of business leaders here tonight.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican incumbent, and her Democratic challenger, James E. McGreevey, chatted as they posed together for photographers at the beginning of the dinner meeting of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, and then addressed the group separately. 
 In her address, the Governor reviewed her record over the last four years and announced that, effective next month, she would reduce the amount that employers must pay into the state's unemployment insurance fund.
Mrs. Whitman, whose first public appearance with former Gov. Jim Florio occurred at a dinner held by the same group four years ago, underscored what is sure to become a familiar theme in the coming months, as she pursues a second term.
"This is where prospective governors come to make promises and sitting governors come to show what they've achieved," Mrs. Whitman told the 600 people at the dinner at a Princeton hotel.
She pointed to statistics that show job gains in the state and asserted that the tax cuts she promised to deliver during her 1993 campaign had enhanced the state's economy.
"I come before you as a governor who made promises and kept those promises," she said.
But Mr. McGreevey, a State Senator and Mayor of Woodbridge, discounted the idea that the 182,000 jobs created in the state under Mrs. Whitman had helped workers.
Citing a downturn in manufacturing jobs, he said New Jersey was "not keeping up with the rest of the nation."
The state's job growth has been primarily low-paying work in the service sector, he said. "We ought not to confuse a new job with a good job," he said. "Swapping high-paying jobs with benefits and a future for low-paying jobs without benefits and devoid of upward mobility is not a tradeoff we should accept."
Mr. McGreevey called on the business leaders to work with schools to develop job skills programs, and he also used the occasion to take some playful shots at his opponent.
"I want to congratulate Governor Whitman on her primary victory," Mr. McGreevey quipped. Mrs. Whitman ran unopposed in the June 3 primary, and Mr. McGreevey emerged by a narrow margin in a three-way race.
"I understand that Governor Whitman was already asleep while we were still waiting on the final results," he said.
With recent polls showing her comfortably ahead, Mrs. Whitman was beaming confidently on the dais throughout the evening, even when Mr. McGreevey was criticizing her administration.

HEADLINE: In Sink-or-Swim Welfare, Pensacola Staying Afloat

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: PENSACOLA, Fla.

 BODY:
As welfare programs across the country enter a new era of time limits, this sunbaked city of sailors and tourists has become the first place where limits have already expired and poor families are being dropped from the rolls.
After years of ideological debate, real-world experience has brought several surprises. So far, the two-year limits here, imposed under an experimental state program that predates the new Federal welfare law, have failed to serve as the motivating force that their supporters envisioned. The ticking clock has not pushed poor families to find jobs faster or leave the rolls earlier. 
 At the same time, however, the loss of benefits has not typically led to the deprivation that critics feared, at least not in the early stages. Most families initially land on their feet, and some former recipients even praise the cancellation of their benefits, saying it offered the motivation they ultimately needed to find a job.
Consider the journey of Denise Riley, a 39-year-old mother who spent two years insisting that she had a cancerous colon that prevented her from working. Her caseworkers asked for a doctor's letter. Ms. Riley failed to provide one. The two sides warred until last September, when her monthly $241 checks ran out.
And then what happened?
"I went to work a week later," she said cheerfully. "I had to."
Ms. Riley told the story at a naval-base pizzeria where even her part-time job stocking the buffet at $5.75 an hour pays better than her welfare check did. Though she still says she has cancer -- it is in remission, she says -- she calls the loss of her welfare check an unexpected blessing.
"It made me wake up and get my priorities back in order," she said. "I'll be honest: I might have leaned on that check a little longer."
Even the Pensacola program's most enthusiastic supporters say it is too early to call it a success. Only about 130 of the 2,700 families in the program have hit the time limit, and they come from that part of the caseload considered most ready to work, like those with a high school education or a history of employment. Those with greater problems face a three-year limit, which, for the earliest enrollees, has just begun to expire.
Still, however preliminary the Pensacola experience, it has taken some local advocates by surprise.
"We were really expecting an increase in homelessness, but there hasn't been the influx we were waiting for, at least not yet," said Anne C. O'Leary of First Call for Help, a referral agency for Pensacola families needing emergency aid. "I think it's kind of a sink-or-swim thing here, and people are paddling away. What we don't know is how long they'll stay afloat."
Indeed, the biggest questions center on the families' long-term prospects. Finding work is easier than keeping it, since children often get sick, child care arrangements collapse, cars break down, and layoffs arise. Ms. Riley is prone to bouts of depression that have cost her previous jobs, and even now she tries to steady herself by toting a Norman Vincent Peale paperback to work.
No one knows how well families will manage without the welfare safety net when setbacks do occur. Ms. Riley recently warned her mother, "Whatever I have to do to keep a roof over my head and keep my baby fed, I'll do it." When her mother said this would surely not include bank robbery or prostitution, Ms. Riley offered no assurances. "I said, 'Mama, whatever it takes.' "
What is more, Pensacola has created the Coupe de Ville of time-limited programs, going to an effort and expense that other places will not copy. Those chosen at random for enrollment find an approach rich in caseworkers, training opportunities and other enhanced services. In one case here, social workers spent more than $4,200 on taxi fares in a failed effort to help a car-less couple find work.
Shirley Jacques, the Pensacola program's director, warns that its most important features are already being sacrificed to budgetary pressures as the program goes statewide in compliance with the new Federal law.
"The intensive case management is the key," Ms. Jacques said, "and that's not going to be there."
 
2 Years Pass Faster Than Many Imagine
Despite those misgivings about the future, the encouraging start in Pensacola echoes optimistic findings elsewhere in the country. Spurred by tough new laws and strong local economies, caseloads are falling at unprecedented rates. And early reports from advocates or researchers in places as varied as Milwaukee, Pensacola and Des Moines have suggested that fewer people than many expected have fallen through the racks.
In Milwaukee, where the caseload reduction has been most dramatic, the city has not yet enforced time limits. Instead, it has created a strict work requirement that allows beneficiaries to stay on the rolls only if they join a work program, ending cash assistance if they do not.
The Pensacola welfare experiment, the Family Transition Program, enrolled its first participants in February 1994, long before the Federal law was enacted last year, making time limits of up to five years a national policy.
To the surprise of Pensacola officials, most recipients appear to have given the limits little thought. Those in the program are leaving welfare no faster than similar families in a control group with unrestricted benefits, according to the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, hired to study the program.
Those facing time limits do seem a bit more likely to work while they get welfare. But the differences are small: 46 percent of those in the program have jobs, compared with 40 percent of the control group.
Perhaps most important, the women whose benefits are limited are just as likely as others to have additional children.
"It's not stopping people from having babies," Ms. Jacques said. "That's real significant."
In a survey by the research group, only 40 percent of the caseworkers said they considered the time limits a "very effective" way to motivate clients.
There are several possible explanations.
Some recipients may be staying on the rolls to receive the additional services, like the chance to go to school. Others say they will not believe that the limits are real until they see friends being cut off.
Still others say they care more about food stamps, which are not subject to the time limit and which, in a low-cash-benefit state like Florida, can be worth almost twice as much as the cash.
Some researchers have speculated that setting a limit may paradoxically encourage people to stay on the rolls.
"It may be that the number sticks in people's minds: 'I'll stay on for two or three years,' " said Dan Bloom, the main author of a report compiled by the research group.
In a recent telephone survey, Mr. Bloom noted, only 44 percent of those facing the time limit said they planned to leave within a year, compared with 65 percent of those with unrestricted eligibility.
 
Scarce Understanding, But Bounty of Problems
While the recipients have mostly ignored the limits, the social workers have not. Many consider their reputations to be at stake, particularly since a panel of private citizens reviews each case in which the limit is reached.
"It really puts pressure on us to get them off," Ms. Jacques said. "When it was an entitlement, there wasn't any pressure."
At its best, that pressure focuses attention on women like Louise Armstrong, 49, who has been on welfare for most of the last two decades. A pleasant woman with a gold tooth that forms the silhouette of a champagne glass, Ms. Armstrong cares for a son and two young grandchildren, who call her Sweet Woo.
As soon as she was enrolled in the program, her caseworker was alarmed. With achievement test scores at the second-grade level, Ms. Armstrong has trouble simply understanding what a time limit means. "They say they're going to cut me off -- something like that," she said.
She also had a large hernia that developed after she had been shot by a former boyfriend, and doctors warned her to avoid work that involved pushing or lifting.
Hearing the clock tick, Ms. Armstrong's caseworker, Lynn Anderson, has poured countless hours into the case. First she recruited a medical specialist to operate on the hernia. Then she placed Ms. Armstrong in a workshop for the developmentally disabled. And she has even arranged three visits from the city bus authority, in what remains an unsuccessful effort to teach Ms. Armstrong how to ride the bus.
Worried because Ms. Armstrong has just 15 months of benefits left, Ms. Anderson is now helping her apply for disability benefits under the Supplemental Security Income program.
"This woman's problems would never have been identified under the old program," Ms. Anderson said. "She would have received benefits until her oldest child is 18 -- and then what?"
 
The Workings Of a City's Safeguards
For those who do lose benefits, the Pensacola program is noteworthy for the safeguards it has tried to include. The citizens' panel reviews each case that nears the limit, offering suggestions to caseworkers and participants. And the program has pledged a public job to recipients who cooperate by seeking work or training but who remain unemployed.
Forty-seven of the 130 people who have exhausted their limits have shown such cooperation. But to officials' surprise, not one has needed a public job. (The average unemployment rate here in Escambia County last year was 4.1 percent, compared with 5.4 percent for the nation.)
In addition, a child welfare specialist reviews each case that hits the limit, to determine whether the loss of benefits will create a risk of foster care. If so, the program can arrange for a "protective payee" to receive a reduced grant and monitor the family's use of it. Of the 130 families who have hit the limit, 3 have protective payees.
Among them is Mickey Parker, the landlord of a trailer park on the outskirts of Pensacola who is helping a former tenant. Mr. Parker had doubts about getting involved, because "you get yourself in trouble when you handle other people's money." But, he says, he felt sorry for his onetime tenant, because her former husband "beat her like a dog."
Though she has reached her limit on benefits, this mother of three still refuses to seek a job, because she does not want to place her children in day care. So Mr. Parker receives her $198 check.
"I give the money to her, and I follow up to make sure the bills get paid," he said.
He has even helped her find subsidized housing, and he provided the deposit she needed for a telephone. "Occasionally I've been known to reach into my own pocket, too," said Mr. Parker, who plays the role of good-hearted curmudgeon with evident relish. "The kids aren't doing without."
Given such precautions, Ms. Jacques said, none of the families that have lost their benefits have placed their children in foster care. But poor single mothers often make short-term arrangements -- landing part-time jobs, or moving in with relatives -- that unravel over time.
Indeed, a recent visit to Pensacola found at least one mother on the verge of losing her children, 11 months after losing her check. This 24-year-old mother, Tatashia Holley, makes no secret of her disdain for the experimental program.
"They just wanted people to go to McDonald's," said Ms. Holley, a high school graduate with three pre-school children. "I got too much pride for that. I didn't go to school for that stinking paycheck."
Ms. Holley declined to cooperate with caseworkers and lost her benefits last June, exactly two years after entering the program. At first, she had a safety net. With subsidized housing, she paid no rent. She earned about $40 a week baby-sitting for her sister's children. And she receives $400 a month in food stamps.
But she lost the child care job when her sister was laid off. And she left her rent-free apartment to live with her brother, who soon left her to live with a girlfriend. By this spring, she was so desperate for shelter that she moved into a dilapidated building that seemed less house than tree house.
The porch had all but fallen in. The walls had holes the size of footballs. Relatives were using the place as a drug den. And the electricity had been cut off.
"It was bad when I lost my check, but it just got real bad recently," said Ms. Holley, who initially declined to talk to a reporter, fearing he was a state worker who had come to take her children.
Convinced that she could no longer cope, Ms. Holley awoke on the morning of May 22 and decided to call the child welfare department herself, to place her children in foster care. At the last minute, her sister talked her out of it, emphasizing that Ms. Holley had hated her own years in foster care.
Instead, Ms. Holley persuaded her mother to care for the children, despite objections from her mother's boyfriend. But that plan too seems fragile. Within a week, her mother had become ill and returned the youngest of Ms. Holley's children, a 10-month-old boy named Kierre.
"I think we won't see the end result for a while," said Mary Allegretti, who supervises the program's child welfare reviews. She was speaking not only of Ms. Holley but also of the thousands of others who, exhausting benefits, enter the post-welfare world.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Nabobs Lite

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On the 25th anniversary of the Watergate break-in, let's imagine how today's very different media might cover the scandal.
The Miami Herald, after discovering in focus groups that readers are not that interested in national or world news, ignores the story, fearing it will turn off those looking for a pleasant reading experience. 
 U.S. News & World Report decides to put "Best Mutual Funds" on the cover instead of Nixon. Explaining this decision, the editor, James Fallows, says: "The Watergate story is just another case of the mainstream press putting tactics ahead of substance. Instead of worrying about the maneuverings of the White House staff, the news should treat the Presidency the way it does the scientific establishment, judging it by public pronouncements and not looking too far behind the veil."
ABC's "World News Tonight" plays the Watergate story third, after an in-depth look at how you can be fit even if you're fat and an expose about the American Kennel Club peddling pedigrees to undeserving dogs. Peter Jennings also does a tie-in with the scandal on "Solutions," reporting how the residents of a small Midwestern town are coping with bills from plumbers.
The New Orleans Times-Picayune does not want to focus on something as "negative" as Nixon's Jewish slurs on the tapes, so it assigns 20 reporters to examine the historic, economic and political roots of anti-Semitism in America.
On MSNBC, Brian Williams goes interactive in a chat room consumed with Mo Dean's sex life. On "The Site," Soledad O'Brien scolds Nixon as a technophobe who can't even use his own taping system.
On ABC's "This Week Without Brinkley," George Will and Bill Kristol treat the subject with withering scorn, arguing that Watergate nitpicking is taking away valuable time that the President could be devoting to China. They say Nixon is fighting a battle over the direction of the country, that we are driving good people out of government with impossibly high standards, and that there was no decision made solely on the basis of money. They warn that Richard Nixon is being Richard Jewelled.
On "Crossfire," Pat Buchanan disparages Woodward and Bernstein as "fern bar trash."
On CBS's Saturday morning show, Susan Molinari interviews Spiro Agnew, who rants against nattering nabobs of negativism and says there is no controlling legal authority. She nods sympathetically, chirping, "Watergate doesn't speak to the problems of working mothers."
Pat Nixon visits Rosie O'Donnell's show. The two share a Devil Dog and sing a duet from "No, No, Nanette."
Publicizing his $2.4 million book deal with Random House, G. Gordon Liddy looks for closure with Oprah, Baba and Johnnie Cochran, confiding that his alienation began when he was born prematurely and had to be kept in an incubator. Charlie Rose presses him: "Didn't it ever bother you, holding your hand over the candle flame like that? Does it impress women?"
On the final day of the Watergate hearings, NBC's "Nightly News" is in a panic. It goes with a split screen: Watergate on one side and the lack of progress in the JonBenet Ramsey case on the other.
On CNN, Gen-X pundit Farai Chideya calls the story overblown, arguing, "What does it tell us about the real lives of people of color?" Her conservative counterpart, Kellyanne Fitzpatrick, shrugs: "The country is way prosperous. Why are we in a shame spiral over petty theft?"
Joe Klein meets Deep Throat in a parking garage. Anonymous wants to discuss ghost-writing Mr. Throat's memoirs.
In a darkened room in the White House, Richard Nixon nurses a Scotch and listens to "Victory at Sea." He is contemplating his future, considering bids for three-pic-pacs from Oliver Stone, Jerry Bruckheimer and the Coen brothers.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Bullets and Rockets Fly In Capital of Cambodia
Heavy fighting broke out in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, between bodyguards loyal to the country's feuding co-Prime Ministers, Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Hun Sen. At least one person was killed and several were wounded, including an American journalist. The fighting was not directly connected to the reported confrontation between factions of the Khmer Rouge guerrilla leadership, in which the movement's founder, Pol Pot, is said to have killed a top aide, Son Sen. A1 

Saudi Suspect Deported to U.S.
A suspected terrorist implicated by Canadian officials in a bombing that killed 19 Americans in Saudi Arabia last year was deported to the United States. He has agreed to cooperate with the Justice Department in the investigation of the attack. A1
 
Suspect in C.I.A. Killing Seized
United States officials working with Afghan rebels and Pakistani intelligence officers have seized the lone suspect in the murder of two C.I.A. officers, Government officials said. Mir Amal Kansi is suspected of having shot five commuters in a morning rush-hour traffic jam outside the gates of the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters in Langley, Va., in January 1993. A1
 
Europeans Ponder Expansion
Leaders of the European Union were unable to reach agreement on the thorny question of how power could be shared once new members from central Europe are admitted. The 15-nation European Union is unlikely to be in a position to admit new countries until around the middle of the next decade, officials said. A3
 
Clinton Urges New Africa Policy
President Clinton joined with members of Congress to promote a series of trade measures with Africa intended to encourage free-market reforms of the continent's most promising economies. Mr. Clinton plans to urge the nations gathered at the G-7 summit meeting this week to help Africa, and to ask the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to forgive some of the debt burdening a number of of the poorest nations. A10
 
South African Sentenced
The leader of South Africa's neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement was sentenced to six years in prison for the beating of one of his black workers in 1996. Eugene TerreBlanche was also sentenced to a one-year prison term for setting his dogs on a gas station attendant two weeks before the beating. Mr. TerreBlanche was released after his extremist supporters paid his bail in large bags of coins. A4
 
Japan Allows Organ Donations
Japan's Parliament approved a bill that would allow heart or lung transplants, but only in cases where the donor has given prior consent. The bill did not give a new legal definition of death, which in Japan has been understood to be the point at which the heart stops beating, making transplants impossible. The bill gives the donor's family the right to veto the patient's wish. A6 
 
NATIONAL A14-21, D22
 
Republicans in Senate Propose a Tax-Cutting Bill
Senate Republicans proposed a tax-cutting bill that the Clinton Administration said was a slight improvement over that of House Republicans, but one that was still tilted too much toward the wealthy. Although the proposal addressed some of the concerns of the White House and Congressional Democrats, it did little to clarify the prospects for passage of a tax-cutting bill without a prolonged partisan standoff. Fugitive Held in France

HEADLINE: G.O.P. IN SENATE OFFERS A MEASURE FOR CUTS IN TAXES

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Less than a week after House Republicans pushed a package of tax cuts through their committee without a single Democratic vote, their Senate counterparts proposed a version today that the Clinton Administration said was a slight improvement but still tilted too much to the wealthy.
Although the Senate proposal addressed some of the concerns of the White House and Congressional Democrats, it did little to clarify the prospects for passage of a tax-cutting bill without a prolonged partisan standoff with President Clinton. 
 William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, included in today's proposal the main provisions that his party has promised for years, including a tax credit of up to $500 per child and a reduction in capital gains taxes.
But unlike Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Senator Roth appeared to have a good chance of winning some Democratic support. His bill has several measures favored by Democrats on the committee, including a plan to link the child tax credit to a college savings program.
In one indication of how Mr. Roth had wooed Democrats, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the Finance Committee's ranking Democrat, issued a statement listing 11 provisions that were included in the tax bill at his behest. They ranged from a permanent extension of the tax exemption for employer-provided educational assistance to additional financing for Amtrak and a reduction in the excise tax on draft cider sought by apple growers in New York and Vermont.
Democrats said they were unlikely to introduce an alternative to Senator Roth's bill in the Finance Committee, but left open the possibility that they might push for a vote on a competing plan when the measure reaches the Senate floor.
Administration officials said they were pleased that Mr. Roth had taken account of some of their concerns about the House bill. But they said the Senate proposal, which will be taken up by the Finance Committee on Thursday, remained unacceptable to them, largely because it would benefit the wealthy far more than lower- and middle-income people and because it did not provide as much in tax breaks for college as Mr. Clinton wanted.
Administration officials have stopped short of threatening to veto the legislation, but they reiterated today that they would demand substantial changes before the President could sign it.
"The Roth bill improved on the Archer bill in certain important areas," said Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. "But having said that, we still have serious concerns with the Roth bill."
The Senate bill is likely to be amended somewhat by the Finance Committee, and it will no doubt face many attempts by members of both parties to amend it further when it reaches the floor. It would then have to be reconciled with the House bill, which is likely to face a vote on the floor next week. All the while, the Republican leadership will have to make delicate political judgments about how far they are willing to go in pursuing their own agenda at the risk of prompting a veto from Mr. Clinton and another partisan standoff.
The Roth bill differed from the House version in several important areas. Mr. Roth's bill allocates somewhat less to capital gains tax reductions than Mr. Archer's bill -- unlike the House bill, the Roth measure would not allow investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating their gains or reduce the capital gains rate for corporations -- but it provides more generous reductions in Federal inheritance taxes to business owners and farmer, and contains more measures to expand the Individual Retirement Account and similar savings programs.
Both the House and the Senate versions contain a $500-per-child credit for many families, but the Senate version would require parents to put the proceeds into an educational savings account for children 13 through 16 years of age.
Mr. Roth's bill does not include any version of a $10,000 deduction for college expenses that the President has fought for -- a modified and stripped-down version of the proposal was contained in the House bill -- but it has other provisions with bipartisan support, including making interest payments on student loans deductible.
In an effort to soften Mr. Clinton's opposition, Senator Roth expanded his original provision for a tax credit for the first two years of college. The credit is one of Mr. Clinton's priorities in the bill. He had initially proposed a credit of $1,500. Mr. Archer's plan scaled it back to 50 percent of up to $3,000 in tuition and book costs after taking account of financial aid. Mr. Roth's plan tracks the House bill, but adds a provision that the credit could be 75 percent of up to $2,000 in expenses -- or $1,500 -- for students at community colleges and technical schools.
While acknowledging Mr. Roth's compromises, Administration officials again argued today that both the House and the Senate bills failed to live up to the terms of the balanced-budget package agreed to last month by Congress and the White House.
Administration officials said the budget agreement explicitly provided about $35 billion for the President's package of college tax breaks over five years, while the Roth bill allocates less than $21 billion and completely strips out the Clinton plan to make up to $10,000 a year in college expenses deductible.
Treasury officials said their preliminary analysis showed that the Roth plan was skewed toward the wealthiest taxpayers, with the top 20 percent getting 65.5 percent of the tax cuts, and the top 1 percent getting 13.1 percent of the cuts. By contrast, they said, the bottom 60 percent of the population by income would get 12.7 percent of the benefits.
Republicans defended the plan as targeted toward helping middle-class taxpayers who most need relief from rising tax bills.
"Republicans, Democrats and President Clinton can all claim authorship for various parts of this proposal," Senator Roth said in a statement.
"This debate should not be partisan," he added. "It should not be about class warfare. It should be about working together to help the American taxpayers save, invest, pay for college and keep more of what they earn."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "COMPARE AND CONTRAST: Tax Proposals in the House and Senate"
A comparison of the tax bill passed last week by the House Ways and Means Committee and its Senate counterpart, which was released today by Senator William V. Roth Jr. the chairman of the Finance Committee.
 
Tax Credits for Children
House -- A credit of up to $500 per child up to age 17, phased out for couples filing jointly with incomes above $110,000. The credit would be $400 next year, rising to $500 the following year. Many lower and middle income families who already claim the earned income tax credit or the dependent care credit would not receive the full child credit.
Senate -- A credit of up to $500 per child up to age 17 through 2002, and then up to age 18, subject to the same income limits as the House bill. For children aged 13-16, the proceeds of the credit would have to be placed in an educational savings account modeled on an Individual Retirement Account.
 
College Education
House -- For the first two years of college, a tax credit of up to 50 percent of $3,000 in tuition and book costs, after accounting for financial aid. Deductions of up to $10,000 a year for college costs when money is saved through several varieties of savings plans, and would allow penalty-free withdrawals from IRA's for college and graduate school.
Senate -- For first two years of college, a tax credit or up to 50 percent of $3,000 in tuition and book costs, after accounting for inflation, or up to 75 percent of $2,000 for costs of community or technical colleges. Would make up to $2,500 a year in student loan interest payments deductible for five years. Would create educational savings accounts and allow penalty-free withdrawals from IRA's college and graduate school.
 
Capital gains
House -- Would reduce the top rate for individuals to 20 percent from 28 percent and set a bottom rate of 10 percent. Would allow investors to factor out the effects of inflation in calculating gains starting in 2001. Would allow profits on sale of a primary home to be exempted up to $500,000 for couples filing jointly, $250,000 for single filers. Would reduce the top corporate rate to 30 percent from 35 percent.
Senate -- Would reduce the rates for individuals in the same way as the House bill, but would not allow indexing for inflation and would not reduce the corporate rate. Would include the same provisions as the House bill for sale of a home. Would also provide special capital gains reductions for small businesses and venture capital.
 
Retirement Accounts
House -- Would create new form of IRA open to taxpayers regardless of income level. Contributions would not be tax deductible, but would accrue interest tax free and could be withdrawn tax free after retirement or for buying a first home.
Senate -- Would expand income limits for traditional IRAs and would create new accounts similar to those in the House bill.
 
Inheritance taxes
House -- Would increase the exemption from Federal estate taxes from $600,000 to $1 million over 10 years.
Senate -- Would increase the exemption to $1 million over 11 years, and would provide an additional $1 million exemption immediately for many family-owned businesses and farms. (pg. D22)

SECTION: Section C; Page 15; Column 2; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1775 words

HEADLINE: A Tragically Fallen Star Smolders in Memory;
Hollywood's Tryst With Dorothy Dandridge Inspires Real Love at Last

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
When Dorothy Dandridge played a 1953 engagement at the glamorous Mocambo nightclub in Los Angeles, cigarette girls sold copies of Charles Alfred Kinsey's "Sexual Behavior of the Human Female" as a publicity stunt. That was one small measure of Dandridge's phenomenal sultriness, thanks to her rare mix of poised elegance and voluptuous beauty. Reviewing her great triumph on the movie screen, The Hollywood Reporter put it succinctly: "Dorothy Dandridge in 'Carmen Jones' -- Wow!" Describing another of her nightclub appearances, Time said aptly that she "came wriggling out of the wings like a caterpillar on a hot rock."
Like her acquaintances Marilyn Monroe and Ava Gardner, Dandridge had allure that could bewitch an audience and demolish all memory of the nice girl next door. She had looks, talent, ambition, everything -- everything except a career. As an enticing black star of the 40's and 50's, she fell victim to bigotry, personal tragedy and one of Hollywood's great failures of imagination: after "Carmen Jones" in 1954, the year of Brown v. the Board of Education, there were no worthy follow-up roles for its incandescent star. She died at 42 in 1965, an apparent suicide, with $2.14 in the bank and much more than her share of regrets. 
 Adored in her day especially by black audiences ("She was our queen," said Nichelle Nichols, who later went on to "Star Trek" fame), Dandridge later fell into relative obscurity. "Carmen Jones" is a television perennial, and filmmakers including Spike Lee (in "Girl 6," whose heroine dreams of Dandridge as a role model) have offered glowing homages to her memory. But in David Thomson's "Biographical Dictionary of Film," an invaluable reference book with 1,000 entries, where the D's go deep enough to include Mark Donskoi, Basil Dearden and Harry d'Abbadie d'Arrast, she does not even rate a mention.
Now her memory is revived by "Dorothy Dandridge," Donald Bogle's splendid and highly readable new biography (Amistad Press), and by a two-week retrospective (enterprisingly programmed by Mr. Bogle and Bruce Goldstein) at the Film Forum from tomorrow through July 3. In charting the course of her life, both the book and the film series also offer considerable insight into the racial climate that shaped Dandridge's rise and fall.
And her story, which also has the makings of an extraordinary soap opera, will be heard again. Whitney Houston's production company is helping to present the series now that Ms. Houston has won a much-publicized battle for film rights to the biography. Others eager to star in the story reportedly included Halle Berry and Janet Jackson. (Among contemporary black female stars, it is Ms. Berry who comes closest to Dandridge's sexy insouciance and stately beauty.)
 
From Churches To the Movies
Dandridge's story begins at a time when no mass-market movie about an alluring, tragic black heroine would have been undertaken. Born in 1922, she grew up well aware of segregation thanks to her career as a singing child star. First as part of the Wonder Children and then with the trio called the Dandridge Sisters (only one, Vivian, was actually her sister), she performed on the church circuit and then at the Cotton Club, where black singers were instructed not to mix with white patrons. Pushing her vigorously into show business were her mother, the character actress Ruby Dandridge, and Ruby's female lover, who cruelly disciplined the children. Dorothy had two stage mothers.
As a young performer, Dorothy appeared in little films known as "soundies" that were made for video jukeboxes of the 1940's, with titles like "Congo Clambake" and "Lazybones."
This was also the time of so-called "race movies" for black audiences, made on low budgets with energy, unself-conscious attitudes and a surprising sense of freedom. (This era in black American film history is currently being explored at the Museum of Modern Art, with the May series "Within Our Gates: American Race Films 1918-1949" being reprised from June 24 through July 28. There will also be a panel discussion on June 24. And on June 28, the American Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, will revive a related artifact, the 1928 musical version of "Uncle Tom's Cabin.")
On the Film Forum's July 1 composite program billed as "Dandridge: The Early Years," her fresh, flirtatious talent is much in evidence. This show includes an incredible excerpt from the Sonja Henie musical "Sun Valley Serenade," in which the very white Glenn Miller Orchestra performs a sunny musical number in a ski lodge setting. Then, completely incongruously (so that the sequence could be excised by theaters in the South), out comes Dandridge in slinky black satin, beaming coyly and tap-dancing with the Nicholas Brothers as she asks the musical question, "Pardon me, boys, is that the Chattanooga Choo-Choo?" The Glenn Miller part of the sequence looks awfully Tyrolean next to that.
Dandridge went on to marry one of the brothers, Harold Nicholas, in a brief union that brought her lingering grief. She went into labor with the couple's only child, Harolyn, on a day when Harold rushed off to a golf game and left her stranded without car keys. The baby was born brain damaged, and, rightly or wrongly, Dandridge always ascribed the trouble to a delay in the baby's delivery. She was unable to raise her daughter herself and placed her in foster care. When, late in life, Dandridge became too impoverished to pay Lynn's expenses and the child became a ward of the state, it was one of the last and worst humiliations contributing to her decline.
But first came the glory days: nightclub triumphs (even in hotels that banned her from using their coffee shops or elevators), ardent admirers and increasingly interesting movie roles. She played a kindly, sensitive schoolteacher opposite Harry Belafonte in "Bright Road" in 1953 and then a year later floored both him and movie audiences with "Carmen Jones."
 
First Love, Then Isolation
This blazing colloquial adaptation of Bizet's opera (with lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Dandridge lip-synching wonderfully to Marilyn Horne's voice) holds up extraordinarily well thanks to Dandridge's prescient sexual confidence. Brazen, teasing and exhilaratingly free, she was a vision of womanly power well ahead of her time.
Always proud and even royally haughty, Dandridge loathed the flagrant way in which "Carmen Jones" was promoted. (Ad copy: "That man crazy, dazzle dancing gal -- sultry and savage -- incendiary -- whirling through a jungle world in Bizet's pulsing beat and blood-surging musical!") But she fell for Otto Preminger, the film's director, who had initially deemed her much too ladylike for the role.
Her long, surreptitious affair with Preminger was one of Dandridge's many liaisons with white lovers, romances that served to separate her from black Hollywood. (Eventually, she would contemptuously refer to her second husband, a white restaurateur who ruined her financial stability, as "the headwaiter.")
As a mocha-skinned woman whose features suggested Caucasian looks, Dandridge found herself ever more isolated as the civil rights and black power movements took on momentum. Nobody, black or white, seemed to know where she belonged.
She was nominated for a 1954 best actress Academy Award along with Audrey Hepburn ("Sabrina"), Judy Garland ("A Star is Born"), Jane Wyman ("Magnificent Obsession") and Grace Kelly ("The Country Girl"). And there were many who thought her Carmen deserved to win. (Kelly did.) But after that professional peak, there were surprisingly few job offers, and even those presented her with either supporting roles or characters of ambiguously mixed race. Politically aware and at times outspoken, she regarded the latter parts as demeaningly incomplete.
When Darryl F. Zanuck tried to coax her into the supporting role of Tuptim in "The King and I," Dandridge openly rebelled. "I can't play a slave," she said. And with that, she took on a reputation of being difficult and relegated herself to more iffy roles.
Splashiest among these is her performance in Robert Rossen's 1957 "Island in the Sun," a lurid tropical romance that stands out today for its currents of racial tension. There were open hints of attraction between characters played by Joan Fontaine and Mr. Belafonte. ("At least I have made them agree that Harry and I can drink out of the same coconut," Ms. Fontaine said.) But it took elaborate negotiations to allow for a scene in which John Justin, a white man, vaguely expresses love for the woman Dandridge played. A kiss was out of the question.
That same year, she wound up making "Tamango," an obscure French film that is this series's most interesting oddity, since it anticipates the blaxploitation era and plays upon Dandridge's own ambiguous racial identity. As the refined mistress of the white captain of a slave ship (Kurt Jurgens, another of her lovers), she is gradually awakened from her benighted ways and enlisted to join the brewing black mutiny on board. In this film and especially in the noirish 1960 "Malaga" with Trevor Howard, Dandridge's private evolution is evident on screen. The confidence and delight are on the wane, replaced by jaunting sadness and self-doubt.
There had been loose talk of a Dandridge "Cleopatra" and a Dandridge "Lady Sings the Blues" directed by Orson Welles. But roles like those proved tantalizingly unavailable, and professional disappointment only made her private problems more consuming.
 
Descending to Drink And Disappointment
She drank too much and took antidepressants, drugging herself so heavily that she fell asleep at the reception for her second wedding. The costs of keeping up glamorous appearances as a nightclub star became prohibitive, but economic pressures and problems with the I.R.S. forced her to keep working. Essentially shy and even reclusive, she had always hated the pressure to perform for live crowds.
By the end, she had been reduced to playing Anita in a Chicago company of "West Side Story" and auditioning for the role of a black sidekick to Debbie Reynolds's Singing Nun. (She did not get the part.) In an epiphany tailor-made for a movie biography, she appeared humiliatingly as a lounge act in a hotel that had once featured her in its main room.
Beautiful and relatively young as she still was, she reminded one suitor of Gloria Swanson in "Sunset Boulevard." As Mr. Bogle writes, "Her fall from grace oddly had made her all the more a haunting and romantic figure."
In better times, Dandridge said, "If I were Betty Grable, I could capture the world."
