HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Real G-7's

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Tomorrow in Denver the Group of Seven major industrial democracies, along with Russia, will gather to discuss the global economy and any other issue they can rustle up to make their tired annual summit meeting seem relevant. The G-7 has to really scrounge for a role today because as a group it no longer represents the most important powers shaping the world economy. I mean, would you look to Canada for economic advice? Hockey yes, but not money. With that in mind, I offer my biennial listings of whom you'd invite to the G-7 if you weren't stuck with the U.S., Germany, Japan, Italy, France, Canada and Britain.
I. If you wanted to have a fascinating discussion about how the global economy really works -- but with all the participants wearing bags over their heads -- you would have the all-criminal G-7. After all, the lowering of borders and improvements in communications and financial transfers have made the movement of illicit funds and drugs some 8 percent of the global economy. "Crime has become the global growth industry," says Louise Shelley, an American University expert on global corruption. 
 A summit of the G-7-Most-Wanted would bring together representatives (and their lawyers) from the Russian-Ukrainian Mafia, the Chinese Triads, the Cali Cartel, the Mexican drug Mafia, the Nigerian Mafia (any government official would do), the Italian Mafia and the Japanese Yakuza. Heading the meeting (for a small fee) would be a representative of the Swiss banks who launder all their money (for a small fee).
II. A more legitimate gathering would be the All-in-the-Family G-7. It would discuss how some cyber-tribes, big billionaire families, now span the globe and are becoming as powerful as small countries. Around the table would be: the Wallenbergs of Sweden ($36 billion in Swedish companies alone), the Riadys of Indonesia (banking, real estate), Tata Sons Ltd. of India (80 companies, 250,000 workers), the Toyodas of Japan, Kim Woo Choong's Daewoo Group from South Korea ($52 billion in annual revenues), Mexico's Carlos Slim and family (telecom and retailing), with Rupert Murdoch as chairman. (No Americans in this group, but they all depend on our market and technology.)
III. If you insisted on inviting nations, you'd have the U.S., Germany, Japan and China. In addition, one chair would be shared by the world's three most dynamic regions: northern Italy, where entrepreneurs and manufacturers have created the richest district in Europe; Bangalore, India, the Silicon Valley of South Asia, and the Singapore-Malaysia-Indonesia high-tech triangle. The sixth chair would go to the Netherlands, where a novel deal between industrialists and labor unions has found a way to maintain many European-style social benefits while doing U.S.-style downsizing, privatizing and loosening up of labor rules. It's given the Dutch faster growth than Britain, France and Germany, with only 6.5 percent unemployment. The last seat would go to Chile, whose strong economy is a Dutch-like growth model for developing countries.
IV. If you wanted the rising economic powers you would invite Intel, whose chips are to the post-industrial revolution what coal was to the industrial revolution; Microsoft, because once it's done linking software, media, banking and the Internet it will play a role in virtually every human interaction; Cisco Systems, which makes the black boxes that tie the Internet together, and the more the Internet expands the more will Cisco; Citic, the state-owned Chinese trading company that has its finger in every piece of China's development, from airlines to telecom; and Unocal, the oil company whose foreign policy counts for far more in Afghanistan, Central Asia and Myanmar than the State Department's.
This group would also include an anonymous 23-year-old currency trader, who would sit at the summit table trading on a computer screen, never saying a word to anyone else. He would represent the brutal and anonymous disciplinary force of the global market, and he would short the currency or stock of anyone at the table who says anything bad about Alan Greenspan. He would have to share his chair, though, with a French truck driver, who would speak for all those workers who feel squeezed by globalization. The French trucker would insist the summit's sessions last only 90 minutes a day, with three hours off for lunch, and with all three days counting toward his pension.

HEADLINE: House Panel Says C.I.A. Lacks Expertise to Carry Out Its Duties

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency and the rest of the nation's intelligence services do not have "the analytic depth, breadth and expertise to monitor political, military and economic developments worldwide," a House committee that wants to increase intelligence spending reported today.
The House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, whose chairman, Representative Porter J. Goss, a Florida Republican, is a former C.I.A. officer, said the intelligence services had "a largely inexperienced work force," often unable to speak foreign languages and unfamiliar with the countries they analyzed. 
 In addition, the committee reported, the agency has an "uncertain commitment and capability to collect 'human intelligence' on a worldwide basis through espionage." The panel said the United States should spend more money on that task.
The committee wants to increase secret intelligence spending by at least 5 percent, bringing it to more than $30 billion, several Government officials said. If approved by Congress, that would be the biggest budget in five years.
About one-tenth of the money goes to the Central Intelligence Agency and almost all the rest goes to military intelligence services like the National Security Agency, which spies on the telecommunications of allies and enemies alike; the National Reconnaissance Office, which builds spy satellites, and the Defense Intelligence Agency, which coordinates military intelligence.
The committee's annual report with its budget authorization for intelligence is classified, as is the budget itself, but the panel published an unclassified version of the report today. The report is a combination of scolding and encouragement -- a critique of the intelligence agencies' intellectual abilities and derring-do, and a spur to do better, with the help of more money. A C.I.A. spokesman said the agency had not seen the panel's report and could not comment on the criticisms it contained.
The report said the intelligence agencies continued to spend billions of dollars on advanced photo reconnaissance satellites and electronic-eavesdropping equipment, but lacked the brainpower to analyze the information collected by these technologies. A former director of the National Security Agency, Adm. Noel Gayler, has compared trying to get hard facts from the undifferentiated flow of data to trying to take a drink of water from a fire hose.
The nation "no longer needs, nor can it afford, to continue pouring vast amounts of money into expensive, high-tech collection platforms if the data collected is not exploited," the panel said. "Collecting information that is not processed and analyzed is a waste of taxpayer dollars."
The committee said it was "very concerned about the criteria and techniques used in the process of declassifying intelligence documents," because it feared that too much information might be released. Historians awaiting the declassification of intelligence records from the 1950's and 1960's have strongly criticized the slow pace of the C.I.A. in releasing those documents, which are supposed to be made public after 25 years.
But the intelligence panel said it was "highly skeptical that the true costs of declassification have been determined accurately." Those costs, it implied, can be measured in dollars and in the potential damage to national security from opening up the C.I.A.'s archives.

HEADLINE: The Endangered Bookshop

 BODY:
The demise at month's end of the Doubleday Book Shop on Fifth Avenue and 56th Street will leave more than a physical void. For upward of a century, midtown Fifth Avenue was the premier showcase of Publishers' Row. Generations of authors strove to appear nonchalant as they looked for their new progeny in the gleaming windows at Scribner's and Brentano's. No more. Soaring rents years ago doomed both bookstores, and B. Dalton as well. The corridor's sole survivor will soon be the giant Barnes & Noble outlet at 48th Street.
In this respect, Fifth Avenue resembles a hundred humbler Main Streets. Just over half of American readers now buy their books in chain stores. Out of some 30,000 American bookstores, chain outlets accounted for 13,500 last year, and their number is growing. Barnes & Noble, to cite the most visible example, has 439 "superstores" and 569 mall-based stores, and is planning to open 70 new outlets annually for the next three years. 
 Optimists point to the excellence of many superstores, with their seemingly huge stocks, coffee bars and regular readings by authors. Sprouting around these giants are new niche bookstores, catering to special audiences -- readers of mysteries, women's studies, New Age and so forth. Moreover, Amazon.com has sold books to readers through the Internet with enough success that the chains are now scrambling to sell their wares in cyberspace. Amazon not only sells obscure academic titles, but offers book reports by customers.
To pessimists, though, the real problem is the leverage that superstores exert on publishers by displays that concentrate only a few titles for a few weeks at the front of the store. If a book does not take off instantly, unsold copies will most probably be returned to the publishers, as happened to 35 percent of all adult hardcover copies last year. The system is good for celebrity books, how-to manuals and romance novels. It is not good for serious titles that sell fewer than 10,000 copies.
Moreover, booksellers worry that sales have not kept pace with a thriving economy, possibly because of competition from other media. Sales of hardcover books for adults fell 4.4 percent last year, while paperback revenues grew only 1.8 percent.
Independent booksellers complain that the playing field is not level, alleging that chains use their market share to obtain unfair discounts, a practice that has already provoked litigation. This is not simply a commercial concern, since books are essential to the nation's intellectual life.
It may well make sense to encourage the countervailing power of independent booksellers, in some cases with special concessions. Columbia University, for example, has helped establish Labyrinth Books, specializing in academic titles, by turning over 7,000 square feet of space at affordable rent. If other educational institutions emulated this benign synergy with commerce, it would sharpen competition and palpably benefit common readers everywhere.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Finds 'Pockets of Weakness'

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
A few "pockets of weakness" have emerged in the nation's booming economy, the Federal Reserve said today in a report presenting what analysts saw as fresh support for keeping interest rates steady.
In a survey of regional conditions and compilation of anecdotal reports from its 12 district banks, the Fed portrayed an economy shifting to a more sustainable pace after hitting a decade-high annual growth rate of 5.8 percent in the first quarter. 
 "All 12 district economies expanded in May and early June, although there were pockets of weakness," said the survey, known as the beige book because of the color of its cover.
Jobs are going begging and that is leading to some wage increases, but so far higher pay has not forced companies to raise retail prices, the survey said. "Retail and manufacturing prices were being held in check by heavy competition," it said.
The survey's comments about prices were echoed in a separate report from the Labor Department today that suggested strong productivity gains as a reason for the small increase in consumer prices.
In the first five months of this year, consumer prices have advanced at an annual rate of only 1.4 percent. Meanwhile, nonfarm productivity grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 2.6 percent in the first quarter, double the 1.3 percent rate of the fourth quarter, the Labor Department report said. The 2.6 percent gain was revised from a 2 percent rise reported earlier. It was the best performance since a 2.6 percent gain in the fourth quarter of 1993.
Robust increases in productivity -- a measure of the time and effort of producing goods and services -- mean that businesses can raise wages without increasing their prices because workers are producing more in each hour of work.
The Federal Reserve's report appeared to support most economists' belief that Fed policy makers, due to meet July 1 and 2, won't need to quash inflation by dampening the economy with higher interest rates.
"It's clearly a signal for the Federal Reserve to hold interest rates unchanged in the near term," said Lynn Reaser, an economist with Barnett Banks Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla. "It confirms other reports the economy is still growing, but at a moderate pace."
Fed policy makers nudged short-term interest rates higher on March 25 for the first time in two years. But, amid signs the economic growth was moderating, they did not touch rates at their May 20 meeting.
The beige book, based on information collected through June 9, found construction and real estate strong across much of the country, despite weak growth in some areas.
It said retail sales were weaker in many Fed districts but manufacturing remained at high levels and growing. That has resulted in some unwanted pileup of inventories, it said, noting a sizable rise reported by an auto manufacturer in the Chicago district. Ms. Reaser said the overhang of unsold goods should act as a brake on growth this summer.
At the same time, the beige book found many examples of the impact of the booming job market, which pushed the nation's unemployment rate to a near 24-year low of 4.8 percent in May.
Companies were having trouble hiring skilled professionals in the high-technology, construction and energy industries. And some districts -- Atlanta, Chicago, Dallas, Kansas City, Minneapolis and San Francisco -- reported shortages of both skilled blue-collar and entry-level workers.
Temporary help firms in the Cleveland district have had to turn to marginally qualified workers and spend more on training. A Wisconsin contractor reported paying wages to an idle crew between jobs for three weeks just to avoid losing workers to competitors.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map: "Some Slowdown in Growth Is Seen"
A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the beige book report issued by the Fed yesterday.
 
Minneapolis -- Retail sales of cars and general merchandise were brisk. Unemployment rates remained low.
 
Chicago -- Most industries expanded moderately. Labor markets continued to tighten. Loan demand was strong.
 
Cleveland -- Construction activity slowed because of wet weather. Businesses reported labor shortages but little change in wages.
 
Boston -- Retailers and manufacturers reported sales growth and increased hiring. Prices were mostly stable.
 
New York -- Retailers reported slower sales, due in part to poor weather. Banks reported rising loan demand.
 
Philadelphia -- Retailers reported steady sales as factories noted increased shipments and orders.
 
Richmond -- Manufacturing and service sectors grow rapidly. Retailers reported rising inventories.
 
Atlanta -- Factory activity and demand at retailers weakened. Continued labor shortages reported.
 
St. Louis -- Car dealers and retailers reported slowing sales. Manufacturers reported moderate sales and job growth.
 
Kansas City -- Manufacturing remained strong. The only sign of weakness was a slowdown in construction activity. Labor was tight.
 
Dallas -- Labor markets were tighter, and the shortage of workers pushed wages up. Price reports were mixed.
 
San Francisco -- Growth was strong in most areas. Manufacturing remained strong, led by the aerospace industry. Companies reported widespread shortages of skilled labor.
 
Map of the continental U.S. shows the 12 districts.
 
(Source: Bloomberg News)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Higher Despite Japan Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped yesterday after a surging Japanese trade surplus was reported, but the United states currency recovered to end higher after top American officials hinted they would not confront Japan over the imbalance at the Group of Seven meeting in Denver this weekend.
Rising military tensions on the Korean peninsula and further indications that Europe's planned single currency will be a weak successor to the mark also helped the dollar. 
 "The dollar is now stuck in a tight range, and this lack of movement will continue toward the end of this week because everyone's anxious to see how the G-7 turns out," said Tatsuya Enomoto, chief foreign exchange dealer at Sumitomo Bank in New York. The Group of Seven major industrial nations are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States.
The dollar fell to an intraday low of 112.90 yen in early dealings before recovering to settle in New York at 113.65 yen, up from 113.31 Tuesday. The dollar settled at 1.7333 marks, up from 1.7308. The pound cost $1.6388, unchanged.
Data released by Japan's Finance Ministry overnight showed the Japanese trade surplus in May totaled an unexpected 738.27 billion yen, or $6.5 billion, tripling the level of a year earlier. The surplus with the United States nearly doubled to 322.87 billion yen, or $2.8 billion, the eighth consecutive monthly increase.
Jeffrey Frankel, a member of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, said such monthly statistics were misleading and did not necessarily signify a trend.
"The trade data has been pretty well discounted in the market," said Bill Bertha, foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
The dollar was also helped by a flare-up of antagonism between North and South Korea that raised demand for dollars as a safe haven investment. In an unusually strong statement, North Korea's defense ministry accused United States and South Korean forces of secretly planning for war.
Against European currencies, the dollar's strength reflected further indications that the European Union will have to loosen the strict criteria on deficit reduction designed to keep the euro strong when it makes its debut in January 1999.

HEADLINE: Security Is Tight for Denver Meeting of Industrial Nations

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 18

 BODY:
It sounds like a scene for pulp fiction: A week after a jury in Denver hands down a death sentence for the deadliest act of political terrorism on American soil, the same city is host to the leaders of eight of the world's most powerful nations.
Plausible or not, that is the real-life scenario faced by security planners as foreign leaders start converging here on Thursday for an annual meeting, this year called "The Denver Summit of the Eight." The Group of Seven leading industrial nations -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- has invited President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to attend the meeting, and some people are now calling the gathering the "Group of Eight." 
 As eight-foot chain link fences and concrete barriers rose today around the downtown meeting site, security officials declined to detail their plans, much less draw links to the death sentence imposed last week by a Federal jury on Timothy J. McVeigh, the far-rightist convicted of carrying out the bombing that killed 168 people in Oklahoma City in 1995.
But although protests are planned by a plethora of groups, including a march by 6,000 Iranian exiles to demand a trade embargo against Teheran, official fears are directed at an algebra equation of the far right: "G8 = N.W.O.." In translation, the Group of Eight equals the New World Order, a phrase coined by President George Bush after the collapse of Communism that has become shorthand among militia and other conservative groups to refer to an elite, international cabal designed to oppress and enslave individual Americans.
"It sounds like the New World Order to me," James L. Pate, a Soldier of Fortune magazine editor with strong militia contacts, said today when asked about the summit meeting. "But have I heard any rumblings out in militia land? No, I haven't."
Still, without a lot of advance publicity, Denver's three-day summit conference does not seem to have registered on the radar screens of far-right radio commentators, who often claim the title of "patriots."
"I monitor the patriot reporting on shortwave radio, and, to my knowledge, there have not been any references to the summit," said Lawrence Myers, a free-lance writer on far-right groups.
Starting last winter, before the Oklahoma bombing trial began here, the authorities have paid close attention to far-right groups working in Denver.
In the spring, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation attended public meetings that John Trochmann, a founder of the Militia of Montana, a right-wing group, gave here. In May, The Denver Post reported that the F.B.I. had investigated attempts by this group to recruit new members among security guards at Rocky Flats, a former nuclear weapons plant in suburban Denver, where 14 tons of plutonium are stored.
In the most decisive action to date, on May 1 F.B.I. agents arrested three local men who claimed to be part of "the Colorado First Light Infantry, North American Liberation Army."
According to a Government inventory of material seized in the raid in Aurora, a Denver suburb, the three men stored in their house five illegal machine guns, 22,000 rounds of ammunition, a pipe bomb, a mortar, a hand grenade, 100 feet of fuse, and stocks of chemicals that could be used for making explosives, including ether and black powder.
As of today, bond had been set for only one man, Kevin I. Terry, 24. The other two men, Ronald D. Cole, 27, and Wallace Stanley Kennett, 33, are being held without bond.

HEADLINE: With 6,138 Lives, 'Cats' Sets Broadway Mark

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
Like Grizabella rising to the Heaviside Layer, "Cats" ascends to Broadway heaven tonight, when it overtakes "A Chorus Line" to become the longest-running show in Broadway history, with 6,138 performances.
The musical, which opened at the Winter Garden theater on Oct. 7, 1982, has been an audience favorite, seen by more than 8 million people in New York, roughly equivalent to the total population of the five boroughs. A financial juggernaut, with ticket sales totaling $329 million in New York, it was the first in a wave of megamusicals that reshaped Broadway in the 1980's, redirecting the Broadway market toward blockbuster hits and foreign tourism. It also made Andrew Lloyd Webber, the musical's composer, a global brand name and established Cameron Mackintosh, its producer, as a theatrical mogul. 
 Big, spectacular, laden with special effects and not dependent on stars, "Cats" has been presented and marketed from the outset as a special event. It was the first musical to develop an internationally marketed logo, the now-famous pair of yellow cat eyes against a black background, and it has never quoted reviews in its advertisements. The show itself is the star, and like a certain kind of celebrity, it managed to become not only famous but also famous for being famous.
" 'A Chorus Line' ushered in a new kind of American musical, and 'Cats,' in its own way, also gave us a new kind of musical, the pop opera," said Gerald Schoenfeld, the chairman of the Shubert Organization, whose theaters have been host to both shows. "It has sustained the theater in this country in a very important way, especially outside of New York, and I hope it continues for a very long time into the future."
Along the way to its longevity record, which applies just to Broadway shows, "Cats" has piled up some big numbers. It has provided employment to 231 actors, two of whom, Marlene Danielle and Susan Powers, have been with the musical since it opened. (Nineteen cast members have died.) The magical tire that carries Grizabella heavenward has clocked more than 114 miles in its nightly voyage to the Heaviside Layer. "Memory," the show-stopping song that ends the first act, has been recorded by more than 180 artists. The New York production has used more than 1.5 million pounds of dry ice and 2,706 pounds of yak hair for wigs. It has sold 390,000 T-shirts, 130,000 sweat shirts, 147,000 lapel pins and 1.14 million souvenir books.
More seriously, "Cats" has pumped a lot of money into the New York economy. A recent study done for "Cats" by Audience Research and Analysis found that the musical had contributed $3.12 billion to the city's economy, most of it through foreign tourism, and more than $195 million in state and local taxes.
"Compare that to the economic impact of the World Series last year, which was $34 million," said George Wachtel, who carried out the "Cats" study and who has surveyed audiences at the musical over the years.
Outside New York, "Cats" almost single-handedly revived the sagging road business, which was suffering withdrawal pains as "Evita," "Annie" and "A Chorus Line" left the scene. The show has had four national touring companies. The remaining national tour, Cats National IV, has been on the road for nine years and traveled more than two million miles, returning as often as yearly to major cities like Atlanta. In North America, the road companies have grossed more than $400 million. Worldwide, the musical has grossed more than $2.2 billion and has played to more than 50 million people in 42 productions seen in more than 30 countries.
Tonight, "Cats" will celebrate its milestone with an early performance attended by invited guests, including Lord Lloyd Webber and Trevor Nunn, the show's director, as well as former cast members and employees. After the curtain rings down, actors and audience will pour out of the theater and onto Broadway, which will be closed between 50th and 51st Street, where the members of the original creative team will address the crowd.
The street party will conclude with a laser light show projected on the Winter Garden theater and a procession up Broadway and east to the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton, where the cast members, crews and personnel of all the shows on Broadway have been invited to a party.
Not everyone will be celebrating. When "A Chorus Line" swept into first place as the longest-running musical on Broadway, it displaced "Oh! Calcutta!" No tears were shed. But the thought of "A Chorus Line" slipping into second place is too much for some theatergoers.
"It's heartbreaking," said Gary Stevens, the co-author of "The Longest Line," a history of "A Chorus Line." "I can't believe it's becoming a reality."
Mr. Stevens has devoted much of his life to "A Chorus Line" since first seeing it when he was 12. He has transformed the foyer of his Manhattan apartment into a "Chorus Line" museum crowded with artifacts from the musical. He is taking the "Cats" triumph hard.
"I think it's a shame that 'Cats' is what's going to represent Broadway," he said. " 'A Chorus Line' was savvy and sophisticated, not flash and trash. 'Cats' is a theme park. It's all about branding and marketing."
That is a common assessment among the detractors of "Cats," and there are more than a few who see the "Cats" phenomenon as the theatrical equivalent of the rise of the megabudget Hollywood action film. For them, "Cats" is a soulless money machine.
Others disagree. "I refuse to believe that if it's as awful, boring and horrible as some people say, that it would have run 15 years,' said Ken Mandelbaum, the author of " 'A Chorus Line' and the Musicals of Michael Bennett." "By running so long, it has built up a certain resentment, but it represents a little more than the triumph of the megamusical."
"People forget, but it was an original and daring musical," he added. "Putting poems by T. S. Eliot to music was odd. You have to give credit to the composer for creating 25 songs about different kinds of cats. Not many people would be up to that."
For Ian Hamilton Fisher, whose musical revival series in London inspired the Encores! series in New York, the rise of "Cats" marked a turning point in taste. "It put to bed once and for all the kind of musical that fascinates me, and has made it difficult for more traditional book musicals to open and sustain a run," he said. "We can't really go back."
In the beginning, the smart money was not betting on "Cats." "We had almost everything going against us," said Lord Lloyd Webber, who proceeded to tick off the negatives: No one could see the future for a musical based on cat poems by Eliot. Mr. Nunn had never directed a musical. Neither Lord Lloyd Webber nor Mr. Mackintosh were the important producers they later became.
"We couldn't get the investment companies interested," Lord Lloyd Webber said. "People were intrigued by it, but the word around London was that the show was, to put it mildly, a risky enterprise."
For his part, Mr. Nunn felt like a man who had drawn the short straw. "I was cursing my ill luck," he said. "Hal Prince gets the show about a South American dictator and upheaval in an entire country, and the other fellow gets the crucifixion. I get to do a show about pussycats. I thought the best I could hope for was to avoid humiliation."
Soon after the show opened in London, Mr. Schoenfeld and his partner, Bernard Jacobs, were on the plane to London. "We saw it immediately and we wanted it immediately, Mr. Schoenfeld said. David Geffen, at that time the president of Geffen Records, became a co-producer of the New York version, supplying most of the $2 million needed to renovate the Winter Garden.
In New York, the show repeated the success and the pattern of the London production. Critics were lukewarm, but audiences embraced the show.
Writing in The New York Times, Frank Rich described "Cats" as a "collection of anthropomorphic variety turns" lacking in emotional power and devoid of ideas. He also predicted that it would linger long on Broadway. "Whatever the other failings and excesses, even banalities, of 'Cats,' it believes in purely theatrical magic, and on that faith it unquestionably delivers," Mr. Rich wrote. "Cats" went on to win seven Tony awards, including best musical.
Fifteen years later, a largely out-of-town audience with a large proportion of foreign visitors continues to buoy the musical, which took in $352,000 last week at the box office, a healthy number for a musical late in its run. Somewhere in the course of those 15 years, "Cats" became the musical that visitors to New York had to see. Some came to New York, in fact, with the primary purpose of seeing it.
Why?
Mr. Nunn and Lord Lloyd Webber listed several reasons. First, a lot of people like cats. Lord Lloyd Webber recalled being warned early in the development of the musical that half the world loves cats and half loathes them. "I said, 'I would be very happy to play to half the world,' " he said.
Then there's the source material. Eliot's "Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats" has enough literary quality to hold the attention of adults and enough whimsy and fantasy to charm children. "You must remember, we are dealing with fabulous pieces of verse," Lord Lloyd Webber said.
Mr. Nunn said: "It's very visual with some intellectual ingredient for those that want it. It's a very literate set of lyrics with all sorts of classical references, but it's immediately understandable."
Understandability is perhaps the most important reason of all. Mr. Wachtel said that his audience surveys had shown that about 80 percent of the "Cats" audience came from out of town, and 40 percent from outside the United States, with visitors from Brazil, Germany and Japan predominating. Even those who speak no English can enjoy the show.
Mr. Wachtel discounted the marketing explanation for the show's success. "All the marketing, hype and publicity in the world will not help if you don't have word of mouth," he said. "This show has, to an unprecedented degree, multi-generational and multinational word of mouth."
For Mr. Nunn, it has been a long, rather peculiar trip. "Anybody who does a musical in England never really feels they've done it until it goes to Broadway and survives or fails that test," he said. "That is the journey. Now, when I walk past the theater, with that big sign, I do feel a little strange at times, because it's so much a part of the New York landscape."

HEADLINE: Study Says Pataki's Welfare Plan Will Increase Deep Poverty

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 18

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to overhaul the state's welfare system, combined with stricter Federal welfare rules, would double the number of families living far below the poverty line, according to a study by Columbia University's School of Social Work.
Over five years, the number of families in the state living in deep poverty -- defined as an annual household income below 75 percent of the poverty line, or $9,975 for a family of three -- would rise to 290,000 from 140,000, the study found. 
 The report's conclusions are likely to give ammunition to local government officials and advocates for the poor, who say Mr. Pataki's plan would create greater poverty and shift the cost of caring for the poor from the state to local governments. The findings may also strengthen the hand of Democrats and some Republicans in the State Legislature, who have expressed grave misgivings over key elements in the Governor's welfare plan.
The study concluded that more than 48,000 families would be pared from the welfare rolls over five years, with about half taking low-wage jobs and the rest turning to their families or charities for help.
The Pataki administration dismissed the study, which used 1994 data, as faulty. The administration said that the population on welfare has changed since then, partly because of a steep decline in the welfare rolls. The administration also argued that economic opportunities for people coming off welfare had improved in the last three years.
"It's outdated," said Dan Hogan, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Social Services. "Our job is going to be a lot easier, because the remaining universe of welfare recipients is much smaller."
Mr. Hogan also said that the study failed to take into account an assurance that the Governor has made to local governments: if they spend more on welfare than their basic state grants will cover, the state will pay half the cost overruns.
Mr. Pataki's plan is intended to bring New York into compliance with the Federal welfare law enacted last year, which ends decades of guaranteed government help to the poor. The Federal Government no longer provides states with money based on the number of welfare recipients they have, but offers them fixed sums, called block grants, and gives them greater responsibility for tailoring their poverty programs.
The Governor's plan would make the most extensive changes in five decades in a system that serves 1.4 million welfare recipients, most of them in New York City. It calls for cutting cash benefits by 45 percent over five years for poor families with children. It would also abolish Home Relief, the state's own cash-assistance program for poor, childless adults, replacing it with vouchers for essentials like food, clothing and shelter. Legal immigrants and others who no longer qualified for cash benefits under the Federal law would be included in the voucher plan.
The authors of the Columbia report -- Jane Waldfogel, an assistant professor of sociology, and Irwin Garfinkel, a professor of sociology -- arrived at their projections through an analysis of Census and State Department of Social Services data.
The Columbia study looked at the families on public assistance in New York at the end of 1994, roughly 600,000; the number of families on assistance has since dropped to 446,000.
For those who remain on welfare, the study concluded, the situation will worsen largely because of Mr. Pataki's benefit cuts.
The Federal law alone would increase the number of families in the state living in poverty -- defined as an annual income of $13,300 or less for a family of three -- from 432,000 to 462,000 in five years, the study found. The Governor's plan would do almost nothing to mitigate that impact, resulting in 461,000 families living in poverty.
More striking, the study said, is the effect that Mr. Pataki's plan, combined with the Federal law, would have on the number of people living in deep poverty. The Federal rules alone would raise that number from 140,000 to 228,000, the study said, and adding the Governor's changes would push it to 290,000.
In New York City, the study said, the number of families in deep poverty would grow from 97,000 to 210,000.
The authors of the study contend that the problem lies in the central elements of the Governor's proposal: the voucher program and the cuts in cash benefits. The Governor would distribute $1.2 billion to the counties and cities for the voucher program, the same amount now spent on Home Relief. But the pool of recipients would be larger, swelled by thousands to whom the Federal law had denied cash assistance.
"The $1.2 billion would have to be stretched further, so everybody would end up getting less," Ms. Waldfogel said.
The Pataki administration dismissed this criticism, stressing that the Governor's plan requires the state to share any additional expense that local governments might incur beyond the $1.2 billion. But the study's authors argued that local governments, with budget woes of their own, were unlikely to spend more than their basic state grants.
The Columbia study also criticized the Governor's proposal to cut cash benefits for families in stages, so that in the fifth and final year a family received benefits, it would get 55 percent of the starting benefit.
Mr. Pataki and his aides contend that the cuts would be offset by allowing people to keep up to $1,080 a month from their salaries without deducting any portion of their welfare grants, thus providing an incentive for work. Currently, the state cuts benefits by one dollar for every dollar a household earns above $667 a month.
But the authors of the study found that while some families might lift themselves out of poverty by combining welfare grants and job salaries, the average family on welfare would lose between $500 and $600 a year because of the combined impact of the benefit cuts and other provisions in the Governor's plan.

HEADLINE: How the F.B.I. Got Its Man, Half the World Away

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
Just before 4 A.M. on Sunday, five F.B.I. agents sneaked into a hostel in Afghanistan, where Afghan informants had told them they would find Mir Amal Kansi, one of the world's most wanted men, the suspect in a deadly 1993 rampage outside C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va..
Senior law-enforcement and intelligence officials said Mr. Kansi, who had been asleep in bed, drowsily answered the knock at his door, then spat out a stream of expletives when the door was flung open. 
 But he did not put up a fight as his flight from the law came to an end.
"Once he knew the jig was up, there was no resistance," one official said.
Later, after a grueling overland trip to Pakistan to an air base at an undisclosed location, the agents and their captive boarded an American military aircraft, painted in camouflage markings with an American flag on the tail.
Mr. Kansi switched from Pathan obscenities to polite English, the officials said. He had grown a beard since the attack, but when an agent showed him a wanted poster with his photograph, Mr. Kansi examined the clean-shaven likeness and said, "Yes, that's me."
Today Mr. Kansi, a 33-year-old Pakistani with a graduate degree in English and, the officials said, an unexplained grudge against the Central Intelligence Agency, was brought before a judge in Fairfax County in the Virginia suburbs of Washington. He was ordered held without bond by a judge in the shooting deaths of Lansing H. Bennett, a doctor, and Frank Darling, a communications engineer, both C.I.A. employees, on the morning of Jan. 25, 1993.
He did not enter a plea because does not yet have a lawyer.
The Afghans' decision to help the Americans ended a quest that had caused United States law-enforcement, intelligence and diplomatic officials years of frustration. And the capture of Mr. Kansi followed many failures, which were described by Government officials.
F.B.I. agents, some disguised in burkas, the head-to-toe gowns women wear in religious communities of the region, had been searching for Mr. Kansi to no avail in and around Quetta, Pakistan, his home town, on the Afghan border.
There was a bad tip that Mr. Kansi, whose name is also spelled Mir Aimal Kansi and Mir Aimal Kasi, had fled to Thailand in 1994. There was a botched raid four years ago, when Pakistani military and intelligence officials, acting on a equally bad tip from the F.B.I., stormed the homes of Mr. Kansi's family in Quetta. They came up empty-handed, but not before offending local political sensibilities.
But with the strange coalition of C.I.A. operatives, F.B.I. detectives, Pakistani spies and Afghan warriors on his trail, it was only a matter of time before the United States captured Mr. Kansi, Government officials said today.
The breakthrough in the hunt came about two weeks ago through the C.I.A.'s Near East division via the intelligence agency's station in Pakistan. The agents there had maintained some paid informants among the Afghan tribal headmen, guerrilla fighters, religious leaders and village elders it had supported in a $3 billion covert operation against the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in the 1980's.
Mr. Kansi, Government officials say, spent much of his time as a fugitive moving from mud-walled fort to mud-walled fort among the many members of his extended family on both sides of the lightly policed border between Pakistan and Afghanistan. The Afghans in the border region, where the economy is largely based on opium and smuggling, knew Mr. Kansi from his travels through Spin Buldak, a depot town on the only passable road linking Quetta with Afghanistan.
Government officials said the Afghans decided to help apprehend Mr. Kansi in the hopes of a $2 million reward offered by the United States. The reward has not yet been paid, the officials said.
The Afghans put out the word that they could deliver Mr. Kansi to a hostel near the border. United States officials hinted today that Mr. Kansi was lured to the hotel by a ruse.
"I don't think he thought he was going to be arrested," said one official. "He showed up and we arrested him."
The exact details of Mr. Kansi's capture are being withheld by United States officials, who would not say precisely where he was arrested or disclose other details. Their demurrals, one official said, were mostly in deference to Pakistan, the staging area for the arrest. Pakistan is an Islamic Republic and its officials do not want to be seen by some of its citizens as Washington's ally.
Without Pakistan's cooperation, the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. could not have worked the case. But that cooperation followed some pressure brought to bear on Pakistan under a June 1995 Presidential Decision Directive, a secret order in which the United States resolved to "induce cooperation" from foreign nations where suspected terrorists and criminals reside.
The arrest lifted spirits at the F.B.I. and the C.I.A., two battered agencies whose past feuds are legendary. Today F.B.I. agents introduced to C.I.A. employees received a standing ovation -- probably the first time the bureau's agents had ever experienced such affection from their cousins at the intelligence agency.
The F.B.I. agents "put their lives on the line," the acting Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, told the audience gathered in "the Bubble," the C.I.A.'s auditorium. He also praised officers from the C.I.A.'s Counterterrorist Center and its Near East operations division for "a daring job well done."
As the C.I.A. officers applauded, Mr. Kansi was being arraigned a few miles away in Fairfax, Va. Wearing a dark green prison suit, he appeared for two minutes at the Fairfax County court house, where he told Judge J. Howe Brown that he understood the charges against him.
"Do you have a lawyer?" the judge asked.
"No, I don't," Kansi replied in faintly accented English. "I don't have money to pay the lawyers, sir."
Mr. Kansi, the son of a Pathan tribal leader who died in 1989 -- a death that some of his friends and relatives have said left him mentally unstable -- faces the death penalty if convicted on the murder charges.

HEADLINE: FINANCE BRIEFS

 BODY:

Debt
 
* Fannie Mae is selling $200 million of medium-term notes due in 2004 through J .P. Morgan Securities. The notes are noncallable, carry an interest rate of 6.48 percent and are priced at par.
 
* Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $200 million of bonds due in 2012 through Bear, Stearns & Co. The securities, which are callable in two years, are zero coupon issues that pay no quarterly interest, but if held to maturity will yield 8 percent. 

* LCI International Inc., McLean, Va., is selling $350 million of notes that are due in 2007 through Lehman Brothers. The notes are priced at 99.759 to yield 7.284 percent. The issue has a rating of Ba1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
 
* Michigan Municipal Bond Authority is selling $133.1 million of tax-exempt revolving-fund revenue bonds through Bear, Stearns. The bonds are priced to yield a maximum of 5.48 percent for an issue due in 2020. For short-maturity serial bonds, the yields range from 4.25 percent in 2000 to 5.35 percent in 2015. The bonds are rated Aa1 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P.
 
* Old Republic International Corp., Chicago, is selling $115 million of debentures due in 2007 through Lehman Brothers. The debentures are priced at 99.946 to yield 7.008 percent. The issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P.
 
* Salomon Inc., New York, is selling $400 million of notes due in 2000 through Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are priced at 99.918 to yield 6.729 percent. The issue is rated Baa1 by Moody's, BBB by S.& P. and A- by Duff & Phelps.
 
* United Companies Financial Corp., Baton Rouge, La., is selling $150 million of subordinated notes due in 2005 through Merrill Lynch & Co. The notes are priced at 99.403 to yield 8.375 percent. The issue is rated Ba3 by Moody's, BB+ by S.& P. and BBB by Duff & Phelps.

HEADLINE: New Suitor May Emerge For Barney's

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
At least one new potential investor has emerged for Barney's Inc., the luxury retailer now in bankruptcy, including one whose most recent deals are far removed from the world of handbags and haberdashery.
The Texas Pacific Group, an investment firm with holdings in nursing homes, airlines, canned fruit and motorcycles, has expressed an interest in Barney's and has signed an agreement of confidentiality to review the retailer's books, people close to the creditors committee in the bankruptcy proceedings said yesterday. 
 The group, based in San Francisco and Fort Worth, is led by David Bonderman, an astute investor known for taking on an odd lot of companies through leveraged buyouts or recapitalizations. A spokesman for the group declined to comment.
The emergence of Texas Pacific as a potential investor changes the tenor of the bidding process for Barney's, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last year and which just this week announced it would close four stores, including its original store at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street in Manhattan. Until now, parties that have expressed interest in Barney's have been other retailers, including Saks Holdings, which owns Saks Fifth Avenue, and Dickson Concepts (International) Inc., which is based in Hong Kong and owns the Harvey Nichols store in London.
The winning bidder was expected to buy the company outright and run the Barneys stores as part of its own retail operations, extending at least part of its management team into the executive offices.
But a financial investor with deep pockets, like Texas Pacific, might be more likely to keep the Barneys stores as an independent retail operation and to hand over management to a fresh team, should it choose not to keep on Bob and Gene Pressman, Barney's co-chief executives.
Saks Holdings has offered $290 million for the company and Dickson Concepts has bid $240 million.
But those offers represent an outright purchase. A financial investor who is interested less in running the company than in owning a large chunk of it could put up the money to settle administrative claims and the like and convert some or all of the creditors' claims to equity. Some of the claimants could prefer that to getting a pounded-down recovery on their original investments or claims.
Unlike Saks or Dickson, which would probably look to create synergies with their existing stores, financial investors would most likely try to attract a highly regarded chief executive with a desire to run his own company, perhaps by offering an equity stake in the company. The ultimate exit strategy for such a buyer might be a sale or an initial public offering of a revitalized and growing concern.
Last week, in an effort to attract higher bids for Barney's, a bankruptcy judge approved a deal that would allow the retailer to offer an $8.5 million breakup fee to a potential suitor. The fee would be paid if a deal was reached but not completed.
This has brought out several new interested parties, the person close to the creditors committee said, including Texas Pacific, which recently put together $2.5 billion to go shopping with.
Just last week, Genesis Health Ventures Inc. said that it had agreed to buy the Multicare Companies for $1.06 billion in cash, with backing from Texas Pacific and another investor group. In April, the Belden & Blake Corporation, an oil and gas exploration and production concern, said it would be bought by Texas Pacific for $315 million in cash. In March, investors led by Texas Pacific agreed to buy the Del Monte Foods Company, the nation's largest producer of brand-name canned fruits and vegetables, in a deal reported to be worth about $800 million.
In October, Cagiva S.p.A. of Italy agreed to sell 51 percent of its Ducati motorbike division to the group. And in 1995, with another investment group, it bought Kraft Foods' caramel and marshmallow business.
But Mr. Bonderman is perhaps best known for his role as a principal of Air Partners of Fort Worth, which led Continental Airlines out of bankruptcy in 1993.
The diversity of Texas Pacific's holdings illustrates how the group's strategy, should it pursue a bid for Barney's, might differ from that of other bidders whose focus is the art of selling shoes and lipstick. For instance, while Saks would certainly look to get economies of scale with apparel vendors, it is unlikely that Texas Pacific would attempt to peddle marshmallows and pineapples off the fancy dishes in the Barneys housewares department.

HEADLINE: Goldman Profits Highlight Boom On Wall Street

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
The Goldman, Sachs Group yesterday reported a 19 percent rise in earnings before taxes to $1.52 billion for the six months ended May 31, highlighting the surge in profits that has flowed to Wall Street in recent years as brokerage firms and investment banks have moved to the forefront of the nation's richest companies.
Goldman's earnings dipped in the second quarter of this period as the investment firm was buffeted by the turmoil that hit financial markets in March and April. Nonetheless, Goldman, which is Wall Street's biggest private partnership, has improved significantly in recent weeks and appears to be on track to earn as much as $3 billion this year. 
 With such gigantic earnings, Goldman -- along with its big competitors like Merrill Lynch & Company and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company -- is securely placed these days among the nation's most profitable companies.
By comparison, Microsoft made annual profits after taxes of $2.2 billion in the year ended June 30, 1996. (Microsoft's pretax profits were $3.4 billion.) Unlike Microsoft, Goldman's earnings before taxes are the more important figure because its 190 partners settle their taxes individually. Merrill Lynch made net profits of $1.62 billion, and $2.6 billion before taxes, in 1996. The company with the largest overall profits last year was Exxon, which earned $7.5 billion on revenues of $119.4 billion.
In recent years, the stock brokerage business has been one of the most lucrative and fastest-growing industries in the country. John Keefe, an analyst at Keefe Worldwide, a financial consulting firm in New York, said that since the late 1970's, Merrill Lynch, the Travelers Group and other brokerage and financial companies have climbed into the ranks of the country's most profitable companies. He cited numbers from the Commerce Department showing the astounding rise in the profits of securities and commodities brokers over the last 20 years: in 1975 the industry made profits of $4.8 billion, and by 1994 that annual profit had grown to $69.5 billion.
The record results of Goldman for its first half are expected to be a harbinger of robust financial results from other Wall Street firms, which are to report their second-quarter earnings in the coming weeks. The newly merged Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, and Lehman Holdings Inc. will be the next to report second-quarter financial results. Like Goldman, their financial years end on Nov. 30. Most of the other big firms will report next month, as their second quarters end June 30.
As if taking their cue from Goldman's results, the prices for the stocks of Wall Street firms rallied late yesterday, with Merrill's shares rising $2.625, to $62.625, and Salomon gaining $1.625, to $58.25. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette rose $2.875, to $60.125, on continued speculation that it may merge or be acquired.
In its most recent quarter, Goldman's earnings before taxes fell 14 percent, to $610 million, reflecting the slower financial markets of March and April and a rise in expenses. Revenues for the firm's second quarter were $1.674 billion while expenses totaled $1.064 billion, compared with revenues of $1.67 billion and $961 million in expenses for the second quarter of 1996.
For the six-month period, Goldman's earnings of $1.52 billion on revenues of $3.63 billion compared with $1.27 billion during the corresponding period a year ago on revenues of $3.13 billion.
"It was not the best quarter, but it was a great half," John A. Thain, Goldman's chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview yesterday. Wall Street, Mr. Thain said, currently has "all the positives you could want for in the financial industry." He listed low interest rates, low inflation, good company profits and positive market sentiment. "It's hard to imagine it getting much better," he added.
"The trading environment in March and April was somewhat slower than it had been," Mr. Thain said, but that "slowdown in customer activity has basically gone away -- stock markets have rebounded and then some."
The increase in Goldman's expenses, Mr. Thain and his colleagues said, was a result of the addition of several hundred new employees, giving the firm 9,500 employees.
According to the Securities Data Company, a statistics and research company, Goldman ranked second to Merrill Lynch as a manager of public debt and equity issues from Jan. 1 to June 16 this year, handling 492 issues worth $57.9 billion. It also led the rankings of firms managing initial public offerings and advising companies on mergers and acquisitions.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Gains Posted By Treasuries As Fed Buys

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices gained yesterday, as the Federal Reserve Bank entered the market as an active buyer while a survey of business conditions showed pockets of weakness. Investors saw the survey as further reducing the chances that Fed policy makers will raise interest rates when they meet in two weeks.
The price of the 30-year bond ended up 13/32, to 99 8/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 6.68 percent, from 6.71 percent on Tuesday. 
 The Fed's appearance as a buyer, called a coupon pass, was surprisingly large and drew buyers into the market. The Fed bought $1.64 billion of mostly two-year and five-year maturities with coupons running from June 1999 to May 2002. The Fed regularly makes such purchases to add money to the banking system.
But it was the Fed's survey of regional business conditions, known as the beige book, that chiefly bolstered bonds. The survey said that while all 12 Fed districts expanded in May and early June, "there were pockets of weakness." The survey saw labor markets tight, but with little or no wage pressure.
Bond investors saw the survey as providing more evidence that the economy was slowing. Most market participants expect the Fed will hold rates steady at the July 1-2 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making panel.
Still, "You couldn't call it broad- based participation," Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. of Boca Raton, Fla., said of the rally. "The beige book failed to present anything new that would keep the Fed from remaining neutral," he said. "It could have gone the other way, as the market chose to ignore some of the negatives and concentrate on the positives."
Increases in interest rates are expected for later in the year and into 1998 for two reasons, said the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting company in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. First, the second-quarter slowdown in growth is in all likelihood just a temporary pause, with growth likely to rebound strongly in the second half of the year. Second, and more significant, tight labor markets seem likely to result in larger wage increases and more rapidly rising labor costs, which are then likely to make their way into consumer prices and somewhat higher inflation.
As a result, WEFA forecast that the Fed's target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, will be increased to 6 percent from 5.50 percent by year-end and to 6.50 percent by the middle of next year.
Elsewhere, the Treasury announced the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions for next week. On Tuesday the Government will sell $15.5 billion of new two-year maturities and on Wednesday, $11.5 billion of notes with a five-year maturity. In when-issued trading ahead of the auctions, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.02 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.28 percent.
Today the Treasury will sell $13 billion of new one-year bills through auction. By late yesterday, the rate of a one-year bill was 5.32 percent.
In the municipal bond market, prices were little changed as states and local governments sold a total of about $2.3 billion of new securities, led by Los Angeles County's $1.3 billion of one-year tax and revenue anticipation notes through Merrill Lynch. The notes were tentatively priced to yield 3.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Southern Baptist Convention Calls for Boycott of Disney

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, June 18

 BODY:
The Southern Baptist Convention called for a boycott of the Walt Disney Company today to protest that the creators of Mickey Mouse and an animated Snow White have gone astray, profiting from a liberated Ellen and offering health benefits to employees' homosexual partners.
Reinforcing an initially proposed boycott of only the company's theme parks and stores, the 12,000 delegates here voted to shun the entire Disney empire, including movie studios, cable television channels, book publishers, trade magazines, newspapers, television and radio stations and the ABC network. 
 Gay rights groups called the measure an attack on homosexuals that would fail, while Disney said only that the company was dedicated to providing family entertainment.
Southern Baptist leaders at their annual convention here pointed to their numbers, with their 15.7 million members forming the nation's largest Protestant denomination. They said they had focused on Disney because it had moved away from the wholesome entertainment it once, under its founder, provided.
"When Disney crosses to the other side of the street, there's a sense of betrayal and outrage," said Richard Land, president of the Southern Baptist morals and ethics panel, which has monitored Disney since the convention issued a warning last year. "You can't walk the family side of the street and the gay side of the street in the Magic Kingdom at the same time."
Disney, one of the largest communications companies, is only one of many corporations providing benefits to gay partners. But Baptist leaders also pointed to violence in Disney movies like "Pulp Fiction" and sex on its screens large and small.
ABC's brassy staging earlier this year of Ellen DeGeneres's coming out as a lesbian while her "Ellen" sitcom character came out as well rallied gay groups but further provoked the Southern Baptists.
Mr. Land said Disney and his organization had had little direct contact. "On good days they ignored us," he said. "On bad days they contemptuously gave us the back of their hand."
The Southern Baptists are growing rapidly outside their home region, diversifying to include black and Hispanic congregations, but individual congregations are not required to follow the convention's lead.
Even as the communications giants, concentrated on the coasts in the nation's largest cities, have become more accommodating to gay issues, the Southern Baptists have affirmed their convictions about homosexuality.
"We believe homosexuality is a choice and that it's a bad choice," Tom Elliff, the Southern Baptist Convention president and pastor of the First Southern Baptist Church of Del City, Okla., said in an interview. "But as with all bad choices, there's hope and help in Christ."
Mr. Land said the impetus for the boycott came from Florida, where the values of Hollywood and mid-America collide. Disney World "Gay Days" organized by homosexual groups aroused Baptist rancor, although the company has said it had nothing to do with the gay events.
"When you got 1.6 million Southern Baptists in Florida in close juxtaposition to 80,000 gay and lesbian people at the theme park, you got an explosion," Mr. Land said.
Mr. Land and his committee recommended a narrower boycott as easier to explain and enforce. To inform delegates about all they should boycott, the convention handed out a list with more than 100 properties, including the Walt Disney and Miramax studios, the ESPN and Discover cable networks and dozens of trade journals.
Several delegates who favored the broader measure said it might be symbolic most of all.
"Will a Southern Baptist boycott change the Disney company?" Lisa Kinney of Largo, Fla., asked the convention. "I don't know. But it will change us. It will affirm to us and the world that we love Jesus more than we love our entertainments."
Although the convention's vote was so overwhelming that no count was taken, dissenters included Jim Henry, the convention's immediate past president and the pastor of the First Baptist Church of Orlando, Fla. In Disney World's home, his church has hundreds of Disney employees as members.
"If you're the people who are going to boycott us, don't talk to me about coming to church," Mr. Henry recalled some of his members as saying.
Gay rights groups said the boycott was out of touch with most Christians, who favor toleration, and might even backfire.
"What we're challenging is their use of economic power to bully a company into discriminating," said David M. Smith, senior strategist for the Human Rights Campaign, a gay political group. "This would be a good time to go to Disney World or Disneyland if you're planning a vacation."
The boycott plans appeared to at most nick Disney's stock, which fell 1 1/2 points to 82 1/2 today as the broader market also dropped.
Tom Wolzien, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, called Disney an easy target but added that a boycott was unlikely to succeed. Mr. Wolzien said he had organized focus groups in which religious conservatives said they resented some Disney subjects.
"But on the other hand," he added, "they were having a heck of a time telling their kids they couldn't take the trip to Disney World."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. House Tax Writer Retreats on Child Tax

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The chief Republican tax writer in the House dropped a provision today from his tax-cutting bill that had drawn heavy criticism from Democrats, saying he hoped the Clinton Administration would offer a compromise in return and help avert partisan warfare over the plan.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said he would delete a measure that would keep some low- and moderate-income taxpayers from receiving the full benefit of a proposed $500 per child credit if they also claimed a tax credit for child care expenses. 
 Mr. Archer said that he hoped the White House would respond by dropping its opposition to a measure that would limit the benefits of the child tax credit for many families with incomes from $16,000 to $25,000 a year. Mr. Archer said the White House should also agree to have the $500 tax credit cover children up to the age 17, instead of up to 13 as the Administration originally proposed.
Although they welcomed some aspects of Mr. Archer's statement, neither the White House nor Congressional Democrats let up in their attacks on Mr. Archer's bill and a similar Republican proposal being taken up by the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday.
"It seems the Republicans are having trouble fulfilling promises made to their wealthy constituents and still trying to look good to average, hard-working people," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee.
The Democratic attacks centered on how Mr. Archer's proposal would affect people claiming the earned income tax credit, which is designed to reduce tax burdens of low- and moderate-income working people.
Families with income in the range of $16,000 to $25,000 often have little or no Federal income tax liability after claiming the earned income tax credit. Mr. Archer argues that the $500 child tax credit should be granted only to offset an actual Federal income tax liability.
The Administration is demanding that the full child credit be granted to families who have no Federal income tax liability after claiming the earned income tax credit, even if it means the Government would actually pay them the money.
"Writing Government checks to people who don't pay taxes means taking money away from people who do," Mr. Archer said in a letter he sent today to President Clinton. "I don't believe middle-income taxpayers support such a proposal."
Administration officials welcomed Mr. Archer's decision to drop his link between the child credit and the child care credit, and they said they had already decided to support an expansion of the child credit to cover teenagers. But they continued to demand that the child credit plan be revised so it would benefit people receiving the earned income credit.
"These are the working families with children that are trying hardest to get financial security and find a secure place in the middle class," said Gene Sperling, the chairman of the White House's National Economic Council. "The child credit should be designed to help them, not single them out to get no relief."
Administration officials said Mr. Archer should instead drop his proposal to cut the alternative minimum tax for corporations by $11 billion over the next five years. They said he should use the $11 billion instead to extend the child credit to teen-agers and to remove the limit on the child tax credit for people claiming the earned income credit.
